review_content: If you've ever engaged in the timeless battle against slugs and snails invading your garden, then you know it's not just a challenge‚Äîit's an epic saga. Enter the Garden Safe Slug & Snail Bait, a true hero in the world of gardening.This remarkable slug bait is nothing short of miraculous. It doesn't just work; it works like a secret agent sent on a covert mission to eliminate the slimy invaders. I use it in the evenings, and within just a few days, it's like a magic spell has been cast over my garden. Those sneaky slugs vanish into thin air, leaving my plants in peace.But what truly sets this product apart is its benevolence. It's not just a weapon against slugs; it's a guardian of harmony in my garden ecosystem. I love that it's safe for pets, ensuring my furry friends can roam freely without any worries. Even the feathered visitors and the squirrel squad in my garden go about their business, unharmed by this remarkable slug bait.In essence, the Garden Safe Slug & Snail Bait is a necessity for anyone who values their garden as a sanctuary of nature. It's not just a product; it's a garden-saving, peace-restoring, slug-vanishing wonder. This is my second bag, and I can confidently say it won't be my last. If you've ever battled the slimy hordes, this is your trusty sidekick. Garden Safe Slug & Snail Bait: protecting gardens, pets, and gardeners, one slug at a time!

review_content: It seems to be working great. I couldn't tell what was happening at first, i thought it was some insects or mice eating the leaves. But after trying lots of other measures to protect the plants, i finally considered slugs as a possibility. Well, after sprinkling this stuff around some seedlings, none have disappeared so far, so i suppose it must have been slugs all along and so far this stuff seems to be doing what it needs to do.On an unrelated note, amazon was asking me to rate features of this and one of the features it asks about is "comfort" - not sure how to respond to that one, this is supposed to kill slugs and snails, i'm not using it as a pillow or anything, the comfortability of this product is irrelevant to me but i assume it does not generate much comfort for the things that eat it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2023
review_content: I have huge flower gardens and had major problems with snails.  In past years my pets were never attracted to snail bait until my last dog. A few years ago, I dusted the regular snail bait I had used for many years around my garden.  Fortunately I immediately caught my dog laying in the planter licking up the snail bait.  He was rushed to the vet and survived the ordeal (vet said Nugget was the first dog he had ever saved who consumed snail bait).  I stopped using any bait and my flowers were devoured by snails even though I would wear gloves and hand pick hundreds of snails from my plants almost daily.Then I found this wonderful product last year.  My snail population has been reduced dramatically.  I now use it when I first plant or when I see any snails on the plants or around the planters.  It takes only a small sprinkling to kill the snails.  It is easy to see the remains of the dead snails around the plants.  My dog is not attracted to this product and apparently it would not harm him even if he ate it.  Highly recommend!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2021
review_content: I live in a rental property that was obviously neglected lawn and garden-wise for decades, and I have been trying to create a small garden here.  There were a lot of tiny white snails all over, and after a rainfall, you could not walk to the post box without crunching quite a few larger snails underfoot.  It was both distressing and disgusting to feel and hear the crunch underfoot.  So, I tried this product in May 2020, and it helped a lot.  This past Spring/Summer (2021) I noticed a bit of a snail comeback as t'were, so I plan to retreat the property.  I have been waiting for the price to go down under $10 before I pull the trigger again.I cannot guarantee you will have as good results as I have had, but if you apply this generously in infested areas, I think you will see a great improvement.  I made sure to toss some of the bits into my neighbour's grassy area, too, which I am sure helped a lot.  My greatest pest problem now is the grasshoppers.  If only I could rid my garden and yard of those voracious grasshoppers, I would be very content indeed.  They decimated many of my plants again this year, so next year I plan to take drastic measures.  I am not keen to use chemicals, but if that is what it will take to rid my home of grasshoppers, then I am going to take that step.  This year I planned to use organic NOLO Bait in late May, but the company who makes NOLO sold out completely so early last Spring that it was unbelievable, and they never made any more the rest of the season.  Looking back, I should not have waited.  I thought they would make more available, so I waited, but now I realise that was a huge mistake.  I was overrun with grasshoppers all Summer through October again this year.  I will look for NOLO next Spring, BUT if they sell out as fast again, I will use chemicals.  I cannot go through another season with no help against the grasshopper hordes.  Thank heavens this product at least helped me to end the snail and slug problem for the most part.  If you have a snail/slug problem, I suggest you try this product.  Sprinkle generously in infested areas on days that are dry with no rain in the forecast.  You will not see an overnight miracle, but give it 2-4 weeks, and I think your snail/slug problem will be greatly improved.Recommended.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2023
review_content: I bought this product in May.  Used it twice before.  I also used beer traps at the same time.  I don‚Äôt see any big slugs around but I still found those tiny baby slugs on the inner side of the leaves sometimes.  And for the last while I found some of the leaves were fell down on the ground.  It looked like it had been chewed apart.  But it didn‚Äôt look like it has been ate at all.  Just the whole leave and the stem were fell down with the bottom of the stem tearing apart.  I have Hostas for many years and this never happened before.  I finally found out why.  I used the slugs baits for the third time 3 days ago.  The next morning I woke up, all 4 of my Hosta has been chewed and tear apart most of the stems at the bottom.  All of the slug baits I sprinkled on and around the Hosta were totally gone.  Something were eating the baits and probably tried to tear the stems to get in between the stems to get the rest of the baits inside the stems.  Now I found out some other living things like the slugs baits and my poor Hostas were the victims.  I will update the review when I caught the predator.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2017
review_content: Boy did the slugs eat this stuff up! I put a few pellets in front of a slug by my front door one night and watched him go to TOWN on it like a fat kid with a chocolate cake! Did I say fat kid? okay... I meant me. Me with a chocolate cake. Mmmmm cake.What were we talking about again?RIGHT. SLUG KILLER.It almost works TOO good... I had a real problem after letting them go unchecked for about 12 years. I could go out after dark on any given night and there would be dozens on the siding, foundation and walkway. I did a combo of hand picking for several days (go out after dusk with rubber gloves and a ziplock bag and just collect all the slugs, seal em up and throw em in the trash) and then spread this stuff around their hidey holes where I know they sleep in the day (the crack between the walkway and the stairs and the stairs and hollow cement stoop, along flower bed edgers, the waterfall/pond, the woodpile, ect). I barely saw any slugs for several months after putting this out! I think I saw one lone slug on two occasions in the weeks to follow.But BEWARE. I messed with the ecosystem. The delicate balance of nature. And you know what happened? Mushrooms EXPLODED on my properrty. because slugs eat decaying matter and they LOVE a good mushroom feast. and I figured out that that's why I HAD so many slugs. Because apparently I have mushrooms out the wazoo! And fearful for my dogs health (I have the kind of mushrooms that sent Alice on her trippy ride to wonderland. My friend's dog died from eating one) I had now created a new chore. I had to walk around my half acre back yard and collect the bucket of mushrooms that sprouted overnight every single day.So as the slugs started to come back a little, I let them. I don't need to be slug free, I just don't want to worry about where I step when I run out to my car barefoot for my phone charger after dark, lest I get a slimy surprise underfoot!! Therefore I will certainly continue to use this product to control the population around the high traffic areas of the property and around the perimeter of my house!

review_content: I container garden.  I was waking up to finding my new vegetable transplants riddled with holes on their leaves. I had removed the very damaged leaves so only new minimally chewed ones remained on the plants.  I also use Tulle to discourage bunnies and squirrels from messing with my plants.  I saw no additional damage and none since.  Kale, cabbage, spinach, and more looked great after this treatment!  Drink your beer or use it to stop these guys.  Your choice, but I know which I would choose!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2021
review_content: I have tried EVERYTHING to get rid of slugs!  I live in the pacific NW and it rains here all the time....all the time.  I have tried beer traps, copper tape, and every type of slug bait and killer.  This is the only one that keeps the slugs at bay.  After using this for 4 days my dahlias were able to start growing without the fear of being eaten!  The only con is that when this product gets wet for 3 or more days in a row it starts to mold.  I'm assuming that in dryer temps this would not be a problem.The mold is no biggy for me - I just scrape up the moldy gunk, toss it and reapply.  The mold doesn't bother me because the only other alternative is to have my flowers be destroyed by slugs.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2021
review_content: I have an edible garden but I wanted to be able to actually eat from it and not have to be cutting and throwing away my produce because of snails. I am not sure why this review has me rate the "flavor" but I am going to assume it means did the snails like it. These are NOT edible so...yeah.Pros:*These work as intended but do not put them inside the dirt they will mold. I took the advice from other reviews and I sprinkled them around the pots on inside them and it still worked since they went after these instead of my plants.Cons:*After you wet these, or get your surface wet and then sprinkle these on top, they will get real sticky and start to mold after a while. I am so grateful for other reviews that warned me beforehand and sprinkling them on the outside worked just as well.Conclusion: Yes, they eat this and seemed to prefer it and it stopped them from eating my plants but don't put them inside your plant pots. I wouldn't recommend them if you are going to put them on dirt in the ground cause it will cause mold to grow. Also if you place them down make sure it isn't going to rain. It just washes them away. It becomes like mushy after they soak up water.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2015
review_content: I have several tomato plants, cucumber plants and more outside on our balcony patio. We had so much rain for a few days. I started to notice more and more fungus gnats on the soil and if the soil is moved more are flying around.I researched a solution to fungus gnats and came across mosquito dunks as a potential solution which includes Bacillus thuringiensis subspecies israelensis solids as one of the main ingredients. I have researched these online and some people said crushing them up into a powder and then applying them to the soil top would help get rid of the fungus gnats. Other people have followed the mosquito dunk instructions of letting the dunk soak in water for 24 hours then apply. I tried both methods and the fungus gnats are still present.I immediately seeked out advice at a nearby nursery. I go to this nursery for all my plant advice and help. They advised about fungus gnats and told me to pickup some Captain Jack's Dead Bug Brew which main ingredient is Spinosad. I immediately ordered and received it, applied it to all the plants that showed signs of fungus gnats. I then checked them the next day and a few days after. While the mosquito dunks may have worked for some people, it did not seem to be doing enough in the time frame I gave it. However the Captain Jack's Dead Bug Brew showed much less activity of fungus gnats the very next day, Captain Jacks Dead Bug Brew seems to be extremely effective. I would recommend this product to anyone who is looking for a solution for fungus gnats or any other issue that the Captain Jacks Dead Bug Brew is stated to resolve. This product seemed to work the best out of ones I have tried and read about.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2019

Even in 95 degree weather there was no wilting after application.I recommend buying a plant powder duster (about $12) You waste tons of powder or don't get all the spots dumping it out of the bottle.

review_content: We have a lot of aspen trees and Oystershell scale has always been a problem. I have a tree sprayer and attempt to time it right to get the crawlers when they are out and can be killed with Sevin. Unfortunately that is hard to judge and as the trees become mature it is very difficult to spray them because of their height.  Safari is the only treatment I know of that will systemically kill the scale by simply spraying the tree trunks to about chest height.  Safari is not cheap but it is definitely worth the cost in the ability to treat a problem that will eventually kill your trees. Adding Pentra-Bark to the Safari spray helps it to more effectively penetrate the bark.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2013
review_content: Since the bee incident in Wilsonville, Oregon, Safari has been inundated with 1 star reviews by people who have never used the product let alone read the product instructions.For years my neighbor's tree, (a oversized and never pruned Japanese Maple) has hung over my driveway dripping sticky goo on our cars when the weather got warm. I always thought it was sap but we brought in a tree professional who said he believed it was aphids. His solution was to treat the trunk with Safari two weeks ago. The dripping goo has been stopped and nary a bee was harmed in the process.There is no secret that Safari is toxic to bees. It's stated clearly in the documentation on the product. The key issue is when trees are treated. In Wilsonville Safari was applied when the trees were in full flower and full of bees which was negligence on the part of the contractor who applied the product. Had safari been applied earlier in the year when the trees were way ahead of flowering there would have been no bee story. Safari has been used effectively for years with no national headlining stories about bee kills. The discussion about it's use has turned political and away from reality.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2014
review_content: Why all the negative reviews about insecticide that kills insects?  Isn't that the purpose of an insecticide?  I'd hope so!First of all, don't blame the product for the bee kills.  This product doesn't belong in the hands of a home owner or business that doesn't understand how this product works.  I've taken the certification test for pesticide application and you could really pass it without a good understanding of the way many pesticides work.This is a systemic insecticide which means it is absorbed by the plant and makes all parts of the plant toxic to anything feeding on it.  The claim on the label says this is a "super-systemic" which probably means that it not only is transported through the xylem but also the phloem (the transportation system for sugars - which means it will move into the nectar).It should be common sense to the applicator that this will kill every insect feeding on it.  Obviously, that's why it's the most effective insecticide against sucking insects like scale.  I've used it against beetles and scale with great results.  If you have a sucking insect problem, this is your best bet,  It's a little expensive but worth it in the end!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2014
review_content: I purchased this product to apply to a Queen Sago Palm tree in my backyard.  The King and Queen Sago palms are being wiped out in the South do to a mite. I found on YouTube a posting from an agriculture extension agent from the University of Florida. He recommended this product as being the only systemic insecticide that would cure the mite infestation. I followed the instructions that came with the product and it cleared up the infestation and the Queen Sago is disease free and coupled with a liquid fertilizer, that I also purchased on Amazon, the tree is thriving.  You must keep in mind that this this is a very specialized product and should be used with great care.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2014
review_content: Unlike the other reviewers on here I've actually used this product.  It is excellent and is easily the best systemic insecticide on the market today.  It is dangerous to bees so use some common sense and don't apply it during flowering.  Wait till flowering ends to apply it by the following season it will be worn off.  No product works better systemically to kill hard to kill pests like hard bodied scale.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2018
review_content: Firstly, this is labelled as an agricultural insecticide, and I didn't use it for that. I used it to kill two common household pests, and a seasonal one, and a less common one.Now that that's out of the way...it killed three of them (one of the common household pests, the less common one, and the seasonal one).The things to remember are:1. if you're using it by itself, in a water base (which by no means do you have to), it will not stop your misery instantaneously - you'll continue to see them for about a week, but they'll stop feeding before then.2. Only mix up as much as you plan on using: mixtures more than a day old will putrefy and there's no way to prevent this without killing your spores or adding something else.Another thing is that if you're like me, you'll probably have an allergic reaction to it if you're using it in and around places you sleep - not anything life-threatening, but very much like a cold.I was a fan. Pricy, but its cheaper than an extermination and unlike chemical insecticides, pests don't know better than to run away from mold spores.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2019
review_content: I bought this product after reading reviews and blogs regarding the treatment of a dreaded indoor pest that no one likes to talk about. I had purchased a pesticide in liquid and powder form but since these bugs hide under wood trim and crevices it's impossible to make contact with all of them. Miss just one and before you know it, the population explodes again. Also, I'm just not comfortable spraying all that chemical and chemical powder in the house,  especially the bedrooms. With this product,  1 tablespoon mixed with 1 gallon of 70 degree water in a garden sprayer is enough to treat my entire house. Don't make the water too warm or it may kill the spores. I don't feel concerned about applying this to upholstered furniture,  even the sides of the mattresses and box springs. I also spray around the window, door trim, baseboards and a 2" wide spray around the perimeter of the room and area rugs.  Initially, I treated once per week for 3 weeks. 4 days after the 1st treatment my daughter found a live adult in her room. I was not too concerned because it does take a few days after the insect comes in to contact with the fungal spore to die. 17 days later we have not seen any of these yucky pests, which tells me that those buggers that came in contact with the spores carried the infection back to the place they harbor. This product is said to remain active for 3 months,  however I will try to re-treat once a month as my husband travels for work and stays in hotels often. Not that he's ever seen them in any of the hotel rooms he stays in but it only takes one getting into his luggage to reintroduce them. We never did identify how we got these pests in our home. Possibly from the kids spending the night at a friend's house.  Seriously they are so common,  lots of people get them. I will update if my victory is short-lived but for now I'd say this product is the way to go.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
review_content: I have given this product a good long time to make sure I was not being impatient but I am pretty sure the spores arrived dead. I have never seen any sign of the white mold growth on insects and still have an infestation.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2023
review_content: Again, I am making a change to my post. The initial 5-star review was based heavily on previous experience. Several years ago, there was an infestation that was apparently knocked back using this product. It so happens that these beasties can survive for years wrapped in plastic bags.After recently opening one with clothing packed long ago, there was a new infestation; so again, I ordered Botanigard from Amazon. It has taken two months of steady spraying, but finally, no sign for several weeks. I am hopeful.  I did increase the spray application to daily in any area that is frequented nightly by mammalian inhabitants. An unpleasant chore, but less so than having Bee-Bees in the house.But the 5-star review is still being downgraded by one star because there is no expiration date marked on the package, which makes me suspicious. Did it take so long to get positive results because the product was outdated? I'll never know.PREVIOUSLY: I am amending my previous post. Past purchases have been effective. The latest purchase did NOT have an expiration date. Nor does it seem to be particularly effective. Perhaps the latest package has expired. No way to know.Previous post: There are some reviews that discount this item as useless. NOT my experience. There is one dreaded pest whose name I will not utter, where I have found it is the ONLY product to actually bring this scourge to an end. Not immediately. It takes a week or two, and should be repeated monthly for at least a year. I have found these critters can easily do without food, not for months, but for YEARS. They even try to successfully to chew through plastic garbage bags.In my experience, there has been no deleterious effect on me or my pets. My husband did get a mild skin rash that was easily cured by an antifungal cream. I do wear a mask when applying by spray bottle, a teaspoon or so of the powder in about 1-1/2 cups of water. Spray around affected areas. I use it three or four days apart for about two weeks.Do realize this product is not rated to solve this problem, but it does. The dreaded BEE-BEE's.Good luck.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2019
review_content: I bought it for coffee borer beetle when I lived in Hawaii.  As a side effect, it killed all of the ants and termites.  It works so well because it is a fungus and when one of the bugs are infected, they take it back to the nest and infect the whole colony.  Also, it is biologically safe for organic use.  It is a natural product all over the world but usually ineffective until contact.  That is one reason it is not as good for flying insects. I have been using it for about 5 years and love it.  I have moved back to the mainland and will be using it on my garden.Phil

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: Used this "off label" for an invasive species, the Spotted Lantern Fly.  Does NOT knock down the masses quickly, but after time had a significant impact on one of the later instar stages of the insect.  I plan on trying it on the leafhopper adult stage very soon. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
review_content: Anyone considering trying this for indoor bed bug elimination should understand that the spores cannot remain viable in less than 50% humidity.  Living in a desert climate in the winter I had to keep a huge pot of steaming water on the stove to get any results.  After about a month of use and trying different methods I have managed to kill only about half the population.I have given in and purchased the oil suspension Aprehend from a reputable DIY website.  It's supposed to be able to work in less than 20% humidity.Keeping fingers crossed!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: I used this after doing my own online research and it worked for me. We had a bedbug and a bird mite issue in the house we moved into. It is a half double which was already infested, according to my neighbor. The landlord neglected to take care of the issue properly. This did everything and more. I even used it for my next door neighbor and she hasn't seen a bed bug in months. I mixed the amount I needed and sprayed every two weeks. The 2nd week we saw a bed bug crawling on the walls with white fungus attached to it. Which we quickly dispatched and the following month we would see little fungus balls on the carpet. It did give everyone in my home the sniffles after I sprayed. We opened the windows just a little everyday for that, I can say for me it is well worth the money.  I hope this helps someone else get a good night sleep.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2019
review_content: used to treat for root aphids. i recommend using the highest dosage that they recommend and you will need to reapply at least a few times to successfully knock back the population. Did not eradicate but was good for control and managed a successful harvest with minimal impact. After further research i have learned that the fungus will not colonize in your soil spores only live for about 24 hrs. to increase its effectiveness add azadirachtin to the mix to slow the molting process of the insects. Look into a similar product called Met 52 which has the same mode of action but will colonize in your soil and greatly increases the effectiveness of the fungal spores to kill the insects..Good luck!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2014
review_content: What happened to all of the reviews that used to be on here for this product? All I see now are the reviews for the off label use. I also used the product for the off label use (the plague of critters). It seemed as though it worked at first (when it was rainy season) and then stopped working. I figured out that the humidity has to be very high like 90 or so. I began using humidifiers and vaporizers but it still doesn't seem to be working. I put 1 tbsp in a half gallon and have sprayed every week but no results. I have gone to using propane heaters with fans in each room. It takes 2 hours or more but has been more successful. If you don't do it long enough it won't kill the eggs. I got rid of the majority of the problem up front with alcohol and silica gel powder. (cimenax) I believe DE worked for little ones but not adults. I was quoted $4,500 to have a company come in and heat my house. Just too much money. Luckily, I had a propane heater on hand but most hardware stores rent them. I ended up getting some over the counter pyrmethrin insecticide that I mixed up and sprayed around the outer edges of the mattress. I took great care not to come in direct contact with it but I believe that it was effective.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2014
review_content: Worked great. Didn't use it for intended purpose. It was used to eliminate an out break caused by an unsavory visitor. This along with bed covers, diatomaceous earth, and moving beds away from walls solved the problem. We haven't caught a single one since two months after treatments began. We check every month with dry ice traps. It'll be one year to the day on August 2nd, 2014.Use this every two weeks for three months. We only needed a half gallon per treatment. After treatment we still have 3/4 of the container. We know this works since the bugs in question were found with red(blood) spores growing out of them. These were barely alive when we found them. We also found other unrelated bugs with white spores growing out of them. Needless to say, this basically eliminated most bugs in our house. Minor allergy developed during use in one house member, though said member only exhibited allergy when actively complaining about it. The rest of the time, she was fine and never needed anything for her allergy. No one else was affect short of relief that the infestation was over.Side note: Was estimated a 4k+ cleanup cost by exterminators who only offered a three month guarantee. Total cost for self extermination was 600$.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2014
review_content: Great stuff-- I used it in my house for some critters that are not listed, but very hard to get rid of-- and it worked great without any toxicity for the residing plants, animals, or humans.  Beauveria  Bassiana will be used in a new product for household use to kill bedbugs that will be produced next year and available to pest control companies only-- see the Penn State research. Botaniguard is great for the do- it -your-selfer, and those who can't afford a pest control service. Organic gardeners,  including us, have used it in our gardens to control insect blights. It is a natural organism that does not affect humans or animals when used as directed. The directions indicate that it can be used for indoor nurseries and plants.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2018
review_content: This product killed all of my squash bugs/stink bugs in a day! I used the powder straight, though.  Tiny amount sprinkled at the base of the plant under the buds. Later I mixed it with talcum powder for another application, but I don't think I needed a second application. I don't know if I had borers, but the plants were turning yellow, and now they are greening up. I think this works on borers as well. Hope you have good success too.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
review_content: This stuff infects lanternflies and uses their bodies to produce more spores. This stuff is great and so far it's works. I've found dead lanternflies on my property. I will continue to use this as it's better than poisons and actually multiplies by killing the pests thereby infecting even more of these invaders.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2021
review_content: I ordered this because my back patio was taken over by ants, gnats, mosquitos, spiders, leaf miners, aphids, you-name-it-it-was-there!  I couldn't set on the patio without being driven inside by insects and I get migraines from strong chemical smells, so this stuff is a godsend.  I've used it twice over the last 6 weeks and you can tell everywhere I've sprayed the bacteria that it has wiped out a lot of the pests that normally flourish in the sandy soil next to my patio.  All of the rosebushes that were dying are now recovering, as well as all the shrubs, the yarrow, the spearmint, the ornamental ginger and turmeric plants, as well.  This stuff is the best investment I've made in a while.  Well worth the price. Also, it hasn't rained here in a couple weeks and the only plants holding up okay are the ones I sprayed!  I'm so glad I tried it.  Plus, it doesn't kill all the good stuff in the soil like synthetic pesticides.  I'm sold forever.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2023
review_content: I've been using this (concentrate) for a while now.  This small amount goes a long way however.  You need to dilute it well, and put it in to a regular spray bottle, so that you can spray leaves on plants.  My plants in particular are Lantana's.  There is a moth that lays eggs on the Lantana, and when they hatch, then they becomes small worms which will eat all of the young (new) growth on a Lantana bush.  However, if you use this sparingly (dilute it well), and spray the top side and bottom side of all Lantana bush leaves, then it will discourage (or kill entirely) the stupid bugs that eat my plants.  I have been using this concentrate for years with great success.  You might want to wear gloves when applying it, because the mixture is very toxic (kind of) and will stay on your skin for a long time and is hard to get off, when you are spraying plants.  So I always wear some cheap, thin, disposable clear hand covers when applying this stuff.  Hope this helps!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2015
review_content: I wasted the whole growing season having false faith in this product that was recommended by the local nursery. From what I can tell on other reviews it seems people are just as pleased as can be.  I seem to be the only person alive that has fungus, disease, insects, mites, you name it, all over my veggies. If this product did just one of the many things it promises I would at least have one veggie left. But this product did nothing for my aphids, in fact, it seemed to fire them up to eat more. Powdery mildew was on one maybe two leaves of my cucumber when I sprayed as directed, it acted more like a plague distributor as now there is powdery mildew everywhere despite my di!igent temp checks and humidity monitoring and following application instructions to a t. Yes I got top and bottom of each leaf, I got stems, I got new growth, I got the soil, instead of gaining some kind of control, the fungus took over within a week and aside from letting my plant slowly get sucked dry I am tempted to burn it all down. Then I got aphids on my lettuce and they were literally covering the entire plant. I doused it with fertilome and there was nary a single death. It almost seemed they were raising their tiny glasses and cheering me. Next came spider mites on my greenbeans.  This product had no effect. None. This magical potion promises so much. And I have so much I need taken care of. Out of all the insects, diseases, funguses, and mites its supposed to eradicate, is it too much to ask to get just one thing?  Just one?  But no, for me the magic has worn off and all I am left with is putrid smelling worthlessness - although I may have lung cancer in my near future so there's that.  Oh ya and my millions upon millions of new disgusting life destroying scurg of the earth. And just so you know, I have a greenhouse that has a water drip system on a timer, the temperature is regulated morning and night, sterilized soil and vermiculite with monthly fertilization with granular fertilizer along with calcium and phosphates for the tomatoes all are provided via product instructions.  I wanted it to work. I really truly did. I gave it many chances to do something . . anything . . . entire growing season.  . . It simply does not work. Just doesn't. It smells bad and gives me a headache figuratively and literally. Not recommended for greenhouse veggies and fruits.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2013
review_content: So far they have been up for three days in my citrus trees and have trapped a bunch of different bugs. These traps work by attracting the bugs by the color of paper, it is NOT a lure. So far the pest I have been trying to capture, the CLM, has been found in these traps but that is by sheer chance and not in the large numbers I was hoping for. But that is what I expected going in to buying these. If you want a real trap with lure, look somewhere else. Otherwise, these traps work well for what they are.These traps work to catch bugs but they only work by sticking the bug to the paper and by attracting certain bugs by the color of the paper.They are good to get rid of some pests but it wont get rid of all of them. I have noticed a couple beneficial insects trapped as well. The glue has no prejudice and will trap everything that touches it. I have the yellow traps as well but I notice more pests in the yellow traps.All these traps need is some kind of chemical lure and I would have given it 5 stars.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2013
review_content: A blossoming friendship between Uncle Richard and friend Charlie‚Äôs mother, Ellie, promises a holiday in Normandy. The magical book provides a prior history lesson that twins Joe and Jemima, their clever friend and the hilarious talking Tonkinese cat, Max, will never forget. When the children and the beloved pet suddenly appear in eleventh century England, Charlie‚Äôs encyclopaedic knowledge is put to good use as they try to alter the course of history. They travel north with Harold‚Äôs army to witness the defeat of Harald Hardrada, invited by Harold‚Äôs unpopular brother Tostig as a consequence of a family feud. Max and Charlie prove to be invaluable! The children and Max become a part of the historic rush of the King‚Äôs army to the South Coast to deal with the other threat to the English Crown: William of Normandy. Sadly, a greater magic lurking in the flat lands of East Anglia determines the King‚Äôs destiny... plus his refusal to heed Charlie‚Äôs wisdom. Tension and humour add to the enjoyment of reading this version of events leading up to the one Battle that every schoolchild in England knows the date of.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2018
review_content: I've been dealing with a major fungus gnat problem after foregoing soil sterilization on one of my indoor plants.  Prior to ordering these I had been using other brands of yellow sticky traps and, while they are very sticky and will catch some gnats, I always noticed more gnats floating around nearby.  I was having to cut them to the shape of the pot to get any effect.  The blue traps on the other hand catch almost 50 gnats for every one that lands on the yellow trap (see attached picture).  They actually seem to actively avoid the yellow traps as I've seen a number hover around them before slamming into the blue.  I can't say how well these will work for thrisps or other insects but for fungus gnats they're amazing.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2012
review_content: Since I have ordered these so many times I figured a review would be in order.Even though I wouldn't consider these as a way to control a thrip infestation they are really good for alerting you when these tiny monsters are around your prized plants, whatever they may be.  I keep about 6-10 outside in my grow area and change them once they are completely covered.  The thrips are VERY attracted to these and every one they catch is one last critter on my plants.  To date I have not seen any beneficial bugs caught in them like ladybugs or bee's.  I did find a butterfly one time but hasn't happened again since.On a side note I am currently using Captain Jacks concentrate to spray the area to knock down the thrips whenever they come back.  It has worked fairly well along with these sticky traps.  The current price for the traps is pretty good, especially if you get free shipping or have a Prime membership.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
review_content: i live on a farm and powdery mildew in my garden is an every day issue. i have tried so many ineffective products to combat PM and this one is no different. It does not kill on contact as the bottle states. The day after I spray it comes right back regardless if i use the recommended weak solution for PM or double the dose. i can spray my plants every other day and the PM will still come back usually within 2 to 3 days. This is also not systemic so if you're deep into flowering you can easily use over a gallon a plant spraying in all the nooks and crannies of your buds and leaves because the spray has to make contact with the PM itself. But again it doesnt matter because it simply does not work not as a preventative nor as an eliminator. I purchased a gallon for $100 a week ago. The price went up again after a week. A milk and water solution works just as good which is to say it doesnt. The only thing amazing about this product is how many people including myself jumped on the bandwagon to buy this crap after all the glowing reviews. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020

review_content: These are definitely substandard pot stakes for catching gnats, whitefly, etc. they are difficult to put on the stakes as they do not stay. There is a thin clear membrane that you must remove as well if it does not come off with the paper. Because the trap itself does not bend easily as part of the preparation, it folds unevenly and forces you to grasp it with your fingers to position it and then it becomes difficult to place cleanly in the stake. These are less expensive than the Safer traps but I would rather have a product that works with less issues. I am not sure if the traps themselves are as effective because human pheromones left on the adhesive while trying to place the traps may result in ineffectiveness in catching tiny insects.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
review_content: Very good insecticide made with Pyrethrins. I like it because even when the residual effect is short lived, it is safer to humans and pets than an insecticide with Pyrethroids. Even when it is meant for stables, I use it in the house and in the garden. It kills fleas, ticks, scorpions, spiders, ants, mosquitoes, and cold blooded pests including snakes. I mix one ounce on one gallon of water and use a spray bottle such as a FLAIROSOL mister to spray spots in the house mainly by the doors and corners and on my dog's bed. I do not spray it directly on the kennel when my dog is inside. If my dog is scratching, I spray a small amount on a soft wide brush and then brush his back and neck only, never on his belly or genitals. In the garden I use it with a RIOBY Fogger. I never spray it directly on any pet or people.

review_content: Used this along with orthene (which you can also get on this site) to get rid of root aphids on my indoor plants. Root aphids are some of the hardest bugs to get of and this stuff worked like a charm. Find a large bucket and dunk your root balls of your plants for 20 min. Make sure you where protective gear like gloves, jacket, etc. because you don't want to get this stuff on your skin. Your plants will suffer for awhile and your soil will also suffer but it killed them all off in one go unlike most things where you have to use them for weeks if not months to get rid of them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: I like the high concentration and the price is the lowest I can find. Excellent source of organic nitrogen. I have used it as a foliar spray and a ground watering organic fertilizer for all plants. Potted plants, vegetable garden, flower garden, shrubs, and trees. Tomatoes do not seem to like it but all other plants seem to love it. It works great for watering during dry weather conditions. I make an all organic fertilizer. I use one tablespoon per gallon of water. I add one teaspoon of concentrated seaweed extract, one tablespoon of molasses, and one teaspoon of Tide free & gentle. The Tide acts as a sticker spreader. That is the most inexpensive organic fertilizer I have been able to come up with for spraying and watering.

review_content: This stuff is great for plants! You should how big my garden grew last year when I used this. I ordered it from a catalog but am happy to see Home Depot carries it.This is a concentrate that, when mixed with water, looks frothy like root beer but sure doesn't smell like it. Mix up a jug of it to treat each row when you plant your garden or to fertilize shrubs, trees or flowers. I recommend using a throw-away juice jug, since the smell doesn't come out of plastic easily. Since it's a concentrate, you can mix in other nutrient-rich kitchen items such as coffee grounds to fertilize evergreens or roses, or eggshells for tomato plants.I haven't used chemical fertilizers on my garden or plants, so I can't compare the effectiveness but I doubt anyone would be disappointed in how their plants respond to soil enriched with this. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2022
review_content: I have been using this for some time and love it. I mix it with distilled water (maybe that's overkill, but I have hard water) and it never leaves stains or residues on all the various surfaces I have sprayed it on. The type of bottle this comes in is the best -- it makes it just so easy to measure out and pour the needed amount. I actually bought a bunch of these bottles to use with other chemicals as well, but they are not cheap. So great value to get it already in this bottle!BUT the listing here is just incorrect or something. I mean, it says 176 gallons from this 32 fl oz bottle -- the standard mixture rate is 1 fl oz makes 1 gallon; doing the math that is... 32 gallons from this 32 fl oz bottle. I guess they are showing you use the minimum mixture rate there, so be aware.I use this product as a general home defense product. Applied at the typical 1 fl oz to 1 gallon rate, spread around the foundation 2 feet in each direction where the foundation and grade meet. Also 2 ft around every doorway and window, spray the eaves and soffit too. Don't forget your garage doors as well, as insects love to get in there. I don't use it indoors, because I don't want to unless absolutely needed, but I am starting to experiment with using it in the garage, as that is a sort-of outdoors location and there is all kinds of random spots bugs love to collect.When applying this way, and comparing to neighbors, it seems very effective. Don't have issues with insects like wasps under the eaves for example. I apply at least once a month, but when there is a lot of insect activity I do it every other week (instructions say you could do it as often as every week, but every other week seems effective enough to me). I try to apply when there will be no rain in 24 hours in each direction (before and after application) to make sure it doesn't get washed off.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023
review_content: I mix 1 oz of this into a 1 gallon spray jug and hit the perimeter of my home usually monthly (or after any big rain fall). 1 oz will cover ~60-65% of my exterior with heavy spray around the front porch. I live in NC near water so we get all sorts of bugs - especially spiders (black widow/brown recluse) and palmetto bugs. This has done a great job of keeping bugs at bay and you can absolutely tell it works when you step out on the patio or front porch and see the dead bugs.While it isn't necessarily great for spiders (since spiders have longer legs that tend to keep the body away from the spray), this spray does a great job of taking care of all the other bugs which tend to be a food source for spiders - remove the food source and you keep the spiders at bay.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2023
review_content: This stuff has saved us a world of annoyance from ants and other creepy crawlies. We spray all around the outside of our house and we've not had any ants. I spray inside along the floor boards and spiders are gone! We used it in the basement when we had a bunch of flying ants come in somehow and that took care of them. This is SO much cheaper than calling a pest control person! I recommend it, get a good sprayer and you'll be set. We spray after each rain too, and spray our outside porch. When we had carpenter bees, it worked on them, as much as we HATE killing bees of any kind, they were making a mess out of our back porch. We sprayed at night after they had left the holes they'd been drilling. When they came back the next morning they left those area's alone. We were happy because we sure didn't want to kill them. It is their world we invaded after all, and we need all of the bees we can get.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2022
review_content: I had a severe wasp problem here. On soffits and vinyl siding to soffit are wasps were buzzing around. Several corners of the house had this issue. I could not sick on deck, since wasps would buzz me, sometimes aggressively for no reason...I was 30+ feet away from end of house where they seemed to buzz around every day. Warm days, cold mornings...so I got up early and sprayed one really bad corner, soffit, corner vinyl trim piece, got all the cracks and crevices...while the bees slept in out of the cold. I was nervous spraying, expected a swarm. I would spray a second and run far away and observe. Braver and braver I sprayed more. That was one corner on day 1. It stayed cold all day, no wasps. The next day it warmed up, but I was never outside n deck. The day after I walked out and saw several wasps dead on the deck. Hooray! I sprayed again since I did see a few random wasps flying around. Then a day or two later I sprayed all the soffit areas, vinyl trim corners, gaps, holes, crevices, around crawl space to floor wall, in crawl space vents, any place I felt bugs or bees could intrude or live. Success. I occasionally see a yellow jacket or wasp, but no swarms on house or attacks on the deck. A European hornet buzzes by once in a while, but they nest out on the woods. So much happier now without wasps everywhere. Well worth the money and 1 gallon sprayer to treat this house. Also no more crickets in crawl space or inside house. Crickets use to be inside once or twice every week. Happy camper here :-)

review_content: I have a pump sprayer. I bought another brand they took off the market and was skeptical about this brand. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2020
review_content: Best bug killer I've used. I live on the edge of a forest that is nearly 100,000 acres of open chaparral. The spiders and other nasties that crawl out of there are shocking and dangerous.This products toxicity is low for humans and animals, yet yields a high degree of toxicity for flying insects, arachnids and other creepy crawlies.One broad application on my eaves and ground perimeters, topped off with spraying the tops and sides of all bushes and trees, keeps our family and animals bug free for months and months.It seems to keep killing week after week because I find new carcasses months after applying.The amount of airborne insect traffic throughout the day into the evening has decreased dramatically. I believe that to be the result of spraying the tops and sides of all bushes and trees.I have recommended this product to my neighbors for them to try. Its effective for long term pest management and allows us to spend more time outside.This is not a "bang your dead" bug spray. Its systemic and persistent. It will ultimately kill the bugs in large numbers over long periods of time. That reduces the overall population and keeps them from reproducing in annoying numbers.Best wishes and happy bug killing.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review_content: This stuff kills whatever it can reach including fire ants, spiders, beetles etc.  Like any insecticide it will only go so far down into an ant bed & kill whatever it reaches, You will see a ton of dead ants shortly after spraying but alas the survivors will simply resurface somewhere else again after a heavy rain. I use this stuff inside & outside the home, it has no scent & is non staining & pet safe. It continues to kills all kinds of bugs for months after spraying, even outside after a rain.This concentrated bottle will make a BUNCH of insecticide, simply go by the mix directions & get yourself a quality pump sprayer to use. When the bugs get real bad here in the deep South I'll spray my entire yard with a pull behind sprayer with this stuff & enjoy our outside activities while watching the neighbors slap at bugs.  :)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2013
review_content: Lowes doesn't carry this product. Home Depot does, but only online. Home Depot was also asking twice the price I found on Amazon, and with Prime, shipping was free, so the cost was even lower! One other significant difference between this brand and others is that this has 7.9% Bifenthrin, whereas other brands only have slightly over 2%. This is a concentrate, so it does pour out quite thick, but it easily dilutes in water in the sprayer. It's best if you mix the solution before you begin spraying. Just shake your bottle sprayer and you should be good to go.As for how the product worked, I found it to be excellent. I got this specifically to kill the Spittle bugs that were killing my lawn. After I figured out how many sq. ft. my lawn was, I only needed to mix 1 oz. per 1000 sq. ft. in a hose sprayer filled with water,  and I was good to go. It took me two days to do my lawn - I had to blow the leaves off first - completing the front and sides on the first day and the back yard the second day. I covered over 1/2 acre and still have plenty left over for a 2nd application.After spraying my front yard and sides, I went out the next morning and saw plenty of dead Spittle bugs lying in the grass, road and on my driveway. The second day went similarly in the back yard. Now, I'm starting to see my grass come back from the brink of dying due to a very wet Spring and Summer when Spittle bugs are very actively laying eggs and chomping my centipede and zoyzia grasses like there's no tomorrow! Happy spraying...

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2021
review_content: I typically use propiconozole as my main fungicide but wanted to change it up which is a good idea to do! I noticed quick results within 2-3 days! We had 3 weeks of rain and humidity (souther Louisiana). Once I seen 2-3 of clear skies in the forecast I put the fungicide down with my Spray tank (with a serfactant) sticking agent methylated seed oil! I also tank mixed with Green Effect. Fungus cleared up pretty quickly. Wait 2-3 days before you cut to allow the fungicide to be absorbed in the foliage leaf tissue.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
review_content: This stuff is amazing.  It is the only product I have found that takes care of TARR (Take All Root Rot) in my St. Augustine lawn.  I wasted a lot of $ on Scotts fungus cure before doing some research (to figure out exactly what was killing my lawn) and finding this stuff.  I treat with this the week before I do my twice a year lawn fertilizing or any broad spectrum weed and feed products as these products weaken the grass's ability to fight the fungus.  Before I got the root rot under control, I treated with this product, put a good layer of peat moss down on the rhizomes (the fungus does not like an acidic environment) of the grass (a very dirty, time consuming, but worthwhile endeavor), and retreated 2 weeks later.  I also currently patch treat with sulfur, peat or this fungicide whenever I see the grass go chlorotic in any of the problem areas, clears up the problem every time.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: I've noticed oak trees were browning before fall for some time now. Two years my oak did the same thing. I read about several blights and insects that could cause the problem and decided to do something. This is what I came up with to try and save the tree.This tree measured 66" in girth at chest height.I sat three 5 gallon buckets with a 3/16" hole drilled in the bottom of each around the base of my tree.In a separate 5 gallon bucket I mixed:* 4 gallons of water.* 22 ounces of Imadacloprid systemic insecticide.* 4 ounces of Eagle 20EW systemic fungicide.* 24 ounces of liquid fertilizer in hopes the roots would better absorb the solution if the fertilizer would act as a carrier.* Then I filled each bucket with this mixture.¬† (So times 3)Attached is a picture of the oak tree over a year later. So far I don't see any blight or insect damage at all. Maybe that concoction works!?!PLEASE NOTICE: While I did read and follow label directions for the insecticide and fertilizer, this use may not be according to label directions for Eagle 20EW. Please consult with your local county extension office.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2018
review_content: I'm a new homeowner and I started noticing brown patch on my once beautiful lawn.  I started using Bayer Advanced, which was useless... actually worse than useless because it allowed the fungus to get worse.  Within a week of using Eagle 20EW, most of the grass that wasn't too badly damaged started to turn green again.  I just applied a 2nd treatment 2 weeks later to make sure it's all gone.  The best part is that you get a lot of applications from the 16 oz bottle and I'll be able to use it next season too (hopefully just as a preventative).  Although I plan to rotate with a different category fungicide as recommended to prevent the fungus from developing a resistance.My recommendation is to use gloves and eye protection while handling and applying, and maybe even a mask (I didn't do this part) just in case the wind blows it back in your face.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
review_content: I decided to try this instead of Immunox same active ingredient but a lot higher concentration and a lot less expensive per application, I had to do some math to calculate the amount to add to a 4 gallon backpack sprayer, and it is only 1.25 teaspoons per tank so this will last for a long time, but how did it work? I sprayed the trees from green tip to petal fall. When the leaves fully enlarged I saw apple scab and thought it didn't work, but then to my surprise the leaves with the apple scab started withering, and now as it is almost harvest time the trees look healthier than they have in 10 years!!! Finally a product that works to control apple scab on my old apple trees!!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2023
review_content: I've been using Permethrin for (1) My Dogs (2) Clothes to repel pests (3) Garage (4) Shop.... and for MUCH less than other pesticides. I mix the 10% this way... 1 oz of 10% Permethrin with 19 oz of distilled water (or tap water). I mix the 13.3% this way... 1 oz of 13.3% with 26 oz of distilled water. I use a ZEP spray bottle and keep it handy. For the dogs I put the sprayer on stream delivery, start on the head across the two ears then from the head to the tail along the back. One final little spray under the throat. The stream needs to get to the skin through the hair. It lasts about 12 days... no scratching, no fleas or ticks. I don't use pricey Frontline anymore. For the shop and premises I put the sprayer nozzle on spray or stream and then shoot the corners, door jams, any spiders I see get a spray and just go around the garage and shop spraying along the floor. Again it lasts about 12 days but for roaches it seems to last a month or more. A 32 ounce jug of Permethrin last me more than a year so under $1/month does the job.

review_content: I've had great success using diluted permethrin on clothes to keep off ticks but this particular formulation has an intolerable odor which does not go away. I have previously used Martin's 10% concentration which had no unpleasant odors and whatever odor it did have was not lasting. I had no reason to think the 13.3% concentration would be any different but it is like night and day. Cannot store in house after opening and diluting 1:22 to reduce to .5% permethrin suitable for clothing. The label does say "contains petroleum distillates" and that must be the source of the smell. Even if I had a garage or shed to store this in it would not be worth keeping. It smells like gasoline.Doing further research I'm unable to find any concentrated permethrin product that does not contain petroleum distillates. Previous bottle of Martin's 10% was quite old and the liquid was very thick. Unfortunately already tossed the empty bottle away so cannot compare ingredients but confidant it did not contain petroleum distillates as there really was no odor to speak of.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2021
review_content: I bought this for 2 uses: chickens and cats. I dust the inside of my chicken coop ( using a filtered mask) before laying down pine shavings to prevent mites. Works well. Second use was to worm several cats. I had been having trouble administering dewormer to all of them ( own 3) . Wound up putting about a tablespoon of DE into about 2 tablespoons of water, and mixing this into a can of pate style cat food. Distributed amongst the 3 cats, who devoured it with no problem. After a few days, there was no sign of worms in the catbox stool. It did not appear to affect their digestion, as in make them nauseous or give them diarrhea, as had been the case with deworming medicines. Kept the treatment up for a week, waited two weeks, then gave them another course of treatment just in case. The worms have not made a return appearance. This bag is large and very reasonably priced. Properly sealed and stored, it will last a long time.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2017
review_content: I bought this in sprayer form because I've used the handheld spritz bottle before and it worked well in the past. We had two dwarf tomato plants in patio pots and this helped get rid of some fungus and keep them healthy then.Now we have more room, so a lot more plants (a couple dozen) in raised beds; our ventilation and spacing is way better so the plants are healthy and beautiful but OH do the APHIDS love them! They're about 6ft over the beds and too hard to spray manually; this has a broad spray pattern that easily covers the whole plant. We sprayed top to bottom and then bottom to top so the leaves were soaked in both sides. About an hour later when checked, we did find multiple dead bugs and some cleared leaves. It's too early to tell if it'll work for clearing out all the little suckers, but I was pleased to find *some* of the bugs have either fallen off or died so it does seem to be working for aphids as well!The bees seem to be alright and currently are visiting the sprayed plants; the only drawback is, this does have a very... peculiar? smell, I'm not sure how to describe it, but it's pretty funky and it stays on the plants even after they're dried.*Review will be updated as we do more treatments*

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2017
review_content: I was very nervous about using this in my backyard as I have dogs who like to eat grass and generally anything they can. Things came to a head when I started seeing brown widows on our chimney and in our shed and that was the end of it. We looked into having a professional come out, but the price was ridiculous and it seemed like something that we could do. The stuff you can buy at Home Depot doesn't do much of anything so I knew it had to be a stronger product, and after days of research I landed on this product.  The only other things you need are some gloves and a hand held sprayer. The instructions are very clear and give you the mix amounts for different insects you want to kill. We have a 10,000 s.f. lot and it only took two oz of concentrate to produce 2 gallons of spray and I was able to get the entire lot. We were going on vacation so the dogs were already at the kennel so I didn't have to worry about them getting into it, as it is supposed to be safe to large animals and people once dry,  however it remains deadly to small insects at that point though. When I was spraying it the spiders immediately came out of their hiding spots trying to survive but within about 30 minutes when I came back they were all dead. It was a little disturbing to see how many spiders there really were in our backyard but I feel much better now knowing that they are dead. I will be re-applying every month to keep them away. I would highly recommend this and it was very easy to use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2023
review_content: Used this for a flea infestation and it worked well at the recommended rate of 1 oz per gallon on cracks and crevices. Mix with an IGR and its very effective. The negative reviews here are comical because they don't understand what they are buying. This is not a contact kill. It cripples their nervous systems and takes anywhere from minutes to hours to kill. It is a residual killer that lasts a long time. Also, beware the amount you are mixing because it is really easy to contaminate your house if spraying indoors. You shouldn't be seeing a bunch of white liquid ... kind of scary how many people just spray things without any fundamental understanding of the chemicals being applied.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2023
review_content: Made a batch to use on ants.  After only one use of this product its like where did they go? They packed up moved out.  No sorry after checking they are deceased.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2023
review_content: I think this would be effective. It is quite easy to apply with a sprayer. Mixes well with water.Just a small amount is enough for a medium sized home. I still need to learn it.I have read reviews that we will have to use some other chemical after a few applications so the pests don‚Äôt get used to this any one pesticide. I still have to figure that one out.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023
review_content: I had a problem with earwigs and small spiders being able to shimmy under the bottom weather strips of my doors. I would usually find a few in the foyer every morning. Also there is an area under the flashing on my front porch that wasp like to nest each spring/summer. I applied this at rate of 1 oz to 2 gallons of water (.05oz per gal of water) using a hand pump sprayer. I sprayed outside doors, the perimeter of my home and the flashing area on my front porch. Haven't seen a single insect in weeks.Read the instructions:I believe that most people read the first section and ignore or don't bother to read the through the full instruction manual. It has different sections for different applications. There are lots of videos saying mix 1oz per gallon of water. The instructions recommends .01 up to .05oz per gallon of water to kill most insects.(measurements are on the bottle).  The 1oz per gallon is recommended for use when trying to kill a select group of insects listed on the label (More like a soil treatment). There is also a section that covers mixing for indoor use. The ratio of product to water for indoor use is much lower than outside applications.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
review_content: I have to say I was skeptical but decided to buy this after seeing the Rutgers University school of agriculture site that listed this active ingredient as one that is sometimes effective against the dreaded BMSB's or STINK BUGS!!!!!!! I hate those little critters and was rapidly losing the batter against them when I decided I had reached the end of my rope, constantly falling over vacuum sweepers left out to suck up the creepy things and constantly on drapery watch, where they tend to nestle. I received the bottle and immediately sent my hubby to the garage for the sprayer. I mixed up my first batch, 1/3 oz to 1 gallon of water and sprayed all of my window screens from the inside, spraying out, sprayed around all my window and door openings and sills both inside and out and even in the vents of my window ACs, where I know they're getting in. I cannot tell you how happy I am with the results. As early as day two, the number of the ugly bastards was hugely diminished on the screens to just a few here and there and the number I would see on the ceiling, that always seem to just magically appear also was greatly reduced. On day three,I  found dozens of dead critters on the floor in front of doors and windows, both inside and out. Went outside to look at the siding of the house that was polluted with them previously and was astonished to see a war zone like setting of dead stink bugs all over the deck, on the tables and chairs and even a few on the railings. I hope this last was a sign of the last few soldiers struggling to make it to safety before they died, only to expire - fingers crossed * hopefully creepily - before they too kicked the bucket! I finally today reinstalled my freshly laundered and dry cleaned draperies and have yet to see a one today. My first bug free day, DAY 5. It is not a contact kill for these insidious monsters but it sure does the job. Just make sure you handle it properly and carefully in good ventilation and keep free of food prep and eating areas. I intend to keep a small, directed spray bottle upstairs at the ready and plan on spraying the entire perimeter of the house as soon as the spring approaches to hopefully stop them before they even start their migration towards the inside in the spring!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2022
review_content: Recently I decided to go DIY for my yard fertilization, etc.  This summer we were attacked by azalea caterpillars (Datana major, AKA "The Azalea Caterpillar.").  These things were like a Biblical plague as they were rapidly defoliating our azaleas and spreading like crazy throughout our yard. I looked up potential solutions and noted that Bifrenthrin (active ingredient) was quick acting and was supposed to last up to 90 days.  I applied CNS concentrate at 1 ounce per gallon of water and sprayed liberally on the azaleas and really drenched the hundreds of caterpillars that were munching on the leaves.  I would say that within 15 minutes I began to see results.  The next morning I examined the azaleas and could not see any sign of caterpillars!  I can't speak to how long the treatment will last as I sprayed early last night and am writing this review the next day, but I can say that so far it seems to be highly effective.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020
review_content: Pros:1. It barely has a smell.2. Can be used indoors as outdoors.3. It barely leaves noticeable residues.4. Kills a lot of bugs.5. Easy to mix.6. Last months between applications.Cons:1. It doesn't apply by itself... I still need to use the pump. :-)I live in a garden apartment next to a mountain, thus a lot of bugs were used to come in and bother me.  I started using this years ago in my previous house.  I order it again and magically get rid of my issues in the new apartment.  I use a hand held pump (less than a gallon) to spray it every two months to reduce exposure to the chemical.  It's working great.  I use it in a strip of lawn about two feet from the wall, in the walls, around the windows and doors.  Indoors, I use it in the perimeters of the rooms on the floor and wall corners (where usually spiders are hanging out).  No issues for me!  Always, follow the instructions and avoid contact with surfaces that you handle food.  I do use it around my pantry a lot to avoid any insects going in.  I hope this helps you!  Remember that if you have a special bug that is bothering you, you might want something specific for it.  This controls a wide spectrum, but it will not kill everything but it will be darn close.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2019
review_content: I live in a 100 year old house in New England.  Our basement is old and drafty so spider infestation is common. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
review_content: Yeah, it kills bugs if you spray them directly with it.  And it will eventually kill those bugs that cross over a recently sprayed area.  But not many will cross into an area where this has recently been applied because they can detect it and avoid it.  And unless a bug comes into and rolls around on a treated area, Bifenthrin has no effect.  We can't sense it, but they can. I watched a cockroach one evening do a little zig-zag tap dance around a treated area, seemingly giving me the bug finger the whole route. Very demoralizing. Not all will avoid it, just like not all humans avoid unhealthy food, but more than I am willing to put up with will.  Yes, like junk food, eventually it builds up to the point it does kill them, but by then they've reared a few equally flippant generations of pests.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
review_content: I'm a bit miffed about this product, yeah it sounds great and effective but I got a jolt when I read this on the label in their website:This pesticide is extremely toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates. To protect the environment, do not allow pesticide to enter or run off into storm drains, drainage ditches, gutters or surface watersA majority of the people who I know will use this will not even read this or might not even care.This needs to be in BIG BOLD letters on the outside so SOMEONE sees itIn fact what is the portion of rainwater that will not pull this chemical (even when dried) into gutters and then streams ? Next to nothing I feel. Nothing says this is rain or water proof. Yes they say apply when there is no rain, but will it hold, like paint does ?I added another star just because they are truthful and try not to deceive you by making you use it regularly.Will gladly add another star after seeings it effectiveness and another if they add the warning with diagrams for the ones who cannot read.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2021
review_content: I live in a rental property that was obviously neglected lawn and garden-wise for decades, and I have been trying to create a small garden here.  There were a lot of tiny white snails all over, and after a rainfall, you could not walk to the post box without crunching quite a few larger snails underfoot.  It was both distressing and disgusting to feel and hear the crunch underfoot.  So, I tried this product in May 2020, and it helped a lot.  This past Spring/Summer (2021) I noticed a bit of a snail comeback as t'were, so I plan to retreat the property.  I have been waiting for the price to go down under $10 before I pull the trigger again.I cannot guarantee you will have as good results as I have had, but if you apply this generously in infested areas, I think you will see a great improvement.  I made sure to toss some of the bits into my neighbour's grassy area, too, which I am sure helped a lot.  My greatest pest problem now is the grasshoppers.  If only I could rid my garden and yard of those voracious grasshoppers, I would be very content indeed.  They decimated many of my plants again this year, so next year I plan to take drastic measures.  I am not keen to use chemicals, but if that is what it will take to rid my home of grasshoppers, then I am going to take that step.  This year I planned to use organic NOLO Bait in late May, but the company who makes NOLO sold out completely so early last Spring that it was unbelievable, and they never made any more the rest of the season.  Looking back, I should not have waited.  I thought they would make more available, so I waited, but now I realise that was a huge mistake.  I was overrun with grasshoppers all Summer through October again this year.  I will look for NOLO next Spring, BUT if they sell out as fast again, I will use chemicals.  I cannot go through another season with no help against the grasshopper hordes.  Thank heavens this product at least helped me to end the snail and slug problem for the most part.  If you have a snail/slug problem, I suggest you try this product.  Sprinkle generously in infested areas on days that are dry with no rain in the forecast.  You will not see an overnight miracle, but give it 2-4 weeks, and I think your snail/slug problem will be greatly improved.Recommended.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2023
review_content: I bought this product in May.  Used it twice before.  I also used beer traps at the same time.  I don‚Äôt see any big slugs around but I still found those tiny baby slugs on the inner side of the leaves sometimes.  And for the last while I found some of the leaves were fell down on the ground.  It looked like it had been chewed apart.  But it didn‚Äôt look like it has been ate at all.  Just the whole leave and the stem were fell down with the bottom of the stem tearing apart.  I have Hostas for many years and this never happened before.  I finally found out why.  I used the slugs baits for the third time 3 days ago.  The next morning I woke up, all 4 of my Hosta has been chewed and tear apart most of the stems at the bottom.  All of the slug baits I sprinkled on and around the Hosta were totally gone.  Something were eating the baits and probably tried to tear the stems to get in between the stems to get the rest of the baits inside the stems.  Now I found out some other living things like the slugs baits and my poor Hostas were the victims.  I will update the review when I caught the predator.
