review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2017
review_content: Boy did the slugs eat this stuff up! I put a few pellets in front of a slug by my front door one night and watched him go to TOWN on it like a fat kid with a chocolate cake! Did I say fat kid? okay... I meant me. Me with a chocolate cake. Mmmmm cake.What were we talking about again?RIGHT. SLUG KILLER.It almost works TOO good... I had a real problem after letting them go unchecked for about 12 years. I could go out after dark on any given night and there would be dozens on the siding, foundation and walkway. I did a combo of hand picking for several days (go out after dusk with rubber gloves and a ziplock bag and just collect all the slugs, seal em up and throw em in the trash) and then spread this stuff around their hidey holes where I know they sleep in the day (the crack between the walkway and the stairs and the stairs and hollow cement stoop, along flower bed edgers, the waterfall/pond, the woodpile, ect). I barely saw any slugs for several months after putting this out! I think I saw one lone slug on two occasions in the weeks to follow.But BEWARE. I messed with the ecosystem. The delicate balance of nature. And you know what happened? Mushrooms EXPLODED on my properrty. because slugs eat decaying matter and they LOVE a good mushroom feast. and I figured out that that's why I HAD so many slugs. Because apparently I have mushrooms out the wazoo! And fearful for my dogs health (I have the kind of mushrooms that sent Alice on her trippy ride to wonderland. My friend's dog died from eating one) I had now created a new chore. I had to walk around my half acre back yard and collect the bucket of mushrooms that sprouted overnight every single day.So as the slugs started to come back a little, I let them. I don't need to be slug free, I just don't want to worry about where I step when I run out to my car barefoot for my phone charger after dark, lest I get a slimy surprise underfoot!! Therefore I will certainly continue to use this product to control the population around the high traffic areas of the property and around the perimeter of my house!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2023
review_content: I container garden.  I was waking up to finding my new vegetable transplants riddled with holes on their leaves.  Additional research indicated the probable cause was snails and slugs.  I got this product, and sprinkled it around my containers.  It only took 48 hours to see the dramatic difference.  I had removed the very damaged leaves so only new minimally chewed ones remained on the plants.  I also use Tulle to discourage bunnies and squirrels from messing with my plants.  I saw no additional damage and none since.  Kale, cabbage, spinach, and more looked great after this treatment!  Drink your beer or use it to stop these guys.  Your choice, but I know which I would choose!

review_content: I have tried EVERYTHING to get rid of slugs!  I live in the pacific NW and it rains here all the time....all the time. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2021
review_content: I have an edible garden but I wanted to be able to actually eat from it and not have to be cutting and throwing away my produce because of snails. I am not sure why this review has me rate the "flavor" but I am going to assume it means did the snails like it. These are NOT edible so...yeah.Pros:*These work as intended but do not put them inside the dirt they will mold. I took the advice from other reviews and I sprinkled them around the pots on inside them and it still worked since they went after these instead of my plants.Cons:*After you wet these, or get your surface wet and then sprinkle these on top, they will get real sticky and start to mold after a while. I am so grateful for other reviews that warned me beforehand and sprinkling them on the outside worked just as well.Conclusion: Yes, they eat this and seemed to prefer it and it stopped them from eating my plants but don't put them inside your plant pots. I wouldn't recommend them if you are going to put them on dirt in the ground cause it will cause mold to grow. Also if you place them down make sure it isn't going to rain. It just washes them away. It becomes like mushy after they soak up water.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2022
review_content: Long time grower here. I recently got infested with russet mites in my garden. If you think spider mites are bad, russet mites make them look like family pets. Within a week of me noticing the damage (yellow, shriveled leaves and brownish buds) my entire grow was infested. I had some Monterey Garden Insect Spray  on hand. Its active ingredient is spinosad, a non-toxic bacterial byproduct that usually works on spider mites. I tried that, and although it helped, it was only slowing them down. So I went online and did some research and came up with two names: Humboldts Flower Shield and Trifecta Crop Control. Since Flower Shield was cheaper, and had a recognizable company name, I went with that.Oh, boy, big mistake. Not only did this product NOT do as it claims, which is kill russet mites, it also left a sticky residue on my buds. The residue is so tacky I was having trouble harvesting and trimming my plants. It also caused the outer layer of the buds to turn an unattractive orange-brown color, like they were burned or something. So I thoroughly washed my buds before hanging them up to dry, hoping that would remove the residue.Fast forward one week, and upon smoking my buds I was assaulted by a horrible soap-in-the-mouth and something unidentifiable flavor. I suppose I will have to toss this entire batch of bud and start over. Even though some of my buds escaped the wrath of the russet mites, Humboldts Secret Flower Shield made sure that what I managed to save was thoroughly ruined and unsmokable. They claim their product is non-toxic. But then they also claim it kills mites and would not leave a residue... so... yeah.If there is a silver lining to my tale of woe, it is that I finally did purchase the Trifecta Crop Control. It is ridiculously expensive, but it has brought my russet mite infestation under control, and does not appear to leave a sticky residue on anything. The only caveat being, it is rough on the leaves and will burn them if you do not follow instruction to a tee.In summary, stay far far away from this product. Get Trifecta Crop Control instead. Or just nuke your whole grow and start over from scratch if you get russet mites.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2023
review_content: Worth it. My money tree was really struggling. This thing saved my plant. Happy....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2018
review_content: This product performs exactly as it says on everything it says it will...I have been gardening and breeding specific plants many years now and specifically medically the past half dozen years and the results get tested after harvest and I trust this product to do what it says while still allowing me to provide clean medicine to my patients and myself. Use it at the full recommended 2oz /gal to knock down the bugs/mites (Foliar spray and/or drench/dunk depending on where the pest lives) and 1oz/gal to knock down any of the PM or other fungi (non pest/insect uses)...INITIALLY, then after the first dose you should be able to cut it in half for the next couple treatments and then in half again for any follow up...It may not be cheap but it is economical IMO (mainly because it WORKS, lol) and if you stay on top of your spray schedule depending on what you are treating for then you will not require it for long because, again, IT WORKS! ;) ...if you are treating for mites I would recommend spraying at FULL strength TWO TIMES (3 days apart) using the best sprayer/atomizer you can get and really get in there now! The tops and bottoms of all leaves, the branches & stems and the top of your soil/mulch and even the floor surrounding the plants... I will sometimes add Dr. Bronners clear hemp liquid soap at a T per gal for pest treatments...helps with surface tension and further smothering the little bastards! After treatments and in between I like to spray with clean water and sometimes a foliar additive for vigor or growth like kelp (Golden Tree - Same company as this product), willow bark extract, etc., to help the plant recover from the issue that caused the treatments to begin with. Good Luck!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2022
review_content: Long time grower here. I recently got infested with russet mites in my garden. If you think spider mites are bad, russet mites make them look like family pets. Within a week of me noticing the damage (yellow, shriveled leaves and brownish buds) my entire grow was infested. I had some Monterey Garden Insect Spray  on hand. Its active ingredient is spinosad, a non-toxic bacterial byproduct that usually works on spider mites. I tried that, and although it helped, it was only slowing them down. So I went online and did some research and came up with two names: Humboldts Flower Shield and Trifecta Crop Control. Since Flower Shield was cheaper, and had a recognizable company name, I went with that.Oh, boy, big mistake. Not only did this product NOT do as it claims, which is kill russet mites, it also left a sticky residue on my buds. The residue is so tacky I was having trouble harvesting and trimming my plants. It also caused the outer layer of the buds to turn an unattractive orange-brown color, like they were burned or something. So I thoroughly washed my buds before hanging them up to dry, hoping that would remove the residue.Fast forward one week, and upon smoking my buds I was assaulted by a horrible soap-in-the-mouth and something unidentifiable flavor. I suppose I will have to toss this entire batch of bud and start over. Even though some of my buds escaped the wrath of the russet mites, Humboldts Secret Flower Shield made sure that what I managed to save was thoroughly ruined and unsmokable. They claim their product is non-toxic. But then they also claim it kills mites and would not leave a residue... so... yeah.If there is a silver lining to my tale of woe, it is that I finally did purchase the Trifecta Crop Control. It is ridiculously expensive, but it has brought my russet mite infestation under control, and does not appear to leave a sticky residue on anything. The only caveat being, it is rough on the leaves and will burn them if you do not follow instruction to a tee.In summary, stay far far away from this product. Get Trifecta Crop Control instead. Or just nuke your whole grow and start over from scratch if you get russet mites.

review_content: I had bought this product to protect my plants from common pests and mold as I was looking for a cheaper alternative to the better brand pesticides/fungicides. I began to increase my dosage/frequency to attempt to kill off these mites and this product did absolutely nothing to prevent and treat  the mite problem... they just became worse and seemed almost resilient to this stuff. this product does nothing to prevent unwanted pests and mold and would HIGHLY not recommend using it. review_content: I really like the idea of supporting a small business, and have purchased their plant food in the past, and really liked the quality of the product which led me to purchase the fungicide and insecticide set. For the fungicide, I am in the process of treating multiple plants for root rot and truly hope this product will save them and will update with time. As far as the insecticide, I am using that to control gnats in a few of my plants as well as spider mites in my bird of paradise. I have seen the amount of gnats decrease and we‚Äôll see how the product will help long-term. You get a very concentrated mixture, which seems like it would last for a very long time. I also have reached out to customer service with multiple questions and they are very friendly and quick to respond which I think is incredibly important for us as customers to have that kind of awesome support. Overall, so far I am happy and will update with long term results. Oh and the packaging is really aesthetically pleasing so kudos to the packaging designer for such a modern looking product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023
review_content: I am rating this based on the fact that the product is good for organic gardening and the price and amount of usage you will get for the quantity purchased.  I do not know when I will get a chance to use this on an insect problem but will add to this post when I get a chance.  I have to assume it works as described and is truly organic based on the description.You get 2-8 ounce bottles for $27.  One bottle is used against insects, the other for fungi.The insecticide one states it killed bacterial cells and spent fermentation ingredients and can be used on food plants.  It is not a live product and purportedly kills through contact or ingestion of the product.  For foliar pests like caterpillars, mites, aphids and the like, you mix 1 ounce in a gallon of water and spray directly on the foliage.  So you can get a total of 8 gallons to spray on effected plants.  For Turf application, 2.5 ounces will treat 250 square feet; so the 8 ounce bottle with treat 800 square feet.The Fungicide bottle is a broad-spectrum fungicide that can be use for a broad range of foliar diseases, like downy mildew and leaf spot.  Its active ingredient is  a bacillus bacteria and spent fermentation media that is stated to be organic certified and good for organic vegetable gardens.  The application rates are the same as noted for the insecticide so an 8 ounce bottle with give 8 gallons for a foliar spray and will treat 800 square feet of turf.I have an organic vegetable garden and this product if it is effective as described would be useful if needed on my garden.  At $13.50 a bottle this would be fairly expensive particularly if used to treat turf.  For a small vegetable garden that occasionally needs some help to deal with bugs, it may not be that expensive and useful.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2023
review_content: I ordered this product repeatedly- I think it says it all! Satisfied customer!I needed this solution for bugs on my roses. I had these nasty green creatures eating my rose buds and killing all the new growth. This product helps to fight them and make your rose bush bloom again. A couple of very careful diligent treatments took care of the existing problem and after that is just a preventive measure. It did not affect the rose bush leaves in any bad way. I am satisfied with the results and will keep it handy for any unexpected plant guests.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2023
review_content: I have one Monstera recently that was infected by tiny mites that were draining all the colors from my leaves. I used this once a week, alternating between spraying the leaves and watering the soil, and after a month I am confident to say they are gone.Using it is easy: shake the bottle well, then mix according to the instructions and to your bottle size (2 Tablespoons per gallon, or 1 1/2 teaspoons per 32 ounces of water).You have the option to spray leaves or water soil with the solution, or both. Getting rid of pests depends on how severe your issue is. Regular use at controlled intervals will help minimize and potentially get rid of your pests.Plant parents: the price is high but if it helps your plants, then... use it and use it wisely and regularly.I am interested in this new brand and look forward to trying their other products.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2023
review_content: This insect control insecticide and fungicide is organic. The stuff supports plant health, and the listing states it fights fungus, mold, mildew, aphids, spider mites, Japanese beetles, caterpillars, and white flies. I use this product for my outside plants. Several weeks after using this product, I have not seen the best possible results yet. The bougainvillea and gardenia plants still have aphids on them. I am using this product in a spray bottle with a fine mist. The product has smell. After washing my hands, I can still smell the product on them. I think this stuff requires frequent application. Otherwise, this is a good organic product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2023
review_content: My daughter's plants struggle with gnats and tiny little bugs. We chose this to help control them. We really appreciate that it is for organic gardening, both indoor and outdoor. This is a concentrate using 2 tablespoons per gallon of water. Use five tablespoons per gallon for suppression of plant parasitic nematodes. If you know what that means, good on you!The label says for best results use this insecticide if pest species are present but before a populations are causing visible damage.Use only with pressurized handheld sprayers, hose and sprayers, or spray trigger bottles. And do not allow the spray to drift from the application site. There are many more instructions, but these are the basic ones.There are 32 listed insects controlled or suppressed with this insecticide. Some of the ones that interest me are aphids, fruit flies, mites, plant bugs, stink bugs, tent caterpillars, and many more.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023
review_content: The active ingredient is Burkholderia spp. strain A396 which in a 2018 study was found to be effective against aphids and mealybugs.  The concentration is the same as the branded product Venerate¬Æ XC which is usually available only in larger quantities and at a similar price per ounce.  The product description on Amazon also says it controls fungus gnats, but on the actual bottle label, fungus gnats are NOT LISTED!  If they can be controlled at all with this product it would be only by drenching the soil with a higher concentration than the foliar spray, so users (and reviewers) need to be aware that is not the primary usage of this product.  This is most effective on sucking type insects as a foliar spray.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2012
review_content: I used my previous Solo sprayer for hundreds of gallons and 7 years before it malfunctioned.  The sprayer is easy to pump up and the pivoting handle is good for storage.  The pressure gauge is interesting but not much practical value.  Eventually a leak will develop at the hose at the bottom of the sprayer.  This can be resolved by replacing the plastic clamp with a metal hose clamp.  A complete selection of parts, repair diagrams, and repair instructions are available on-line.  There are a number of special parts that can be purchased to improve the sprayer.  A deluxe Solo harness will replace the standard harness which isn't very good for continual use.  A check valve can be installed to prevent dripping between the lever and the nozzle.  A brass or stainless steel or carbon fiber wand can replace the standard plastic one.  A check valve can be fabricated to stop any leakage out the top of the cap.  If the sprayer came with all these features I would give it five stars but it would then not have a competitive price.  For most users it is fine as it is.  All a professional needs to make it acceptable is the deluxe harness.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2010
review_content: The Solo 425 Deluxe is a great performing sprayer.  Glad I got the deluxe model as it has a pressure gauge, a brass nozzle, and padded shoulder straps.  I use it for herbicides and it reaches far enough to spray blackberries with enough volume that I otherwise could not reach with my old small hand-pump sprayer.  The hand pump works really well and is easy to operate without taking the backback off.  Obviously it is heavy when filled to capacity, so I only put 2 gallons in which lasts a long time.  Finally, the Solo is easy to clean.  Great tool!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2020
review_content: Just received the Solo 425 piston backpack sprayer yesterday and assembled this morning. This would have been my 3rd Solo backpack sprayer. Really liked Solo sprayers because they are made in USA. After I assembled sprayer I decided to fill with water instead of herbicide to be on the safe side. I'm glad I did! This tank leaked like a sieve. If I had herbicide in tank  my lower back and legs would have been drenched. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2013
review_content: I had a Northern Tools rechargeable sprayer that couldn't handle Roundup because it was too caustic.  I replaced it with this 'manual' Solo sprayer and it works great.  The ergonomics are great and the pump handle, which is adjustable, can be put in a convenient location.  I like the adjustable spray nozzle and also the fact that the maximum pump pressure can be changed on the unit I bought.  I also confirmed it will handle Roundup, although I can't imagine why anyone would sell a sprayer that doesn't since it's so popular.  Very good design at a good price.Now that I've had this for over a year, let me add these comments.  I spray diluted Roundup 1-2 times per month and the sprayer started leaking down my back and legs after just over a year (warranty had just expired).  However, I contacted Solo and they sent me a rebuild kit for them.  Kudos for doing this.  However, it's now a few months later and it's leaking again.  Upon taking it apart, I've realized there is a seal that is poorly designed and will, in all probability, continue to fail.  I will notify them of this, but will look for another manufacturer of a similar backpack type sprayer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2013
review_content: I purchased several of these backpack sprayers. They were to replace my shindaiwa sprayers sp300 3-gallon, sp415 4-gallon & sp518 5 gallon sprayers. Newer versions of shindaiwa sprayers do have different numbering.  I do believe the solo sprayer fit better on your back as they are concaved for your back. The gauge is helpful if your into pressure & droplet size depending on your tip size. I felt like the straps were cheap & the strap connector to the bottom of the frame are plastic. I am use to metal clips. As I am 6 foot tall the hose length is not long enough. Windy days I try to keep the spraying tip closer to the ground the prevent wind drift. At my height & the length of the hose I need to bend over so the tip is only a few inches from the ground. NOT so good for my back. this model has a 4 foot hose as I am use to a 5 foot hose. If your a few inches shorter most likely not a problem. Over all for myself I will be going back to shindaiwa or even a better product. Please keep in mind as I run a small/medium size landscaping Co. We service about 95-105 customers, average size property 3/4 acre, 4 time annually. If you are looking to purchase this product for personal use or you have a few customers this sprayer will be fine for you for years to come.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
review_content: Been using this for 3 years and has saved my Crape Myrtles.  If you Crepe Myrtles are turning black and have little white dots on them that turn red when you squish them, then this product works wonders.  Black will not go away for a year or two until the tree sheds its outer layer, but the little white insects are killed fairly quickly that cause the issue.  I now use it as a preventative each spring on my Crepe Myrtles right when they are starting to push leaves.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2020
review_content: The ash tree in my front yard has been infested with aphids the past couple years and it was time to take action. The little beasties don't kill the tree but I was getting tired of the ugly aphid clusters and being "misted" while walking or mowing beneath them. I read a lot of reviews of different treatments and this one seemed very promising.  After a bit of research I decided to take a 2-step approach of using this product and also spraying the leaves with a water-and-dish-soap mix.Earlier this spring the tree already had leaf damage and aphid clusters.  Within a week of using this product I could already see improvements.  Six weeks after the treatment the improvement is amazing.  There's no sign of aphids, the tree's leaves are dark and shiny, and there's even new growth.The product instructions are clear, and it's easy to use.  Basically you calculate the number of ounces to mix with water (based on the tree trunk size) and pour the mix around the base of the tree.  The jug is also packaged well, as it comes sealed in a bag within the box so you don't have to worry about leaks.  It's a good value, too, since I'll get a couple more seasons of treatment out of it.10/10 would buy again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2023
review_content: Sprayed trees

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2023
review_content: I buy this every spring to treat my ash trees against the emerald ash borer. It is effective and is a cheap alternative to commercial treatment. I have been using it for 5 years without continued damage from the borer larva. It works.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2023
review_content: Had a tree in back of me infested with bag worms. It was a new unsold house. The contractor wasn‚Äôt going to fix it so I got a gallon and used the whole gallon on tge clump of 6 trunks. Application is 3/4 oz per inch of trunk diameter.  It worked! New leaves are coming out where it had been eaten completely up. It was a horrible infestation. I purchased another gallon to treat my new evergreens.  Saved them! Even the grasshoppers are dying that munch on them. I‚Äôll be looking to buy more next spring!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2023
review_content: I used this product to treat a large centerpiece ash tree in my front yard.  It was easy to use while following the directions, and the price is fair.  I will update this review if anything changes, but so far my big ash is showing no signs of EAB infestation, while there are many dead and dying ash trees in my neighborhood due to EAB.  I used this product in conjunction with a drill-in trunk capsule product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2023
review_content: Does a great job for white flies on confederate rose and poinsettias. Lost plants before I started using this product. Lasts a long time between applications

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2022
review_content: EAB was just starting to hit my area noticeably when I started using this product. I applied it as directed 2 years in a row on my 4 trees.  Trees were fully leaved when I started. Each year there are more dead branches and less leaves, enough so that I think 2 out of 4 trees may be dead next year.  I can't say the product didn't work, as all of my neighbors ashes are completely dead this year and mine still show signs of life.  I think that if you area is getting hit hard, you might want to consider using extra or this plus an additional product. I might try a second application this year in an attempt to save my large ash trees. After buying many jugs of this stuff, I am starting to weigh the cost of this product vs just having the trees taken down. I also have doubts about knowingly dumping volumes of insecticides into the ground...Truly a shame to watch this massive tress die slowly. Good luck in your battles against the green bug.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2023
review_content: Last summer, from mid July through Fall, we couldn‚Äôt use our yard because it was a sticky mess covered in mold, wasps and ants, all from these darn pests. This summer, it‚Äôs now July 24 and I don‚Äôt see anything but dead nymphs. I am hopeful we have reclaimed our yard for our beneficial use again.I used this to treat a giant wall full of Boston Ivy, 5 Ailanthus trees (Tree of Heaven, aka Spotted Lantern Flies‚Äô favorite food!) and a giant Paulownia tree (Empress tree). I applied exactly per the instructions on June 6th. It‚Äôs now July 24th and I have hundreds of dead SLF‚Äôs all over the yard here in Brooklyn, NY. I can see hundreds but I am sure there are many more. The dead ones are late stage nymphs and don‚Äôt have wings yet so I‚Äôm hopeful that means I also won‚Äôt have 10 million eggs to hunt over the winter. This past winter I found and destroyed probably over 150 egg clusters and then caught likely over 1,000 nymphs on sticky tape in April and May but I‚Äôm wondering if any of that was necessary given how effective this pesticide has turned out to be.With that said, I‚Äôd love to apply less of this so I‚Äôll have to see next year if I can scale back the dose and have it still be as effective. I‚Äôm worried about unintentional harm to birds and other beneficial insects so ideally I can cut the dose.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2023
review_content: We live in Queens, NY, and spotted lantern flies have become a real problem here. They began decimating an ornamental pussy willow on our deck, but the Compare-N-Save Systemic Tree and Shrub Insect Drench was a game changer.After one application, SLFs stopped swarming, and those that did munch on the plant were found dying or dead on the ground nearby.We were lucky that our shrub was in its own planter and not something that bees are drawn to. I would not recommend using Compare-N-Save Systemic Tree and Shrub Insect Drench where it's likely to impact bee colonies, and by all means be sure it's safe for other neighboring plants in the soil.But if SPLs are a problem, I can recommend this. We have plenty leftover, too, so I plan to give our plant another treatment come next spring.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2023
review_content: I used this product over the summer, for the price, my guess is it is as effective or more so than things i have used over the past few years.  There is no magical solution to end all pest.  However, this has been a product that has produced the most bang for the buck for me.  I will purchase again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2023
review_content: Aphids and white flies are dropping dead on the deck of my areogarden as though God himself struck them.I previously used insecticidal soaps that claimed to be hydroponic friendly but any soap is going to bubble when the water is agitated. And bubbles trap air and kill everything. This does not bubble. I was expecting a slow build up but half the bugs are already dead, I‚Äôm ecstatic to finally have a solution. My plants, Tradescantia (also known as wandering dude, inch plant and spiderwort) have an aversion to water on their leaves and so the bugs have to be handled systematically. Can‚Äôt wait to watch the other buggers die.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2023
review_content: Used as directed, tree health improvement was recognizable.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2021
review_content: HELPFUL INFO: I found the product info to be insufficient in the listing, as I had no direction on how much product I would need. The water:product ratio is simple, and could easily be in the listing, to help customers with an estimate of gallons needed! I highly recommend pre-measuring the tree trunk(s) to be treated, especially if you have several, and noting them in a similar fashion as I've pictured. Then do the math!The breakdown is easy:  1 ounce of product per 1 inch of the diameter of the tree trunk (at chest height). Or, 3 ounces per foot of shrub height. These amounts are added to 1 gallon (or 2) of water, and simply poured right around the base of the trunk.Needless to say, I'll need far more than 128 ounces (1 gallon) to treat the multiple trees in our yard.** I'll update my review in a couple months, allowing enough time for aphid elimination, based on the absence of honeydew all over our deck and outdoor furniture.UPDATE: It's obviously been more than a couple months. The product does work. But I also learned that application is necessary in the early spring (April) so that the tree has sufficient time to take-in the product prior to the start of aphid activity. Otherwise the aphids get a head start, damage begins, and you're playing catch-up the rest of the season. Today is April 2nd, and I'll be retreating no later than the middle of the month.üëçüèª

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2020
review_content: The tree on the left side was treated. They migrated to the untreated tree on the right. Dramatic and impressive!woolly aphids "honeydew" rained from the trees. That's got to be the most polite word I've ever heard to refer to crap. Due to indirect sunlight, I saw it pouring out of the trees from a gazillion aphids and from that point, I wore a hat. It covered *everything* black - my garden ornaments and flowers, truck, car, lawn. I had to park my vehicles in another part of the driveway out from under the trees. Because I'm not fond of scrubbing insect poop, each year I waited for spring rains to clean my lawn ornaments.I researched products and decided on this insect drench that I bought December of 2019. I also read reviews and decided to use the 10 oz. per tree. Not exactly the amount as recommended by others but I was not going to measure out 9.anything. Some of the trees are old with a circular span of 60+". I used 10 oz per tree no matter its size.What is the point of writing a review right after buying this just to say I'll be back in a few months with the result? So the results are in: Amazing. Awesome. Any superlative I can think of, insert here.I treated in January and June and for the first time in five years, I will see my tree leaves turn color with the fall instead of blackened and mowing them all over the yard in August. I haven't had to scrub "honeydew" off my truck so I can see out the windshield and my car is still white. I'll treat one more time in January just to show the little buggers I mean business if any new ones move in.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2022
review_content: The past two years I fought lily leaf beetles, very nasty bugs that nearly destroyed my prized fragrant oriental lilies. I first took the organic approach with the recommended Neem oil which might work if one sprayed every other day. Last fall I put in 37 new lily bulbs along with the 30 or so that were still left  determined to defeat the bugs. One soil drench application in late April early May as the stalks poked out of the ground did the trick. Mid June and haven't seen another bug. Researching this product shows it can be used on certain vegetable crops like eggplant and the curcubits. I'll use a much weaker solution on them being mindfull of the bees.Edit: There is a lot of hysteria in the questions about killing bees. Follow the directions and use on listed crops. I personally wouldn't use it on any tree that flowers early in the season.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2023
review_content: I have a crepe myrtle that I started from a cutting.  It was doing well up until last year.  It had a very bad aphid infestation and nothing worked.  The infestation started up again this year and despite extreme measures it would not subside.  Then I tried this systemic approach and the tree is bountiful again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2022
review_content: This value-priced alternative to the other brands of imidacloprid root drenches was a great find and a great buy. I live in a region of the country where hemlocks are being wiped out by these invasive adelgids and imidacloprid root drenches are the only thing that can save these trees. I've kept the adelgids under control for years with more expensive products and when I saw them on the hemlocks again a few weeks ago I knew it was time to re-treat. Within a week of applying the pesticide according to the instructions the adelgids were gone and my hemlocks will keep lining my driveway for another year. So many of the hemlocks in my neighborhood are gone because of this tiny insect it's heartbreaking. If you live in the adelgid zone buy this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2023
review_content: Works well for treati g trees and shrubs

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2018
review_content: I used this on 4 Ficus trees with large 18" diameter trunks.  An outside company had trimmed the trees back considerably and apparently infected them in the process.  All of the considerable new shoots were 100% infected, threatening to kill the trees.  I noticed immediate results but it didn't kill all the thrips and I needed two repeat applications before most of the thrips were gone.  Yes, it didn't kill them all, but enough for the trees to rebound, sending out healthy new shoots.  I suspect that on really big trees like these, the roots go very deep and the first couple of applications don't soak that deep and reach all the roots.  It would take time for the insecticide to get down to the bottom and outlying roots.  Trees don't mix all the water they absorb from all the roots into one reservoir to feed the branches.  Roots on the right side generally feed the branches on the right side.Emboldened, I tried a small diluted amount of it on a sapote fruit tree that had another more serious type of thrip infestation for 25 years.  Nothing else I tried ever did any good.  So far, the new leaves are completely free of infection, but time will tell if they will eventually become infected as the thrip life cycle progresses into the spring.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: Extremely pleased with the efficacy of this product! I live in a rental & the tree in the backyard was always dropping TONS of leaves & constant sticky mess (which I thought was sap....) It took me about a year of constant (pretty much daily) cleaning & maintenance of the patio & lawn to figure out that it was actually an aphid infestation in the 70 year old tree. Did research & took care of the problem myself---not only is the mess completely gone, but it took care of the ants & the wasps we were seeing a lot of, as they came around due to the "honeydew" that the aphids produced. Will buy again & reapply when the time comes. Cannot recommend this product enough! For reference, I live in a generally mild climate (Southern California) so the problem was year round here. We are now able to enjoy the yard & the outdoor space is no longer stressful.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
review_content: My 60 year old Austrian Pine was dying along with many others in my neighborhood due to a black pine scale infestation (caused by tiny beetles which attach to the needle and suck the sap). In 2018 I began applying this product each year in the spring. Application is easy and only required once per year. It is now 2022 and my tree is recovering nicely. Nearly all others in the area have since died and been cut down, or are nearly dead and will be cut down soon. I made an effort to take a similar photo near the same day+time in June each year to display the progress, but I skipped 2019. I highly recommend this product for pines!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2023
review_content: One treatment for wooly adelgid on a large Canadian hemlock, bugs gone.  Also treated a Star Magnolia for oyster scale (millions), bugs dead.  Tried everything on the scale bugs but they have an impenetrable shell.  So they just kept sucking in the product and died.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2023
review_content: I have used it on pines, live oaks and ornamental grass . Works great. Trees are thriving and ornamental grasses are free or mealybugs

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2017
review_content: Had a big problem with leaf curling and yellowing plumeria leaves for years. Tried organic with neem oil which temporarily controlled the problem on my large plumeria tree, but required very frequent and expensive treatment almost every week or two. Researched options and found this chemical, and like others found this brand to be far less expensive for the same 1.47%! Well I gotta say, it takes time (took maybe 2 months) since it has to integrate into new leaves for the most part. But worked like a charm! Had beautiful green leaves most of the season for the first time ever and they stayed on the tree longer, making for a fuller lush appearance.TIP: the product says lasts 9-12 months, some years like this one I let it go too far past the 9 month mark and the protection wore off returning the problem. I recommend sticking with no more than 9 months between treatments to keep protection consistent...if you do that I think you‚Äôll be happy with this product!Only con: not remotely organic. So I use this on my plumeria and jasmine vines that are pretty far away from the vegetable garden. You might want to keep this to ornamental areas only if concerned about ingesting, even though the label is somewhat liberal with indications :)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2023
review_content: A systemic drench. Pour around th3 tree or shrub. It is absorbed systemically and kills pests feasting on trees and shrubs.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2022
review_content: I used this in 2020 (as a drench) as all my blue spruce trees were suffering from the effects of Spruce Gall Adelgids.  I also used it on the douglas firs on my property, as even though they area not affected, they play a role with the infection as well.  It worked SO WELL I am amazed.  No new galls on any of my trees in 2021 as well as this year (2022) even though I only applied it in 2020.  (Obviously, it has no effect on existing old galls).  I will not hesitate to use it again if I start seeing any signs of them coming back.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2021
review_content: About 20 years ago I planted three weeping birches on my property. I wish I would‚Äôve found this stuff in time to save the first two trees. It would probably be easier to just take this last birch out and go with a more insect resistant tree but I‚Äôm not prepared to do that at this time so for me this is a five star product!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2022

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2017
review_content: I found this product to exceed my expectations. It arrived double packaged with easy instructions located under the rear label. It has a pleasant odor and mixed well with water and I wore gloves for my protection. I purchased this for wooly adelgid infestation on my hemlock trees. The instructions were simple to follow and the price of the product was very reasonable compared to the major brands. I did research before I made my purchase and found that the granular type of a major brand was not a good deal at all (10 pounds would only treat two trees) and cost $50.00. I chose the Compare N Save because this was the best value and safest to use of all other products. I was able to treat four trees with left over material in the gallon container when I finished. I also was able to treat my currant bushes which in years past have been attacked by a small moth which lays its eggs and the hatchlings devour the Bush. This year I had currant pie. My currants are happy. Next year I will be treating my blackberries because they get Aphid leaf curl which stunts growth and lessens fruit production. I just wish this product came in a five gallon bucket.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2023
review_content: I use this every year to kill the Aphids on my Green Mountain Ash.I start seeing dead Aphids on the patio by day ‚Äú2‚Äô‚ÄºÔ∏è

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2017
review_content: Our entire street is lined by some type of tree that aphids apparently love, and every summer they have a feast and leave their...lets just say 'leftovers'...on the leaves.  The sticky sappy mess gets everywhere - cars parked underneath, shoes, and gets so embedded in our dog's fur that it's virtually impossible to wash out.ANYWHO, I purchased this last summer in an attempt to combat said stickiness.  I gave it a good dose based on the labels recommendation late last fall, and another this spring after the trees began coming back to life (Not sure if both were needed, but why not...)  Last week we were walking our dogs, and noticed that the entire street is still lined with sticky gooey trees / leaves EXCEPT for the two in front of our house.  IT WORKS!  I've already touted the stuff to many of our neighbors, (selfishly) hoping they'll invest too.The price for the gallon seems a bit steep at first glance, so a bit of context - we've got two 'suburban street' size trees with the aphid poop issue, and after two doses on each tree I feel like I've got enough left for at least one more year.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2023
review_content: I had an Elm Tree infested with Elm Beatles.  It took two treatments but did kill all the bugs.  Just had to be patient.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2021
review_content: Since I have had great luck with this companies products, and I needed a root insect drench treatment, well thought give it a chance. stuff is really thick and milky in color, smell not bad. Mixed the amount it said to for my size of tree and  dumped the mix at around or before the dip tree line, so far so good. I do like that it's a once a year treatment. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2019
review_content: I had a severe infestation of soft scale (Coccidae) and resulting sooty mold on several of my rare palms, many of which are quite large and tall. Using horticultural oil would have probably worked but given the size of many of the palms and the difficulty in coating all leaf surfaces, both top and undersides, this would have been impractical. I had access to commercial "industrial strength" spray insecticide, but I hate using this type of stuff for obvious reasons. I decided to try this systemic and it worked like a charm. Within a week, almost all the scale had turned into dead white powdery masses that easily washed off with a water blast from the garden hose. The company says this treatment will last up to a year, so I will monitor the palms in a few months and reapply if necessary. It's convenient and easy to use and great value for the money. I'm not sure how it will work on hard scale and other pests but I assume it will do what it claims and if you have a soft scale problem I highly recommend it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review_content: One of my fir trees was badly infested with bag worms.  I was sure it would die.  About 1/3 of the limbs were already needless.  I took a chance on this product and a miracle happened.  Easy to apply using a regular drill.  Applied it one day and the next day the grass around the tree was moving like it was alive.  It was....with bag worms in their nests.  We pulled some off, but most of them just fell to the ground.  We burned those that fell off.  That tree today, 2 years later, is one of the fullest in my yard.  I very highly recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2022
review_content: For several years now, we have successfully protected a beautiful ash tree that is near our elevated deck by using this product via an annual trench drench to stave off a dreaded Emerald Ash Borer infestation.  I use a trowel and a hoe to excavate the perimeter so that the trench depth is uniformly level, then fill it with a 1:3 dilution of the 1.47-percent Imidacloprid (mixed in a 5 gallon bucket).  Be sure to use eye protection, long pants and sleeves, and rubber gloves when handling this, or any, liquid insecticide!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2023
review_content: Helped save multiple trees from borers. Pine tree, evergreen and now using on my fruitless mulberry.  Hope it saves it too!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2022
review_content: I have a large amount of huge tropical plants. At some point I got a palm that had scale on it. It spread to my other plants. It was super easy to use I just mixed it in water and watered my plants as usual.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2016
review_content: Emerald Ash Borer became a huge problem in our area of the Midwest several years ago accompanied by a constant warning that the problem was not treatable and that the only solution was to cut down the trees in an area that had an infestation.  Since  most of our shade trees which we had nurtured for years were Ash, we decided to search for a better option, which we found.  However, the solution to the problem was a product which contained the insecticide imidacloprid at 1.47% but it was getting prohibitively more expensive by the year.  Needing four gallons at a time because of the diameter of our trees and at a cost of several hundred dollars, that product became beyond our reach.  We searched again and found Compare-N-Save Systemic Tree and Shrub Insect Drench with the same 1.47% imidacloprid, and for the past three years have used it on our Ash trees as well as on a Maple that was suffering from die-out at the top of the trees from another insect.  Our trees are all doing beautifully, including the Maple.  We've recommended this to others in our neighborhood, and so far, so good!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2022
review_content: I have utilized this at the base of a 50 foot corkscrew willow that looks exactly like Asia‚Äôs Tree of Heaven which I understand is their favorite tree to attack. They don‚Äôt like and won‚Äôt even land on the tree to lay their eggs!! Hallelujah

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2014
review_content: Updated 5/18/2015.  Excellent product, appears to work identically to brand name product, easy to use, very effective. Finding something with the same ingredients only MUCH cheaper (this Compar-N-Save) is a wonderful thing! review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2015
review_content: My Eggplant plants became infested and almost destroyed with Colorado Potato Beetles this year. My experience with fighting them was as follows:1) Seven. The beetles laughed at this product.2) Neem oil. The beetles seemed to say "ouch", then went on with leaf munching.3) Thuricide. Seemed to have some effect, but not much. Everything I read indicated that this product will kill young larvae but not effect older beetles, but i found plenty of young remaining after each treatment.I tried all these products every couple of days which i hated subjecting my garden to, but it was obvious I would lose my prized eggplants otherwise, and I feared they would move on to my pepper and tomato plants next (which to date they have not moved onto).I think the biggest successes i experienced to that point was with controlling these guys with finger picking daily, but it was a losing battle.Finally the Bonide Colorado Beetle Beater arrived from Amazon (could not find this product locally). After ONE TREATMENT the beetles were whipped seemingly off the planet (or at the very least my garden)! Bravo, Bravo, BRAVO!Of note, this product does not seem to have effect on Japanese beetles. They have moved in after the Colorado beetles vacated. Seven works with the Japs, though not as well as in prior years...

I noted after spraying the larva had stopped feeding, some curled up. A day and a half later 99% of the beetles and larva lay dead on the ground. I couldn't ask for more than that.....GREAT STUFF!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2019
review_content: I used this product to control and get rid of Colorado potato beetles this gardening season. It took two "sprayings" a few days apart, but it truly worked....first to get rid of the adults and the second spraying a few days later to destroy the new hatchlings from the eggs laid by the adults. Found it helpful to go through the potato patch and hand-pick the adults as best I could and drop them into foamy, soapy dish-washing detergent added to water, in any recyclable plastic container.  Then spray this mixed chemical (just as the directions say to mix it) onto the plants. Always works for my garden. Keep checking your plants for beetles every few days and re-treat with hand-picking bugs and a dose of this Colorado Beetle Beater.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2022
review_content: I'm an organic gardener who has relinquished many a squash plant to the onslaught of squash bugs and powdery mildew. This year I vowed to do battle! This product works extremely well on squash bugs (i.e., it kills them within seconds, especially the newly-hatched ones. The more mature ones seems to take longer to die, probably because their bodies are harder. I hate killing things, even marauding insects, but at least this works fast so they hopefully don't suffer too much. Be careful not to hit any of your pollinators with the spray, because it will kill them too. Knock on wood, so far I am winning the battle. As far as powdery mildew goes, this product seems less effective than billed. I've had to remove many affected leaves and burn them. I wouldn't count on it for that use. But for squash bugs - yes! That said, you need to inspect and spray every day any squash bugs that you see. You're bound to overlook some and they hatch out like crazy.

Now all the leaves are dead and has brown/black leaves like my bitter melon. I should have take the picture so you can all see what it looks like. My other moringa that stays indoor leaves are still attached but it does not look healthy. The only plants that didn‚Äôt react to the product is my lemon. I really hope that it won‚Äôt react negatively to this product and hope that my moringa will cone back healthy again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2023
review_content: I used to kill fungus gnats in my houseplants. (Actually it worked to prevent these weird ants at my new apartment from getting into plants too, idk what kind of ants they are, but not sugar ants) Ive tried lots of products to get rid of the fungus gnats- hydrogen peroxide, cinnamon, rocks and sand on top of soil, neem oil, other chemicals but those didn‚Äôt work at all and were such a hassle that I absolutely recommend this stuff. I don‚Äôt spray it o , I just dump it on my plants thoroughly (til it runs out the bottom) with this stuff a couple of times- in place of my regular watering in order to kill the baby flies and larvae. EWW. Also I used this preventatively on other plants too because I couldn‚Äôt isolate the main one easily and you don‚Äôt know what has already spread to the soil of the other nearby plants. For any flying around: the Katchy (or whatever brand you find) UV light plug-in trap thing at night and the annoying yellow sticky traps scattered around making my place look real tacky. This product and how I used didn‚Äôt cause any damage to my houseplants. I didn‚Äôt try to avoid leaves either but a few plants have leaves I avoid getting wet so I put this stuff in a bottle with a pointy nozzle to be more precise and miss the leaves and not waste it. Best to bottom water in the future as much as possible to prevent this issue entirely. This only has happened to me in pots that don‚Äôt have a drainage hole meaning I have to water from the top like a normal person.Idk where the fungus gnats come from. They are just around I guess. Probably happened when I got a plant that unnoticeable had a few in the soil even though I do check new plants for pests but it just be like that sometimes when you buy as many plants as I do.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2022
review_content: I was using neem oil and not having any luck getting rid of all the little Natty bugs. This stuff works the first time you use it. The plants don't even notice that you've used it. I am very picky about my plants most of them I grow indoors, with neem oil I was vacuuming up these little Natty bugs constantly it was horrible. One use of this product and the bugs were gone. I do believe there were eggs or something in the soil because a few did come back but it took a while. But one more use of this product and those bugs are now gone. It's been a lifesaver. I will also use it outside in my garden now that I know how well it works. I lost a lot of plans last year to squash bugs and other little bugs. All because neem oil was not working. This stuff does what it says and it is so much cheaper than the alternative very very affordable for what it does. I will definitely be a lifetime user

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2023
review_content: I lightly sprayed this on my thriving basil and broccoli, as a preventive measure because I had an issue with "leaf miners" last year, and in less than 48 hours this pest control spray absolutely decimated everything it came into contact with. Up until the day I started using this product, my broccoli and basil were absolutely thriving. I used the basil in multiple pizzas this summer, and the broccoli was a favorite side during BBQs. Luckily, I didn't spray my entire garden with the stuff because it would've wiped every last plant out. And before you think it, I followed the directions completely and applied the product EXACTLY as instructed. I live in New England and I count down the days before I can begin my garden again, so I don't take any shortcuts whatsoever and I make sure I read and follow directions perfectly because the last think I want is to wait all year to start my garden, just to ruined it because I cut corners of didn't follow directions exactly. So, if you value the time and effort you put into growing your garden, don't let me become all for naught by using this poison. Stay as far away from this product as possible. You've been warned.

review_content: I love this spray I works great for my indoor plants and I‚Äôm sure it would work just the same for outdoor plants as well. I‚Äôve never had any problems with it killing plants or flowers like others have although the packaging has changed since my last purchase. Before with the pure white bottle I had no issue with leakage or loss of product, but with this alteration I have gotten *soaked* with problems. Ha! But truly the new product packaging comes in a bag, which held in leakage, but not completely as there are circle cut holes in the bag. The new handle fits your palm weirdly as its circular and not flat rectangular. And the new locking mechanism I can see it being needed for families with young children but I can‚Äôt see how a child couldn‚Äôt figure out how to turn it. As I accidentally did before I knew it was a lock, I looked down the nossel moving it and sprayed it in my face. Luckily I had glasses on but if my own stupidity can help another families trip to poison control I‚Äôd best share it. Other than the new packaging problems I love this product, can‚Äôt get a better price! But just be careful with it, better not eye down the barrel!

I had an incident where the wind blew my way when I sprayed this on my plant, I got some of the chemicals on my face and inhaled some. Not a fun experience.Price: It came with 2 bottles, one was broken, so I had to pour it on a different spray bottle to use. With the price paid, it was ok - I didn't really expect much and it does kill smaller bugs. But if you have snails or bigger insects, I would recommend find something stronger for your garden.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2019
review_content: I'm using this for spider mites on succulents. There aren't many, no webs, but I can see them using a microscope. This does work better than alcohol. Know that if you're using this on succulents, some may handle it well and others may not survive the treatment because they are so sensitive to moisture, even if it's only on the leaves - particularly varieties of echeveria and other high light succs that rely on a heavy coating of farina (jades, for instance, don't have this problem). The oil in this also may leave a shiny layer which helps kill mites but may also inhibit the farina (waxy coating) from properly restoring itself. Because the farina builds up slowly and protects the leaves from bright light, it's important to slowly introduce them to the sun and best not to give them full afternoon sun/lighting until the shiny neem oil coating is gone and the powdery farina is able to build back up, otherwise you will likely get burns on the leaves and get some die back. No product is perfect but this is some pretty good stuff! I feel much better using this than some kind of systemic, I only smell it right after I spray and it dissipates quickly. Highly recc'd!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
review_content: We had a terrible gnat problem in our house for the last two months. They were driving me insane. Living in the plants, drains, and god knows where else. We have a super clean house so this was insanity. They flew in my face constantly and I went to freaking war on these suckers. First, I repotted my plants. No brown uncoated clay pots. In each plant I got rid of as much old dirt as I could and then topped them with an inch of sand. Then, I sprayed this stuff around the vents, the toilets, into the drains then closed them to starve off eggs and hatchings of gnats. It worked amazingly. This stuff did actually kill them on spray contact and kept them away too. So far no adverse effects on the plants but I also avoided spraying the leaves and plants themselves. I spritzed the sand and the areas I saw them most. I have finally had three days of peace and am super grateful. For me, this stuff worked awesome but I only needed it for fruit flies/gnats. We‚Äôll see long term but I think I got the suckers once and for all.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2015
review_content: This stuff worked on scale!  I had scale on my indoor lemon tree.  I tried insecticidal soap first because I am trying to be as organic as possible, but it did nothing to those nasty little scale bugs.  So I got this as it is a light thin horticultural oil.  It took two sprayings - I took the tree outside, sprayed it, let it dry, brought it back in, waited a week and a half and repeated the process.  The first spraying killed most of the scale, but some survived; they really need to be hit with the oil, and the little buggers hide.  So then I did it again and got the newly hatched and the survivors.  I am checking to see if I get more, but the oil did a good job.  Just scrape off the dead scales with your fingernails; they don't fall off or disappear, then check the tree later and you can tell if you need to do it again.  Scale is difficult to kill so I am glad this works so well.

review_content: Saved me a ton of money on a tree service that was coming to spray the tree with horticultural oil,  so I figured I'd do it myself and my results were alot better than the expensive tree service! It's basically oil that prevents the mites from being able to breath,  so you're just killing them by making it impossible for them to breath! Trust me,  mites on your trees are a real nuisance. Good old watering of the underside of the leaves also helps because water makes it harder for them to hold on and with all the rain this past summer that helped as well,  but my tree is back to its healthy self now! This product can be used as a maintenance product to keep those pests to a minimum.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2023
Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2018
review_content: My baby apple tree (grown indoors from seed) was infested for almost two years by two-spot spider mites (which I identified by magnifying glass and found they are a common scourge among apple trees.) I tried hand washing each leaf.I tried fumigation the whole thing with sage smoke. I tried the Three-Ways Organic pesticide. I had gotten so obsessed I was scanning leaves with the magnifying glass DAILY and almost always could find a couple, or the eggs, and I was spraying twice a week.A garden pest site said the best approach is 1% horticultural oil spray, and I bought this one. Sprayed it heavily, just ONCE about 5 weeks ago. Not a single bug since. Not one.  A few leaves (which I had left dripping with spray) did go brown on the edges. But the tree shot up at least 6 inches since I sprayed it. I still check a leaf or two once or twice a week. But clearly this spray kills the spider mites AND THEIR EGGS.  So grateful ; ).

review_content: I first bought this horticultural oil after I lost some english ivy to a horrible spider mite infestation. I have been able to kill them all off in one to two treatments with this stuff by taking the plant outside, spraying aggressively, letting it sit for 24 hours, then wiping the leaves down. Forget about neem oil, rubbing alcohol, qtips, or dish soap. I swear by this stuff!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2021
review_content: I had a massive infestation of aphids and aphid-harvesting ants that invaded my Fukien Tea Bonsai. I tried several approaches including neem oil, various concatenations of useless essential oils, soap, etc, and all were futile at defeating my foes. In fact, many of these chemicals, including neem oil, can have devastating collateral effects on many plants, weakening their defenses, making them more vulnerable to future insect attacks once populations recover from the slight setback.That's where this product comes in. I mixed it at a concentration of 8 mL/L, and watered my plant with a watering pot, including all the foliage, the trunk/stems, and all over the substrate/soil to the point where the milky product was seeping out of the pot holes.Suffice to say, next day there were no more ants, no more aphids. Also, there was no appreciable damage to the plant, and after a few days, I fed the plant as usual, and already began noticing new sprouts of growth.Therefore, I have to say that I recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2022
review_content: I have struggled with a severe aphid infestation in my new greenhouse since May of this year. I refuse to use chemicals so I have tried predatory insects, Castile soap mixed with alcohol and h2o2, but nothing compares to this product. The Castile soap mixture kills well too, but I always find a leaf covered in live aphids the next morning. I have thousands of these demons destroying my veggies and my nerves. Upon the first application, I found only 3 live aphids the next morning. I realize more will hatch, so will do this every 3 days for a week or two just to be sure. Kills them dead so the only harm these parasites can do now is vote democrat from the grave. Cant have it all I guess.

review_content: I'm always reluctant to give a bad review so I give Pyganic 5 stars for all the great reviews on here for critters it works on. In the case of my tomatoes...it has been a dud. Just a dud. This note is strictly for tomato hornworms...nothing else. As such not a general fuss on the product which works well for some.But for tomato hornworms...I'd use a certain other powder substance (which nukes tomato worms) and if you're a long time gardener you know which one I'm talking about.I had used the other substance to great effect...but when the rain washed it off and the tomatoes coming in heavy I chose Pyganic because it is so much less potentially toxic. The other stuff...you have to wait days before picking.Anyway I have 32 plants in two rows. I went to the garden about 10PM the other evening, mosquito face net and all. I poured two gallons through my sprayer dousing the plants and the wheat straw beneath. Wet 'em good!At this writing it's about a week later and there are many new chomped tomatoes. I don't believe it did squat to the vicious caterpillars. Anecdotal chomp evidence admitted. That's my ruling.

review_content: I used this product to kill the three life cycles of clothes moths: adult, larvae (cocooned and active), and eggs. I followed label instructions to the letter, wore PPE (nitrile gloves, splash safety glasses, an N-100 respirator) and sprayed the rugs with a Ryobi battery powered garden sprayer using a non-atomizing spray pattern, applied to both the front and back sides of the carpets, fairly heavy (approximately 16 fluid ounces of diluted product to treat both sides of a (9‚Äôx 12‚Äô) carpet). review_content: Got our share of the Japanese Beetles suddenly on our apple trees and thought we lose all the fruit and leaves of trees by the time product arrived a week later. Next day after spraying, beetles virtually all gone and haven't come back. Very pleased with results while helping save expensive replacement costs of mature fruit and berry trees/bushes from the beetles. We love using as much natural products as possible on our property due to pets and surrounding wildlife which come from timbered areas that cross through. Each year we also give away fruits to our family members and finding a product that's safe enough to use right up to the day of harvest was a no-brainer for us.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2015
review_content: This product is about the only thing that will deal with Chili Thrips on roses effectively with only one or two treatments. 1 tsp. per gallon.  It goes a long way but for certain pests this is the only thing that works.  Got the name of it from professional rose growers.  Don't be fooled by similar versions with Spinosad in it.  This has 11%, the others have .05 %, less than 5% of the active ingredient. It is very expensive, but if you grow roses in the southeastern US you probably will need it eventually. These pests came in on a hurricane years ago.  Chili Thrips start out on the new growth turning it brown and shriveled. Eventually they will kill the bush.  This is a biological pesticide so it is fairly safe.Only use if indicated, not as a preventative.  In the pictures you can see a bush that looks like it might die from the infestation. It was a delicate white first year rose "Pope John Paul".  It has been treated twice but got hit so bad by Chili thrips that it may yet die.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2022
review_content: Works very well!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
review_content: Expensive stuff but so far it seems to be working great! -1 star for the price of Spinosad... seeing how Dow Agro is the only company contracted to make this stuff so they basically get to control the prices we pay for the stuff...Reading through the instructions booklet I found out I will need to mix about 2.4ml of Conserve per gallon of water (0.6ml per quart) to help get rid of the pests we have... for some reason this year our outdoor fruit and vegetable garden had a lot more nasty bugs compared to previous years, when the weather got colder all those bugs one way or another found their way inside to all our house plants...There I was wondering why our plants all started to look sad and die off one at a time?!? Then I was wondering why the Ghost and Habanero Pepper Plants I was trying to start for next years outdoor plot would either not sprout, or would sprout then "die off" a few days later...Temp too cold/hot? Nope seemed fine around 70 to 75 F all day and nightWas it lack of organic foods or lack of bennies/mycos in the soil? Nope that just made things worseWas is lack of or over watering? No that isn't the answer either, things still getting worseWait a second... what is that moving in the soil, on the plants, and in the flowers?!? BUGS!!!We had aphids, thrips, leafminers, spider mites, and gnats all having their way with our poor plants and future sprouts...Tried every kind of "organic" concentrate I could find at the local stores, used Worry Free Pyrethrin, Safer Insect Soap, Horticultural Oil, and Neem Oil was all they were selling in the stores... some things "worked", but not really in the long run... Pyrethrin and Horticultural Oil would kill every bug it touched but a few days later the bugs were back with a vengeance exploding in numbers and eating more of the plants... and those two didn't do anything for the bugs eating away at the roots of my plants. Insect Soap and Neem Oil didn't do a thing either, seemed to feed them and make the bugs stronger :(So I researched and ordered spinosad 11.6 percent concentrate... figured I would get over 300 gallons of "ready to use" product and Conserve SC was the least expensive product in the long run compared to "Dead Bug Brew" and other 0.5 percent versions of spinosad that cost $30 a quartMade a mix of spinosad and water, filled a quart sized spray bottle and used about 5 gallons of spinosad/water mixture to drench the soil in our planters... should have seen all the bugs come rushing out of the soil when the water started to drench through... easy enough to take care of them, spray those emerging bugs down along with the rest of the plant, watch those evil bugs twitch and die and move onto the next plant :)* Edit * Applied a second treatment of spinosad about a week later and noticed 1/4 to 1/2 the amount of bugs come rushing out of each planterAfter I was done watering with spinosad the second time I went and ordered 30 million nematodes from Arbico Organics to finish this battle and to keep those pests away for months at a time

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2023
review_content: I used Ortho products years ago and decided to add it to my arsenal again when my regular treatment for black spot wasn't working as well. I ordered this and the dial hose sprayer. First, the sprayer wastes a lot of product. I've flipped the nozzle and tried different water pressure; it is just wasteful. The second issue I have is that it makes the foliage stink. I usually wear gloves when I garden but if I bring in cut flowers, I have to keep my gloves on and remove all of the leaves. It is a smell you can't seem to wash off, so I'd definitely wear gloves when handling the flowers if you use this product. The last thing I'll say is that while it does seem to cut back on the black spot I'm seeing, it didn't work like it used to and I am still removing a lot of diseased leaves.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2020
review_content: We have an ongoing battle with black spot here in north central Texas.  I use the Ortho Garden Disease Control to control it and it works very well, but when conditions are bad, I have to spray up to three times a week to save my roses.  I have been looking for a systemic spray for quite a while and have tried a couple of products claiming to have systemic action for roses.  I decided to try the Ortho Rose and Flower Disease Control since the Ortho Garden Disease control works so well short term.  I sprayed my roses with it, and within three days they were covered with yellow leaves with black spot on them.  I contacted Ortho and their explanation was (copying directly from his email) "Many plant diseases cannot be controlled once the "symptoms" are apparent.  It may be that the product will not control this specific disease."  Does that even make sense?  Black spot is one of the list of diseases they control, but now they are saying in their email that it may not control this specific disease.  So disappointed once again.  They are at least going to reimburse me for the product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2017
review_content: Used this product for three years in a row now.  Truly makes a green lawn.  Truly keeps insects out of yard.  Knats, spiders, grubs, etc.  Does not work for fireants however, but that's a separate product that works for that.  I used to have to water so often, rotating sprinklers once a week all day procedure.  Having 30,000 square feet of lawn, often by the time I got done with whole yard, first part where starting was showing water defiency already.  This Summerguard product works so well, I barely have to water at all.  Maybe once or twice a Summer.  In fact, moisture holds so well in lawn that you MIGHT have to apply a fungicide if it's been raining often, as mushrooms will start popping up.  I love the time this product has allowed me to have doing other stuff in the yard besides water, water, water.  Saves money on our water bills.  Think of that when you spend money on this product.  Went up $20.00 per bag of 15,000 coverage, which I freaked out over....but I only ordered 2 bags this year instead of 3.  (used to order extra bag for late summer...skipping that this year.)

I know it can't be my fault as the reason why the product failed for the insect control because all I had to do was apply the product with a spreader which I did as directed using this brands product spreader. Take it for what it's worth either a money grab with the extra features and benefits it offers or I just have some stubborn pests in my yard.
