review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2021
review_content: Though I seem to be in the minority, I did not experience any burning with this product. I applied as instructed both with the setting on the spreader and the distance apart per application. I watered thoroughly after the fact and have continued to water as normal. About a week later, my grass is green and healthy.For reference, I water all 4 zones of my yard for an hour daily. Tall fescue. In Virginia clay with no shade in the heat of summer, watering an hour a day every day is necessary to keep my lawn green and vibrant. During the dog days of summer, mid-July through September, I water an hour in the early morning and then half an hour in the afternoon.I say that because maybe it was the extent of watering that kept my lawn from burning. Now, my lawn is the greenest its ever been in the summer. For comparison, last summer my lawn really suffered in the heat. It was thin and damaged. This year, after applying scotts products, including summer guard, my lawn remains green and grows healthily even when my neighbors lawns have stagnated in the heat.4 stars because there is much more product in the bag than 5000sqft if you apply as directed (3 3/4 on rotary spreader 5 feet apart).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2023
review_content: Same BIG difference once this was down.  Basically took about 24hrs to start seeing a difference and 48hrs to seeing my cricket and grasshopper problem go away.  Because it's been so dry they are back sooner than I would have liked, but I get it.  Would totally get this again to help with my problem.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2020
review_content: I have used Scotts brand of fertilizer for many years, using the different varieties depending on the season.  Here the summers are long and tend to be hot and dry as well as having a large insect population, so I use this every summer to help strengthen the grass as well as control the insects.  I have never had an issue with burning the grass.  If you follow the directions and use a spreader to put onto your yard, you will have no issues. Do not over sow the fertilizer or you will burn your lawn.  I apply some variety of fertilizer every 3 to 4 months, with the Summerguard version in the summer. Make sure you lightly water your grass immediately before you apply the fertilizer as that helps the fertilizer control the weeds. Also water your lawn thoroughly a couple days later to help the nutrients get into your lawn.  This works well at helping strengthen the lawn and to a lesser extent bug control.  I also use a bug control product to supplement this throughout the year.This 15 lb. bag is a bit small and I think it is a bit pricey compared to other brands, but is comparably priced currently ($25 per 15 lb bag) to the box stores.4 stars

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2016
review_content: This product has been, by far, the best of ALL the fertilizers I've tried; Scotts and others included. In fact, this one was even better at turning my grass green than the Scotts Southern w/ 2% iron. Since my last fertilization of my yard, I keep telling my wife I've never seen our grass look so green. My visiting friend says it's "lush."  Right now, my grass is in the top 99 percentile for my neighborhood. That's not me bragging ... just trying to paint a clear picture of how amazing this product has been.I just put it in one of those hand spreaders and do it. I did measure each section of my yard to get Sq. Ft., so I would know how much to put in each section. Sometimes, I just throw it out by hand. Bottom line, don't be so concerned about overdoing it. Just do it and your grass will love you for it.As for bugs. Before I put it in, I would cut the grass and see flying bugs jumping through the grass as I was approaching with the lawnmower. I haven't seen that since applying this stuff.I live in Central Florida and have St. Augustine (Floratam) and I water three times a week.Disclosure: This is my THIRD time fertilizing this season and my grass was looking good to begin with. I have it on my calendar to fertilize every two months from March through November.

review_content: I've used this product in late spring for several years.  We all hate walking barefoot on grass and have our feet get bitten up. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2018
review_content: I received Scotts Turf Builder Lawn Food on a Monday afternoon.  That night I used a broadcast spreader, following the manufacturer's instructions, spreading the fertilizer in my front and backyard.  I watered the yard(s) really well Monday evening.  Rain was predicted Tuesday but none fell so real early Wednesday morning I watered the areas of my yard that had been looking the worst.  Thursday night, I again watered the entire yard. (Rain was predicted again so I did not water the yard as much as ordinary.)  Unfortunately, we still have not had any rain!  Today is Friday and we are noticing already areas of the yard which were appearing very scorched and bare from the intense heat this summer are already looking very good!!  (In central Texas we have been experiencing drought conditions with triple-digit temperatures daily for over two weeks.  Despite fertilizing the yard in April and watering the yard about every other day, the yard had more brown areas than green.  I will definitely purchase the Scotts Turf Builder Lawn Food again!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: I user Scotts on St Augustine grass and within a week see results. Be sure not to put it down if you have a very heavy  rain either use a sprinkler or light steady rain. Scotts has been great for me over 20 years in Florida east coast and the Panhandle. We don't get snow, but the tropical weather is a haven for fleas, sod worm, chinch bugs and grub worms. UGH!!! If you use one of the products every 3 months you will have a great healthy lawn and I have dogs running on mine. Read the bag before you buy as Scotts lays it out for you each season. Don't burn your  grass by not watering or using the winter products in summer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2018
review_content: I have been using this for years.  Every spring I put this down right before the ants started attacking.  Its getting harder to find this but luckily, Amazon and had it and I had it in two days.  Product was applied right at the start of June and no ants streaming around our front door area.  No anthills all over the place.  I did notice a little browning of the lawn which I  know is normal during drier periods but I think this product may have made the lawn a little more susceptible.  That is why I gave it four stars.  I'll still continue to buy it as long as it is available though because it does rid the ants.  This is the only non natural product I use on my lawn and I only do it once a year.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2021
review_content: After doing some research on how to try and get our yard looking nice I decided to go with Scotts Turf Builder 4 step program.  Do to late snow in the spring I had to start late with the Turf Builder but each time I applied it the grass looked better and healthier. It's now summer and I have applied the summer guard as directed. It's been a week since adding it to the grass and I have to say the yard looks amazing.  It was easy to follow the instructions and we have seen good results. Make sure you follow the instructions. I highly recommend!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2020
review_content: Works as intended. I applied while temps were in the high 80¬∞F but in late afternoon and hosed down lawn to soak it in. After two weeks, the nitrogen is hard at work greening up the lawn and even with less water, the grass is growing quickly and coming in thicker than ever.The biggest pro is that it killed many pests and insects and honestly stopped ants from creeping around my house. It was rather quite noticeable.A minor drawback is that it pushed weeds to grow rather than kill them off. Chickweed and clover in particular started to really take off. This was resolved by buying weed killer that was specifically designed to kill those weeds.Use with Scott's other products rather than just throwing down a random bag. You'll thank yourself for years to come.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023
review_content: After using "flea bombs" repeatedly, we had just about given up on eradicating the flea population in our basement. We couldn't get rid of them on the dogs, and nothing seemed to kill the eggs. My husband set off twice the foggers designed for the space and left for a week. When he came back, the fleas were as bad as ever.Then my husband heard about this product. He tried it. I came back a week later, and the fleas were gone. Finally, it seems the fleas are gone.The flea treatments we were using with the dogs clearly wasn't enough, and vacuuming wasn't sufficient to stay ahead of the fleas either. However, now that we've applied this product to all our carpets, it looks like the flea collars are working. The dogs have stopped scratching and the one that is most allergic to the fleas is regrowing a healthy coat of fur.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
review_content: We live in an area with hot, humid summers and lots of shade trees - so our mosquitoes were pretty bad. Just a week or so after spraying this product on and around all the bushes and flowerbeds, there was a dramatic decrease in the number of flying pests. It also (so far) stopped the bad flea problem our neighborhood has been experiencing. Yet, it doesn't appear to have impacted the lizard population, and I still see an occasional bee (we never had a lot), which is a plus. I've only had this down a few months, so I can't say if it really lasts 6 months or not. As I have seen a small increase in mosquitoes recently, I suspect a more realistic expectation is to plan on applying 3x per year, rather than two. Certainly if your city gets a lot of rainfall. Still, it's far superior to toxic pesticides that need applied monthly, or organic treatments that wash away easily. And unlike conventional bug sprays, the insects don't develop resistance to the IGR. We spray it ourselves with a hand-held sprayer we also got on Amazon for 13 bucks. More effective than the pest control companies, at 1/3 the cost. You can't beat that

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2016
review_content: We had a pretty large flea infestation in our rental home which in turn we brought them home to our regular home on our clothing, so then I needed to treat 2 homes.  I was going absolutely crazy! I had never had an encounter with fleas before, so my first instinct was to go and buy flea bombs and set them off in the home, so I did.  I went back to the home a few days after I had set the bombs off and the fleas were just as bad.  I tried spraying with just an adulticide, Tempo SC, this worked immediately to kill the living fleas, but then they started to hatch again and then the cycle started all over again.  So I did some research online and this was recommended along with the adulticide.  I used this product mixed with Premetherin and sprayed the homes inside and out. I also vacuumed diligently once a day. Within 2 weeks,there were no sign of fleas, I sprayed this product by itself again after 2 weeks for good measure.  It has been 2 months now and we haven't seen any sign of fleas in either home.  This will be my go to product if I encounter a flea infestation again, its awesome!  We also treated our dog by flea combing 2-3 times a day in a bathtub filled with 1-2 inches of soapy water so that when the fleas fell in the water during combing, they died immediately.  Our vet also gave our dog a pill which would kill the fleas and deform any eggs laid by the fleas that would inhibit them from hatching.  With all of these steps we were able to get rid of the fleas.  Its a lot of time and effort, but it's worth it in the end.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2023
review_content: Does a really good job as far as controlling insects...

review_content: I like the product so much that I ordered it for my daughter. She moved from Utah and now has new address in Vegas. As hard as I tried to cancel the order before it shipped was useless.  It was shipped today inspire of requesting cancelation.  Great product, no customer service.  I hope who ever gets this expensive product can use it. I had my daughter reorder it. Now the company has 100.00 + of my money. Good luck with your orders.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2015
review_content: I was suffering from a moderate flea infestation and tried treating the animals with various neck/back drops and flea collars, as well as bathing them in flea shampoo every few days and spraying all of the carpets, drapes, and furniture with a pet store purchase that was SUPPOSED to kill all fleas and prevent more showing up.  Nothing was working, and I was about ready to bite the bullet and hire an exterminator to come bomb the house.I received this order almost exactly 1 month ago today.The day I received it I mixed it up 4 ML / gallon of water and sprayed my entire yard, around all doors, windows, and the foundation of the house, and the first floor and basement of my house as well as the stairs leading to the 2nd floor.About a week later I wasn't seeing much improvement and sprayed the whole yard and first floor again.This label suggests multiple treatments appx. three weeks apart.In the last month I have gone from pulling 15-20 fleas off a 5 lb dog to finding 1-3.  My legs have almost completely healed from where I was being bitten.  My dog's hair is growing back (she was scratching and chewing it off).  I will be following the suggestion of the label and treating my yard and home again now that 3 weeks has passed, but this seems to have done the trick as of right now.  I would HIGHLY recommend this product to anyone who is having problems with fleas, and while I can't personally speak for the other 20 or so insects it claims to combat, my guess is it works just as well against them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2015
review_content: I was skeptical at first because I bought Nyguard and did not have the quick results others had.  However, after suffering through having tons of fleas in my house for over 3 months, and trying sevin dust, Black Flag Xtreme Flea spray, Viper, and other products, I am very thankful that after the 2 weeks specified on the bottle as the average time to see a noticeable decrease in fleas, and the time to respray if needed, my house was almost flea free!  Only a few jumped in the bowls after 2 weeks.  I didn't even respray, and the fleas are completely gone after 3 1/2 weeks!  Like some have suggested, on blogs and such, I put out white bowl with water and soap ALL over the house.  You just couldn't imagine the amount of fleas that jump into these bowls - which only exposed the magnitude of the problem I had.  Fleas reproduce SO rapidly, that if you don't get a handle on the problem early, it will then get MUCH worse before it gets better!1) I would recommend this product to anyone with a serious flea problem - just give it the time allowed to work!2) Vacuum your house slowly EVERY DAY!3) Put out low profile white bowls with soap and water all around the infected areas (I put 5 in each room).4) Don't wear white socks around the house - fleas are EXTREMELY attracted to white.  Just wait to see all the fleas in your bowls after a day or two lol...5) Make sure you spray Nyguard on drapes, and anything fabric - carpet, drapes, etc....It works!!!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2018
review_content: Do not be discouraged by the price or size of the bottle. Literally a little bit goes a long way. We had an indoor/outdoor cat who left some pesky baggage after unfortunately not coming home one night. We have laminate flooring all through the house, which makes flea control more of a hassle. We spent a small fortune on bleaching, vacuuming, bombing...EVERYTHING. I scoured the internet and finally found this. Nygaurd paired with Permethrin has been a life saver. The Permethrin kills the fleas instantly and the Nygaurd prevents the fleas from maturing enough to reproduce, even while in the egg. Definitely follow the ratio directions for both because this stuff is extremely potent...our house is 1000 sq. ft. and a gallon solution more than does it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2018
review_content: Doggy-sat a friend's Golden Retriever for a few weeks.  Poor dog had fleas.  Infected all my dogs then.  I went crazy getting my dogs de-flea'd after our four-legged friend departed. I am back to having a flea-free home environment.  This was 2 years ago and no sign of fleas since.  I swear by these combined products.  Warning:  Do NOT have your animals in the house when you apply this solution.  It must be totally dry before they come back into the house.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2018
review_content: Just to be clear and reiterate what a few reviews already have said, this product alone WILL NOT KILL insects outright, it merely affects their ability to hatch and/or grow and mature into adults capable of reproducing. YOU MUST mix this with another product like Bifen XTS if you want to kill adult insects and also destroy any eggs/larva they leave behind. Nyguard is very effective controlling fleas and other bugs that lay eggs that are not easily destroyed or controlled with normal insecticides but not meant to KILL adult bugs by itself. This is a VERY small bottle for the money you spend but a little goes a very long way and eliminated the mosquito population around my property as well as the chigger infestation I had.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2022
review_content: Bayer makes Temprid FX and they say..."For bed bugs, do not exceed an application rate of 0.075% - 0.27 fluid ounces (8 milliliters) of Temprid FX Insecticide per gallon of water." I don't understand why less is better. I use probably three times as much concentrate which I mix with water. I estimate that I use 25 ml per gallon. I don't care how much I need to spend. I just want those bedbugs dead!Also, you can't keep the mixed Temprid around more than 24 hours, because water destroys the microencapsulated spheres that are in the concentrate. The microencapsulated spheres of insecticide are not going to break down if the water in your mixed spray evaporates within an hour or two. This leaves behind a dry deposit. I have never sprayed Temprid on live bedbugs because I rarely see them. I know that if you spray Temprid on live bedbugs, there is quick knockdown. What I'm more interested in is how the dry deposits kill the bedbugs. After the spray I applied has dried, I have seen bedbugs strolling along on the treated surfaces! It is frustrating that they don't die right away, but I understand that Temprid will kill them within a few hours or a day. The microencapsulated spheres stick to the legs of the insect and start to release the chemicals over many hours into the nervous system of the insect. I don't have the patience to wait for the insect to die. I will kill any bedbug that I see. However, when I am not looking, I am hoping that the Temprid dry deposits are coating the legs of the bedbugs and the bedbugs will die within the next 24 hours. That's what I am hoping for. I can't stay awake 24 hours a day watching for bedbugs that come out of hiding!And also, Temprid is supposed to look like milk. And it's not supposed to have a strong smell. That's why the insecticide is microencapsulated. The water that you mix evaporates and leaves behind a dry deposit of microencapsulated spheres.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2022
review_content: Company came out to advertise me and sell me on a monthly pest control plan, I said no, my neighbor said yes. I waited for tech to come out to his house, he was a newbie and told me all the names for all the products that they use when I aked him... I found it here and ordered it same day. Salesman was saying the product they use you can only get it with a license- LIE. All they do is charge for easy simple service. All products are similar though.Sprayed inside the house baseboards and under couch, just in case (I did wear respirator just in case), around windows, then what was left I sprayed outside around doors and windows (it does leave a little greese spots on glass but wipes off easy or water spots I guess). Inside did not leave any residue... used it as a general bug/ants protection.2 days later: Bugs/flies/BLACK WIDOW laying messed up on the groud. Seems like it doesn't kill upon the contact. They just get literally messed up, laying on the ground twitching until they pass out... Seems like it affects their nervous system. My kid left a door open an inch for few hrs bunch of flies entered. They all went to windows which I sprayed and now few hrs later they just laying chilling on the ground - trying to get up but can't...Time will tell on longevity. But good product..Use as recommended. Nothing more or less. It works.Use Delta Dust along with this for cracks and plumbing access points, but protect the house from outside in a first place and you will be set.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2021
review_content: Buy a pump sprayer and read the label before anything! This product is absolutely amazing. I work in Pest Control for a company out in Southern California. We use this all the time for exterior services. This is the best product in the market for spiders. The residual on this lasts about a month on the outside (I mean in all technicality, it‚Äôll always be there, but for it to actually kill pests then for about a month.) This does not repel insects, so if you‚Äôre having any issues with anything this is great.If you have German roaches in your household, then before applying please buy all the Personal Protective Equipment before applying and get into any little crack or crevice that you can get into and retreat as directed. This stuff will kill all roaches in your house/apartment. Make sure to not have any kids, pets, or anybody in the area until it dries. Once dried it‚Äôs perfectly safe if you follow the labels directions. Combine this with a growth regulator such as Tekko Pro, Archer IGR, or Gentrol IGR, to prevent any roaches from being able to reproduce.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Temprid is an Excellent product. I‚Äôve been using it for years for maintenance spraying for bed bugs and other insects. Do your self a favor and read the EPA‚Äôs Pesticide Application Core Manual: the manual that pesticide applicators have to test to get a license to apply pesticides. One product is not sufficient to deal with BB‚Äôs, it takes a multi vector approach. I use Crossfire and Temprid FX. They‚Äôve kept my building BB and other insects free for years. I also back it up with Diatomaceous Earth under appliances, in plumbing holes in walls, and under cabinets. Heat is not affective alone: I‚Äôve used it alone and found that heat can be defeated by common insulating materials in a home (carpet, walls). Heat will kill them that day, but remember, BED BUGS ARE HITCH HIKERS. You can get rid of them with heat and pick up a new set while staying at a hotel, traveling on a plane, or sitting in a chair in someone‚Äôs office. You need a residual to prevent further infestation. Spraying twice in the first 30 days and once a month has solved the problem for me. Please read the EPA‚Äôs Pesticide Application Core Manual to learn which chemicals are effective, and how to use them safely.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2019
review_content: My son brought home bed bugs from one of his friends houses.  By the time we realized it... his room was INFESTED with them.  I sprayed this chemical, along with a powder that I got to spray into the walls and cracks.  The bed bugs died.  But then they came back.  So, I mixed up some more, pulled the moldings off the walls and sprayed this stuff (very liberally) into all of the cracks and crevices, including those exposed by removing the molding... and they died, and we haven't seen any more for 6 months.  We also haven't seen any roaches, spiders, or any other bugs.  We live in rural Northern Florida... so that's saying something.  I highly recommend this product for pest control... but don't be scared to use a TON of it if you have bed bugs, and pull the moldings off the walls in the effected areas to really get the solution in there.  It leaves a good residue behind after it dries.  Worked great for us.UPDATE:  So, it's 1/11/20... over 6 months later.  We haven't seen a single bed bug.  Not one.  So, I think this stuff is really amazing.  In addition, we also have been free of any roaches... which living in a heavily wooded part of Northwest Florida, is saying something.  Of course the prep work I mentioned earlier is a must... simply can't break the reproduction cycle without proper prep, but this spray is amazingly effective, when coupled with the powder filling all of the cracks and crevices they like to hide in for a good residual kill of future hatchlings.

review_content: I have been dealing with a locust invasion of Eastern Lubbers this year.  I've never seen them so bad.  They are very hard to kill, especially as adults.  I applied the high-dose of Temprid to the walls of my house, fence panels, soffits, tree trunks and non-blooming foliage.  I've got dead lubbers everywhere.  Very cost-effective!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2019
review_content: Bed bugs are a tough lot and I've been fighting them for about six weeks now.  Began with a couple of "natural" products; one promised a two week residual but you needed to apply it every day so how could you tell.  I also used diatomaceous earth which seemed good in theory but now way to know it's effect.  Temprid was a more "nuclear" option as it is supposed to have a three week residual but the danged bbs keep raiding me every night.  I've reduced the numbers dramatically but not eliminated them with Temprid as I'd hoped.  I've moved on to my fourth and fifth attempts at eliminating the danged things.  The more I read the more I believe it is not the products ineffectiveness as much as it is the adaptations of the pest I am combating.  Have thought of burning the house down but I think that would make the wife angry!

After spraying weekly, it only took me a little over a month to get rid of them. So I highly recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: I was recommended this product after talking to a friend of mine who swears by it.  I wanted to stay as 'organic' as possible.  But I also wanted a product that actually works! You need to make sure to use as directed and make sure to apply WHEN NO BEES ARE PRESENT.  And you need to get the undersides of the leaves for it to work.  But if you do that I promise this product is safe to use and effective.  I've used it on everything from strawberries, chard, parsley, beans, tomatoes, cucs and carrots.  I use it weekly when the bugs are really aggressive.  This does not get rid of ants.  But it will get the aphids.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2021
review_content: I normally use the spray bottle, but it was only available as the hose end sprayer on clearance where I bought it last. As others have said the sprayer is difficult to control. I reccomend applying at night for 2 reasons. 1. It will kill bees if it comes directly in contact with them. The residue will not kill them if sprayed a few hours before they start foraging for pollen. 2. The scent seems to REALLY stir up wasps. If you have wasps in the application area spraying when they are active may pose a safety issue. Other than that, my plants appear much healthier for a few weeks after application. I use a separate for fungal issues, but it's a good insect broad spectrum.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2019
review_content: I bought this insect spray for my prize rose bush that had an pretty good attack aphids and midges.  After reading the reviews I was just that more careful in reading directions and the hook up to the hose.  There was absolutely no problem.  You will need to pull back on the stop before you can move the sprayer (I found this a little hard but pulled back as far as I could then used a small straight screwdriver to pull back the rest).  I was careful in connecting the hose and did not tighten it too tightly.  And walla it worked the sprayer worked beautifully.  The rose bush is covered and it was easy.  In detaching it I used the same gentle manner.  I turned the sprayer to the stop position and replaced the stop.  I did not encounter leaking or broken attachments.  On the issue of smell yes there is a smell but it is very mild.  I cannot understand how others found it to be strong unless they were spraying it on directly without mixing it with water.  Anyway it is mild and not unpleasant.  I will wait to see it's effectiveness on the eradication of the pests however I know from experience with other natural essential oil repellents that they do work.  I will post the results later.

review_content: My yards has been a haven for gnats for the past 33 years.  I could not doing any yard work without applying some type of repellant - most of which had limited effectiveness. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
review_content: I moved into a house that is "mosquito central" during the summer months, thanks to a particular area behind my house where they rest during the day. Prior to purchase of this product, I largely lost the use of my deck in the evening and, since the daytime-biting mosquitoes were also present, I began to feel like a prisoner in my own home from May through September. I first tried a mosquito zapper and while it killed scores of the little buggers, it barely made a dent in their plague-like numbers. This product changed that. It was sprayed nearly two months ago directly on the mosquitoes where they congregate during the day and did not stain the wood siding, which was a concern. Better yet, it appears to have deterred new mosquitoes from replacing the ones that were killed off. This product does not have a strong odor, did not stain my painted siding and was worth every penny.

review_content: When I was a small child I would earn a small allowance in exchange for doing small chores -- anything mom could cook up to teach me the value of earning my way.  I invariably wasted money I'd earned on toys.  Since I became a big child I've invariably wasted my money on toys.  My thinking as a small child and my thinking as a big child have never changed.  It's always been this:  you're going to spend your money on something.  Don't spend your money on Summit Mosquito and Gnat Barrier.  I did.  I'm sorry I did.  I've never used the stuff.  It's still sitting on the floor of my garage right in front of my big toys.  I need to get rid of  Summit but I really don't know where it could safely go.  The label says it will be seriously bad on you if it touches your skin, gets in your eyes, invades your system through breathing or gets on your clothes.  It says something like "peel back this label for directions as to how to use this business, and for information on all of the bad stuff it will most assuredly give you."  So I peeled back the label.  Guess what, peekaboo, there's nothing there.  I tried to get the vendor to explain all that but never got a response.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2021
review_content: This bug spray is cleverly (and not innocently) marketed like a wonder insecticide that will kill everything it gets near. This is a permethrin spray. That's a repellent, not an insecticide, and mosquitos are tougher than most bugs you find in suburbia. It works by stinking and thus disguising what really attracts mosquitos, and that's CO2 in human breath. They're good at detecting movement too.This smells sulphury like garlic. This may confuse your mosquitos but they'll be back tomorrow night to rekindle relationships. Giving everyone fresh garlic pizza might work better than this stuff.Well, it's live and learn. Mosquitos are killed by direct spray contact by an insecticide (either by wetting or by misting/fogging) or by suction trapping at a CO2 source. Liquids strong enough to work don't belong around kids and other people. UV lights don't work. This junk don't work.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2023
review_content: This product literally saved my infested Lemon tree!!!I recently used Bonide Insecticidal Soap in my garden, and I have been thoroughly impressed with its performance. This product has been a game-changer in my battle against garden pests, and here's why I'm giving it a glowing review:Effective Pest Control: Bonide Insecticidal Soap is a highly effective solution for controlling a wide range of garden pests, including aphids, mealybugs, spider mites, and more. It acts quickly to eliminate these nuisances, helping to protect my plants from damage.Gentle on Plants: One of the standout features of this product is that it is gentle on my plants. Unlike some chemical pesticides that can harm the foliage, Bonide Insecticidal Soap is a mild, soap-based formula that doesn't harm the environment or my garden. It leaves my plants looking healthy and vibrant.Easy Application: Applying this insecticidal soap is a breeze. It comes in a convenient spray bottle that allows for precise targeting of problem areas. The spray nozzle provides good coverage and control, ensuring I can reach the undersides of leaves where many pests hide.Fast Results: I noticed a significant reduction in pest populations within a short time after using Bonide Insecticidal Soap. It's reassuring to see quick results, especially when dealing with a pest infestation that can threaten my plants' health.Environmentally Friendly: As someone who values environmentally friendly solutions, I appreciate that this product is gentle on beneficial insects and does not harm the overall ecosystem of my garden. It's a responsible choice for pest control.Versatile Use: Bonide Insecticidal Soap can be used on a variety of plants, including vegetables, ornamentals, and fruit trees. Its versatility makes it a valuable tool for maintaining a healthy garden.Safe for Home Use: I feel confident using this product around my home because it is safe for pets and people when used as directed. It provides peace of mind knowing that I can protect my garden without exposing my family to harmful chemicals.In summary, Bonide Insecticidal Soap has become an essential part of my gardening toolkit. Its effectiveness, plant-friendly formula, ease of use, and environmental responsibility make it a top choice for pest control in the garden. I highly recommend it to any gardener looking for a reliable and eco-friendly solution to keep their plants healthy and pest-free. It's a fantastic product that delivers excellent results while caring for the environment.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2023
review_content: I am returning this product - it kills bees!!!I didn't research this product before purchasing and now I regret it...Although I was directed to this product from an organic gardening site and do need something to control pests in my organic garden, I'll stick with my neem oil recipe!The ingredients on this product may be organic but further research when I received the product warned that bonide kills bees and other pollinators as well as the tomato hornworms, black flea beetles, and squash bugs I need to get out of my garden... I'm very disappointed! We need bees üêù  both for pollination in my garden and for the very survival of all plants on our planet!The product instructions state that to avoid killing bees one should apply the product at dusk or dawn "when bees are less likely to be present." That was my first clue that this wasn't the product for me...Squash bees are most active at dawn and other pollinators like butterflies are active at dusk... the last thing I want to do is to kill my pollinators!!! I'd rather let the pests eat my garden.Neem oil concentate mixed with water and a drop or two of catille soap to distribute the neem oil in water does work to kill hornworms, mildew diseases, baby squash bugs (before they get their hard shells) and supposedly the black flea beetles on my eggplant, it just needs to be reapplied frequently especially after a rain.But the neem oil doesn't kill my bees!!!I'd never test that theory by actually spaying bees or the flowers right before bees will visit... But I believe that neem oil mix is a much safer bet to save the bees üêùDisappointed!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2023
review_content: Every year I have white flies. Everywhere. Indoors where I start my seedlings, outdoors where I planted seeds into the soil‚Ä¶ it was beyond terrible last year. I almost couldn‚Äôt pick my beans and tomatoes due to the swarms. They were on my melons, my herbs, my lettuces, even my hibiscus was affected by the whiteflies. I used my camera‚Äôs zoom video and dug through seedling‚Äôs soil to see squirming larvae. I tried everything. Nothing worked. Neem oil was useless, as was soap and water, and finally pyrethrin and malathion‚Ä¶I read this BioAdvanced Fruit, Citrus & Vegetable Insect Control, Concentrate could be used as a preventative ‚Äì it‚Äôs poured into the ground. It is systemic, and I love to stay organic, but living in Tennessee, you sometimes can‚Äôt go the organic route. So, I tried it this year. I used it on most every seedling except my lettuces and bock choy because I simply forgot them‚Ä¶ no whiteflies except, you guessed it, my lettuces and bok choy. It was amazing. I actually let my tomatoes go quite a bit this year, inviting white fly infestation‚Ä¶ never happened!Systemic or no, it saves my vegetables and fruits from the white flies! You do have to use this as a preventative. Once you have white flies, it‚Äôs pretty much too late. Harvest best you can.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2023
review_content: I purchased one container of this product a while back. I have a large property in the California high desert and was having some problems with bugs eating my plants and trees in the summertime. I tried those spray on insecticides for plants but had mixed results and the effectiveness of those products did not seem to last very long. This product was used for smaller sized Mulberry trees and small pomegranate plants. Those insects seem to prefer the younger plants I have for their daily meals.The insect control concentrate has worked fine. I have not had any problems at all with the bugs returning after application. It sure is much easier than continually spraying the plant or tree over a long period of time with some other product like I did before. If the bugs come back again this summer I will need to order another container for new applications. I give this product a thumbs up for a purchase choice.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
review_content: I have previously used really strong solutions of imidacloprid for my front yard bushes to take care of beetles and other pests. It was really easy to use since this is a systematic pesticide. That is, you just mix with water and pour it on the roots. The plants takes in the imidacloprid and stores it in its tissue so that you only need to apply the pesticide once a year and no further treatment is needed. However, the concentration of imidacloprid for my frontyard treatment is far too strong to be used on the edible crops and plants that I grow in my backyard.That is where this pesticide comes in. It only contains 0.235% Imidacloprid making it suitable for edible crops. Like the stronger concentration pesticides, it is systematic, so you only apply it once a year. The low concentration means that the fruits are safe to eat, and since I am only spraying once a year, you end up saving a lot more compared to other pesticides that require a spray every week or two. Since the chemical only affects insects that feed on the plants (usually harmful pests), this is safe for most pollinators like bees.I have actually had this product in mind for the last year. Amazon was offering this product at $13.54 after the coupon discount (The normal MSRP is $26.99), so there was no reason not to buy it.This pesticide is designed for fruits and vegetables. But there are a few things to note. The Pre-harvest Interval, that is, the time needed after each application before you can harvest the crops vary from plant to plant. So you have to check the label prior to use. While it can be used on the listed vegetables, in many cases, the Pre-harvest Interval is 21 days. So you cannot harvest the vegetables for 21 days after application. This might be problematic when it comes to short harvest crops. E.g. Some vegetables may only take 3 or 4 weeks from seed to harvest, so that rules out the use of this pesticide. The pesticide is applying by mixing in water and then pouring it around the roots, so there is no need to spray anything on the plants. It's mostly practical for fruits and less useful for leafy vegetables.If you are a busy gardener and have no time to spray your fruit trees every other week, I would highly recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
review_content: I live in southern california and have several citrus trees in my yard. All of them were being attacked by several types of pests and were not looking very happy. I had grasshoppers, sharpshooters, leaf miners, aphids, and scale all on my trees. I couldn't even stand under them as I would get "rained" on by aphid excrement that was like a light mist. I did not want to use a poison and held out as long as I could, spraying them with neem oil but that did not seem to help at all. So I finally broke down and bought this. I made sure not to use it while the trees were flowering due to the fact apparently it is really toxic to bees. I applied it at the end of the growing season and this spring the trees are all doing really great. The new leaf growth is untouched by pests whereas normally they would take advantage of that. Now that I've gotten the pests reigned in I'll see if I can't maintain them with just neem oil instead of having to use something as poisonous as this.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2023
review_content: We have about 50 young citrus trees on our property, planted earlier this year. In the late spring practically all new growth was horribly mangled by leaf miners. One application of this stuff knocked them back to almost nothing! You can even see on some of the leaves where the miner died after only a row of eating, saving the leaf. It remains to be seen how long the protection lasts, but it was worth the cost just to see a flush of green without any curled, yellowed, eaten leaves.

I went to six local stores, 4 of whom are Farm and Ranch Stores and could not find it but they had replacement from some company I never heard of.. Probably because they were stuck with all the Bottles of Spray On Chemicals and wanted to get rid of them by not carrying the Bayer Product..... This year the Trees were eaten alive by this product that I have heard of before,,, It did not work.. review_content: Sandy soil will cause more of the product to be lost to waste.  That's important because, this is the primary product which can stop Citrus Greening.  Either saturdate the ground first and then apply or, contain the application to the roots "some how".  Another useful piece of experience is, it took two weeks before the chemistry worked itself into the plant and leaf structures.  There was some damage done due to my ignorance on TIMING.  This product works, keeps working BUT, you must have it bioavailable before the time comes that it's needed. I'm getting hit hard in Central Florida in August.  Since the product is bi-annual, I'm going to use March 1st and July 1st for the application dates.  I'm concerned about the price. It's too high.  I have six citrus trees and that's more than one bottle handles. I believe that's on purpose, to force the buying of a second bottle. It's expensive to use. I will be seeking alternatives with the same active ingredient. Lower the price and I won't need to.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: Last spring a friend gave me a Maple tree sapling, as I had wanted to grow one and see if I could make it into a Bonsai of sorts. Unbeknownst to me, this sapling had a terrible mealybug infestation - which I then took into my house and placed next to my other plants. I returned from vacation to find an all out infestation on *all* of my indoor plants.I bought this product to try and eliminate the bugs. I cleared and quarantined my plants in batches, waiting 8 - 12 weeks after application / the bugs disappearing to make sure the bugs had been cleared out before reintroducing treated plants to the rest of my (clean) plants. I could clearly see the difference in my plants, as slowly but surely the mealybugs vanished.Most of my plants are bug free and living happy lives. But a few others still show signs of mealys - a few cotton puffs here and there and an occasional little mealybug. I have poured WAY over the suggested amount and concentration, especially for indoor plants, and the bugs still survive on these plants (mostly succulents). Unfortunately I didn't realize the bugs were still present and placed infected plants next to my Bonsai, which then became infected. I treated my bonsai with this product. It was dead within a month.This product helped 80% of my plants, so I can't tell you not to buy it. But it also didn't solve my problem, it killed my favorite plant, and allowed the mealybugs to spread. So use with caution, and follow-up with supplemental care. DO NOT treat your bonsai with it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2019
review_content: I overwinter our pepper plants inside, and thus brought in aphids that quickly multiplied due to a lack of predators. After tiring of repeatedly using pyrethrin sprays (sometimes which would damage foliage), I mixed this pesticide into a regularly scheduled watering. Within a week many of the aphids were gone, and within a couple weeks wiped out virtually. Due to the fact that it would be six months before I put the plant outside again, most of the pesticide should have metabolized before it is exposed again to potential pollinators. Since we keep bees, I would not use this outside in the summer just to be safe.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2022
review_content: I don't really like chemicals and pesticides around my fruit plants ... certain chemicals are pretty natural and others are not. I tend to put this in the 'not' category, even though most sources (in the US unyways) say that this is relatively safe. Right off the bat, I will say that this is an outdoor only product. I have a large, potted lemon tree in my house, which spends the cold winters indoors and in front of a large window for the sun. Originally, I ordered it for that purpose ... but I read that you should not use products (especially concentrated ones) with the active ingredient Imidocloprid for indoor plants. Strike one.Imidocloprid has varying reports as to it's safety. For the US, it is listed as safe to sell ... and the magazine Entomology Today lists it as safe for pollinators and bees when used in moderation. Imidoclopril is banned in the European Union as some studies show that it may be harmful to honeybee populations and pollinators. There isn't a ton of concrete evidence on either side and there are conflicting reports at times.Imidoclopril is a pesticide which works by affecting the nervous systems of insects negatively. You can see by my photos of the product's labels what types of insects this will target. This is very heavily geared towards citrus pests ... whiteflies and aphids are big issues in the north and south, whereas the Asian Citrus Pysllids are very, very bad bugs to have on your citrus crop ... and unlike whiteflies and aphids which can be eradicated once you find them, once your tree is infected with Pysllids, that's pretty much it for the tree's ability to produce edible fruit. So, for those with outdoor citrus trees, this product might be worth its weight in gold.I used this on my tree outside on my deck. It's chilly at night but not cold enough to harm the tree. A week later, the infestation is still there as strong as before. The only thing which seems to get rid of whiteflies and aphids, albeit temporarily, is Neem oil sprayed onto the leaves.This works by measuring the distance of the branches from the trunk out to the end of the furthest branch (dripline radius) and using the chart I photographed. For small trees, like mine, the dripline radius is less than 3 feet, so only 1.5 ounces is needed. For large apple or orange trees, you'd need 1/3 or more of the bottle. So the bottle will do 2-3 large trees ... or lots of small trees or bushes. The labels say its safe for everything from blueberry bushes to fruit trees. However, I don't think after seeing how ineffective it was against my whiteflies if it's worth putting a chemical like this on my fruit baring trees.Imidaclorpid is the Active Ingredient and measures .023% vs. 99.765% inactive ingredients, which are likely water and dye. This is a concentrate, so you can imagine how strong Imidaclorpid is, if way less than 1% of this product is active ingredient. Likely why your honeybees will be safe if you use it ... maybe.Overall, this wasn't the most effective Bioadvanced product I've used. I do think many of their products (once owned by Bayer ... then sold off around a decade ago) are good for citrus bug temporary prevention and for the most part safe to use. However, this product didn't really work for me and the warnings give me pause to use it again ... so I likely will not. For bigger, planted, outdoor citrus trees, the protection against bugs which will do your plant harm might be worth it to you.

review_content: I don't really like using chemicals on my trees, but sometimes you have to fight dirty to get ahead of pests. This is the first time I've used this brand, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I do like that there was no spraying involved. All I had to do was mix and pour. The season is still young, but so far, so good. It claims to be effective for 2 months, so we'll see - if it isn't, I'll come back to update. I am wondering about what's going to happen after the 2 months. From what I'm seeing in the information, you use this once a year. Well, my apple trees have bloomed, but it will be August or September before they're ready to pick. Since we're still in April, I'll be looking for something else to do after this wears off. That's a drawback in my opinion. So, we'll see how it goes and if there's something to report, I'll update.

review_content: BioAdvanced Fruit & Citrus Tree Insect Control is a very effective product to have in your home gardening insect control arsenal if you have fruit, nut, or citrus trees. It controls all the bugs that seems impossible to get rid of. I have lemons, limes, key limes, bananas, and some other trees and shrubs that have been insect magnets in the past and this product has solved my issues.The best advice I can give is to pay close attention to the instructions and follow them completely. The dilution and application is different based upon the tree or plant that you are treating and the size. When you receive the jug of BioAdvanced Fruit & Citrus Tree Insect Control, you will  notice a booklet attached to the back of the jug. Remove the booklet, read it, and keep it for reference. The instructions are very specific for each kind of nut and fruit tree and for every kind of vegetable, herb, grape, banana and all of the instructions, if they are followed completely will give you the results that you are expecting.Two non-buggy thumbs up from me! üëçüèºüëçüèº

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2022
review_content: Excellent insect control for your garden! We have 4 potted citrus trees that are outside most of the year, and we applied this at the beginning of the summer. We also went ahead and applied it to our other potted plants outside as well. It has been very effective! Recommend!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2022
review_content: This insect control is designed particularly for fruit and citrus trees, although you can use it for all kinds of different vegetable plants (and the detailed instructions tell you exactly how to use it for all kinds of plants!)I am very happy with this insecticide and got it for my citrus trees. I have some dwarf orange trees that got hit very badly with mites last year and it was a constant battle to keep them under control. I am hoping that using this insecticide will better control the pests and allow my trees to further thrive. I was also quite happy to see the range of plants (and pests) that this is effective on since I have a number of different fruit trees and I plant a full garden every spring. This will definitely be getting a lot of use!Do make sure you read the instructions fully though to be certain that you use this at the correct time of year. This is a once yearly application and the insecticide is concentrated, so it needs dilution! Overall, I am super happy with this so far - it‚Äôs a great value and I will be able to use it on a lot of different plants. Highly recommend.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2022
review_content: Just to clarify, this product only needs to be applied once a year. The amount applied depends on the size of the tree you're applying to. So, if you have large trees you may not get 9 trees out of the bottle as it says. If you have young trees like I do, then you'll get several years worth of applications out of a single bottle. The application is very easy: look at the label and figure out how much you need based on your tree's drip line size, pour into a gallon of water and apply around the entire drip line of the tree. For me, this was a great bargain because my trees are young and only have a 3ft drip line. I'll get at least 3 applications on 9 trees out of this bottle. Not bad for $20.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
review_content: I have a dwarf orange tree that I have been growing and babying for over 5 years now.  It is about 7 feet tall and it's drip line is maybe 3-4 feet around.  I have never seen pests on it until this spring, I went to water one day and it was absolutely covered in aphids.I received this product just in time. The instructions were pretty easy to follow.  It helps to have a watering can to measure and dilute the product.  I also didn't know that the ground should be moist, not soaked, before you use it, they recommend watering the night before you treat to allow the product, so that cooled my initial excitement, but I was able to use it the next day.The product says it could take days to weeks to see it working, depending on the size of the tree.  Since my tree is on the smaller side, I noticed a difference in about 3-4 days, and now two weeks later the aphids are totally gone!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2022
review_content: I was comparing to the BioAdvanced Fruit, Citrus, and Vegetable insect control concentrate I'd used last year, and I think this is the same product with a slightly different name and label design. Active ingredients and bugs treated seem to match. Interesting they no longer have vegetables in the name though...  Maybe one of the "other ingredients" in the active ingredients changed or something? Not sure. Last year I definitely noticed fewer bugs on my apple and cherry trees. I just applied this to my trees for this year. Unfortunately, this was shipped in a bag and the measuring cup and cap were broken. Luckily since it's a safety cap there's a cap inside the cap and the inner one wasn't broken.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2022
review_content: Yup it is as easy as ABC. Just mix and pour at the base of the root. Every year i need to climb up the ladder to spray my Lemon tree say no more. So easy and solve the problem that i have every year. Love how easy the problem solved. Said goodbye to those climbing up ladder &spray the poison on the leaf, poison spray all over your face when wind blow, poke by torn and danger of climbing up the unstable base.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2022
review_content: I was surprised to learn this will only treat up to 9 fruit trees.  The application is easy than having to use a sprayer.  You mix and pour at the base of the tree.  It is hard to say if it actually is effective until I make it thru an entire season.  The price is pretty good.  Basically you pay a little over a dollar a tree.  A lot of chemicals are so overpriced that this seems reasonable to keep your fruit trees pest free.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2022
review_content: I used this product on two of my citrus trees that had become re-infected with white flies and meely bugs. I initially used another product that required me to spray the trees down and then re-spray a couple of weeks later, which was not only tedious, but also got me covered in spray! This product avoids the spraying. I simply mixed with water and watered my trees with the product as noted. The white flies on my orange tree were gone with one application.  As the meely bug situation on my grapefruit tree was a little more severe, I  re-treated ut after about 4 weeks and now the meely bug is completely gone.An excellent product for your citrus trees that is systemic, effective, easy to use ,and doesn't make a mess.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2022
review_content: To use this product, you need to use the included guide to determine how much you will need, once figured out, its just a matter of watering this into the base of your fruit trees. I use 20 gallon slow release watering bags that drip its contents over the course of 10 or 12 hours to ensure a slow and deep watering. I simply added my measured amount in the watering bag and let it slowly seep into the soil. This time last year I noticed some bugs on my trees, and perhaps its still too early, but I feel quite confident that this product is indeed actually working as advertised. Aphids are a common problem, and so far there is no sign of them since using this. This is simple to use, and for the listed price and effectiveness, I would consider it a great deal, especially when compared to the alternative of watching your fruit trees become overburdened by pests.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
review_content: I have many fruit and citrus trees in the yard and they needed a little bit of extra love - so I ordered this.  The price is right and it was easy to apply. Five stars.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2022
review_content: This took care of a small bug issue with our hobby fruit trees that had started to become more of a concern. Good value for the price and no harmful side effects that I can see, though the bugs would probably see that differently! Glad I decided to try it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2022
review_content: I'm a long time user of Bayer Advanced products for the garden.  I love their rose formula which keeps my plants in tip-top shape all season and year long.This is a systemic formula that gets absorbed by the roots to be used internally.It does a good job of protecting the plant without the hassle of spraying the foliage which can be difficult for larger trees.I find that it works pretty well.  I don't see any insect damage on my trees and I consider this a kind of insurance policy for my orchard.  I use it on lime, lemon, orange and avocado trees.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2022
review_content: If you have fruit trees, then you know what a pain it can be to keep them healthy. It seems there is always insects or some disease attacking them. I have tried many three in one products and they will work for a short time, but then the insects always come back and destroy them. This one is different. You do not have to worry about getting suited up and spraying dangerous chemicals all over the trees and getting it in the wind and on your stuff. Simply mix some in a container and gently poor it around the drip line of the tree. Smaller trees require much less so it will last a lot longer.It's not only easy to use, but it actually works! The leaves in our trees are so healthy and no trace of insects yet! I have seen them in my there plants munching away, but not on the fruit trees that I used this on. I couldn't be happier and it's just one less thing to worry about with my trees this year!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2022
review_content: This product does what it says it will. I used this on a dwarf lime tree a couple of months ago and as far as I can tell, it is working well. I haven't noticed any insect issues since then.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2022
review_content: I got this for our fruit trees. We have a grapefruit, kumquat, and a lime tree. We also have blackberry bushes, which don‚Äôt need it as they‚Äôre very resistant to bugs. Our biggest problem has been leaf miners and swallowtail caterpillars. We try not to kill swallowtails but instead relocate them. The leaf miners are maddening, though. I found the instructions for this to be extremely complex. There‚Äôs a different instruction for each kind of tree. It‚Äôs very thorough for anyone who needs to know how long to wait before eating any fruit. It was easy to measure out without spilling because of the little cup it comes with. I used it in a pressure pump type of sprayer. I‚Äôll report back later if it takes care of the leaf miners because very few things have worked in the past. It also doesn‚Äôt have too pungent a smell. That‚Äôs a big plus.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2022
review_content: I have used several different types of BioAdvanced products. I‚Äôve been waiting several days to see the results and review this product.The product has been helping me get rid of leaf-miners on my citrus tree.I use it for my indoor plants as well. Some plants are highly sensitive, they handle well near this stuff. Will buy more.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2022
review_content: BioAdvanced gives us a fantastic insect control solution for fruit and nut trees. The active ingredient is imadacloprid, which is a very effective insecticide, killing a wide range of bugs from apids to scale to leafhopper and more!! Because it can be taken up by through the roots and than transported throughout the plant, you get fantastic protection. Application is very easy since this is a liquid formulation. You dilute the insecticide and apply around the base of the tree. As with all pesticides for your safety and for the safety of the environment, it is very important to follow the instructions, including amount of to apply to each tree, and how often you can apply each year (only once).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2022
review_content: I have been using BioAdvanced products for several years and have had good success with them. So far, there have been no sign of bugs or other problems.  I wish I would have used it sooner.This is simple to use, much like the ash treatment.  You just mix an ounce in a gallon of water and pour it around the tree.  The tree draws it in through the roots and repels insects.  Couldn't be easier.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: After YEARS!, I mean YEARS of what I learned last year was ‚ÄòScale‚Äô growing on my mum‚Äôs Japanese Magnolia Trees (2) (see the pic = YUCK!) I did some research, and learned about this product. Initially, I tried to treat the plant using just diluted Neem Oil spray. Unfortunately, the treatment did more damage than good (when treating w/Neem oil it really has to be diluted or it will burn the plant‚Äôs leaves, etc..)..Apparently, all I needed to do was get this stuff, Shake out a bit and scatter it around the base of the trees. The way this product works, is that the product sits at the base of the plant, and when watered, the product then soaks into the ground and the plant then uptakes the product into its system, and when the pests (scale, gnats, aphids, etc..), attack the plant, they basically get a mouth full of YUCK!ü§Æ and either die or go away. DO NOT USE WHEN RAINING! as the product will not soak into the ground and treat that specific plant, but instead, it will go where ever the water goes and potentially contaminate your garden and any edible plants growing nearby, and you DO NOT want to EAT anything treated by this product!I figured ‚ÄúMeh, Why Not?!‚Äù I‚Äôll give it a try at least, at approx. $23USD, it was well worth it to try.Around February, I had my mum (82yo) treat the trees, which consisted of just shaking out the designated amount of product and tossing It around underneath both trees. I stated her age to emphasize that anyone can use this product, it‚Äôs that easy to use.By March, both of her Japanese Magnolia trees put out blooms like they had not in YEARS! I mean they were GORGEOUS! We had neighbors comment on how beautiful the trees were. All that, compared to previous years, where both trees were sickly, covered in leaves, but few if any blooms, and almost every joint in the trees had these yellow black ‚Äòlumps‚Äô. I now know the ‚Äòlumps‚Äô were ‚Äòscale‚Äô, and the black stuff was likely black soot/fungus. We live with some tall trees behind us/on our east side and the trees although located further out in the yard, probably both were infected by the black soot being in the air/drifting on the wind and landing on the trees. But, after this treatment, all GONE! *smiles*üòÅüëçüèºI HIGHLY RECOMMEND You try this product on ANY ‚ÄúNON-Edible‚Äù plant. Do NOT use on ANYTHING You plan to EAT! Because, this product works by your plant up-taking it into the plant itself and distributing it throughout the plant‚Äôs roots, stems, leaves, blooms/fruit, etc...Also, You only need to make sure to use this product far enough in advance of Spring/Summer that the plant has time enough to up-take it and distribute it internally. BEST OF ALL, You only need to use this product ONCE every YEAR!! (12mths!)‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢> PRO‚Äôs: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ EASY USE - Just Shake it out and distribute it under the plant at the base.‚Ä¢ PESTS / Lots! = This product treats a WIDE VARIETY of plant pests and disease(s).‚Ä¢ QUANTITY / Lasts! = Depending upon the area/plants you wish to treat, it really only takes a little bit of product. Plus, as You only need to apply the product ONCE YEARLY, a little bit goes a long way, and the container size should last you a long time.‚Ä¢ ANNUALLY = You only need to apply this product ONCE YEARLY!‚Ä¢ COST = The approx $23 cost is minimal when you consider the quantity you get, along with the amount of product needed to treat a plant, considering all of that, the price is cheap!‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢> CON‚Äôs: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ TOXIC = This product is toxic enough that it should NOT be used on ANY plant that produces Edible Produce/Fruit. Because the plant up-takes the product into ALL parts of the plant, the stem, leaves, blooms/fruit, so that anything edible will be full of this toxic product, not edible and toxic if eaten.‚Ä¢ CONTAMINATION = MUST be applied to plant at base on a dry day, because otherwise, the product will spread to where ever the water it sits in travels and can potentially contaminate other plants that produce edible fruit/produce, making it in edible or if eaten, potentially poison whomever eats it.‚Ä¢ TIMING = Must be applied early enough before Spring/Summer that the plant has time to up-take the product into itself internally and distribute it through out itself.‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢> OVERALL OPINION: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢Overall I feel this is a GREAT product to use and try, it worked WONDERS to completely cure two very over run and sickly Japanese Magnolia Trees, which are now producing Gorgeous Blooms! And, I no longer feel bad/guilty, because the trees look so bad/sickly (& I don‚Äôt have to worry about the scale spreading to our other plants!!) Unfortunately, I do not have any of the pics from the trees blooming this year, because I waited too long and there has been so much rain, BUT, I‚Äôll try to update with pics next time they bloom, to show you just how gorgeous the tree and blooms are now, all cured, green lush and entirely covered in beautiful purple flowers!üòÅüëçüèº

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: I had to use this on my Aloe Cacti I brought home from the Outdoor Market that were selling plants and they had rolley polley all in the bottom of the container and where coming out and trying to go to my other plants.  So I had to use this right away in the the summer heat to protect my other potted plants and it burned all the bottom leaves , so I am glad I waited before putting it in any of my other new nursery plants and will have to wait until it is cool outside before subjecting them to this hopefully they won't get any bugs until the cooler temps get here.  So summer is a definate NO for using this product.  Also it has food in it so there is no need to buy food too because it has it in it.  But all the bugs are gone and I expect that this product will do what it is supposed to do but you will get some burning, if done right you plants should live and recover.  I would give less than the recommended 6 mo dose and I would give it in Sep 15 and  March 15 every year. It burned my plant for about two weeks before it quit burning and I would give it a good wash with water if you see it burning so it will get down into the planter or ground and the concentrate dissapates.  It works it just a bummer to see your plants get burned from a needed product when they looked good before.Update:  It is October now and it is 90 degrees daytime and 60 at night  now and I have had no trouble putting this on my Oleander what so ever or my Agave Cacti in small doses at a time.  Because of the experience with my Aloe Cacti I have learned it is better to just divy up the portions  that I would be giving them in September and in March and take those 2 doses and making it 1 and then dividing it by 6 months and that is what I am feeding the plant every month during the WINTER.  That way when spring comes and the bugs hatch outside my plants will be fertilized from the Winter feedings and will stay away from them until it gets to hot for the bugs and I won't have to worry about burning them in the spring when the weather starts turning hot/cold.  This way it is in the plants root system.  It is just to hot where I live and no shade is cause for disaster.  I did use this on a Boxwood and it does not like it at all.  The leaves are not dark green anymore and are drying up so it works good on some plants and others it can be sensitive to.  Now my Agave is not having any problems with it and it; babies are shooting out from the soil.  But I am only giving tsp measurements every month because I don't want to risk burning my plants.  As far any tree goes  the label does say (not to use) it on a certain tree but I can't remember the name right now.  But it definately is hit and miss with this product  depending on the plant species lets see what happens after a winter of feeding and see it the bugs stay away in the spring that will be the real test come spring I will let you know then.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2023
review_content: I had several gardenia and ixora bushes that were struggling with black fungus on their branches and leaves.  I applied one treatment of these granules and within 2 weeks all the fungus was completely gone.Not only was the fungus gone, but the leaves and new growth looked happier and healthier too. $60 for a jug of these granules may seem like a lot, but considering you apply this just once a year, I think it's actually a way better investment than those cheaper products that don't even work half as well.The only issue that I had was that I didn't read the instructions well enough and I applied this to all my trees and shrubs  - - - including the lemon and orange trees.It did a fantastic job getting rid of the aphids and white fly on those citrus trees, but evidently this product is taken up into the plant via the roots, so the product affects any fruit borne from the tree as well.I applied it last summer so we will just forgo consuming any lemons and oranges for a year.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2023
review_content: I am choosing three stars only because the product arrived without the measuring cup that is supposed to be on the top of the bottle.  This is an amazon issue, not a Bayer issue.  Otherwise, so far so good but I just drenched my Brush Cherry which is lousy with psyllids.  I am hoping this will do the trick and rid me of these nasty little buggers.Not getting the measuring cup wasn't a big deal but just wanted to mention it and also how I got around it.  DO NOT USE a measuring cup from your kitchen.  This is poison and the instructions which you really need to read state: never use anything for food prep with this product.  I used an old margarine cup, what one normally tosses in the trash after the butter is gone.  I needed to mix 11 ounces of this stuff so I put 11 ounces of water in the disposable cup, marked it with a sharpie, dumped the water in a plant (can't waste water in California) and then filled the cup with the poison/fertilizer to the line.  Then mixed with water and then drenched my brush cherry roots.  Easy peasy.If this rids me of the psyllids, I will come back and change my rating up to 5 stars.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2023
review_content: I used to get Magnolia Scale every summer on our Magnolia tree, and was considering removing it. Even though the tree was not dying, the scale produces a sticky sap dripping from the tree which attracts mass quantities of wasps. It was like every wasp in the county was on my tree which is located near our front door.Total game changer and the scale is completely cured. I love that I do not have to spray the tree, and that it only needs to be applied once a season. I put it down before the tree leafs out in like April(near Chicago) Also I put it down under the mulch by digging a trench in a circle around the tree and spreading the granuals in the trench. I use the whole jug, and cover the pesticide with soil and mulch to try to protect animals from coming in contact with it. It then soaks down into the ground with rain water and is taken up by the tree through the roots.Works GreatThanks for reading my review

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2023
review_content: Well, I bought this on a Friday installed it on Sunday. It rained Sunday night and a little drizzle on Monday. I planted them the third time with much care and even to see one struggling is heartbreaking. I studied them and I noticed that our backyard has a lot of white flies and mosquitoes. These pesky things were attacking my trees and I couldn‚Äôt find anything that would stop them. I even bought some Neem spray and that didn‚Äôt work because each day the pesky flies would return.I saw this product on Amazon, read the reviews, and I said I‚Äôll try it. From what I‚Äôm seeing, I think it‚Äôs going to work. The browning/rusty color is not all the way gone but I can tell it‚Äôs doing better.I would definitely recommend this product. Thanks to the makers of it, I may will be able to see the beauty of healthy trees by the end of this summer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2023
review_content: I owe a lot to this product.  My large bonsai-styled black pine had a moderate beetle infestation, evident by appearance of small holes on trunk made by woodpeckers to get at the grubs, visible gummy and sawdust looking crap in some cracks of the bark, and a large bald spot on the trunk due to bark loss.  I was in a panic because it is my favorite tree in the garden and one of the main trunks was already looking compromised as a couple of extremities had already died.  I read that imidocloprid was the only thing that could help the situation so I researched and found this product.  Upon using it for one season, the damage/infestation seems to have been halted.  We cut off the dead branches and the rest of the tree is now doing pretty well.  It was the first time I'd seen it shoot up amazing long "candles" from every branch.  The needles are long, thick, and green.  I'm very thankful for what it has done for my sick tree.  I split this bottle between my black pine and cypress and they're both just lovely.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2022
review_content: We built a house, therefore the backyard was dirt. After a visit to a well known nursery in the area and a huge amount invested in plants (no idea what I was thinking) we headed on home. About a year later I noticed these brown looking bumps all over the branches that came off if I picked them and the leaves of my 19 Indian Laurel Columns looked wet. We discovered it was scale . Never even knew there was such a thing. After heading back to the nursery who gave us one bottle of their product , which I knew was not going to be enough for a total of 22 plants, I googled and came across this product. We purchase 2 bottles due to the plants being very close to each other. I didn‚Äôt want to exceed the recommended amount per acre.We had to apply in May in AZ due to how bad the scale was and it is now July and the scale is flaking off and the plants are happy again. No more wet leaves. I will be applying every year to keep the bugs in check. I use it on the Jacaranda, Hibiscus and Laurels. The $100 a year this will cost us is well worth it to ensure we are doing everything we can to protect our investment.February 2023 update: scale was completely gone from the laurels by the end of 2022. Now back to purchase what will be our yearly treatment for 2023.
