review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2023
review_content: It's too early for me to write a review on how well this product works, but it's not too early for me to write a review on the value for the money.The largest container available (10lbs of granules) covers a whopping three established trees with 30 inch circumference trunks at 4 feet off the ground. These are mature trees, but they are not enormous. The comparable size container of liquid concentrate covers roughly the same amount, so it's not any better bang for your buck.With the massive amount of this product that you need to put around each tree, they should sell it by the 5 gallon bucket or 55 gallon drum. I only have around 30 trees to treat. God help you if you're trying to save a moderately wooded yard from invasive bugs!Here's hoping the product works for this price per tree.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2023
review_content: Like another reviewer, I have used both the Granules and Liquid form of this product, on trees. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2015
review_content: I bought this product because it is recommended to control wooly aphids on hackberry trees. I discovered this problem about three years ago when a hackberry tree on the corner of the patio started depositing black residue on everything underneath. I treated the tree late last fall, even though I knew it was too late. But, I hoped the systemic insecticide would be stored by the roots as the tree went dormant.I also treated a river birch that always had about half the leaves infested with something that distorted the leaf and had a bumpy texture. This is a big tree and I had no idea how to use a spray.In April, as the leaves began to bud, I did a full treatment on the hackberry. We had a very wet spring, and the roots should have had a good dose.In June, the hackberry looks very healthy. I have not seen any of the wooly aphids. But, the jury is still out on whether this works. July and August is when it happens.I do want to report that the river birch looks great. The leaves are shiny and dark green. This is a notable difference. I do not see any infested leaves. That is a Wow.I'm starting to like this product. I'm tempted to use it on all my ornamentals.UpdateIt is now August 12, and there is no sign of the aphid infestation. I do occasionally see one of the little bastards floating in the air, but not like in the past. There is no black residue below the tree. I also treated a crepe myrtle near the tree that usually got covered with the residue, and that plant has been amazing. It might be the fertilizer, but the leaves are bigger and dark green, and the flowers are awesome.UpdateOctober 12. I say it worked.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2013
review_content: I have a hackberry tree and for years it had "hackberry nipple gall." This is when the leaves of the hackberry tree get yellow bumps on them. I was told hackberry nipple gall doesn't hurt the tree by the folks at the local nursery but it sure looked bad.  It was like the tree had a disease.The Bayer Tree and Shrub Protect and Feed Concentrate was recommended by this same nursery. I purchased it and applied it exactly per instruction on the container. It is a systemic product so it takes a while to be absorbed into the tree. We treated our tree in the late fall of 2012. When spring sprung and the leaves emerged the hackberry nipple gall was a no issue.  I would estimate the gall was reduced by 95% and this is with only one treatment.I will treat the tree again this fall as I did last fall and expect there will be no infestation of the dreaded hackberry nipple gall.This is the only tree I've treated with this product. My first purchase of this product was at the nursery and have switched to Amazon.com because of better pricing.August 2014.I'm still happy with this product. Since treating my hackberry tree, which is doing just fine with zero sign of the nipple gall, I've also treated some of my ash trees that became infested with leaf curling aphids. Once again it took a while for the product to be absorbed into the tree but once it got there the aphids just disappeared. Took about 4 weeks.I have also started applying this product to my trees in the early spring versus late fall. My wife read the label and I was reprogrammed... Ha.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2022
review_content: CAUTION: These products are very toxic to bees. Avoid treating plants when possible. If making an application, wait until after the trees or shrubs have finished flowering to reduce pesticide exposure to bees. Do not apply systemic insecticides to the soil when bee attractive flowers are planted directly adjacent to trees.  Also, do not use on fruit or vegetable plants as the product does carry through the plant systems.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2015
review_content: I have been using this for several years on several large Leyland Cypress trees and two large River Birches in our yard. review_content: Came one home day and noticed some of my arborvitae‚Äôs were infested.  I immediately began to pull the bag worms off the trees.  Then I went online and purchased this product.  I know I pulled at least 200 bag worms off the tree and there were many more that were not easily found.  So i sprayed the tree with this product 2 times - one week between spraying. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review_content: We recently planted a couple of grape vines in our Tucson, Arizona backyard and after a few weeks noticed that some of the leaves were starting to get eaten by tiny, 1/8" long, yellow and black striped caterpillars.  These things were eating the leaves from the bottom side up.  I looked on Amazon and immediately found this Bonide brand Thuricide-based product and bought it hoping it would work.It most certainly worked!  It took two applications over a period of two days, following the instructions, and, most importantly -- making sure to spray UNDER THE LEAVES directly on the pests.  After two days they were 100 percent dead, as in completely dried up and turned into little shriveled up caterpillar skeletons.  After the first day there were still maybe 30% still alive, but I attribute that to the initial, too-quick, application I did on the leaves.  However, after spraying the product on the leaves the second day, and making sure I sprayed under all the leaves, that ended up ensuring they were all dead by the third day.It does smell a little funny, but that's OK.  It stains, but seems to wash off without any problems and is not permanent.  The reason I downgraded it one star was, as others have noted, is that it only contains 15% Thuricide.  In my case, and since I don't anticipate using it too many times again (I hope), it doesn't matter because it's more than enough to last me a few years.  But if you're going to be using it a lot/very often, or have a lot of plants you need to treat, then I suggest you buy something else that has a higher concentration of the active ingredient.  I've seen on Amazon that there are a number of choices with a more than 80% concentration.  They're more expensive, but in the long run a better buy.But if you're looking for something cheap, easy to use, and you don't need a lot, then this Bonide brand Thuricide is a good buy.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
review_content: I had given up on growing tomatoes because I hated dealing with tomato worms and their damage to plants and fruit. The natural ingredient ‚ÄòBT‚Äô found in soil is concentrated in this product. I applied using a low cost sprayer every week or so. Moth eggs hatch to caterpillars which beginning eating immediately. The BT is ingested and kills the caterpillars within two days. I never saw a living caterpillar bigger than 1/2 inch.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2023
review_content: I had a couple of my pumpkin plants showing signs of vine borer damage. So worth it and I can use it next year if I have problems again, this saved my whole harvest!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2023
review_content: I bought a 16 ounce bottle of this Thuricide BT, kept it in the fridge, and used it for three years to keep the green worms off of my broccoli and kale. Each year, I had to mix it a little bit stronger. Now, at the end of the 3rd year, it‚Äôs still working, but I plan to buy a new bottle next spring. This stuff is amazing. For years, I tried to do organic gardening with diatomaceous earth. BT works 1000 times better. I even had pretty good success spraying my apple tree with it. If I spray the apples well every week or two and after each heavy rain, they didn‚Äôt get worms.I injected it with a syringe into the stalks of my zucchini and was able to beat the zucchini stock borers.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: If you grow cannabis outdoors and didn't use something like this product I imagine you've experienced moth larvae in your buds late season if you live in certain areas. It makes it look like bud rot. If so, if you use this as directed it will work perfectly. I even tested it. I purposely didn't spray a couple bud sites on certain branches of a few plants and makerd them to keep an eye on them. I've seen what they can do to crops. The ones I sprayed were 100% untouched. ALL the ones I didn't spray late season were ruined by the little larvae worms. They burrow into the bud down into the stem of the bud and kills it. And who wants to smoke or cook with wormy buds? Not I. Seriously guys and gals, if you're looking for thuricide bacillus thuringiensis also called (Bt), which is what makes it so these larvae won't eat, this is your stuff. I personally don't think I'll take a chance with another since I know it works and it's safe if you follow the directions.Don't forget to pick up miticide also my grower friends. You'll need to get that also. This is for leaf worms and the like.  Happy growing! Whatever you grow.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
review_content: I have a smallish garden and plant one zucchini plant a season.  Last year, worms got to the zucchini and I lost it halfway through the season.  That would've been the case again this year, until I heard about Thuricide.  Since I don't need much, I mixed 1/2 tsp. in a spray bottle with 1 quart of water.  I spray it on my zucchini, tomato, collard, and kale plants about once a week at dusk, and also the night after it rains, as the rain washes away the Thuricide.  The first time I used it, I was amazed to see the black worms jump off the plant and onto the dirt!  They were NOT happy.  Since I don't need even the reduced quart of Thuricide mix, I unscrew the sprayer and pour the remaining amount on the zucchini plant itself to ensure it's well treated. As a result, while the main stem of my zucchini plant does not look good at all, the plant keeps on producing zucchinis.  If I fall down on the job, the worms come back and I'll lose a couple baby zucchinis, but the plant recovers and keeps on going.  Those zucchinis must have lots of anti-oxidants!  Do not hesitate to buy this.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2019
review_content: I have an aquaponics system with fish I plan on eating in the future. A Miller Moth got into my indoor garden and I ended up with little inch worms eating my Kale. I sprayed this product on the kale and surrounding plants, waited a few days and sprayed again. I went from having dozens of caterpillars to none within 10-14 days. The instructions say to add something to help it stick to your plants. In my case I didn't see the point. Even though the caterpillars would be on the bottom side of the leaf I only sprayed the tops since they were eating through the leaf, leaving a hole so they still ate this stuff and killed them. I didn't have any issues with my aquaponics system after. I checked the water quality before, 24 hours after the 1st spray, before the second spray, 24 hours after the 2nd spray and continued my weekly water conditions and I never saw an increase or decrease in any of the tests. Fish are healthy, plants look great, and everything I've eaten since then has tasted way better than anythin I can buy at the store.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2017
review_content: We‚Äôve had a statewide Gypsy Moth caterpillar infestation this summer and they were attacking my apple tree and eating all the leaves so after a quick Google search I picked up some of this.This looks and smells almost exactly like green permanent marker so I definitely recommend wearing latex gloves while mixing and spraying this.  I mixed this at 4 teaspoons to the gallon in my 2 gallon sprayer and added about half a cup of molasses (recommended in the instructions to make it stick).  The spraying process was not fun and you should expect to get it everywhere and end up sticky and unhappy afterwards - especially when spraying overhead - but it was definitely worth it.After about a week I started to see results and there were no more large caterpillars.  I still need to do a second spray (the instructions recommend spraying two times, two weeks apart) but so far it is working well and there is no additional damage to my tree.While this smells unpleasant and is sticky to use this works incredibly well and is worth every moment of discomfort if I can save my tree.  I highly recommend it!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2015
review_content: First time indoor gardener, already had a few fungus gnats flying around my place and about 2 weeks after I started my veggies and herbs the gnats had gotten pretty bad. I had so many sticky traps I dubbed it "Flauschwitz". The traps were sticking more and more of the adults but I took a closer look at one of the pots one day and saw a ton of larvae crawling on it. Did some quick research on forums and products and came across this, even though it doesn't say it controls fungus gnats it was recommended by other growers. They have essentially the same life cycle/eating habits of other larvae anyway. It's been 5 days since I watered my plants with this mix and I haven't seen one larvae in 2 days despite my topsoil still being very damp (prime habitat). Thought I saw some dead ones but they're so small that once they are dead it's hard to tell them from a piece of the dirt. Not 100% sure it has worked but it is looking like it did the trick quite well. Seems like some good stuff, and since you only use teaspoons to tablespoons per gallon of water this stuff will last me forever and allow me to keep those pesky gnats off my turf even when the adults are able to lay eggs that hatch.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
review_content: i started growing squash a few years ago.  The plants would have squash and look healthy.  Then one day the vines look droopy, and the next day they are dead. So far no plants have died.My secret  - I used an insulin needle to inject solution directly into vines the first day I noticed plants collapsing and dying. review_content: Having recently moved from CA to TX, we were unsure of the pests in our greenhouse garden this season. Most deadly were the Tomato Hornworm. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2023
review_content: It worked ok to get bugs off my roses. But when I tried it on other flowering plants (bacopa for instance) that had whiteflies it worked very poorly although label says it kills whiteflies. Even daily spraying didn't help. They claim it is also systemic - well I saw no evidence of that over several weeks because the whiteflies were just fine. I finally used Bonide's indoor houseplant systemic granules for insects and even though this flowering plant was outdoors in a pot, that worked although it took a few days. So while Rose Shield may be systemic for its fungicide I don't think it is for bugs since on other plants I tried literally for weeks, daily, to kill those whiteflies and they just kept coming. I could get the backs of leaves to be clear of all whiteflies while spraying but they came right back so I don't think it was due to eggs hatching. I think it just doesn't work as systemic for bugs. Or possibly it absorbs so slowly that your plant will be half-dead before it works. Next year I am going to start with Neem Oil, which works very slowly but if you start before the whiteflies show up it apparently works very well to keep them off your plants, according to what I have read.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2017

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
review_content: Do your research. Research the top ingredients of this product.Difenoconazole and Thiamethoxam appear to make spider mite infestations worsen, and speed up their reproduction.I can say from experience this is a fact.I purchased this as an effort to find a systemic that will work on Spider Mites, as I had a few houseplants that had very mild infestations (maybe one or two mites per leaf, no webbing etc)After using this product, the mites exploded and tripled. I resorted to using MiteX, which in the past would wipe out the mites quickly. They returned with a vengeance, and the MiteX did absolutely nothing. I then used Captain Jacks Deadbug brew, and the mites keep coming back next day, no matter how much I treat.Stupidly, I thought maybe I didnt apply enough of the Rose Shield. So I did a second application a few weeks later.Again, the spider mites came back, FAST, and MANY. Almost immediately after that second application.After doing some research, I found that the top ingredients in this product actually are known to worsen spider mite infestations.... so why on EARTH is Bonide listing Spider Mites as a controlled pest.I contacted Bonide for help with this.They had stated that the reason why this product didnt work is because I used it on houseplants. This is BS. They said the spider mites that I have on my houseplants must be different than the spider mites outdoors. Which again, BS. I have identified the mites Im battling as two-spotted and red mites, which are common to infect outdoor plants as well as houseplants.They seemed more concerned about me using this product on houseplants. I figured since the bottle said that the area was safe to inhabit once the spray was dry, meant that it would be okay on houseplants as long as you weren't spraying them inside. But apparently not, apparently co-existing with plants indoors that were previously treated with this chemical is very dangerous to you and your pets health. I understand that houseplants werent listed on the label. But a lot of houseplants are considered ornamentals, which are listed on the label.So 3 reasons I cant recommend this product:-It doesnt work as described-It seems to be more dangerous of a chemical than the label makes it seem-Poor customer service

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2021
review_content: I normally use the spray bottle, but it was only available as the hose end sprayer on clearance where I bought it last. As others have said the sprayer is difficult to control. I reccomend applying at night for 2 reasons. 1. It will kill bees if it comes directly in contact with them. The residue will not kill them if sprayed a few hours before they start foraging for pollen. 2. The scent seems to REALLY stir up wasps. If you have wasps in the application area spraying when they are active may pose a safety issue. Other than that, my plants appear much healthier for a few weeks after application. I use a separate for fungal issues, but it's a good insect broad spectrum.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2019
review_content: I bought this insect spray for my prize rose bush that had an pretty good attack aphids and midges.  After reading the reviews I was just that more careful in reading directions and the hook up to the hose.  There was absolutely no problem.  You will need to pull back on the stop before you can move the sprayer (I found this a little hard but pulled back as far as I could then used a small straight screwdriver to pull back the rest).  I was careful in connecting the hose and did not tighten it too tightly.  And walla it worked the sprayer worked beautifully.  The rose bush is covered and it was easy.  In detaching it I used the same gentle manner.  I turned the sprayer to the stop position and replaced the stop.  I did not encounter leaking or broken attachments.  On the issue of smell yes there is a smell but it is very mild.  I cannot understand how others found it to be strong unless they were spraying it on directly without mixing it with water.  Anyway it is mild and not unpleasant.  I will wait to see it's effectiveness on the eradication of the pests however I know from experience with other natural essential oil repellents that they do work.  I will post the results later.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
review_content: We took all of our grass out in our front yard and back and decided to go xeriscape with only laying down leaves so that they eventually mulch into the soil. Well...the leaves are working and the soil is rich but that brought in lots of Japanese beetle grubs and the armadillos/skunks were having at it on our yard both front and back.After spreading granules from this product, it eventually wiped out all the grubs and I have very little (if any at all) armadillos/skunks coming into our yard. I spread this now at least once a year seeing I continue to mulch my yard with leaves from the fall.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2018
review_content: I just assumed that as this is a granular product that it was meant to be activated by rainfall and actually laid this out as it was drizzling outside. I only checked after it had turned into a downpour that it wasn't meant to be laid down that way so I was very worried that I did this all for nothing. Additionally, based on the reviews it seemed that I was putting this down way too late (September 20th). Well all I knew was I had very small grubs infesting my entire lawn and that we were expecting more warm weather (daytime weather between 70-80s, nights in the 60s). So I took my chances. Today September 26th I checked the soil. The grubs are all dead with just a few stragglers struggling to move. When exposed to air they just seem to stretch a bit like I disturbed their sleep and then won't burrow down like they normally did. This is very unlike they were before I laid down the Merit, so it is clearly working and working great. I'm very impressed with this product and am leaving this review in case it can help someone else. Thank you!Here we are now in May of 2019 and I just wanted to add a few details. The entire insect life was completely eradicated by this product. I would like to say that I still would have used this product because I live at a NJ home that didn't receive any lawn care for probably 30 years. Lifting just one paver on my lawn would expose about 30 grubs, so I literally felt that I was at ground zero for the Japanese beetle problem. I had skunks, an army of birds, opposums, racoons, you name it digging up my lawn at all hours of the day and night. Now however I am trying to make the soil healthy and know this is unnatural and not good, not to have a single earthworm etc. left over. I can't say with absolute certainty that it was the Merit, it could be that the Tenacity weed killer I've used also contributed to this but be aware that this is a very strong product.  Once you get your problem under control or you only have a minor problem, I would choose a product that is less harmful to all the other insects and bees as those bugs are very important to your soil health and if you are growing flowers and/or have a garden.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2018
review_content: Works extremely well, but seems to wash out with a heavy rain.This is the 8th summer I've had here at my house in Columbus, OH.  I almost always see grub damage begin towards the end of May; even if I apply the consumer-grade grub control that's available at the hardware store, I always see a little bit of damage.  This year I decided to try Merit, and there was 0 visible grub damage! ...Until just a few days ago.Here is my experience:I applied Merit in early may and successfully avoided the damage that I normally see towards the end of may/early june.I had an average amount of rain for the first 2 weeks of June, and all was well.However, the last 2 weeks of June had unusually heavy rain (bad enough that it caused lawn flooding).After the rain, I had 4 days of no rain.Sadly, now I see lots of fresh grub damage.I don't want to wait for a second delivery, so I purchased some grub killer at the local big box store and hopefully that + the residual merit will be enough to fend them off for the rest of the summer.I'm definitely going to buy this again next year, but I might buy 2 bags so I'm ready to re-apply in case it we get the same crazy amount of rain.

I used a scotts edge guard spreader on 4.Definitely a great buy!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2023
review_content: I have been using Merit for a few years after one year of learning that my brown easy-to-pull-up grass was a result of grubs. Merit fixed that. Then moving into a new home the lawn was green, but I started feeling soft areas in the lawn that were not there when I cut the grass a few times. There were also raised trails and a large patch of soft grass. I learned that I had moles! Moles eat grubs. Merit kills grubs (and other insects you may or may not want). Grubs and moles are now gone!I read reviews claiming Merit didn't work for them. I call that a likely user error. YOU MUST apply Merit at the appropriate time. If you don't, it will not work, or not work as well as it can. It's up to the user to do their homework because every environment/location is different. Watch the weather so you don't end up with it washed away because of too much rainfall. Most importantly, timing matters. You can't get rid of grubs if you apply Merit, or any other product at the wrong time. Don't expect results that you think should work if YOU apply it at the wrong time. Again, don't blame the product for that.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2023
review_content: I'll start by saying the reason I do not like using this product is because it can be harmful to beneficial insects like bees and lady bugs.  I try to limit usage to target grubs and plants that are infested with bugs like aphids  when less aggressive treatments don't seem to work.I initially found out about the active ingredient Imidacloprid when researching how to fix issues with grubs ruining the lawn.  That's when I learned the plants will absorb imidacloprid and will kill the insects when they eat the plant.  Imidacloprid seemed to work great at eradicating grubs from my lawn.I picked up this bottle of liquid concentrate for its low price and to use with both 1 gallon pump type sprayer and also hose end sprayer.  My lawn is only around 1,000sf so I dont really need alot of this stuff.  I already have a bunch of old hose end sprayer bottles from other lawn care products so I didn't need another spray bottle.  To spray the lawn for things like ants I'll just add a few ounces to an old spray bottle, I'll use a bottle that was labeled to have the same coverage rate, which would be 32oz for around 5,000sf.  For my 1 gallon pump sprayer I'll mix the labeled rate of 1/2oz per gallon.For grubs in the ground I'll mix up the recommended rate on the professional type products, which would be 15oz of this product per gallon of water which will cover 1,000sf.  I'll walk around and spray the lawn using the pump type sprayer and then go back and water it in.  I'll do this around the end of June.  I'll do this just for grubs, everything else I use the rates listed on the bottle.

review_content: We live in Southern Georgia & we were *swarmed* with ants, into everything, crawling in the pet's food bowls, etc. NOTHING helped, or only lasted a few days. I did the 3oz:1 gallon ration & went around our entire house from about 3ft up on the wall to about 3ft out on the ground. I also sprayed every inch of our 3 wooden porches at the front & 2 back doors. It took about 2 days to kick in, but now it's been 2 weeks & I have seen ZERO ANTS!! YES! This week I am going to spray the trunks of our multiple trees in the yard from about 6ft on down to the ground...*We also are *blessed* in this area with something called 'palmetto bugs', which are basically a cockroach almost the size of your pinky finger!! Luckily, they generally stay outside in the bushes, leaf litter, etc. Once in a blue moon you'll see one inside, but that's not very often at all, thankfully. IT KILLED THOSE TOO!! Woohoooo!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2018
review_content: Cluster Flies.In the 10 years we have been here every summer has resulted in hundreds stuck to stick strips hung in our 5 picture windows. A couple boxes worth on average. Outdoors sunny side of house would see them by the scores or hundreds. All of that, even after using the exotic stuff found in pricier scientific concentration quantities at stores like A_way. While over 95% of brand labels don't even mention cluster flies.Well this season, with this stuff, I may have found the solution. First warm day I saw flies basking on side of house, I simply made a batch of this stuff and sprayed off the first 80 or so from the side of the house. And then --- MOST importantly I double sprayed the ground beneath that morning sun side of the house.With cluster flies this is the secret. The treatment must already be in place on the ground where and when the larvae TRANSITION into adults.The WHEN (which day and time) is going to be the first warm (over 64F) sunny MORNING after snow has melted. In past years I did not think a weeks wait mattered. This year I ordered early to be ready for the first signs of that chrysalis day or whatever they call it.I swear. Seems too good to be true but so far it has been a week and the only flies I have seen have been random individual flies.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2021
review_content: This is a highly effective and economical insect killer. As always, mid-July brought the leaf-eating bugs -- including Japanese Beetles -- and for the cost of a couple bags of chips, this insecticide exterminated everything.It attaches to the hose and creates a leak-less seal, then shoots from its nozzle colorless, clear, and scentless, and with ample pressure and distance. Then it just keeps on coming: While it may ludicrously overstate its coverage at 5000+ square feet, it still exceeded my own non-measured, common sense expectations, adding to its great economy. Bugs went belly-up all over our patio, and with no negative impact on plant foliage.Apply in the morning so it can dissipate throughout the day, and keep pets indoors for as long as you possibly can, as this is a purely chemical concoction. An elite product and elite value at this low price. - (Was this of use? If so, let me know by clicking "Helpful." Cheers!)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2019
review_content: I bought this on a whim after hearing the ingredients were awesome at getting rid of root aphids for plants like cannabis. It was pretty much the only info on treating root aphids successfully and quickly anyway. Peroxide didn't do anything and neem oil wasn't working (at least not fast enough). I was super nervous to try this on my house plants because I own well over 30 of them and didn't find much on it not harming plants, but decided to try it anyway. My plants were no longer thriving because of root aphids and about 15 plants were already infested on my window sill. I couldn't bring myself to get rid of any of them.I used the recommended dose for each gallon and watered my infected house plants with this stuff. I haven't seen any of the bugs crawling around on my sill or under my pots. And there's no longer any fungus gnats anywhere. Not even on the plants I didn't treat yet. I also have been spraying neem oil and have yellow sticky traps out to be safe,  but this is what killed them all off instantly. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2015
review_content: Works awesome for mosquito and wood ticks in the upper midwest.  As some have "complained", you do need to reapply every 4-6 weeks, which in my opinion is simply common sense, its not going to last forever during rain and new grass growth etc.  2-3 applications every summer and you see significantly less mosquitoes and wood ticks every time within 24 hours.  Simply reapply every 4-6 weeks when you see the mosquito population hatching again. You will actually be able to enjoy your shady areas during the day in the summer without being eaten alive.  We just moved to a new home with lots of "old growth" that has been undisturbed for years that allowed the wood ticks to grow out of control.  Our 6 children were each picking multiple wood ticks off every day, within 24 hours of spraying, and now over the last week, we have seen 1 single wood tick, not the dozens we were seeing prior and no mosquitoes.  I have used this product for approximately 5 years and will continue to buy religiously.  Best bug control I have ever seen, don't waste your time fogging, etc.

review_content: I typically use propiconozole as my main fungicide but wanted to change it up which is a good idea to do! I noticed quick results within 2-3 days! review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
review_content: This stuff is amazing.  It is the only product I have found that takes care of TARR (Take All Root Rot) in my St. Augustine lawn.  I wasted a lot of $ on Scotts fungus cure before doing some research (to figure out exactly what was killing my lawn) and finding this stuff.  I treat with this the week before I do my twice a year lawn fertilizing or any broad spectrum weed and feed products as these products weaken the grass's ability to fight the fungus.  Before I got the root rot under control, I treated with this product, put a good layer of peat moss down on the rhizomes (the fungus does not like an acidic environment) of the grass (a very dirty, time consuming, but worthwhile endeavor), and retreated 2 weeks later.  I also currently patch treat with sulfur, peat or this fungicide whenever I see the grass go chlorotic in any of the problem areas, clears up the problem every time.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: I've noticed oak trees were browning before fall for some time now. Two years my oak did the same thing. I read about several blights and insects that could cause the problem and decided to do something. This is what I came up with to try and save the tree.This tree measured 66" in girth at chest height.I sat three 5 gallon buckets with a 3/16" hole drilled in the bottom of each around the base of my tree.In a separate 5 gallon bucket I mixed:* 4 gallons of water.* 22 ounces of Imadacloprid systemic insecticide.* 4 ounces of Eagle 20EW systemic fungicide.* 24 ounces of liquid fertilizer in hopes the roots would better absorb the solution if the fertilizer would act as a carrier.* Then I filled each bucket with this mixture.¬† (So times 3)Attached is a picture of the oak tree over a year later. So far I don't see any blight or insect damage at all. Maybe that concoction works!?!PLEASE NOTICE: While I did read and follow label directions for the insecticide and fertilizer, this use may not be according to label directions for Eagle 20EW. Please consult with your local county extension office.

review_content: I'm a new homeowner and I started noticing brown patch on my once beautiful lawn. Within a week of using Eagle 20EW, most of the grass that wasn't too badly damaged started to turn green again.  I just applied a 2nd treatment 2 weeks later to make sure it's all gone.  The best part is that you get a lot of applications from the 16 oz bottle and I'll be able to use it next season too (hopefully just as a preventative).  Although I plan to rotate with a different category fungicide as recommended to prevent the fungus from developing a resistance.My recommendation is to use gloves and eye protection while handling and applying, and maybe even a mask (I didn't do this part) just in case the wind blows it back in your face.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
review_content: I decided to try this instead of Immunox same active ingredient but a lot higher concentration and a lot less expensive per application, I had to do some math to calculate the amount to add to a 4 gallon backpack sprayer, and it is only 1.25 teaspoons per tank so this will last for a long time, but how did it work? I sprayed the trees from green tip to petal fall. When the leaves fully enlarged I saw apple scab and thought it didn't work, but then to my surprise the leaves with the apple scab started withering, and now as it is almost harvest time the trees look healthier than they have in 10 years!!! Finally a product that works to control apple scab on my old apple trees!!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2015
review_content: I have a few hundred Fruit trees in my orchard and have never had trouble with mice and voles girdling the trunks before. The last two winters have been the coldest on record and I had 10 trees stripped right down to bare wood. I was able to successfully 'Bridge' Graft 4 of them and start new grafts on the rest. However I needed something to keep it from happening again. The University recommended adding copper to the white Latex paint that I use to protect from sunscald. When I received the Liquid-Cop there was nothing on the label about this so I contacted the company. They had never heard of using it in this manner. I contacted some of the bigger orchards and the university and it seems a good amount is the maximum use called on the label which is 4 Tablespoons per Gallon along with a cup of pine pitch which I have plenty of. This way I will get two benefits from one process. My wife and I paint in the spring but will now switch to the fall. this will keep the critters from chewing and protect from sunscald in the spring.I also have leaf shot so I sprayed for that about 2 weeks ago. All of the new growth is clean and shot-free. I may still use the lime-sulfur for the tougher issues like Black Knot on Plum trees but this is safe to use on apricots so it will be my main fungus treatment from now on.I was using a Lime Sulphur mix for fungus in my orchard. I received a notice not to use it on Apricots as it can kill them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2022
review_content: MIRACLE HAPPINESS.pine trees can get bagworms that eat the pine needles, that wasnt my problem.  (if you do have any type of pine tree/ bush and have bagworms ugly black worms that turn into white moths, and eat the pine needles, or bush leaves, get bifiden) my problem was a fungus that makes  the needles fall off and from growing again called needlecast.  i have many pine trees and 3 were really bad 1 almost gone,  trying to save it.  after one dousing good application and fertilizer stakes to encourage new growth,  several that has some of this are like new.  2 of the 3 which were really bad are almost there, and 1 which was almost dead with no needles, I am trying to bring back.  the bad and kinda bad ones i did 2 applications so far  2 weeks apart, bc it rained a lot.  but this stuff kills the fungus and the needles come back.  it makes enough for me to use it for 5 years this little container.WORD TO THE WISE. after you mix this with water, only a couple oz are needed per gallon, use the mix, if you let it sit it gets ugly stick black,  use it and rinse the container out.dont spray near a white fence, will turn black.clean up any that spills when you mix right away and no problem.  its really dark blue.thought it would be green. was surprised.I am going to spray the really bad trees every 2 weeks until like new, and the ones with a little bit just april, june, and sept.also for really good growth and vibrant pines, put the fertilizer stakes in april after ground isnt frozen, and in sept.  i didnt fertilize them in sept. before but now i do.  much better looking trees.if you happen to smell it in the wind, you get a faint catpiss scent.  very faint.  dont spray too close to your house it can stain the siding, shingles, paint, or dont do it on windy day. I would imagine if you have to spray close to house, if you have garden house on and ready you can just rinse it off it you do it right away

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2021
review_content: I bought this product because our lawn is ravaged by a fungus at the moment, and this and other potent fungicides are banned for home use in Ontario, the Canadian province in which I live. The product arrived at our door from Alabama by air freight and by courier quite promptly and in perfect condition. Alas, the shipping charges the exchange on the Canadian dollar, and customs duties all made this a VERY expensive undertaking. But, it does seem to have stopped the spread of the fungus, and we are now continuing to treat the fungus with lime sulphur, something that is reputed to be less effective, but as it is available here, it is 10% of the cost of importing this more effective fungicide. Our willingness to spend so much to get this product is an indication of how desperate we were. I can heartily recommend both the product and the vendor to American shoppers.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2022

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2013
review_content: I tried this product 2 years in a row, but it's failed me both times on my primarily tall fescue lawn.  I applied it in May 1 and June 1 both years only to see massive death to my lawn due to some kind of leaf spotting or fusarium blight, and i'm pretty sure a Pythium disease in some areas.  After having another recurrence starting this year, i did a lot of research and found that the active ingredient in Bayer (propiconazole)  is not that highly rated for those types of fungi. Thiophanate-methyl (which is actually found in the Scott's fungus control granules) is better rated, and for Pythium, you have to go with some heavy duty stuff not found at your Home Depot (but other places like do my own pest control dot com do have).  If you're having issues, search out NC State's Turf Files website. There's a ton of great info there.In any case, when i saw fungus starting up again in my yard this june, i bought a product called "Heritage" and coupled that with the Scotts product, and within a few days, the fungus started to retreat and the yard was recovering. I did a second application 2 weeks later and its under control. the areas that died didn't come back, but the grass that started to brown has recovered thankfully and it's not spreading like it did last year.the other thing to keep in mind when dealing with fungicides is that you can't use the same one too often or the fungus will build a tolerance to it, so it's good to find a couple different classes of products and rotate them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2022
review_content: The day after I applied the granuals and watered my lawn, it showed a greener lawn.  I did reapply after 14 days.  This seems to be getting rid of my sad lawn problems.  I will purchase it again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2015
review_content: Fertilizer promotes fungus growth so make sure you apply this product right after you fertilize if you've seen signs of fungus and bought this for that reason. I find that using this product with the second and third round of fertilizer spreading, in June and July, leaves my lawn free of the orange/yellow grass blades that occur from fungus growth after nitrogen fertilizer is spread. Don't make the mistake of over-watering the fungus areas, which many people do because it looks like the grass needs more water. It doesn't, and excess water actually aids the fungal growth. I use the same spreader that I use with the granular fertilizer and I do it immediately after spreading the fertilizer. Note that the granules of this product are quite light and will spread unevenly when the wind is blowing. Avoid that and apply when the wind calms down. Water the fertilizer and fungus control well after applying, then go back to your normal watering schedule.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2022
review_content: I have a few areas of lawn that stay damp and shaded well into fall/winter and generally get some disease. This stuff cures it right up in 1 or 2 treatments come spring time.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: Mixed review. I switched from scotts fungal killer which i saw immediate results after watering in. I brought bayer figuring the bag say it kills and cures...keyword cures....i put this down even more then bag reccomended(doesnt harm lawn period) to ensure the fungus would be killed and cured. Guess what? If it killed and cured i need to reseed because i have big dead holes with mad thatch....but when i used scotts the grass immediatly grew back entirely without holes...but with scotts the fungus returned 2 weeks later....with bayer i don't see fungus returning and at least bayer saved my lawn ...i only have to reseed...so i guess bayer wins for longer results....and a reseed....also I'm wondering if the fungus was immune to bayer? These issues can occur meaning its not the product but the fungus itself. Ok I'm tired now hope this review helps you make your decision.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: It's very good at its job: killing fungus.  Took care of my fungal issues on my flowers right away.  And it's natural, so you can use it on crops without worrying about tainting your veggies or accidentally poisoning small critters.My only issue with it is this: why doesn't it come with a small measuring cup or eye dropper?  You have to dilute this stuff (it's in industrial strength concentration) and it's hard to measure without some kind of small measuring device and you most certainly do not want to use your kitchen stuff on this.  Farmers and serious growers aren't going to buy the 8oz version, they go larger.  This size is for the weekend warrior, and weekend warriors don't have $1.5k+ spray machines that auto dilutes the mixture.  The manufacturer should tape a small pipette or eye dropper to can so it's easier to measure out.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2019
review_content: After searching to find something that would treat the many ails of this very fussy tree, I think this finally was a keeper.  After diluting per instruction, sprayed all surfaces - top and underneath - every leaf.  Spray once, then reapplied 7 days later, and one more time 14 days after that. It seems to have mostly stopped the scale and the leaf mildew.  The tree has definitely perked up, and thankfully, is flowering for the third time in as many months.  You have to be very careful with this solution. It is POISON to animals and not so great for humans either. Wear gloves, clean up any solution that drips onto the floor - and wash your hands.  Kind of a pain, but this tree is too, so yes it's worth it!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2023
review_content: I've been using this (concentrate) for a while now.  This small amount goes a long way however.  You need to dilute it well, and put it in to a regular spray bottle, so that you can spray leaves on plants.  My plants in particular are Lantana's.  There is a moth that lays eggs on the Lantana, and when they hatch, then they becomes small worms which will eat all of the young (new) growth on a Lantana bush.  However, if you use this sparingly (dilute it well), and spray the top side and bottom side of all Lantana bush leaves, then it will discourage (or kill entirely) the stupid bugs that eat my plants.  I have been using this concentrate for years with great success.  You might want to wear gloves when applying it, because the mixture is very toxic (kind of) and will stay on your skin for a long time and is hard to get off, when you are spraying plants.  So I always wear some cheap, thin, disposable clear hand covers when applying this stuff.  Hope this helps!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2015
review_content: I wasted the whole growing season having false faith in this product that was recommended by the local nursery. From what I can tell on other reviews it seems people are just as pleased as can be.  I seem to be the only person alive that has fungus, disease, insects, mites, you name it, all over my veggies. If this product did just one of the many things it promises I would at least have one veggie left. But this product did nothing for my aphids, in fact, it seemed to fire them up to eat more. Powdery mildew was on one maybe two leaves of my cucumber when I sprayed as directed, it acted more like a plague distributor as now there is powdery mildew everywhere despite my di!igent temp checks and humidity monitoring and following application instructions to a t. Yes I got top and bottom of each leaf, I got stems, I got new growth, I got the soil, instead of gaining some kind of control, the fungus took over within a week and aside from letting my plant slowly get sucked dry I am tempted to burn it all down. Then I got aphids on my lettuce and they were literally covering the entire plant. I doused it with fertilome and there was nary a single death. It almost seemed they were raising their tiny glasses and cheering me. Next came spider mites on my greenbeans.  This product had no effect. None. This magical potion promises so much. And I have so much I need taken care of. Out of all the insects, diseases, funguses, and mites its supposed to eradicate, is it too much to ask to get just one thing?  Just one?  But no, for me the magic has worn off and all I am left with is putrid smelling worthlessness - although I may have lung cancer in my near future so there's that.  Oh ya and my millions upon millions of new disgusting life destroying scurg of the earth. And just so you know, I have a greenhouse that has a water drip system on a timer, the temperature is regulated morning and night, sterilized soil and vermiculite with monthly fertilization with granular fertilizer along with calcium and phosphates for the tomatoes all are provided via product instructions.  I wanted it to work. I really truly did. I gave it many chances to do something . . anything . . . entire growing season.  . . It simply does not work. Just doesn't. It smells bad and gives me a headache figuratively and literally. Not recommended for greenhouse veggies and fruits.

review_content: I don‚Äôt believe in over reacting or to making ANY exaggerated claims.  With that in mind I need to tell you experience with this spray was GREAT.  I have a young mango tree and 90% of the leaves were black/brown and curled into what looked like totally useless form when it comes to absorbing sunlight.  I was tempted to pull ALL the leaves off.  That is how bad it was.  So I got this spray after reviewing possible ideas and totally sprayed all the leaves top and bottom.  After 7 to 10 days I came back with the idea I might spray again to help the poor tree along.  But what I saw was shocking.  ALL the black and brown shrivel was TOTALLY gone.  The tree looked healthy and so did EVERY leaf on the tree.  Literally there was not one dark spot or sick leaf.  The entire tree looked vibrant.  Just so you know, there were no leaves on the ground so the did not dry up and fall off.  Somehow they got cured.  So now I spray it once every 3 weeks and the tree is a model of perfect health.  Note:  I bought this product with my own money and have zero affiliation with the sellers or manufacturer and I am not a tree expert.  It just worked so good that I was surprised so I reviewed.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2023
review_content: I purchased this Copper Fungicide spray to treat various succulents (including Jade plants) that had white mold & black spots. First, I cut off affected leaves, then copiously sprayed each plant, covering every portion, every 5 days for months. I continued to cut affected leaves & repeated the process until the mold/spots resolved. Some plants were nearly bald but the leaves have grown back & my plants are healthy. After months of treatments, I wiped each and every plant (leaves, branches, etc.) with alcohol pads to clean off any remaining debris, then rinsed each plant with water. This product saved my plants. It took a lot of time, patience and effort, but it worked. I highly recommend this fungicidal spray. You must be patient and willing to take time to save your plants. Good luck!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2022
review_content: I have been using Garden Safe brand for years with very good results. The key is to learn what plants it works best on, as well as which pests. For example, I learned it worked very well for my vegetables boxes, but not for my Hydrangea. This spray is also best for catching the issue early or even using it preventatively (early or pre-infestation/infection.) I start with this product in the beginning of my gardening season (cucumber, tomato, okra, eggplant, etc.) to keep everything healthy, without the harsh chemicals. That way I can harvest on the same day I've sprayed, if needed.Because you do have to spray until runoff, for several days, I recommend buying this larger bottle. (Small one doesn't go far.)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2022
review_content: I did not have an issue with the sprayer working, it operates fine for me. The sprayer handle is very small and I have small hands, so I can imagine this would be a pain for someone with larger hands. Due to its size, it does take several repeating sprays to cover the plant that you're treating.  I was okay with that since I am treating smaller rose bushes. It would be a hassle treating larger plants.My rose bushes have new clean growth after treating with this spray. I'm careful not to spray any new buds as need is lethal to bees as well as pests. I used this as a last resort to save my roses and they are looking much better with new growth.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2022
review_content: I bought a gallon sized hibiscus off the sale rack at my local garden center. It was dried and sad but only $1. It did fine for a while but was starting to drop its leaves and after it's first bloom, the flowers started to drop as well. I had no idea what was wrong.I ordered this product as it covered a range of issues from fungus to pests. I don't like to use herbicides/pesticides at all but wanted to save her. As this is an organic product, I gave it a try.It worked! I applied per instructions and she is getting new shiny leaves. I think she is on the way to becoming a beautiful plant.I will definately be keeping this product for future use but will still use only when absolutely necessary. Organic or not, it's still best not to use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2022
review_content: I love roses for their beauty and scent.  But, they can be difficult to nurture because of the fungi (Black Spot Disease) that loves them, too.  Unfortunately, I hate mixing and spraying fungicides and consequently, I'm just not inclined to use them.This summer I had an opportunity to use Garden Safe Fungicide3.  I found it very easy to use...It comes premixed so you just shake it up a little and spray the roses with the built in, hand pump, sprayer.  It takes about ten minutes to treat a medium to large rose and about five minutes for a small one.I found the fragrance pleasantly citrusy.  The hand sprayer can cause a bit of muscle fatigue in the forearms, but provides an even, fine spray that covered the cane and leaves quite thoroughly.  After using it twice this summer on two and once on one of my four of my remaining roses, all the new growth is completely disease free.  Keep in mind, this product will not rehabilitate already infected leaves, but it will allow new growth to flourish.  It takes time for the plant to rehabilitate, but the job gets done.I'm very pleased with the results.  I will continue to use it because it is easy to use and gives the desired result.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2022
review_content: I love Garden Safe Fungicide3 for use throughout the summer in my vegetable garden since it's the only product I've found that is both safe/recommended for organic gardening and effective. It attacks multiple problems in a single spray: fungus, insects, and mites.  This large bottle replaces all the small, ready-to-use bottles I usually keep in my garage.  I find it especially useful on my tomato plants which tend to get whiteflies and fungal disease near the end of the summer when humidity is high.  This spray doesn't get everything, but it tamps down problems enough for the plants to thrive.You must remove the cap and insert the hose end fully in the opening.  Once the hose is extended, the trigger pumps effortlessly.  I love that I can usually leave the bottle on the ground while using the hose,  The only time I need to pick it up is when I need to reach the tops of my tomato plants.  For beans, peppers, and eggplants, I just leave it on the ground.  I always make sure that I use it in the evening when bee activity is at a minimum.  I don't want to wipe out the pollinators with the thrips, mites, aphids, and whiteflies.  Note:  this doesn't address destructive pests in worm form.Finding this Garden Safe Fungicide3 in a large, ready-to-use jug is a thrill.  While that might sound like hyperbole, it's not.  I go through small bottle after small bottle throughout the summer, and this is much more convenient.  Plus, it sprays better.  Next year, I'm going to start with it.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

There was no mixing or measuring involved the ready to use formula treats garden fungicide, insecticide and miticide. The large 32oz size is a considerable value compared to other leading brands.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2022
review_content: I had no issue at all with this sprayer - in fact, it‚Äôs one of the easier ones.The key is to pull the tube out all the way, then prime the sprayer for about a minute & voila! You‚Äôre in business, either mist or stream.I‚Äôm using this for a powdery mildew on my Ninebark that seems to happen in the middle & outwards, so I coated the center since a bit has already appeared & it‚Äôs not progressing - all good!Also using it on the mites that like my hostas. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2022
review_content: Finished up my last bottle of organic spray and decided to try Fungicide 3 for the first time for possible better results. In comparing ingredients with my old spray bottle, I did noticed both are 3-in-1 products with the same ‚Äúactive ingredients‚Äù list. Both list Neem oil at 0.9% and ‚Äúother ingredients‚Äù at 99.1% which basically told me nothing. What I did discover is Fungicide 3 is effective on controlling and stopping powdery mildew and the few aphids tested on. I had a zucchetta & delicata squash both showing early signs of powdery mildew where I removed a couple of bad leaves, sprayed, repeat and waited. The spray was great at controlling the spread and the plants cleared up nicely without a reoccurrence.  I guess you could say ‚ÄòI dodged that bullet‚Äô catching it early on. As a insecticide, I can‚Äôt really give it high marks. I usually let the lacewings and ladybugs do their thing on the aphids, but decided to test the spray on one plant for effectiveness and it did work! The big test was spraying direct onto the various nymphs, larvae and other pests that were thriving on my veggies and it did not work. They were maybe stunned for a couple of seconds then continued on with their activities. Overall, I think this is a good and effective 3-in-1 spray for powdery mildew on squash plants. It also works on insects & infestations included on their product list, but anything not listed will probably be hit-and-miss. If you have a pollinator garden, you will still need to confine your spraying to early morning or late evening outside of bee working hours (‚ÄúThis product is toxic to bees exposed to direct treatment‚Äù) & avoid spraying plants that butterflies and caterpillars feed on (especially milkweed if you‚Äôre helping monarchs). For me, this is a powerful powdery mildew eliminator and definitely will consider the larger bottle concentration for attaching my water hose. As an insecticide I‚Äôll have to wait and see what next spring brings.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2023
review_content: The product arrived in good outer condition.Inside the bottle... well that's another story.  The spray bottle would not work.  Unscrewed the top to find the contents coagulated...lumpy and waxy to the touch.I removed the spray bottle and washed with warm soapy water to get it working.  I returned it to the bottle and placed the bottle in a warm water soak.  Later I shook the warm bottle to properly mix the contents.  Sprayer now works and product flows freely.I wonder if the product separated during storage,  traveled to my cold climate and couldn't remix?Time will tell!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2023
review_content: We purchased a 4ft Hibiscus tree that had or developed a terrible infestation of aphids and powdery mildew that weren't apparent at first. Noticing that the plant was struggling, we used online gardeners to identify the  problems and used several natural methods for some weeks with a small degree of success. The powdery mildew seemed to abate but the aphids returned - so many that that every flower bud fell as soon as it appeared and leaves were dropping fast. Worried that our other plants would be affected and to save the tree, we finally purchased the Garden Safe Fungicide as a last resort. We'd heard the good and bad about Neem Oil and decided to use it in moderation and with care.There was a quick and obvious improvement that we monitored and treated as necessary over the following weeks. After that first month or so, we haven't had to use the fungicide and thankfully, our other trees and plants were not affected.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2021
review_content: This product is advertised as effective against aphids, but as far as I am able to tell, it seems to have almost no effect on their behavior.I have a small indoor brussel sprout plant which has a minor infestation of grey cabbage aphids. Application of the product in accordance with the instructions has had little effect on the aphid population over more than a week.Groups of aphids do not react to it in any obvious way when sprayed directly. They do not move away from it, nor do they seem to avoid areas where it was sprayed, nor do they appear to vacate the general area in which it was applied, even after saturating the area (per the instructions). Even several days after the application, there seems to be little difference in the overall density or behavior of  the aphids over the full plant.  Examination of groups of aphids in sprayed areas with a hand magnifier shows that some  aphids have indeed stopped moving, presumably having died in place, but quite a few are still obviously alive and moving, and as far as I can tell using the magnifier, still happily feeding on the surfaces of the leaves.In short, it seems to have little more effect than a spray of plain water to just wash them off.  I emphasize that I carefully read the instructions and applied the product accordingly: Shaken vigorously before use, applied in a saturating manner ("until run off") to all leaves.I haven't tried it in any situation other than the one described above, so perhaps it is effective against other pests in other contexts, but it surely is not a useful product against cabbage aphids.I fell back on my previous technique which was just to brush the aphids off the leaves using a soft-bristled paintbrush. Much more effective than this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2022
review_content: Effective against spider mites and to a lesser degree mealybugs after repeated applications. Some plants tolerate this spray very well. Some will get burned regardless of light levels, so be cautious.The hydrophobic liquid that the neem oil is dissolved in can also stagnate in crevices of tight plants like faucaria or hawarthia and lead to crown rot, so make sure they dry out after application or the rot will kill them faster than the pests.The safe genus as far as Ive seen has been:MonsteraCrotonBegoniaSygnopodiumAgleonemaTradescantiaSansevariaFaucaria (lithops)CrassulaEchevariaSedumHuerniaAoniumPhilodendronHoyaAll cactaceaeThe genus that were burned:CalatheaKalanchoe (burned bad)AloeAlocasiaFittoniaHawarthiaFaucaria (tiger jaws)I applied in the evening and they were burned overnight. Most survived but had significant scaring. Lost a few different species of kalanchoe so definitely avoid spraying those. It looks like generally sensitive species don‚Äôt tolerate it well, but we had some succulents get mangled too, so test it out before use.

review_content: I was having a slight problem with some fungus gnats on a couple of my orchids and norfolk island pines and what appeared to be spider mites on a bonsai and this has cleared the problem right up. I gave each plant a light misting every evening for about 7 days and I haven't noticed any more pests buzzing around which is a tremendous relief. I noticed a couple brown spots on a leaves of a new orchid as well and have been using this in the hopes that if it is a fungus this will take care of it. The plant is still growing and I haven't noticed any negative effects so this certainly isn't doing any harm but I don't think I can speak to its fungicidal benefits. As a gentle insecticide though it's a life-saver! It's a great amount for the price as well. I do live in a small apartment but with ~20 plants I imagine this will last me years.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2014
review_content: I was referred to this product by some instructions I found online for getting rid of gnats/fruit flies, whatever the tiny bugs are that have been breeding in my creeper plant and spreading to the rest of my house plants. The steps involved were to: remove the top layer of soil, spray the soil and plant with a vinegar and dishsoap mixture, wipe clean the inside of the planter, put down a layer of new soil, then a layer of aquarium gravel (I used sand), spray with Fungicide 3, and water the plant from below. I did this a week or so ago, and I have not seen a fly since. So the Fungicide 3 worked in combination with the other steps. Can't say whether it works by itself. But I was afraid it might kill my plants and it did not. So I am pleased.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2016
review_content: I honestly can't say if this product really helped much. I had a really bad fungus gnat issue  & powdery mildew for months, but the only way I really managed to get rid of them was to finally use sand & river pebbles to cover the soil of all my potted plants. The plants stopped getting exposed & I also started watering in the morning only and being really careful not to get ANY leaves wet, base plant only.  I am just using plain neem oil applied to the soil now, but this product seems to be mostly neem oil anyway. You would probably save yourself a lot of headache and just get plain neem concentrate and mix your own. It will go a much longer way than this bottle & you can get better bang for your buck. I really didn't feel like this product made much of a difference in the long run, but wasn't horribly priced for what it contains.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2019
review_content: .9% Neem oil, 99.1% other ingredients not identified.  Toxic to skin, breathing, eyes, pets.  States must wash contaminated clothing separately or dispose of, wash skin thoroughly with soap and water and rinse 20-25 minutes under running water, contact poison control center.  I bought this because of the misleading "Garden safe" and Neem oil.  Not a safe product to use without gloves; and definitely not with any breeze or wind...  I have used it, it is effective against soil mites...but the hazards outweigh the benefits.  I need something safe to use indoors.  I wouldn't trust overspray on any porous or semi-porous material, and am definitely freaking out that any got on my skin while using.  Only spray on items at ground level to avoid breathing in any mist, and make sure the area is covered with plastic for any overspray.  Definitely do not use if you have kids or pets around where you spray it.  I'll be turning this in to the local Hazardous Waste disposal day when it happens this year, and using a natural, albeit more expensive, alternative.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2015
review_content: I have to admit, given some of the "information" that I found online, I did not have high hopes for this type of product. But I had these ugly mushrooms in my house plant and I wanted to give anything a try that might work. And to my  delight this worked after only three treatments.I think the key might be in the process. I made sure to remove all of the mushroom caps first and then sprayed the small fungal growth that was at the base of the mushrooms. After the first treatment, there was some continued growth and I was a little worried that the product might not work. But after two more treatments, I've had no more mushroom growth in my plant.Give it a try, if you have those somewhat fluorescent, yellow green mushrooms and then this should work for you.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2017
review_content: Awesome product to use on an organic garden. I had a lot of trouble with whiteflies, they were taking over my cucumber, zucchini, and melon plants. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2014
review_content: My potted plants and seedlings got a bad mold problem over the winter due to damp, cold weather. This fungicide got rid of the mold and kept it from coming back. It also killed spider mites and fungus gnats that had been plaguing me for several months. Now I spray it on all planting mediums before starting seeds to keep my house mold free and pest free.A Note on Product Safety:This fungicide uses neem oil, which is derived from the seed of the Azadirachta indica tree. I almost didn't buy this product because reviewers said it was too dangerous to use around humans, but a little research revealed that neem oil is very safe; it is even used in cooking and alternative medicine. The excessive warnings on the product label is probably due to the fact that rare individuals might have slight allergies to neem oil.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2023
review_content: I thought my Sky Pencil might be dead but I noticed some small signs of new life on it.  Then on closer inspection, I realized the reason it had been defoliated was spider mites.  I blasted the plant with water from the hose to remove as many as possible and then started a course of Neem treatment.  I've never used Neem before but try to avoid chemical pesticides so I thought I would try it.  It doesn't kill eggs so you need to reapply every 3-4 days for about two weeks to make sure you get them all.  And you have to make sure you get all sides of the leaves.  There's lots of new, healthy growth so about all I can say is "so far, so good."  And it has a kinda nice almost orange scent to it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2020
review_content: I usually don't write product reviews unless I'm totally satisfied with a product.  This concentrated Neem Oil has obliterated most of my pests issues.  If you have experience growing plants you'll know that pests come and go and they are never really totally gone.  In the past I've had white fly infestations, fungus nats, millibugs, aphids, scales, etc.  My mixture kills all... I mix about a couple of table spoons to a gallon of water with a table spoon of dish soap and shake it.  I even pour the mixture in the substrate because this mixture also works systemically.  I'm very satisfied with the results.  Don't get the Neem Oil that's already sold in a sprayer bottle; that stuff stinks and does not do anything.  This concentrated mix has a citrusy smell to it that's more tolerable than the spray bottle stuff.

review_content: I have a sprayer dedicated to neem oil only but I didn't spray like I should have earlier in the year (once every week or two). review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2017
review_content: Southern AG Triple Action Neem Oil got rid of our tree's significant aphid infestation. I highly recommend this product. Expect effective though not immediate results; Neem oil does not kill aphids on contact but does lead to their untimely demise. Other products we used - for example Bayer Advanced - didn't touch the problem when used alone. We used Neem in combination with Bayer Advance (three applications: Neem, Bayer Advanced, Neem) and successfully resolved our aphid problem. Would Triple Neem Oil have worked on it's own? I suspect so, but since I had Bayer Advanced on hand, I threw in a treatment in between Triple Neem Oil applications and this likely resolved the infestation more quickly.

Another downside is because my plants are delicate, it can leave micro burns on the leaves (they look like tiny barely noticable yellow spots), but that has not affected my plants' overall health or growth. Also it can lose effectiveness over time so a second application may be necessary later in the season.It literally saves my plants' lives year after year so I'm otherwise pretty happy with the product.
