review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2023
review_content: Seems to have worked great as a curative for dollar spot in my bermuda lawn. Due to circumstances, I was forced to water my bermuda lawn at the end of the days during the hot humid month of june. This caused a mild case of dollar spot on certain areas of my lawn. I sprayed the entire lawn at the low rate to prevent any new dollar spot from occuring and I concentrated a little more on the areas with the current dollar spot. You do need to move a little quicker than you might think, the product does dispense fairly quickly. A week after applying the fungicide, I fertalized the lawn to help the lawn grow out the fungus. By week 2, all of the dollar spot is gone and all spots are green again. Next year I plan on spraying a preventative dose in mid june. I gave the product 4 stars since sthe stuff is pretty expensive.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2018
review_content: We had an infestation of mushrooms that we never had before.  They came through two fences and clusters were as large as a head of cauliflower!  I would walk by the area to take out the garbage and there would be no mushrooms and when I would walk back to the house they would be all along the fence!  I dug them up and found them under rocks, lumber, and even in the seams of the concrete!I ordered the product after doing some research on how to get rid of the mushrooms.  The first time I sprayed, it didn't seem to work, so I dug up the mushrooms again and flooded the area along the fence with the spray.  The directions say to use every two weeks.  Sure enough, two weeks to the day, the mushrooms were back, but not nearly as bad.  Some areas had no mushrooms at all and they weren't busting through the fences as they were before.  I did have new areas with mushrooms so once again, I flooded the areas, but I felt I was winning the battle.I have a week left before I'm supposed to spray again, so I'm hoping they won't be back.  Also this area is not where our dogs go.  On the area where there were mushrooms and our dogs would likely walk on, I flooded it with the spray and put lawn furniture over it.  The directions say that as long as the spray is dried, pets can be on the area.I didn't take any pictures, but perhaps I should have.  It looked like something out of a science fiction movie!UPDATE 5/16/2019:  It's been nearly a year and there are no signs of mushrooms on either side of the fence!  However in my neighbor's yard they are growing where I haven't sprayed.  That's okay.  I would highly recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2023
review_content: As many have already said this bottle will only cover a small portion of your yard bc it comes out too fast. I asked for a video from the company of how to cover 5000 sq ft but have received no response. I use Cutters Backyard to spray for mosquitos with the same type of spray bottle (for about $10 vs $20+) and it covers 5000 sq ft as advertised so this could be fixed. Cutters covers my whole yard but this funguscide only covers about 1/2 of my front yard! I even had my water on low but it didn't make any difference. It would cost my over $100 to cover my entire yard vs $10 with Cutters. Just trying to help you understand how much you'll need. Help them out Spectrum or make a funguscide for us!  I don't know how well it works because it's only been a couple of weeks.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2023
review_content: Liked sprayer, used on front lawn to stop brown spot fungus. It has helped fungus from spreading, but prior areas will need to be dug up, add new dirt, seed and covered with more dirt. I used a brass lever shot off valve on end of hose attached to container. That way I can better control the amount of product. Depending on the area you need to cover, you will usually need more than 1 container.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2022
review_content: For the past several years my lawn has developed a summertime fungus.  It is almost like clockwork around late-June when I noticed small patches of white fluff, almost like cobwebs, in the morning on the dew covered lawn.  These spots quickly turned white and then died, and this spread rapidly around the yard creating small circular dead spots that would often merge together.  It was hideous, especially for someone with lawn OCD.  I haven't officially identified the fungus but have narrowed it down the likely culprits to dollar spot or brown patch.  So here comes the remedy...This BioAdvanced spray works wonders and stops the growth and spread of this fungus, when caught early enough in the process.  It seems to work more quickly and effectively than the Scotts DiseaseEx that I tried in other areas of the lawn.  However you will blow through this bottle very quickly and there is no way this will cover the 5,000 square feet as advertised.  I probably had my bottle emptied within two minutes and maybe covered 1,000 square feet.  You definitely want to be prepared to hustle and have your hose spread out in advance to maximize your application.  You will probably need three bottles of this for an average size lawn.  That didn't bother me based on the fact this product worked and saved me from the cost and trouble of reseeding dead patches of grass.  Five stars for a product that works!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
review_content: Ordered this item on the advice of a professional landscaper. It works but did also require some manual effort, pulling out the dead  St Augustine grass .

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2023
review_content: Update 2023.07.27 -- The manufacturer provided a refund. Good for them; but what about the faulty nozzle? I had one unused bottle left (from an earlier purchase) with the new style spray nozzle. I decided to do an experiment. I place a hose on/off value between the end of the hose and the bottle. I left the spray nozzle open. I controlled the spraying with the on/off value that I added. The bottle of product worked perfectly. I could start and stop spraying with no problem. So then I decided to control the spraying by the nozzle's actual on/off switch. As soon as I turned the nozzle's switch to the off position the bottle ballooned outward and I could see that the bottle had filled itself up with water, thus diluting the product.In short, the new style spray nozzle does not work for me. I must control the spray on/off by some other means.Manufacturer, I do not want another refund. Rather, I am very curious whether this problem is specific to the water pressure (or something else) at my home or is this a widespread problem. If wide spread, when are you going to fix it or go back to the old nozzle style which worked great?Original ----------I have used this product for years. No complaints. I buy 3-4 bottles at a time. I liked it so much recently started a subscribe & save. However, I could not effectively use the last batch of bottles. In each case the bottle seemed to be working until I realized#1) that the shape of the bottle had ballooned outward due to inside pressure.#2) the fluid level in the bottle had gone up rather than down.#3) the fluid was so diluted that it was nearly clear and could not be seen on the bottle's gauge.In summary, the water from my hose was going into the bottle diluting the product and causing the bottle to expand.Now as to why. I am not certain; but I observed three things.#1) the spray nozzle had changed designs.#2) the straw in the bottle to suck up the product has a smaller diameter when compared to bottles I previously bought. Yes, I sometimes save empty spray bottles.#3) I turned my faucet down to about half flow, reducing the pressure coming out of the hose. This worked. The product drained from the bottle as it should *until* I turned the spray nozzle off so as to move to another section of lawn. Once moved and ready to start again, I saw that the bottle was now full and ballooned outward. The rest of the product was diluted so as to be ineffective.This problem cost me to waste 3 bottles of the product. To save the contents of the fourth bottle I poured into the old bottle I had saved. It had a much larger straw and an older style nozzle. I started spraying. NO PROBLEMS. I turned the faucet back to full flow. I continued spraying. NO PROBLEMS.In short, the manufacturer has screwed up the bottle's sprayer. This error has cost me 3 wasted bottles.I hope the manufacturer reads this post. I am an unhappy customer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2022
review_content: I just applied it so at this point I can only assume the product will work well.  My concern is that the dispense rate is way to fast to be usable.  The instructions do say it will empty the bottle in 5-6 minutes but this is much faster than any other ready to spray product I have used.  The general assumption that you need to at least lightly wet the area being sprayed must be incorrect.  In general I walk fast, but one bottle emptied in less than 2500 sq ft.  Maybe if you have a large area with no obstacles, curves or discontinuous areas and walk very fast you could get the 5000 sq ft coverage.  If you need to stop spraying to move to another area or move the hose, etc.  too much is wasted just trying to shut off the spray with the built in control since it will lock in the ON position too.  My suggestion is break off the locking tab or use a secondary on/off control.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
review_content: I've never had a fescue lawn before, so its been a learning experience. I discovered that in hot temperatures, fungus inevitably creates large brown areas in the lawn. The effects of the fungus makes it look like your lawn hasn't been watered, which a lot of people think is the cause. My yard was in bad shape and after researching to discover the actual issue, I applied DiseaseEx granules AND then followed that with this liquid fungicide.After three weeks I could not believe the difference - green, healthy lawn. If you have visible fungus damage, make sure you apply both treatments and then use DiseaseEx granules as a preventative monthly during the hot, summer months. I guarantee you'll be amazed at the results. I was!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2020
review_content: I had a bad fungus problem in my front yard.  I put down Scott's DiseaseEX first, waited about 2 weeks, and it did not seem to do much (my neighbor also had a similar experience with the Scott's product.)  I then got a bottle of BioAdvanced and it really seemed to do the trick for my yard.  The bottle actually lasted MUCH longer than I thought it would.  I sprayed an area that is approx. 100 feet wide and about 75 feet deep.  I did not run out.  I had read reviews where people said that the bottle only lasted 2 minutes but that was NOT my experience.  My problem was in my front yard and I had enough spray to take care of my entire area.  I really was pleased, and I believe I have it under control now.  I have an extra bottle for future use.  I will suggest this - when you see this stuff starting do something quickly. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020

My neighborhood seems to have a serious brown patch problem as EVERY yard gets taken over by it.  This year my yard has remained green while other yards look terrible.Finally a product that works after years of trying other products.  Spectracide is pure garbage...their granules and spray do NOT prevent brown patch.  This is the first product I've found that actually prevents it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2016
review_content: It seems to be working for the brown patch my yard was experiencing.  As others have stated, it dispenses very quickly, but if you know that and move with a purpose, you can get it applied in a reasonable fashion.  It says on the label that established diseases may take repeated applications every two weeks.  Makes since, kind of like treating a ringworm.. So far, I'm on my third application, and it seems to be retreating.  Just remember to rake away the dead grass and along the outer edge beforehand so that it works better.  I never can seem to get the last inch or so of product out of the bottle.  I just mix it with about a 1/2 gallon of water in a pump sprayer and apply the rest that way.  Good product, needs a better container.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2022

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2018
review_content: I'm a new homeowner and I started seeing brown patches on my once beautiful lawn that resembled photos I looked up for brown patch.  So I decided to give this a try.The first problem is that when hooked up to the hose, it doesn't take long to deplete the entire bottle and I wasn't able to cover the entire area that I needed.  It might've stopped the fungus from spreading but because I didn't see any improvement after applying, I thought maybe I misdiagnosed the problem and maybe the areas were dying from lack of water.  The photo I attached is the before but it could also be used as the after.  There were other areas also, but this was the worst.It wasn't until over a month later it started to spread again.  I tried another bottle, and even though I knew it applied very quickly, I still wasn't able to cover the entire area.  I saw no signs of improvement, and the fungus continued spreading very quickly.So I gave up on the Bayer Advanced and tried concentrated Eagle20EW.  I liked this much better because I was able to dilute it and control the application rate much better.  Within about a week I saw most of my grass starting to turn green again.  I wish I used the Eagle sooner because the areas I initially applied the Bayer Advanced were too far gone at that point to be revived and they needed to be re-seeded.  So I would definitely not go back to the Bayer Advanced, which happens to be much more expensive per application and nowhere near as effective.  Just beware that the Eagle 20EW is more of a commercial grade product and you should take extra precautions (wear gloves and eye protection, dilute properly).  Actually, these precautions are probably recommended for any fungicide.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2014
review_content: For those of you who complain about using up the bottle too fast, try these tricks. Put the liquid concentrate into an Ortho Dial 'N Spray bottle sold here at Amazon and choose a concentration like 4 oz or less. Test a patch so you don't ruin an entire lawn. You can control your spraying by depressing the lever to turn the water on. Or you could attach the blue bottle to a hose use one hand to bend or crimp the water hose to reduce or stop the water flow as you move down the yard. I've seen my yardman to this, he moves the nozzle up and down the yard FAST as he walks and crimps the hose until he gets to another section. Hope my suggestions help.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2022
review_content: Long time grower here. I recently got infested with russet mites in my garden. If you think spider mites are bad, russet mites make them look like family pets. Within a week of me noticing the damage (yellow, shriveled leaves and brownish buds) my entire grow was infested. I had some Monterey Garden Insect Spray  on hand. Its active ingredient is spinosad, a non-toxic bacterial byproduct that usually works on spider mites. I tried that, and although it helped, it was only slowing them down. So I went online and did some research and came up with two names: Humboldts Flower Shield and Trifecta Crop Control. Since Flower Shield was cheaper, and had a recognizable company name, I went with that.Oh, boy, big mistake. Not only did this product NOT do as it claims, which is kill russet mites, it also left a sticky residue on my buds. The residue is so tacky I was having trouble harvesting and trimming my plants. It also caused the outer layer of the buds to turn an unattractive orange-brown color, like they were burned or something. So I thoroughly washed my buds before hanging them up to dry, hoping that would remove the residue.Fast forward one week, and upon smoking my buds I was assaulted by a horrible soap-in-the-mouth and something unidentifiable flavor. I suppose I will have to toss this entire batch of bud and start over. Even though some of my buds escaped the wrath of the russet mites, Humboldts Secret Flower Shield made sure that what I managed to save was thoroughly ruined and unsmokable. They claim their product is non-toxic. But then they also claim it kills mites and would not leave a residue... so... yeah.If there is a silver lining to my tale of woe, it is that I finally did purchase the Trifecta Crop Control. It is ridiculously expensive, but it has brought my russet mite infestation under control, and does not appear to leave a sticky residue on anything. The only caveat being, it is rough on the leaves and will burn them if you do not follow instruction to a tee.In summary, stay far far away from this product. Get Trifecta Crop Control instead. Or just nuke your whole grow and start over from scratch if you get russet mites.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2023
review_content: Worth it. My money tree was really struggling. This thing saved my plant. Happy....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2018
review_content: This product performs exactly as it says on everything it says it will...I have been gardening and breeding specific plants many years now and specifically medically the past half dozen years and the results get tested after harvest and I trust this product to do what it says while still allowing me to provide clean medicine to my patients and myself. Use it at the full recommended 2oz /gal to knock down the bugs/mites (Foliar spray and/or drench/dunk depending on where the pest lives) and 1oz/gal to knock down any of the PM or other fungi (non pest/insect uses)...INITIALLY, then after the first dose you should be able to cut it in half for the next couple treatments and then in half again for any follow up...It may not be cheap but it is economical IMO (mainly because it WORKS, lol) and if you stay on top of your spray schedule depending on what you are treating for then you will not require it for long because, again, IT WORKS! ;) ...if you are treating for mites I would recommend spraying at FULL strength TWO TIMES (3 days apart) using the best sprayer/atomizer you can get and really get in there now! The tops and bottoms of all leaves, the branches & stems and the top of your soil/mulch and even the floor surrounding the plants... I will sometimes add Dr. Bronners clear hemp liquid soap at a T per gal for pest treatments...helps with surface tension and further smothering the little bastards! After treatments and in between I like to spray with clean water and sometimes a foliar additive for vigor or growth like kelp (Golden Tree - Same company as this product), willow bark extract, etc., to help the plant recover from the issue that caused the treatments to begin with. Good Luck!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2022
review_content: Long time grower here. I recently got infested with russet mites in my garden. If you think spider mites are bad, russet mites make them look like family pets. Within a week of me noticing the damage (yellow, shriveled leaves and brownish buds) my entire grow was infested. I had some Monterey Garden Insect Spray  on hand. Its active ingredient is spinosad, a non-toxic bacterial byproduct that usually works on spider mites. I tried that, and although it helped, it was only slowing them down. So I went online and did some research and came up with two names: Humboldts Flower Shield and Trifecta Crop Control. Since Flower Shield was cheaper, and had a recognizable company name, I went with that.Oh, boy, big mistake. Not only did this product NOT do as it claims, which is kill russet mites, it also left a sticky residue on my buds. The residue is so tacky I was having trouble harvesting and trimming my plants. It also caused the outer layer of the buds to turn an unattractive orange-brown color, like they were burned or something. So I thoroughly washed my buds before hanging them up to dry, hoping that would remove the residue.Fast forward one week, and upon smoking my buds I was assaulted by a horrible soap-in-the-mouth and something unidentifiable flavor. I suppose I will have to toss this entire batch of bud and start over. Even though some of my buds escaped the wrath of the russet mites, Humboldts Secret Flower Shield made sure that what I managed to save was thoroughly ruined and unsmokable. They claim their product is non-toxic. But then they also claim it kills mites and would not leave a residue... so... yeah.If there is a silver lining to my tale of woe, it is that I finally did purchase the Trifecta Crop Control. It is ridiculously expensive, but it has brought my russet mite infestation under control, and does not appear to leave a sticky residue on anything. The only caveat being, it is rough on the leaves and will burn them if you do not follow instruction to a tee.In summary, stay far far away from this product. Get Trifecta Crop Control instead. Or just nuke your whole grow and start over from scratch if you get russet mites.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2023
review_content: Worth it. My money tree was really struggling. This thing saved my plant. Happy....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2018
review_content: This product performs exactly as it says on everything it says it will...I have been gardening and breeding specific plants many years now and specifically medically the past half dozen years and the results get tested after harvest and I trust this product to do what it says while still allowing me to provide clean medicine to my patients and myself. Use it at the full recommended 2oz /gal to knock down the bugs/mites (Foliar spray and/or drench/dunk depending on where the pest lives) and 1oz/gal to knock down any of the PM or other fungi (non pest/insect uses)...INITIALLY, then after the first dose you should be able to cut it in half for the next couple treatments and then in half again for any follow up...It may not be cheap but it is economical IMO (mainly because it WORKS, lol) and if you stay on top of your spray schedule depending on what you are treating for then you will not require it for long because, again, IT WORKS! ;) ...if you are treating for mites I would recommend spraying at FULL strength TWO TIMES (3 days apart) using the best sprayer/atomizer you can get and really get in there now! The tops and bottoms of all leaves, the branches & stems and the top of your soil/mulch and even the floor surrounding the plants... I will sometimes add Dr. Bronners clear hemp liquid soap at a T per gal for pest treatments...helps with surface tension and further smothering the little bastards! After treatments and in between I like to spray with clean water and sometimes a foliar additive for vigor or growth like kelp (Golden Tree - Same company as this product), willow bark extract, etc., to help the plant recover from the issue that caused the treatments to begin with. Good Luck!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2023
review_content: I used this for my indoor plants - to keep mold from growing on the top of the soil. Since I was not going to need a large amount, I only mixed up 1 cup of water with 1/2 teaspoon of fungicide in a small spray bottle. I carried my plants outside and after spraying the soil, I left them there for an hour to dissipate any lingering vapors. The fungicide does not smell bad, so it is important to maintain good safety procedures.  However, although the fungicide did not affect me, my husband was extremely sensitive to it and I had to banish my plants to the camper for a few days. He had headaches and breathing issues.I shall be giving my peach trees a light spray in a month or so after I have picked all the peaches. Although the trees are Florida-specific varieties, the humidity can get a bit much in summer.It is nice to see an organic product for fungus, as I thought there were no organic solutions for that problem. This bottle carries the OMRI logo, so it is bona fide. This bottle will last a long time (I estimate the bottle contains about 16 oz).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2023
review_content: I have had some issues on my plants with fungus due to a change in the area with towers.  The parasites of insect and fungal origin are much higher than before the monstrosity hit.  Having this handy is helpful.HOW THIS COMESThis comes in a nice thick bottle which is opaque.  The top is on tight and not too difficult to use.  The back label peels off so you can read it, but be sure your hands are clean or it won't stick shut again.HOW I USEI use this for now in a two quart spray bottle with 1 tablespoon of liquid mixed with half gallon of water.  I spray it on the plants well and make sure to get top and bottom of the leaves as much as possible.DOES IT WORK?I used it the first time on what I thought was a fungus, but it turns out it was teeny tiny little bugs that I did not realize make it look like fungal infection.  This helped some, but I used my Dr Bronners diluted mix for it instead and it worked better.  For a later development of spots on a few other plants where no bugs were evident, it seems to be giving the plants a good boost and they are looking better.MAKE UP ONLY WHAT YOU NEEDThis needs to be made up with only what you will use at any given time.  It is not supposed to sit around a while.  I have had it sit for a week and used it on a new plant and it seemed okay, but it is not advised.CAN THIS BE USED INDOORS?This can be used both indoors and outdoors.  The instructions are a bit different for each, so be sure to pay attention to that when you use this.  The video shows a different concentration than outdoors.THE BOTTOM LINEI wanted this for my vegetable and flower plants.  I wanted organic.  So far my plants are not too far along, so I have only used it some, but I plan to use it when the roses get hit with black spot like they do every year.MY RATINGFIVE STARS so far. This does not smell bad and is not difficult to use.  It seems effective so far.

review_content: I recently tried Arber bio fungicide in my vegetable garden, and I have to say, I am really impressed with the results! Arber fit the bill perfectly.The instructions were easy to follow, and I appreciated that the dosage was measured out in tablespoons per gallon, so it was easy to mix up the right amount for my needs. I applied it using a spray bottle, and within just a few days, I could already see a noticeable difference in the health of my plants. The mildew was starting to clear up, and the leaves looked healthier now.What I really appreciate about Arber is that it's organic certified, so I can feel confident using it on my vegetables without worrying about harmful chemicals.Overall, I would highly recommend Arber bio fungicide to anyone looking for an effective and safe solution for fungal issues in their garden.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2016
review_content: > Great for controlling fungus on fruit trees and vegetables, because copper sulfate in small quantities is not toxic to human beings.  If your fruit or vegetables absorb a little copper, they are perfectly safe to eat.> It actually needs to touch the surface of the plant that is affected---that is, both the top and bottom sides of leaves, and needs to set there for a while.  So, spray from multiple angles, and don't apply unless you expect conditions to be dry for say 6 hours or more.> Can kill or repel snails and slugs, since they are very sensitive to copper.> I mostly spray it on my citrus and mango trees.  For some varieties of mangos it is essential in order for the flowers to set (i.e., develop into fruit).  I also paint undiluted copper sulfate on tree wounds (e.g., such as those caused by trimming a limb).> It is recommended not to use it on orchids or bromeliads---but I've had no choice when I've treated trees which had orchids and bromeliads growing on them--but the orchids and bromeliads seem to tolerate it with no problem.> Copper sulfate mostly works on the surface of the leaves, kills the surficial fungus, and is washed off with the next rain -- very little is absorbed. Copper sulfate is ineffective against (systemic) fungal infections of the stems or roots, since it is NOT absorbed at significant levels.  That means little gets into the fruit or vegetables.> If you have serious fungus problems on non-fruit trees or other ornamentals (such as roses), you may need a systemic fungicide.  I use

review_content: We have a very aggressive fungus on our azalea and rhoto bushes, we have 15 bushes so buying a concentrate was really our only option. This is a great price for the quantity it makes, we use about 1.5 gallons each treatment and the bottle contains enough concentrate to make over 40 gallons. Well worth the money. I recommend a pump garden sprayer to apply if you're working with multiple large bushes.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2021
review_content: This was recommended for treating some types of leaf spotting caused by funguses. It worked well to slow down/stop what I think was septoria spotting. This started on the lower leaves (which unfortunately were touching the ground when I transplanted the tomatoes) and started moving up. After two spray applications (10-days apart) all fresh growth was spot-free. The active ingredient also breaks down after a week or so, which is important if you are spraying food crops. I think this is a reasonably safe product if you want to treat rather than destroy your crop, but do your own homework on safety!

review_content: Earth's Ally Fungicide is certified safe around humans, pets and bees by the Organic Material Review Institute (OMRI),. All you have to do is hook up your water hose, turn the water on,  pull the little tab and turn a little knob on the container.The active ingredient is food-grade citric acid. which forms a protective barrier.  (Due to the time of year,  I haven't yet had an opportunity to test this product personally, but will gladly update this review at a later date.Earth's Ally Disease Control is also available through Amazon in a 32 oz container for $24,98 as of October 13, 2022. It is listed as safe to apply on fruit, vegetables, flowers and ornamental shrubs. The concentrated formula should be mixed in a ratio of 6 Tablespoons of concentrate to 1 gallon of water.I like having a product that addresses many of the plant diseases plaguing my region while simultaneously ensuring the safety of the environment for my cat, dog and family.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2020
review_content: Bonide copper fungicide was almost instantly effective against mildew on Monarda and so far has prevented spread elsewhere in garden. It may yet keep me from losing all of the pepper plants I purchased at a nursery to bacterial spot and seems to have so far blocked its spread to other seed-raised vegetables. Not sure of names of other fungus diseases and blights, but my garden in hot, humid VA has seen its share over the past few years. At one time or another, tomato leaves have matched all the pics I‚Äòve found online and I‚Äôve pulled up cukes and squash by mid-July. This year, things are looking better with proactive treatmentBUT BE CAREFUL!I thought I was observing all precautions and still ended up with chemical burns on my arms and legs as well as conjunctivitis. I wasn‚Äôt aware I had gotten any on me. I wear glasses. I wore a bandana around my nose and mouth to save my mask for other uses.  However, I saw some squash and cucumbers that needed pruning while I was spraying. So before bathing, I cut the vines and leaves and carried them to the far edge of the property where we dispose of such things. All those little, irritating, recently-sprayed hairs, wrapped in m arms. I also walked in my mint bed, spraying where I‚Äôd cut it back the week prior because of blight. Bare stems must have rubbed my legs and ankles. Finally, I came and quickly showered off, not thinking any product was on me. The burns began appearing 12 hours later and continued to worsen the next couple of days. At least they haven‚Äôt been painful, but now 4 weeks later, I‚Äôm beginning to think I have permanent, dark and very noticeable scars that have peeled several times on my legs and forearms. I wear long pants and long sleeves now when I use the product and shower immediately after. So should all users.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2023
review_content: The tree's leafs were rapidly turning brown during the summer from a blight. Every day a new branch was turning brown. Just one spraying, and the blight was immediately stopped in its tracks. I could not believe how effective this product can be.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2023
review_content: I used 3 chemicals (all bought at Amazon) to save my big Bradford pear. It contracted "Fire Blight," which is somewhat unique to Bradford pear trees. I used the recommended strength of Immunox multi-purpose fungicide, Fertilome fire blight spray, and Captain Jack's Copper Fungicide. I mixed them in a sprayer (all of them together) and sprayed the tree heavily. I sprayed each weekend for four weeks. And I cut off all the dead limbs and leaves I could reach. Some of the affected areas were high in the tree, and I could not reach them. At the end of my treatments, the tree looks great! I have some solution remaining, so I will continue the weekly sprays until the solution is gone.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2021
review_content: My recommendations are to wait for a dry day and remove all infected leaves; if there are many sick leaves, just cut the whole branch off back to where you see healthy growth.  Use sterile scissors or sheers.  Then, apply this at 30 mL/gallon (that's about 1 ounce, anything more seems overkill to me), preferably not in full direct sun.  A warm morning or evening will do.I grow almost entirely peppers, annuums, chinense, baccatum, and also a few tomatoes.  It has been annoyingly damp this year, always raining just enough to keep leaves wet but never enough to really water anything.  And plenty warm.  If you've been gardening for almost any amount of time, you know those are ideal conditions for mold and bacteria to attack your plants.  And boy they did.  So, I turned to this product for the first time.  It has worked great so far.  I was worried a few pepper plants were lost causes, but they've recovered and are now setting pods.  Nice.  This stuff is pricey, but it definitely works.  Will buy again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
review_content: Concentrate works just as well as the pre mixed. Better value mixing it up as needed. Really helps to keep my rose bushes looking nice.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2017
review_content: Bought with Garden Safe Neem Oil Extract for diseased tomato plants and used the bundled Chapin 2000 Sprayer to apply 2 oz of each product mixed together with a gallon of water.  Followed directions of mixing well and shook sprayer throughout application.  I applied in the evening at almost dark after the bees were gone.  One gallon well covered 35 2 foot tall plants.  Two days later, it rained for almost a week so theoretically, everything was washed off.  If you grow tomatoes, you know that extended rain can worsen symptoms of sick plants.  Amazingly, all the plants, even the most pitiful looking one had bounced back and were growing with little signs of problems.  I have applied again twice and my plants are really the best ever!  I also used it on some Pepper Plants that had begun to falter when the week of rain came.  They are thriving as well.As a beekeeper, I avoid pesticides, natural or mass produced, sometimes to the detriment of my garden.  I am confident that application at almost dark allows these products to dry before the bees are out the next morning, minimizing their exposure.  I have noticed to bee deaths and will continue to use this method at the slightest indication of plant problems.  These are recommended as preventative but like all chemicals, I will only use them for treatment if indicated.Be sure to carefully rinse your sprayer immediately after use!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2015
review_content: I use this copper fungicide to suppress (but not eliminate) powdery mildew on ornamental plants (primarily Phlox and Monarda) and slow down the ravages of septoria blight on tomato plants.I garden in Central Wisconsin where septoria blight is a serious problem on tomato plants.  This fungicide works well to slow down septoria blight but does not eliminate it.  It allows me to get a crop of tomatoes - without it I would only have blackened plants and a few shriveled fruit.  Many of my neighbors have similar problems and few get much of a tomato crop w/o using copper spray.It's pretty straightforward to use - mix 1/4 cut to 1 gallon of water and apply with a pressure sprayer.  I apply it from the first setting of my plants until mid-August - after that the septoria and the plant duke it out until the first frost.  I use an organic vapor mask while applying - maybe not necessary but I don't like to take chances.I also use it on ornamental plants.  It does a good job suppressing powdery mildew but, again, does not eliminate the disease.  Again, I use it from early in the growing season until mid-August - once the flowering period is over I cut out all infected stems and dispose of them in a separate area (no compost!).This is the most effective product I have found for both septoria and powdery mildew.  However, heavy use tends to build up a high copper content in the soil with unknown long term consequences.Nothing is free.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
review_content: I purchased this item along with these other 2 items:Bonide 024 Concentrate Neem Oil Insect Repellent, 16-OunceBONIDE PRODUCTS 775 Ready-to-Use Copper Fungicide, 32-Ounce (spray bottle)I found that if you mix 1-2 tablespoons of Copper Fungicide with 1-2 tablespoons Neem Oil (per gallon of water) and spray/saturate (top and bottom of leaves, stem and about 2-4 inches around the ground at the bottom of the stem) every 2 days in the beginning and any time after it rains, it works wonders.Remove and discard/burn any and all infected leaves every day.After doing this for the first couple of weeks...you can back off a bit and spray once a week...so on...TIP: Only spray very early mornings or early (cool) evenings....the sun WILL bake then if they haven't had a chance to dry.  I always did mine early mornings just as the sun was rising. That way they were dry before the sun hit them.  If you do it in the early evenings...make sure they have time to dry before nightfall....they don't like sleeping while wet....neither do I.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: Our peach and nectarine trees had very bad leaf curl on them.  I was trying to just remove the infected leaves and hoped it went away, but it quickly took over the entire tree.  I sprayed this on them twice, one week apart.  Immediately halted the leaf curl, and the new leaves that sprouted after have been perfect.  It has now been over a month and I haven't had to do another treatment.  At first I was worried that this little bottle wouldn't last too long, but you actually fill the sprayer with water and only put a little bit of the bonide.  I made 1.5 gallons the first time (and only used a spoonful of bonide), and covered two trees fully and still had a bunch left in the sprayer.  I read the bottle and it works for some rose diseases, so I went and sprayed those too (and still didn't empty the sprayer).  That was off one spoonful, so this little bottle goes a long way.

review_content: It took a bit more than two weeks, but the new growth shows no signs of Early Blight and the plants have taken off heading to bloom. We are very excited to have found this stuff. review_content: It‚Äôs easy to mix & use, but gradually effective. I had to apply spray to plants over & over, removing affected leaves over & over till rust was gone.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2016
review_content: First of all, this stuff works!  We planted some Leyland cypress trees and one started turning brown and was rapidly spreading.  The local extension office examined it and told us it was a disease that cypress can get and to use a copper fungicide.  First we bought the ready-to-spray type, but it's around $10 a bottle and it takes about a bottle to fully cover a 5-6" cypress tree.  Then we found this which has to be mixed, but is much more cost effective.  The tree had to be treated every week for a bit, but the copper fungicide stopped the progression of the disease right away.  The continuing treatments have gotten it healed pretty well and kept it from spreading to adjacent cypress.  Overall very pleased with the product.  Of course I like the convenience of the pre-mixed spray better, but not the price, so when you need to use it regularly or for large coverage areas, I would suggest getting this and mixing yourself.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2014
review_content: In a perfect orchard you won't need to treat for fungus on a regular basis; only as needed and hopefully not every year. Your soil, bug life, and healthy trees will keep it in check.But that's not my orchard. It was here when I bought my house and had been neglected for years while the house was empty. As one step in many to recover what trees I could and add more I needed to treat the stone fruit trees for fungus.Copper will build up in your soil. It will make your leaves and grasses more nutritions for farm animals. But it will be hard on your worm life. And worms are your friends, peeps. So, use sparingly and skip it when you can.I mixed a strong batch and sprayed all of my trees, even the pears and apples. And I let the excess drip down onto the soil and around the trunks. I'm trying to get fungus from years of neglect and over growth into check. It seems to work. I'm right after bud break and not seeing any issues on my blossoms or leaves. I'm really happy with this safe alternative to chemicals.Glad to have it on hand if and when I need it in the future.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2015
review_content: I have never had an issue with my tomatoes before but this year, I bought my seedlings and was unable to plant them right awahy so they sat on my lawn for awhile. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2018
review_content: So far so good. I live in Charleston, SC, and it has been a very humid, wet, and hot season for my Tomatoes. I started out using Daconil and Mancozeb, and my plants broke out with Bacterial Speck and Spot. As a first year grower I was frustrated and couldn't figure out why my Fungicides were not working. I found out that they do nothing for bacteria. At first I had thought it was Septoria Leaf Spot, and once it got worse, discovvered it was bacteria. I have since removed all of the infected foliage, and have added Copper to my Mancozeb mixes. So far it has done a great job at controlling the Bacterial spread, and since spraying the plants have been very healthy. The Bacterial Speck and Spot still creeps into certain branches and fruit sets, but it is unquestionably helping keep a lock on it from getting much worse, and the spread is very minimal now.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2015
review_content: I bought a 32 oz. bottle of pre-mixed Bonide Copper Fungicide from a local home improvement store and used it on my rhododendrons beginning this past spring.  This year they are now looking healthier than ever before.  I love this product.  Now for the interesting part‚Ä¶I paid $10.97 for 32 oz. of the pre-mixed version.  Through Amazon I paid $16.35 for 16 oz of concentrate.  Here is where it gets interesting.  Mixing at the maximum ratio of 2 oz per gallon is equivalent to ¬Ω oz for a 32 oz bottle.  In other words a 16 oz bottle of concentrate will provide thirty-two 32 oz bottles of mixed solution.  So, the $10.97 I originally paid for the pre-mixed version has now become $0.51 ($16.35/32 bottles) when I mix my own solution from concentrate.  I am still stunned by the value in buying the concentrate.  By the way, I plan to keep reusing the spray bottle that the original pre-mixed Bonide Copper Fungicide came in.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2019
review_content: If you've had prolonged (weeks) of warm and foggy mornings and your tomato plants have dried up leaves in the middle section with stretches of black colored stems, you have the "Late Blight" fungus.  This is what caused the great Irish potato famine in the mid=1800's.  This copper fungicide will stop the fungus in its tracks if you get to it before the main stems have turned black.  It will turn the affected areas of tomato plants black and dead.  A healthy plant can grow in its stead.  If you are too late, your only alternative is to rip out the tomato plants with all fallen leaves as well as 4-6" of dirt, and then add new dirt and plant anew all over again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
review_content: This works. Period. I live in zone 8, and summers are extremely humid. So together with an out of balance good /damaging bugs, for my gardens there will be fungus. No matter how many steps I take for proper garden practices, not over watering, not wetting foliage, no leaving debris on the ground from trimmed plants etc.Anyway, last year was the first time I used it and it saved my gardens. This year, just as helpful . I really had a difficult time deciding with what type of fungicide to choose from . I was considering the copper one. I'm just glad I went with this. Yesterday, there were signs of blight I could just see it on half of my plants . The pumpkin vine leaves were all droopy and the female buds turned brown and died before opening. I sprayed the vine , and the VERY next day it had perked back up with a green female bud visible.  Same with my annual flowers .I can spray this properly diluted ratio (I go a little under just to be safe) directly on any plant parts and there has been zero foliage burn. I don't have to spray it directly on the flowers, bc I do not want to harm pollinators. However, without this product , there would be zero flowers /plants for any pollinators and my plant therapy would be no more. I am not even being dramatic.This works. It's safe for garden flowers and plants. Does not cause any browning. Simple and effective . Fact. I keep this stocked (although it lasts a long time with one application,  and there are plenty of applications with this concentrate).I use a 32 oz high output regular style spray bottle. This method is certainly less hassle compared with the other styles, excluding mass planting areas. I will include a photo for reference.First picture - this pumpkin would not exist if I hadn't used some spray on the leaves and mainly the female buds that never opened- small, brown/yellow that would shrivel right off. The poor things were just helpless, it seemed nothing could keep them healthy!  However, this product did such,  ridding whatever fungus present. A week or so later, a robust female flower was able to prosper.Second picture - we had a tail end of a hurricane (2017) come through, which "mashed" this zinnia to the ground. The area was soggy and humid, yet this fungicide prevented fungal infection. Every orange flower is on this one zinnia. This example is fairly odd and unflattering, yet it demonstrates the effectiveness of this product.Third picture- the type of bottle referenced above.Last: balsam impatient plant, day before & day afterLong review but my passion is this right here, and without this product, in my area I would not have thriving plants.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2024

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2013
review_content: This product worked as described, but I had a few issues with it.  My main complaint is that I think I waited much too long to use it.  I decided to first try some "organic' and "home" remedies to control the mold issue I was having in and on potted plants on my lanai.  That was my first mistake.  While I was dabbling with White Vinegar, and an assortment of other household chemicals, the mold was destroying my plants.By the time I actually had gotten around to applying this product, the damage was quite extensive.  The product got to work quickly, but most of the damage had been already done.  I mixed the product as described, and immediately noticed a reduction in powdery mildew and mold on the leaves of the plants.  Most of them required a second and third heavier application before seeing the mold eradicated completely.I have a wide variety of flowers and each had a varying reaction to this product.  Most had little to no reaction to it, however, there were a few that were worth noting.  A few of my more delicate orchids definitely had some yellowing of leaves and wilting flowers.  They came back pretty strong.  What was hit most strongly was my Blue Ginger.  I don't think it will ever be coming back.  What the mold didn't kill, the fungicide most definitely did.Overall, I would recommend this product with a few disclaimers.  First, start at the first warning signs of mold or any fungus, whether it is in the soil, on the leaves, or on the stalks.  Second, if using on potted plants, make sure you are mixing the solution exactly.  Too much of this product is not a good thing, it will burn up your delicate plants.  It is much better to mix it too light, and apply it more often.  Mold is resilient!  Third, apply secondary precautions to help the fungicide.  Remove affected plants, if possible, from others as mold will spread, increase air flow, and increase sunlight.  Make sure your potted plants have plenty of drainage! All of these are mold deterrents.Oh, and cover your face both around the mold, and when using this product.  Both have shown to be pretty noxious, especially if you have pre-existing breathing issues.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2023
review_content: I have excellent results with this product.  When used as directed it will cure the black spot.  My roses had new growths and leaves within the first week.  I used weekly for the first few months.  I use it at least monthly for prevention.  I had a lot of products that weren‚Äôt as effective in the past. I use them every now and then to prevent resistance.  I have a lot of bees , they arrive early so I spray in The evening.  I haven‚Äôt seen a decline in population. However They are like addicts  for other flowers such as cuphea and angelonias and I don‚Äôt spray those so that maybe a variable.  I thought a few roses were over sensitive to the product because they burned every time.  I didn‚Äôt mind those spots However recently other roses burned and some were slow to recover. The same type of roses in another area did fine. Eventually the burned rose looked water deprived as well. I got a moisture meter and learned some areas weren‚Äôt retaining water well.  So  make sure plants are well hydrated before spraying. One problem I have is that Amazon has never packed this product well. One cracked leaked saturating the bottom of the box.  Never order chemicals with other stuff especially  other chemicals because not everyone  packs chemicals with care.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2023
review_content: I used 3 chemicals (all bought at Amazon) to save my big Bradford pear. It contracted "Fire Blight," which is somewhat unique to Bradford pear trees. I used the recommended strength of Immunox multi-purpose fungicide, Fertilome fire blight spray, and Captain Jack's Copper Fungicide. I mixed them in a sprayer (all of them together) and sprayed the tree heavily. I sprayed each weekend for four weeks. And I cut off all the dead limbs and leaves I could reach. Some of the affected areas were high in the tree, and I could not reach them. At the end of my treatments, the tree looks great! I have some solution remaining, so I will continue the weekly sprays until the solution is gone.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2016
review_content: I bought this product because my peach tree which is only about 2 years old began to show signs of leaf curl which I know can defoliate my tree early and cause it to die.  I decided on this product based upon some research on the internet and decided to give it a try to cure the leaf curl.For starters,  I have sprayed my tree down as I was supposed to in order to avoid this but upon doing some research, the spray I was using wasn't strong enough to use at the end of the season. It was just an organic three in one fungicide, insecticide and miticide,  I found that the product I was using is best just to spray on during the season as opposed to preventing diseases long term. Anyway so I decided on this product.My tree started showing signs about two weeks ago and I tried my original three and one spray which didn't help in the least bit, I would pull the damaged leaves off every day and it showed no signs of stopping or slowing down. I bought this and mixed it in a spray bottle as directed only putting in a little of the fungicide and I added some dish detergent to help it stick to the leaves better.  I sprayed it on the leaves on a warm, sunny day in order to help the drying process and pulled off the rest of the damaged leaves.  Usually if I would pull them all off, I would get at least 4 more the next day.  After using this I had two leaves the next day and then the following day I didn't notice any.  Since I have applied it about a week ago, I have only noticed one other leaf that had it. I'm optimistic that this cured my tree and will be reapplying it at the two week mark just to be extra cautious.  Fingers crossed that this stuff continues to work.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2014
review_content: This is the first pesticide/fungicide (non-natural/organic) that I've bought as a homeowner, but there is a reason I did...it works. My rose bushes have a big problem with powdery mildew, and the organic sprays just weren't cutting it. I looked at other organic or semi-natural brands but the reviews were mixed, so I caved and tried this.It really does work. I've only sprayed the roses once, but it rained heavily for two days afterward (a few days after), and the powdery mildew is gone from the leaves. I'm going to spray them again soon (the label recommends every 10 days for roses) but I'm relieved that the mildew is already retreating. My hydrangea is starting to get some black spot, so I'm going to start spraying that, too.I will say that the smell is extremely chemical and feels toxic. I was also quite nervous about mixing the concoction, especially having to use a pressurized sprayer with such a harsh chemical (very important to make sure it's de-pressurized before opening the lid--you do NOT want this stuff splashing near you). But it works as long as you're careful and wash your hands very thoroughly after. I would never use this on vegetables or anything someone would eat, but it's fine for decorative flowers and such. I hate using chemicals, but hey...they work.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2012
review_content: UPDATE: SEPT 3, 2013-Here in Florida rust is a major problem for Plumeria plants during the rainy/humid season.  Even the huge Plumerias in the Disney resorts are covered with orange powder this time of year.  But not mine - this stuff has kept me rust free this year.  I have 6 Plumeria plants that are about 6 feet tall, and I started using the immunox at the first sign of rust (about July 4).  It only takes about a half a gallon in a pump sprayer to treat them all (be sure to spray the bottoms of the leaves too), and I apply it about every two weeks.  All of my Plumeria trees are still growing and blooming while others in the neighborhood are losing all their leaves due to the rust.  This is good stuff.Original Review:I live in Florida, and I have several Plumeria plants that were covered in Plumeria rust this fall.  I had been using Orthenex as part of my standard insect/disease spray regimen, but it was not helping with the rust.  After some Internet research I found a few products that were reported to work, but could not find a suitably small quantity of any of them, so I decided to give this fungicide a try.  After a couple of applications, it seems to have cleared the rust and the plants are growing new leaves.

I still have plenty of this product left and treated all of my plants, even if they didn‚Äôt have signs of the disease yet. This product is wonderful, and so worth the price. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2021
review_content: After moving to the Southeast from the Northeast USA, we tried to grow tomatoes every year for six years and had no luck.  The vines would grow fine until mid July and then they would start dying.  We finally figured out that a fungus was killing our tomato plants.  It is the same fungus that causes "brown spot" in Southern lawns.  We first tried some "tree hugger" solutions (including the copper fungicide), but they didn't work.  Then we tried this product.  Suddenly, our tomato vines did NOT die in mid July.  They kept growing and growing and we had more tomatoes than we could eat.  Highly recommended.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2017
review_content: This is my third bottle for a bad case of rust which is killing off all like builder planted shrubs. I have my entire front preceeding the lawn, 15x25 feet, with these shrubs which would require massive re-landscaping if they die. Even though my neighbor's are just 12 feet away and half gone, literally holes there, I use this every two weeks as directed and am winning the battle. I should have begun earlier with the ones closest to the neighbors infected ones. Rust is carried by air borne spores. So as long as your neighbors contaminate the air...you will have to use this as directed every 7-14 days. Yes I have spoken to the lazy neighbor, who was penny wise and now is pound foolish as they will have to pull all the shrubs out and buy something different and bring in a landscaper. For me 63 and disabled this is a far better alternative. I use a hose sprayer and it takes very little time and effort, not a cheap product but a very good one.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
review_content: I just finished the original bottle and bought another two of them. Years ago I had 9 fruit trees and lost 8 of them to brown rot. The first symptoms would show up soon after blooming when little twigs and bigger branches would suddenly wilt and die. Not all the twigs were affected. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2015

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
review_content: So far, I have had pretty good success. We planted four new hydrangeas this year. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: Every year I spray copper fungicide on my garden (usually tomatoes, a couple squash, cucumbers) every 2 to 3 weeks to keep blight and mildew at bay. It's pure magic and I'm never going back. I had some early blight on my tomatoes that stopped in its tracks. I haven't seen a single spot of fuzz on any squash/cucumbers. Every leaf is green green green. My tomatoes have more fruit on them than I've ever seen. My cantaloupe is covered in flowers.Buy this!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2013

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
review_content: I use this as a preventative measure for our dwarf Goldrush apple tree which is susceptible to cedar apple rust due to the many junipers and red cedar trees in the neighborhood. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
review_content: I don't give many things five stars. I always have always fought the tomato blight and had to reapply fungicide after rain.  This year no problems.  I applied it early and let it go. Since the application lasts so long your tomatoes can blossom and ripen fully between applications so it is not as good at preventing spots and blossom end rot as the more frequently applied products.  On the other hand the the healthier plants yield added production and the reduced effort more than makes up the difference.  I apply it every three weeks and love the results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2011
review_content: I had a problem with cedar apple rust and with three sprays, I'd say it's about 80--90% reduced from last year, though not completely eradicated. review_content: Best anti-fungal lawn treatment I've found for southern (St. Augustine grass), high humidity environment lawns. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2015
review_content: Purchased for use mainly for tomato plants. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2015
review_content: We had a terribly wet June and July this year. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2014
review_content: I am not sure how this item manages to be so highly reviewed;  I would give it zero stars if I could.  I live in Mississippi, and roses here are constantly plagued with black spot.  I used this product for 2 years now.  Every year my roses flower beautifully in March, only to lose all their leaves by June.  I usually begin spraying before the first leaves appear, and I spray every week as outlined in the instructions.  This year, I even began mixing the concentrate 50% stronger than recommended.  I have 2 rose gardens, and this year I decided to spray only one of them.  I was surprised to find that the black spot tore through the two gardens with equal voracity, seemingly unfazed by Immunox.I have not tried this product on other applications.  It will probably work on fruit trees or something.  Just not roses.  At least not roses in Mississippi.But there is good news at the end of this review.  I bought Bayer rose spray this May, and began spraying my roses after the black spot was well-established.  Much to my surprise, my roses have begun to show signs of life.  New leaves are sprouting, and I actually have a few blooms.  They seem to be getting better with each passing day, and there are no more black and yellow leaves.Forget this product and go with Bayer rose spray for your roses.  It's cheaper as well.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2011

I thought, no problem... simply call the 800 Spectracide Customer Service line. The representative said "I should never go to ot trust the official Spectracide Website for use information" (what the ???) and I "should not use the fungicide on Ligustrum.  A second call to a supervisor said Immunox "could be used..but was not officially approved for use".  Why would the website state it could be used? Why was I told not to read the information the company posted on their own website?  This lack of coordinated, correct information coupled with rude customer service is too confusing and irresponsible. I cannot write a positive recommendation for this company. Immunox might work but the Spectracide Company fails.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2015

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2017
review_content: I bought this in sprayer form because I've used the handheld spritz bottle before and it worked well in the past. We had two dwarf tomato plants in patio pots and this helped get rid of some fungus and keep them healthy then.Now we have more room, so a lot more plants (a couple dozen) in raised beds; our ventilation and spacing is way better so the plants are healthy and beautiful but OH do the APHIDS love them! They're about 6ft over the beds and too hard to spray manually; this has a broad spray pattern that easily covers the whole plant. We sprayed top to bottom and then bottom to top so the leaves were soaked in both sides. About an hour later when checked, we did find multiple dead bugs and some cleared leaves. It's too early to tell if it'll work for clearing out all the little suckers, but I was pleased to find *some* of the bugs have either fallen off or died so it does seem to be working for aphids as well!The bees seem to be alright and currently are visiting the sprayed plants; the only drawback is, this does have a very... peculiar? smell, I'm not sure how to describe it, but it's pretty funky and it stays on the plants even after they're dried.*Review will be updated as we do more treatments*

I pulled the cuke plants as totally lost, then ordered this. The first application visibly slowed the progress of the fungus, and three weeks later I am harvesting some tomatoes, and just started getting some eggplants. I now think I might have even saved one cuke vine. I'll be using this weekly through the entire growing season next year.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2023
review_content: It's taken me a while to write this review but after a full year using it on my roses I still don't quite know if I liked it or not. It's very easy to use but my success has been so-so. I started spraying this on my roses leaves as soon as they started appearing, as instructed, and all growing season last year I faithfully applied the spray to my rose leaves every other week, as instructed. The photo attached shows that I still, despite consistent application, got spots on my leaves though I will admit the spots weren't as bad as the previous year. I also noticed, but forgot to take a picture of, was that as the season progressed the spots did appear less frequently and I even had a good amount of leaves with no spots, I hesitate to say this product solved the problem. It helped certainly and I'll continue to use it again this upcoming year but it wasn't a miracle product. Maybe I was doing something wrong, I don't know. I would rate this 3.5/ 5 as it does help the spotting to some extent but didn't solve it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2020
review_content: I‚Äôm thrilled! I wish I‚Äôd discovered this product sooner. BioAdvanced is saving my diseased roses after a black spot riddled spring and summer. Several roses also suffered from mold and this stuff treats that. It‚Äôs even restored a climber with sickly pale leaves that no amount of fertilizer could improve. I considered digging up that pitiful rose and am delighted with its healthy green growth. That must‚Äôve been some kind of fungus, too. This product treats multiple diseases and hasn‚Äôt harmed my beneficials. Ive tried various organic fungicides religiously for years but none of them worked. Our western Virginia weather is hard on roses and mine were dwindling from losing so many leaves and canes to disease. Now they‚Äôre flourishing. BioAdvanced also treats the leaf spot on my phlox, Iris, and day lilies, the rust on hollyhocks, and mildew on bee balm... Next season if I begin spraying in April, I‚Äôll have much happier plants, and I might be able to spray less if I get on top of disease early. For those who insist mulching roses with quality compost gives them enough oomph to resist disease, I want to say I do that. I also add worm castings, but the plants still got sick. I needed help and this is it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2022
review_content: I finally used this for my 12 rosebushes after noticing some spotting on the leaves and powdery mold on them as summer has come. It was a pain to administer the product because I don‚Äôt have my sprayer for the amount you need to dilute. For the roses, I first poured 3 gallons of water into a bucket and then poured in the recommended product carefully (1 1/2 TBSP) for each gallon of water. Then I put on gloves and dipped a regular spray bottle in the bucket to fill it and sprayed each rosebush thoroughly. Problem is, it‚Äôs impossible to get every part of the bush this way, and in the end I put quite a bit around the base of the rosebush because I read the product goes through the roots. Directions are vague.It was a heck of a job but I already notice much less mold and rust. I also trimmed the roses way back and I think that helped as well.I plan to do another application after 2 weeks. Seems to be working, so I‚Äôm happy.By the way the product goes a long way so it‚Äôs a good value for the money.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2011
review_content: We bought this to get rid of black spot that was killing our newly-established rose garden.  We had planted Knock-Outs, which are supposed to be disease-resistant, but they got the disease anyway.  The leaves all dropped and the bushes looked terrible.  After reading many threads about how to get rid of black spot, we decided on Bayer.  I am not disappointed!  We have only put on one application and already the bushes are reviving.  The new growth is green - no sign of the disease.  We will put on another application as recommended and continue to use it to be sure the roses stay healthy.I looked for this product at local stores and found the Bayer Disease and Insect Control, which I did not want.  We had a lot of bees on the flowers and did not want to kill them.  This product gets rid of the disease without harming the bees.My only complaint was the shipping fee.  I have no idea why it was so expensive ($18.00!!!), but I felt it was a way to protect my investment of the rose garden so I paid the fee.  I give this product a rating of 4 stars because of the shipping, but the quality of the product is definitely a 5!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2021
review_content: Update:  it worked great!  Almost every leaf has black spot mold and I didn‚Äôt know if the vines would survive losing all leaves, but, two weeks later, new leaves, buds, and it came back!  I fertilized, also,  But the blooms are smaller and not as much fragrance.  I applied a 2nd spray two weeks later, as directed, and even though we had more rain since first spray, it still worked.  Better wear a hazmat suit!  After I read the instructions, I was worried to use it!  Trying to save my climbing rose vines after two weeks of rain! Just about every leaf had black spot . I mixed up a quart and used a plant mister.  Hope it works!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
review_content: If you‚Äôre growing cannabis, don‚Äôt spray this stuff! I didn‚Äôt realize until after I sprayed my only hemp plant that this product is waterproof. This is also bad for your lungs. If you make the dumb decision I did to spray this on anything you‚Äôre planning on smoking, eating or anything, don‚Äôt look online or on the site because there‚Äôs zero information on how to clean your leaves of this stuff. Luckily it only stays in the plant for two weeks, and I had only 7 weeks left to go to harvest. How to clean your leaves should you make this blunder? Use milk, oil, and hot water. Wet a washcloth and rub the leaves with this solution. You can also use baking soda and water. I cleaned the leaves about three times with this solution, and it was a lot of work. Please read everything and google this product before you buy. I don‚Äôt like that it‚Äôs waterproof, because if you accidentally get some on the wrong plant, there‚Äôs zero information on how to clean the plant. Also I no longer like this brand because it‚Äôs not natural and is unsafe to animals and the environment. If you have a cat, don‚Äôt use this! Cats sometimes nibble on plants so this can be very toxic. Sorry but I‚Äôm sticking to natural for now on. You‚Äôre better off just spraying your plants with oil and milk to remove mold and keep away pests. Or baking soda and water. At least it‚Äôs not unsafe and not hard to rinse away unlike this nightmare. I really should‚Äôve seen this coming but this is my warning to you before you decide to buy

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2017
review_content: Our Bradford Pear trees got a fungus a couple years ago. Everything I read on the internet and all the people I talked to said, they are going to die. Chop them down and replace them.  These are nice big trees. I know they are short lived but they still have a lot of years left and they give us a lot of needed shade while the long lived trees are growing up.  So, I got this CHEMICAL.  I am not a fan of CHEMICALS but those trees are not near any river or creek runoffs, not near any of my gardens, so I decided to give it a go. It worked!  The trees lost all their leaves from the fungus, I got this, hubby poured around the tree according to directions and the next year, the trees came back.  Not perfect, but we use this each spring and this year... they look good as they ever did.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
review_content: Bought this to treat some powdery mildew on my pansies. Before I opened it up, I did a bit of research on Tebuconazole, the active ingredient, and its impact on wild bees. According to a UMass study, as well as a 2019 study from WSU, tebuconazole has an extended residual toxicity (ERT) of around 2 days.The label notes this is toxic to fish and mammals and you should only apply it 3x per YEAR 14 days apart for most plants. It also lists itself as a pesticide (although this may just be a broader scientific categorization that fungicide falls under)While I love my pansies and there is not much definitive info on if this is toxic for the environment, I‚Äôve decided to return it and not take any chances.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2021
review_content: I‚Äôve had the worst time with shotgun fungus in my mulch and black spot all over my plants. It was to the point many of my plants no longer had leaves as I was pruning off so much to get rid of the black spot.I treated my plants with this product three times, each treatment two weeks apart. By the third treatment, most of the black spot was gone and shotgun fungus was dead. One plant died after treatment, but all my other plants have new fungus-free growth.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: I have about 15 roses in my yard and black spot spread to nearly all of them.  I used Daconil fungicide, which is sprayed on and plants and leaves a white residue.  It did not work at all and black spot spread to more roses around my yard.  This year I tried BioAdvanced and I'm amazed that it has completely eliminated black spot from every rose in my yard.  I followed the instructions and did 3 applications.  I started in March (in Massachusetts) just when the leaves were starting to come out.  then I did 2 more applications every 2 weeks.  Black spot is completely gone and all new growth looks healthy.  I definitely recommend this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: We had a big mountain laurel that was near death, with a horrendous fungal infection destroying every leaf on the thing. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2024
review_content: We have had mealybugs on our house flowers for several years. This is an infection that is difficult to remove. I have always used spinosad, which I respect very much. However,‚Äãthese bad guys seemed to be hiding in the roots and coming out onto the leaves again and again. I bought a systemic insecticide. However, I was afraid to water my collection citrus and coffee trees with the full amount (as the instructions advised). The systemic insecticide appears to have weakened the mealybug population. This drug helped destroy the remaining ones. however, I also diluted it with 3 parts solution and 1 part water. I always try diluted first. Plants are very dear to me in every way. One thing, a respirator is required. Perhaps this kills parasites inside a person (just kidding) I didn't do any experiments.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2024
