review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2020
review_content: This is my first time using a systemic product.  The pros outweigh the cons.  However, I was out of Rose Rx, which I use on everything, and I could get this quicker,  Now I may stay with the systemic. Rose Rx works wonderful but I feel like I have to use it every 1 to 2 days to  manage insects.  I am new to planting flowers and maintaining them.  It's a lot of work and expensive and it's hard to find what really works and on what.  I hope the following details help,.HibiscusThis is my first time using systemic product.  I sprayed this on 4 mature hardy hibiscus ( 2 years old and 3ft tall) to address Japanese Beetles..  They appear to be gone but they were already into when they disappear so I cannot confirm it was the spray.  (5 stars if I could confirm it took care of the beetles)AnnualsI sprayed it on two small posts of red salvia and white begonias as a preventative against leaf miner which I eradicated about a month prior.  No sign of sock.RosesI sprayed on two mini roses (7 months old planted from root ball) as a preventative.HydrangeasI can say that in one day the spray, even after a heavy rain, significantly reduced rust on my young phantom hydrangea (2 years flowering)  and two vanilla strawberry hydrangea trees (3 months no flowers).  Rose Rx works well but never this quickly and dramatically.The rust was the result of almost 3 weeks of rain to include 14 inches in one week.  After I sprayed, we had heavy rain that night and the next morning.  I checked and the rust had lightened significantly.  My phantom and trees was covered in rust and now it was almost gone.  I could not believe it.I sprayed this on my other hydrangeas, planted just a month ago and all with blooms (4 gallon pot size--Quickfire, Limelight, Inrediball, and 5 gallon Vanilla Strawberry shrub form).  I focused on the leaves but I am sure some got on the blooms.  I think it's safe for blooms but the package suggests not spraying because of bees and other pollinators.  I  did make sure there were no pollinators when I sprayed.  All the hydrangeas seem to be responding well; no sign of shock from the spray.  No problems with the blooms.NegativesThere is a strong odor and there has to be no wind. The leaves feel a little stiffer on all the hydrangea.  However, the types I listed have leaves naturally thicker and coarser feel.  I think the spray added a little more texture. Even after rain, the texture was still there so that at least tells me it adhered as the product describes.  The other negative is if you bring blooms and leaves in the house, I would be careful that there isn't a chance of the cuts coming into contact with food. This is a toxic, non organic spray.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2023
review_content: This product worked, once I really doused my plant in it.I moved into a house with lots of flowering plants in the yard, but I knew nothing about gardening. I first noticed black spots and white powdery stuff on a giant rhododendron in 2020. Was it a fungus? Mildew? I had no idea. Not thinking much of it, I just trimmed away the handful of affected branches.The black spots and white powder were back in 2021. I bought this spray and used it kind of meekly. I can be mechanically challenged and was actually intimidated by the hose connection; the printed instructions made it sound confusing but once I saw the spraying mechanism, it made sense. I was surprised at how big and far-reaching the spray was, so doing a quick once-over seemed like enough at the time.In 2022, the black spots and white powder came back with a vengeance. Now I was getting worried. I actually did 3 things:1. I aggressively cut away the blighted branches. I mean, I really butchered it.2. I cut away branches that were low to the ground and reached waaaaay under the bush to rake away old fallen leaves and dead branches. Maybe this is obvious and something an experienced homeowner would do as regular maintenance, but it was something new for this gardening newb.3. I used this spray GENEROUSLY. I started on the far side and made sure the spray reached the very back of the bush, top to bottom, then slowly made my way around the plant, making sure the spray reached the trunk and every inch of interior branches and leaves.Now it's 2023, and I put down new mulch in the spring. I've been so relieved to see new leaves growing in to fill all the empty spots that had been cut away, and I'm thrilled to report that I see NO black spots or white powdery stuff!!So, along with trimming and doing general plant clean-up, I do credit this spray with reviving my rhododendron.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2020
review_content: Go no further. You can go with the need or whatever all that other stuff is. I tried several for my...let's just say broccoli to get rid of spider mites. I didn't even know I had them at first, I started getting bit in bed I have my tents in my room, either that or I was getting bit after turning off the lights and just didn't start scratching till I went to sleep. Then as most of you know as I was watering one day I see these big round balls/sacks yellowish and golden brown, some milky white rolling around in the Coco and whatnot. Kinda knew what it was but thought spiders only got outdoors this is my first time really going hard or whatever indoors. Picked one up and splat, luckily it wasn't mature. There were several in all the pots I tried all the oil stuff/ need-humbolt oils that said it would knock them out. They all seem to work but only for a few days, and the one thing in assuming none of them did that this stuff did was kill the eggs and the spiders. I only had to apply this stuff twice and I have seen one egg or sack since. With the other stuff, every 3 or 4 days it was like the eggs would even multiply and I would really soak them and do it at night with the lights off. This stuff lights on light to medium spray and nothing since. I'm going to give them one more spray before the flowers start to get really plump even thkuit says through harvest on non edibles. But I highly recommend this it takes out all the extra money and time those eggs really freak me out but I only say one actual mite the whole time through the observation window and those things are super predator aware as soon as I opened the tent that thing turned into a ghost. Never got a chance to from a web or cluster either, great stuff.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
review_content: This is a very hard one to write, but I feel compelled to share my experiences since I‚Äôve only used this to eradicate mites on my indoor houseplants.First off, yes, this completely annihilated the creepy critters that I‚Äôd first found on an Alocasia. The alocasia survived, but I feel like it does have a slightly slower growth ever since. It‚Äôs not a flourishing plant, but the bugs are gone.The second time I used it was on my variegated monstera, which I discovered a ton of tiny white mites crawling in the top soil. Addressing the top soil, they are completely gone. This was very recent so I am still hopeful the plant survives.The reason I want to write this review is to let you know this is a VERY harsh chemical. Do not use it unless it‚Äôs an absolute emergency. Wear a face mask, goggles and kitchen gloves and only use the product outside. The odor alone will make you cough, and I personally am not one that coughs other than for the extremely obvious reasons. I‚Äôd recommend a shower after as well. Set it to a mist and use it sparingly so you don‚Äôt give your plants too much of this. Good luck with whatever you‚Äôre dealing with. I will recommend this stuff, but yeah I‚Äôve personally referred to this product as ‚Äúthe crazy stuff‚Äù.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020
review_content: I tried EVERYTHING to get rid of the spider mites on my plumeria. I searched high and low across the interwebs for a solution that works and the only things anybody would recommend were "natural" or "organic" like neem oil and citric acid or vinegar. Well I tried all of those. I tried soap and water. I tried blasting the buggers off. I soaked the soil in the stuff.  But the treatments destroyed my plants and the mites ALWAYS came back with a vengeance.I tried looking up chemical miticides but information is just apparently really hard to find - probably because the entire internet is crowded with junk advice like the above. But I did eventually find this. They advertise as "Science-based" and I do love me some science. I read the ingredients, read the MSDS for the solution as well as each of the active ingredients separately, and of course checked reviews. And then I bought it.AND THIS STUFF WORKS.Mites gone. Plants healthy. No, I mean HEALTHY. I haven't seen the leaves on my plumeria look this good in ages! It also eliminated the cross-contaminated mites from my citrus bonzai. Now that I have this I'm saddened that I gave up on my jackfruit because of the mite infestation.I won't use this outdoors because I keep honeybees. Please think of the bees before using this in your yard.It is non-edible so don't apply to anything you plan to eat. (Thankfully spider mites don't like pineapple!)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2021
review_content: Insect, mite, fungal disease -- if there‚Äôs something evil plaguing your baby (ies) and you want it dead, this will make it dead. I'm honestly convinced that the people this didn't work for used it incorrectly (e.g., didn't spray behind/ under the leaves, didn't remove infected/ infested growth,etc. ) because when it comes to the question of whether this stuff works, it works. Sometimes you have to spray a couple of times in case you missed a spot, but it works. That being said, this isn't your hippie dippie "DIY get rid of mealy bugs with these 5 regular household ingredients!" this is a POTENT chemical insecticide/miticide/fungicide and wearing PPE is a MUST. If you can't get your hands on a particulate respirator (which at the time of writing this, you should not because COVID), then double or triple up on non-fabric face masks because this will launch full frontal assault on your nasal passages. Wear gloves and goggles just to be safe too.  And no, you cannot spray this inside your house. If this is not something you're comfortable, go back to spraying your plants with milk, and leave the stuff that actually does something for the rest of us.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2021
review_content: The products look identical right.  I thought so too.  Bioadvanced (formerly branded Bayer) mades a fine product that bears # 71262 in the title. This one bears #06328687 and it is  very different in terms of formula and protection period.  I didn't notice until after I got this one and it is going back!  Why? Because model #71262 provides 6 weeks of protection while the this one states you need to apply it every 7 to 14 days. One ingredient in common is the fungicide Tebuconazole. In the #06328687 they REDUCED the amount of the ingredient by about 20% which is why you likely need to apply it more often. Applied every 14 days makes this product 3Xs more expensive!! No thanks. These companies are getting greedy. You have to remember that when you read the labels of all manufactures, they list the "active ingredients" which in general comprise less than 2% of the product. The other 98% is mostly water!! We seem to pay a lot for mostly water don't you think?

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2020
review_content: I planted about 20 Drift and Knock Out Roses last fall and they all began to develop black spot, my Drift roses looked especially bad. Prior to application I pruned all the roses (and discarded the diseased leaves) and they are all beginning to put out healthy new growth. I‚Äôm going to continue to treat them until all the black spots are gone, then continue to use this product monthly throughout the summer and will probably add it to my routine care for some of my other plants. For those concerned about bees... it‚Äôs always best practice to apply pesticides and insecticides at dusk when the bees have already gone to sleep, it reduces the chances of causing them any harm.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2020
review_content: This product is incredibly easy and so effective to use. This year, I planted tropical milkweed. After a couple months of beautiful growth, much to my dismay, aphids decided to invade the plant. The plant started dropping leaves and all the remaining leaves were turning yellow. It looked like the Charlie Brown Christmas Tree of plants. I honestly thought I would need to remove the milkweed, as it seemed covered with bugs and (eggs?)... disclaimer, I do not have a green thumb, am new to ornamentals-  and was at a loss as to what to do here. I read this product treated aphids, and while milkweed was not listed, was drawn to the idea of placing granules on the ground and letting the product do the job. I was nervous about liquid insecticides and such, having never used products like that before and liked the idea of a fertilizer with this product. I treated this milkweed similar to a shrub and used half a capful and watered it in thoroughly. I didn‚Äôt bother burying it like it suggested; just sprinkled it around the base and watered in. In about a week, this plant looks like it has come alive and completely looks different. I see no live bugs on it and new leaves have sprouted out everywhere, and it looks so perky. It has completely saved the plant. I‚Äôm now planning on using it on some of my other shrubs/plants as I am excited by how well the fertilizer portion helped the milkweed.

I was lucky there was no spillage.As to the product, it is excellent on my roses and other plants in my yard. Best product I have ever used that provides so many benefits.  Thank You, Bayer.

review_content: I used the systemic 3 in1  last year and found it very easy to use.  I have mobility issues, but I love gardening and especially my roses. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2022
review_content: I had been fighting a fungus and some sort of caterpillar that was eating the roses. I tried this product it does a good job with fertilizing. My roses started to grow faster with more blooms. The fungus went away so did the bugs but when the time frame for it to work came up it definitely stopped working. It has to be applied the number of weeks that it says in the directions to keep the product working all season. It was not very easy to apply because you have to measure the amount into the provided measuring cup and then put that amount into your watering can. I have a lot of roses I should have purchased the one that connects directly to the hose.  I imagine  that would have made application easier. The pellet form of the product I have also used and that is very difficult to apply because you have to dig up your dirt and put them in the ground, it‚Äôs more work to use those. As long as you follow the directions, the product does what it says it will do. Something which I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs related to the product or not, this winter I had a number of rosebushes that froze and even three of them froze to death. I had never had that happen before. I generally don‚Äôt cover my roses in the winter. I‚Äôm in Chicago. Last summer was the first summer I used this product. Last winter was the first winter that I did anything for the roses to help them during the winter. I pruned them down and covered them with leaf mulch. Several of the roses that had stems sticking out above the leaf mulch had stems that froze and had to be cut back almost to the ground in the spring. Three of the roses died completely. I had never had that happen before. I have no idea if it is related to the fact that I used this product that summer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2022
review_content: after buying some rose starters online, they had arrived with black spot. there were yellowed leaves falling off and signs of black spot disease that looked pretty bad, as shown in the first photo.i bought this stuff immediately as it was recommended from the seller, and figured why not try it out. i applied it as directed at the base of the canes, and as added protection have been spraying neem oil mixed with dish soap and water on the leaves every few weeks when theres no rain to help lessen the spread of the black spot while the fertilizer mix has been treating my plant. the bioadvanced was applied may 19th as soon as it arrived and it is now almost 4 weeks of the 6 week cover period, june 13th and my roses are thriving beautifully when i was sure they might die off from the infection. the leaves are lush and a lovely green and have little to no black spot left so it is being treated appropriately. and the blooms are just starting to open up and grow now, and the plant is really thriving!i think the only thing that confuses me a little about this product is the combined disease protection and mix with fertilizer that makes me wary to apply any rose food so that i don't burn the plant or over fertilize. but so far this product is doing my roses a great service.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: We've had these rhododendrons along our back deck for more than 30 years.  About 8 years ago the leaves started turning yellow, the entire plant was looking sick due to mites.  We were spraying an insecticide on them 3 times a year, as directed by a professional agronomist.  After about 5 years, they plants were looking worse and worse but we weren't seeing an improvement in the mite infestation.  I ran across the Bayer 3-in1 product and began using it.  The leaves are now healthy, mite-free, and look at those blooms!!  They are full  of blooms. I have never seen rhododendrons so lush.  When I started using it on the rhododendrons, I also started using it on my azaleas and knock-out roses, having the same results.  Profuse blooms.  I also no longer have to spray my roses for Japanese beetles.  I find it much more pleasant to toss these granules at the base of my shrubs rather than spray nauseating insecticides on my lovely plants, plus I'm getting profusely blooming and healthy shrubs out of it. Highly recommend it!  I use the cap as the measuring cup.  the only problem I have is that I cannot get the lids off by myself until after my husband first opens them for me.  If you have arthritis or small hands, the large childproof caps are difficult.  I apply it the first Sat or the month or the next pretty say after the first Saturday of the month from May through September.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2015
review_content: I've used this product for three years and have obtained more for use during this spring and summer.  I live in the southwest which is not particularly hospitable to any plants let alone roses.  The humidity is very low and the clay-like soil is devoid of most nutrients.  Prior to using Bayer Advanced All-in-One all my roses developed powdery mildew and black spot fungus as soon as the weather warmed up.  I have found this product to be pretty effective in preventing these diseases.  Last year my Henry Kelsey, Stairway to Heaven  and Cl. Jeanne LaJoie roses were all spared infestations.  One Nearly Wild Rose (Floribunda) developed some powdery mildew.  All-in-One is therefore good for preventing infestations and diseases but is not 100 per cent effective in this regard.  I did not think All-in-One produced more blooms than conventional granular fertilizers.  I have also found that for maximal effectiveness it is better to apply this product every four weeks  and not every six weeks as recommended by the manufacturer.  Another change that I made was to water the roots prior to applying All-in-One.  The volume of each application as recommended in the instructions is small and I doubt that it can reach the entire root system without prior  and later watering.  Additionally, I used larger amounts than recommended by the manufacturer for larger rose bushes.  In conclusion, I find All-in-One indispensable.  I could not grow roses without it in my area.  I have not given it five stars though because I did not think it particularly effective in producing blooms that looked better or were more numerous than I got with conventional granular fertilizers and I did not think that it prolonged the blooming period.  However, the convenience of a single product to provide fertilization, to prevent and treat insect infestations such as aphids  and to prevent and treat fungal diseases is a huge advantage of this product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2017
review_content: We live in a California wine raising valley about 15 miles north of the bay and about 50 air miles to the ocean with a tidal river.  This results in foggy nights mornings, most of the year and high humidity. Great for the wine vines and not that great for roses.There can cause a lot of mildew with roses.  The budding season can start in early March and run into late November or early December. This increases the demand on the plants.with a long season.My wife has about 3 dozen roses of all types, and the conditions above made it tough to have thriving plants.Years ago we went to a Rose show with local Master Gardener to discuss the above problems.  Several recommended Bayer Advanced 701110 All in One Rose and. besides the regular timing to use if we saw signs of mildew, brown or yellow leaves. So we bought some and started using it as directed.The results have been tremendous with beautiful plants, year round and wonderful roses until the first freeze.This bottle size has enough product (about one capful/plant).  We keep it out on a shelf near the roses, and our yard man uses it when he or my wife thinks that it is indicated.We just had a hot July during the days with the cooler damp nights.  He added the product at the end of July.  We have new growth and new buds on every plant with healthy/dark green leaves/twigs.  My wife and the yard guy dead head any brown or yellow leaves. That is it re care with the exception of auto drip everyday instead of every other day due to the heat.  They are pruned back at the first freeze.Neighbors, local relatives and out of state friends and relatives can't believe how great our roses look.  Our midwest/east coast relatives wait for my first pictures of our great roses every spring to brighten their winter days in spring.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2016
review_content: I don't know what to make of the colorful attachments to my two Knockout Rose trees the past few days. Haven't seen that in months and months. I noticed that a bee was suspicious also...his faced buried in exploration.For nearly a year I was immensely loyal to the recommended organic products for those trees, the granular fertilizer in exact doses and remembered schedule. I had a few brief glimpses of blooms. Mostly leaves. Chewed leaves. Some yellow. I added loyalty to neem oil in all its cold pressed purity, along with insecticidal soap. Nicely blended and shook. So proud of myself.The leaves didn't care, and the bugs felt right at home. I had more blooms in my toilet than those trees.This blue bottle isn't cheap and the company obviously tries to trick you toward overdose. It's darn tough to stay within the inner capful as opposed to spilling over toward the rim. It actually feels like you're doing the right thing. The designers were rolling in laughter on that one. You'll be shelling out another 20 bucks sooner than you think.I smoothed an 18 inch range surrounding the stem and worked this stuff into the soil. I don't claim it was wonderfully balanced. Most likely I had a 55-45 tilt toward one side or another. Mosquitoes were trying to straighten me out but recently I'm trending against them.Some added soil on top and a brief watering. I knew this would work. It had to work, like a taunt at wasting all those organic months. Six days tops. That's all it took. More like three but I was determined to look away for a while. Too much hype and they'll jack the price.The nearby large family of lizards doesn't seem to realize it is supposed to be floundering and relocating, amidst all the chemical invasion.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2017
review_content: This stuff works great. This year we had a real bad Japanese Beetle infestation. I hate those damn things. They're pretty to look at but they'll eat every leave and most flowers you can grow. I tried some of that neem oil baloney but I'm not all that much of a tree hugger. It would make the beetles get agitated and fly off but I didn't see any dead beetles. I used this Bayer Rose and Flower Care stuff and dead beetles were everywhere. I guess it'll kill bees which I don't like. But buying, planting and tending to flowers and plants adds up to a pretty big investment. I'm not willing to let bugs eat up all my work. Plus the Japanese Beetle thing in this area usually only goes for about a month. After that I can use some neem oil or that Seven stuff. I know that I see Bees, Bumblebees and a Bee type bug that's in between those two in size and they are doing OK. The Japanese Beetle problem here in Missouri usually runs from mid-June to mid-July. Last year I had them real bad in about two dozen rose plants I had. They'll burrow right down into the flower and eat all they can. They did that again with the dahlias I grew this year. They'll eat everything from cannas to roses to the foliage and the flowers. I've even seen them eating on marigolds and I didn't think anything would chew on those nasty smelling things.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2017
review_content: Works great for roses! However you only want to use it as very lightly, and as shortest term possible, or your roses will get hooked, and not build up an immune system for themselves- much like kids. I currently have 63 rose bushes, and many other bushes, trees, plants etc I use the Bayer products to start out, and then rotate with Neem oil.Bayer one day week one, Neem oil same day on week two, so on,& so on until the roses strip dropping leaves like hot potatoes, then I do Neem oil every two weeks to stop any new black spot, and Neem oil is a insecticide too, so bonus!Both Bayer, and Neem oil work topically, and systemically- which means from the roots up. They both fight their best against fungus systemically- Neem oil works best against insects topically, so doing 14 day rotations with the two help your Roses defense while they are getting healthy (fertilizer application, removal of diseased leaves on ground, and on plant - but you have to leave enough leaves so the plant can survive) and as soon as you see your roses getting better start to put less then no Bayer. :) Just use Bayer like an aspirin not a cure for healthy roses! Your fertilization should come from better sources then Bayer.I DO recommend this product as long as you don't overuse.I also hope my review was helpful!!

review_content: I used Ortho products years ago and decided to add it to my arsenal again when my regular treatment for black spot wasn't working as well. I ordered this and the dial hose sprayer. First, the sprayer wastes a lot of product. I've flipped the nozzle and tried different water pressure; it is just wasteful. The second issue I have is that it makes the foliage stink. I usually wear gloves when I garden but if I bring in cut flowers, I have to keep my gloves on and remove all of the leaves. It is a smell you can't seem to wash off, so I'd definitely wear gloves when handling the flowers if you use this product. The last thing I'll say is that while it does seem to cut back on the black spot I'm seeing, it didn't work like it used to and I am still removing a lot of diseased leaves.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2020
review_content: We have an ongoing battle with black spot here in north central Texas.  I use the Ortho Garden Disease Control to control it and it works very well, but when conditions are bad, I have to spray up to three times a week to save my roses.  I have been looking for a systemic spray for quite a while and have tried a couple of products claiming to have systemic action for roses.  I decided to try the Ortho Rose and Flower Disease Control since the Ortho Garden Disease control works so well short term.  I sprayed my roses with it, and within three days they were covered with yellow leaves with black spot on them.  I contacted Ortho and their explanation was (copying directly from his email) "Many plant diseases cannot be controlled once the "symptoms" are apparent.  It may be that the product will not control this specific disease."  Does that even make sense?  Black spot is one of the list of diseases they control, but now they are saying in their email that it may not control this specific disease.  So disappointed once again.  They are at least going to reimburse me for the product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2023
review_content: It worked ok to get bugs off my roses. But when I tried it on other flowering plants (bacopa for instance) that had whiteflies it worked very poorly although label says it kills whiteflies. Even daily spraying didn't help. They claim it is also systemic - well I saw no evidence of that over several weeks because the whiteflies were just fine. I finally used Bonide's indoor houseplant systemic granules for insects and even though this flowering plant was outdoors in a pot, that worked although it took a few days. So while Rose Shield may be systemic for its fungicide I don't think it is for bugs since on other plants I tried literally for weeks, daily, to kill those whiteflies and they just kept coming. I could get the backs of leaves to be clear of all whiteflies while spraying but they came right back so I don't think it was due to eggs hatching. I think it just doesn't work as systemic for bugs. Or possibly it absorbs so slowly that your plant will be half-dead before it works. Next year I am going to start with Neem Oil, which works very slowly but if you start before the whiteflies show up it apparently works very well to keep them off your plants, according to what I have read.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
review_content: Do your research. Research the top ingredients of this product.Difenoconazole and Thiamethoxam appear to make spider mite infestations worsen, and speed up their reproduction.I can say from experience this is a fact.I purchased this as an effort to find a systemic that will work on Spider Mites, as I had a few houseplants that had very mild infestations (maybe one or two mites per leaf, no webbing etc)After using this product, the mites exploded and tripled. I resorted to using MiteX, which in the past would wipe out the mites quickly. They returned with a vengeance, and the MiteX did absolutely nothing. I then used Captain Jacks Deadbug brew, and the mites keep coming back next day, no matter how much I treat.Stupidly, I thought maybe I didnt apply enough of the Rose Shield. So I did a second application a few weeks later.Again, the spider mites came back, FAST, and MANY. Almost immediately after that second application.After doing some research, I found that the top ingredients in this product actually are known to worsen spider mite infestations.... so why on EARTH is Bonide listing Spider Mites as a controlled pest.I contacted Bonide for help with this.They had stated that the reason why this product didnt work is because I used it on houseplants. This is BS. They said the spider mites that I have on my houseplants must be different than the spider mites outdoors. Which again, BS. I have identified the mites Im battling as two-spotted and red mites, which are common to infect outdoor plants as well as houseplants.They seemed more concerned about me using this product on houseplants. I figured since the bottle said that the area was safe to inhabit once the spray was dry, meant that it would be okay on houseplants as long as you weren't spraying them inside. But apparently not, apparently co-existing with plants indoors that were previously treated with this chemical is very dangerous to you and your pets health. I understand that houseplants werent listed on the label. But a lot of houseplants are considered ornamentals, which are listed on the label.So 3 reasons I cant recommend this product:-It doesnt work as described-It seems to be more dangerous of a chemical than the label makes it seem-Poor customer service

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2023
review_content: Just wanted to share my experience with Atrazine Herbicide. I've been using it for a while now, and it's been a pretty reliable ally in my gardening battles.The effectiveness is pretty decent. It does a good job of controlling most common weeds and my lawn has definitely seen better days since I started using it. It‚Äôs not perfect - a few stubborn ones still peek through now and again, but it's managed to keep the majority at bay.The mixing and application process is straightforward, although, I'd have appreciated a bit more clarity on the instructions.Where it really shines, though, is its lasting effect. I've noticed fewer applications are needed compared to other products I've tried, which is definitely a win in my book.While I've had a good run with Atrazine, there's a small room for improvement. If the product could tackle all the weed varieties and the instructions were a bit clearer, it'd be hitting a solid 5 stars. Still, all in all, a solid 4-star performer. A reasonable choice for any gardener looking for reliable weed control.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
review_content: There may be local or state laws regarding how you can use Atrazine in your yard.  I try to be careful, using it once a year only, but this last winter was an exception.An invasive grass invaded my St. Auustine Palmetto backyard over the winter, and I have had a heck of a time getting rid of it.  It is a creeping type grass that came from one of my neighbors yards.  I've been able to dig a barrier on the property line to keep it from happening again, and now I"m dealing with what's remaining in my yard.The Atrazine did kill the surface greens with one application.  It took about 7 to 10 days, so don't expect the instant effects that glyphosate gives.  Now, part of the issue here is that after about a month, the grass started growing back.  I expected this might happen, so I fully expected to have to do two applications.  I tried to space them as much apart as possible knowing that I really shouldn't do a third application until next year.Here is where it got interesting.  After the greens died from the second application, they started coming back again.  But most of the new grass started growing from old, brown shoots that were left behind from the less-than-stellar thatch job that I did (I was too worried about killing my St. Augustine).  That meant that most of the new shoots were really easy to find and dispose of by hand.  That was actually kind of fun...but on a pair of gloves, follow the steam as close to the ground as possible, and give it a good yank.  Watch in wonder as five other nearby tufts came out in one fell swoops.My lawn is recovering.  I'm convinced that as long as I do rudimentary hand weeding once a week through the summer, that I will be able to solve the problem.  There were some large dead areas where the invasive grass had completely taken over, and the St. Augustine is filling them nicely.The truth is, there really wasn't any alternative to this to do the job I needed to do.  I didn't necessarily need to kill every weed in my backyard.  I just needed to get them down to a manageable level.  This did the job.And now I know that just because it's wintertime in Phoenix doesn't mean that I can neglect my yardwork.EDIT:After a good six months, the area where I heavily treated my lawn looks amazing with a couple of caveats.Essentially the middle of my yard is perfect.  The borders are not-so-perfect.  I tried solarizing one half (worked extremely well, but I left a tarp over that section of the yard for a good 8 weeks).  I tried doing some small spot spraying on the other half.  What I learned is that this stuff *will* kill St. Augustine if you apply too much.I think I'm pretty much done using it, though.  I ended up using a little less than half of the bottle, but I also have a very small yard.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020
review_content: 2021 update:The stuff works (eventually), but there are significant drawbacks.Pros - It does work (eventually) to kill weeds without harming centipede.Cons:* Even under optimum conditions following a recent rain and applying at the recommended concentration of 4.5 oz/gal, it takes a minimum of 2 weeks to see any results and 3-4 weeks for a complete kill.  The problem is that many weeds can mature and go to seed within that period of time which means a brand new batch next year.* The label claims pre-emergence weed control, but early spraying does not seem to reduce spring weeds.* Internal medicine MD's are now starting to link atrazine with the same immunosuppression and male hormone suppression effects as BPA in plastics, so take appropriate precautions to avoid contact or inhaling when spraying.Overall, 2, 4D acts much faster on centipede lawns with nearly the range of weed types killed.https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0072289CA/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1Use it first and save the atrazine for whatever it doesn't get, if you use it at all.2020 Update:Four weeks after initial application about 75% of treated weeds are showing signs of distress.  While the product does seem to work you need the patience of Job (and the good graces of the neighbors) to wait for the results.Original post:Two Weeks, No Observable Results...Used a 4 oz/gal mix and weeds had a full 48 hours of cool dry weather before rain.  Weather has been mild, 40-65F.  Two weeks on, the weeds seem to be doing just fine....  :-(

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2020
review_content: It's HARD to find herbicides that won't kill a centipede grass lawn.  The common stuff that is in most 2-4D, when applied thick enough to kill weeds, will also kill your grass.The only downside to atrazine - it's SLOW to work.  It takes a good 1-2 weeks to see measurable dieback of weeds, and works best on young weeds that have recently started to germinate.  Timing is important..It kills weeds at the roots, so you have to water it in good.  I found that it works best on some broadleaf weeds if I scalp the weeds first, then spray, to get to the roots better.  Scalping weeds can be done with centipede since you are probably cutting it short anyways.

review_content: I will caution the user to be careful where you apply this product as this is a strong herbicide that will permanently kill woody plants, shrubs, and tress.  It was so satisficing to see stubborn, established poison ivy dry up and die in 5 days given 3 applications on 3 consecutive days.  I have wild blackberry all over my garden thanks to the birds and cat briar on the bird feeders pooping out the seeds. These both spread through underground runners. Now all are dead and no new vines are popping up! I had some woody bushes  removed, painted the stumps with undiluted product, no new green shoots from stump. It is dead down to the roots! This is the best weed killer bar none. It even kills Kudzu!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2022
review_content: First off, the effectiveness of the Southern Ag Amine 2,4-D WEED KILLER, 32oz was uneven. However, I'm going to try using it again next year to see if it was my own fault. I SUSPECT I DIDN'T MIX IT THOROUGHLY ENOUGH. It's really important to pay close attention to the instructions. Maybe I need to follow my own advice.I had a bunch of mallow-type weeds. Spectracide and Ortho - even with 2, 4-D as an ingredient - didn't do anything to the mallow. I did some research and it seems that those consumer weed-killers don't have enough 2, 4-D to kill more robust weeds like mallow. Both on Google and Youtube, people recommended getting 2, 4-D, mixing it per the instructions and applying it RATHER than the consumer grade herbicides.I mixed the Southern Ag product with water and surfactant per the directions. I can't guarantee that I did it right. I sprayed the mix on mallow throughout my yard.The weeds that I sprayed first developed white patches/spots after a week. They stopped growing and slowly, over a few weeks, clearly died and withered away.Many of the weeds that I sprayed, as I got to the bottom of the mix, did not develop those same white patches. They didn't shrivel up and about a month after treatment, they were still there. It may be that I didn't mix the 2, 4-D, water and surfactant adequately because there was a big difference in the effectiveness of the first areas that I sprayed vs the last areas.I have quite a bit left and plan to try again next year.

With 2,4-D Amine weed killer I don‚Äôt have to do that anymore, you see noticeable results within a day or two. Once you keep doing every two mi the or so, your lawn will never see weeds again. A little goes a long way. I have enjoyed a beautiful lawn free of weeds for the past two years. I highly recommend this product and will continue to buy it!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
review_content: This combination is specifically for controlling bindweed and NOT meant to be used willy nilly. If you've dealt with bindweed, you already understand the frustration. Use ~ 4oz of 2,4-D per gallon of glyphosate. This is best applied when bindweed is actively growing in spring and early summer. Note that it will take at least 2 seasons to kill an established bindweed patch if all new growth is sprayed weekly. Bindweed has an EXTENSIVE root system (15+ feet vertically and growing 10+ feet in diameter Per Season) so the exercise is to starve this massive root system. Which requires removing or killing any top growth as quickly as possible to starve the root system. This combination penetrates further into the root system than glyphosate or 2,4-D alone so the plant has to spend more energy regenerating that root system thus starving it faster.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
review_content: First, I must make it clear that this product DOES work very well. I have no issues there at all. But...‚ÄúHello.‚Äù‚ÄúThis is Jean, the Postmaster,‚Äù said the angry voice on the phone. ‚ÄúWhat the hell did you order? What IS this stuff?‚Äù‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù‚ÄúWe have a package here for you. It‚Äôs leaking some kind of chemical - it stinks! Did you order something? We need to know what this is! It‚Äôs ruined six other packages and got all over the mail! It‚Äôs leaking all over!‚ÄùAfter a moment of thought, ‚ÄúWell, I think my wife ordered some shampoo from Amaz‚Ä¶ WAIT. I bet it‚Äôs the weed killer! I did order some weed killer a week or two ago.‚Äù‚ÄúWell what the hell do you want me to do with this?‚Äù asked the Postmaster. ‚ÄúDo I need to call HAZMAT?‚Äù‚ÄúI dunno - if you need to know what it is, go ahead and open the package, I‚Äôm fine with that.‚Äù‚ÄúI‚ÄôM NOT GOING TO TOUCH THAT STUFF! God it stinks. I‚Äôm going to get everyone out of the building.‚Äù I heard a muffled, ‚Äúgaaaaack,‚Äù then *click*Sure enough, a few hours later I went outside to find a package on my deck next to my mail. Even though the post office had double-bagged the package it was still noticeably odiferous. I put on my work gloves, grabbed the package, and went up to my shed to see what had happened.Inside the bag was clear plastic bag the post office had put on the package. I could see chemical gunk oozing out. Inside the USPS bag was the original packaging - a plastic bubble-wrap bag. I opened it all up as carefully as I could to find that of the two quart bottles of Amine I‚Äôd ordered had been crushed, and nearly all the weed killer had oozed out. (The shipper had simply put two bottles in a bubble-wrap mailer. I would have expected the package to be bagged and boxed, but what do I know?)I cleaned the mess up best I could, wiped everything down, stored the weed killer in a well-ventilated spot in my shed, washed up in the cold outdoor hydrant, and went inside to write a note to the shipper explaining the whole mess, asking them to maybe call the Postmaster to apologize. Within a day or two I received an answer from the shipper saying they would replace the quart that had been damaged. Cool ‚Äònuff.All this was a million miles away from my mind a few days later when I was out in my grove clearing a bit of deadwood and my phone rang. My wife. I pulled my gloves off and poked the ‚Äúanswer‚Äù button. ‚ÄúHello?‚Äù‚ÄúI need help!‚Äù *thud* silence.My wife is disabled and has many health issues. If Usain Bolt had been there, I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôd have beat him to the house by quite a wide margin - in less than a minute I opened the front door to see my wife laying on the floor, walker on its side. Just as I reached her she went into a full-body seizure. I cradled her head in my hands to keep her from whanging her bean on the floor too hard and waited for the seizure to pass, but just a few seconds into the seizure she made an odd gasping noise and quit breathing. CRAP! The seizures happen fairly often, but it's rare for her to quit breathing.I held her head a few more seconds until her seizure rolled her over on her side, then I bolted to her room to get her nebulizer and asthma medication. Just as I had the nebulizer plugged in and the medicine was percolating into mist her seizure ended. I got the mouthpiece into her and kinda shook her a bit hoping to God she‚Äôd start breathing again. Thankfully she did, a very small gasp, then as a bit of the medicine got into her airway a very large gasp. Within seconds she was breathing normally again and regained consciousness shortly after. She gazed up at me, a tender look in her eye, and very gently said, ‚ÄúWhat the hell stinks? I can barely breathe!‚ÄùI blinked at her for a moment, trying to figure out what‚Ä¶ Oh crap! My gloves! I‚Äôd used those gloves when I‚Äôd cleaned the chemical spill days before! I‚Äôd dropped them on the floor by the door when I ran in, and I probably had some of the chemical smell on my hands as well from wearing the gloves earlier.As all this crossed my mind in a flash my wife closed her eyes and quit breathing again. In a whirlwind I got more asthma meds in the inhaler, threw my gloves out the door, ran my hands under the sink, and shook her back to consciousness again - again she was able to get a few breaths of the medicine in and was able to breathe easier and woke up. Within a few minutes her breathing had settled down and we were able to get her up and back into her bed‚Ä¶ And life went on.Needless to say, I put up a couple hooks outside on the deck where I keep my work gloves now, and when I spray for weeds I entertain the neighbors by taking all my clothes off outside before going in for the day.So - as I said earlier, the product itself works fine and merrily kills weeds as advertised, no problem there. And the fact that it almost killed my wife isn't the issue either - it's powerful stuff and has appropriate warnings on the bottle. But I do wish the shipper had bagged and boxed the shipment rather than sending it out in a bubble-wrapped mailer - it would have saved me a lot of stress had they done so.

review_content: Product is easy to use. So far so good on killing the morning glory infestation in my lawn. As advertised, the turf is ok around the areas treated. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021
review_content: When I say I'm pretty sure my neighborhood nickname is/WAS "Dandelion Queen", I mean it. I have lived here for 14 years and never thought twice about my yard. This year, I decided I was going to mow my own grass, and realized how fast these suckers grow!! If I had been taking care of my yard properly, I could have an amazing yard, but I neglected my duties. Hated to resort to chemicals, but I let this problem become way out of control, so here we are. I sprayed 4/20 (mowed 3 days prior) and today is 4/23 and they are almost ALL DEAD!! I mowed again this morning but the mower couldn't even reach them because they are all shriveled up and dying. Makes me a little sad. I'M KIDDING!! Bye, dandelions!I didn't have a measuring spoon, so I mixed three splashes (?-they were small splashes) into a two gallon sprayer with water and put a squirt of Gain dish soap. Yes, I know how precise that is, just trying to be honest. I knew not to use too much based on reviews but I have an ESTABLISHED problem that I thought required an extra splash...(instructions for two gallons of water was more like two splashes)I didn't even know what kind of grass I have, I didn't care! I said if it all dies, it dies. I'll start over. But it didn't touch the grass!! This product is great. For anyone saying it killed your grass, it might be that your yard was like mine and full-on weeds, so now they are all gone and it's bare. I will definitely be planting seeds to fill gaps in about 30 days or so. Will absolutely need another treatment in the fall but these weeds didn't grow overnight (except they really did) so they won't be gone overnight (except they almost are!)If you have a problem like mine, this stuff works. Can't wait to see what they look like in two more weeks!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2015
review_content: I tried this out because I had read a table that listed it as somewhat compatible with Perennial Peanut. I think this data came from a University of Florida Ag. publication.My hopes were to spray it in the general area of the weeds and hope that it (a) didn't kill my Perennial Peanut and (b) didn't kill what is left of my Bahiagrass.It turns out that 2,4 D Amine is great for weed control but NOT when you want to keep your Perennial Peanut unharmed. Within a day my weeds had begun to brown and wilt, I was so happy. Within a week, all of my peanut had turned brown and disappeared. My wife laughed at me because I was so sure of myself and my decision. I was devastated. Hank Hill would not approve.To its credit, the 2,4 D Amine got to work within 24 hours, devastating all of my weeds. My introverted neighbor actually came out of his house and crossed the street to ask me for a dose because it worked so well; this guy doesn't like talking to anybody if he doesn't have to. He even gardens at night because nobody is around and the sun isn't out. I was glad to share, hoping that the weeds would have a harder time crossing the street, back into my yard. Amazing stuff, although, I don't think it is intended for my application. It is great for making friends too I guess.The Perennial Peanut did not fare so well, nor did some of my bushes (I didn't think I had sprayed them, just near them, but apparently a little bit goes a long way).  The novela length instructions boiled down to something like "A pint per acre with enough water to spread it" which wasn't too helpful since I was using this on my front lawn.The good news: my peanut has bounced back in all of the places where I had lost hope. Relief! I purchased in August of 2015, applied the poison in September, cried a week later. It is now December and all of my peanut has rebounded.The bad news: the weeds are starting to pop up as well. I blame nature. I also blame my neighbor's outdoor cats (feral?) who like to sleep in my front lawn - most likely the ones rolling around with seeds stuck in their fur.  Considering one application controlled the weeds for 4 months, I am content.I still have 90% of the jug left, even after loaning some to my neighbor who has now offered for me to borrow tools "anytime."I will make a second attempt, only this time I will be more careful to steer clear of my peanut and important plants.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2023
review_content: It‚Äôs not like the hose spray kind that wilts weeds in hours but doesn‚Äôt really kill them. This takes 2-3 weeks to see results. But you get good results that keep getting better. I had a multitude of weeds in my yard, about 70% weeds. I ordered this and the matching surfactant. I got a 2 gallon hand sprayer. I mixed it per the instructions. 2-3 tablespoons per gallon, and surfactant 1-2 teaspoons per gallon. I used rain boots, waterproof gloves, pants, long sleeves and a mask because this is a chemical and it says use PPE. Waited until the weather was right, rained the day before and no rain for at least 24 hours after spraying. Sprayed the entire yard. In about 3 weeks my yard looked completely different. The weeds had slowly died out. Spray again in 30 days for even better results. This is the type the pros use. I‚Äôve tried many others - sprays and granules and this has given me the best results. Will keep using and buying. Happy customer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2023
review_content: We not only sprayed the yard but an acre of weeds also. It killed all the weeds but kept the natural grasses.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2023
review_content: I bought this to get rid of a crepe myrtle that was not properly removed. It as cut down and the stump was removed but the crepe myrtle kept re-sprouting like  they do. Applied this to the area once I was able to dig up the new sprouts and was able to see the actual root. Got a saw and cut into the roots thinking and hoping this would allow the solution to absorb better. I did have to reply a few areas throughout last summer but nothing bad. Mostly had to re apply due to not being able to see and get each root the first go round. THIS summer I have had MAYBE  4 little re-sprouts and that is it! I wish I had a before picture‚Ä¶.. to show that  4 little sprouts was NOTHING! I highly recommend this product!!!!!

review_content: Good broadleaf killer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2023
review_content: Morning glory is pretty but also invasive and hard to get rid of. One has been growing next to my orange tree for years and no matter what I did, used sprays or dug it out, it would always come back. This product did the trick! I just poured the entire bottle with water on it and poof it's gone and hasn't revived or come back in months. Obviously that's not what the directions say but my method worked lol

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2017
review_content: I think the reason I like this product so much is that you get to control the amount of dilution as opposed to a "Weed and Feed" type product that you hook to the end of your water hose which always seem to be too watered down to have any affect regardless of the amount of times that I spray the same area. I simply take an empty Weed and Feed container (the type that hooks to your water hose) and I fill it with several glugs of the 2,4-D Amine and the rest I fill with water. I spray the yard immediately after mowing while the weeds are freshly cut open and exposed so the product gets to the root faster. I spray again later that week and then I finish a few days later by spot spray with a gallon hand pump carry-along sprayer...that I dilute to a similar ratio. This killed most of the variety of weeds that I had in my yard. It did not kill my grass, I have a mixture of St. Augustine and Bermuda. It also had no ill affect on my Zera-scape garden which contains a variety of cactus. Just a word of caution it will kill wild flowers. You can smell the product in the yard but it is not over-powering. I was tired of always pulling my weeds and never actually making a difference in the overall look of my yard. My neighbors are the types of people who never spray or pull their weeds, they simply mow them and they multiply to the point that now their yards are entirely comprised of weeds and they in fact have no grass left at all. I am sure that my neighbors can smell the chemicals in my yard but you have to fight fire with fire. I am so glad I found this product, I know it is powerful stuff and people say not to use for residential properties but I am not having any side effects...yet....I'm sure I'll get cancer and die one day but who can say for sure what caused it. Good luck with your yards and your neighbors!

review_content: The product works well. I will be ordering more of this weed killer. I mixed on the heavy side and was happy with my results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2017
review_content: Summary:This kills weeds like Dandelion 100% dead. Unfortunately 2-4D alone is not as ‚Äúbroad-spectrum‚Äù as you‚Äôd imagine. Try a mixture of: dicamba, quinchlorac, triclopyr, sedge hammer, and 2-4D. Obv. Dont mix every chemical full strength. ‚ÄúTrimmec‚Äù will give you good ratios to match.Took 2-3 applications: 80% killed clover, 100% killed dandilion (like it never existed), and killed maybe 40-55% of all weeds. Turned wild violet yellow for 1 day. No effect to creeping charlie, wild onion, wild garlic.+2 stars because this is the cheapest broad spectrum you will find and it did not remotely damage any grass. But -2 stars because dicamba (added), triclopyr (raw chemical), and trimec (a brand name mixture) are all much more effective when mixed at a broad spectrum kill.Depends on the weeds you have, this may be a very very good product. I have to move on to crossbow, trichlopyr, dicamba, trimmec, quinchlorac, or oxalis killer.Most places say you cannot respray within 2 weeks. I find 3-5 days assuming ground temps above 60F and air temp below 90F should be ok. You can always follow up with a 1/2 strength mixture.If you dont see folding over weeds by day 5 (and ground temp is 60F) - the product did not work - spray again, increase dosage, add surfactant, or try dicamba/trimmec/triclopyr. By day 10 you should see severe yellowing of weeds and close death. If it does not look severe at day 10 they could bounce back. Spot spray those weeds!No effect on fescue turf grass or crabgrass. I did notice a very slight light green or yellowing effect on rye grass I sprayed heavy (trying to get hidden weeds). I also noticed most grasses seemed to grow faster that week.I mixed 1 tablespoon per 2 gallons and sprayed approx 2500sq ft. focusing on weeds and ignoring grass. Repeated for remaining yard. Directions say 0.25fl oz (1.5 teaspoons) per gallon per 1000sq ft. Definitely use a non-ionic surfactant at 1 tablespoon per gallon per 1000sq ft.I find Methylated Seed Oil (MSO) + a Non-Ionic Surfactant (NIS) each at approx. 1 tablespoon per gallon will help a lot with weed herbicide penetration.

review_content: I have not used this yet but bought it from advice of a yard maintenance guy that says it is good to get rid of unwanted weeds from the lawn. I will try it at the right time of the year

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2023
review_content: Ok, if you are desperate to get rid of stickers, burrs and countless other weeds this is the product for you. You definitely need to use caution while spraying but worth the effort. Plus, I add the adherent substance to help it stick to the weeds really well and the coloring so I don‚Äôt waste product overspraying areas. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: This is the best treatment for Dandelions that I have ever used.  I followed the manufacturers directions that came with the bottle.  The directions state to use 2 to 3 Tablespoons of 2,4-D Amine to 1 gallon of water and add surfactant.  I mixed 2 and half Tablespoons to one gallon of water and I used a one gallon pump sprayer with wand that I bought here at the same time.  I used one pump of Dawn dishwater soap from my kitchen sink dispenser  into a 6 ounce glass of water and stirred it gently to dissolve the soap, then added it into the sprayer.  I only spot treated the Dandelions but in 36 hours I could see the weeds were beginning to die.  A week later and all of the Dandelions are dead and none of my grass was harmed.  Many reviews here talk about mixing ounces of this weed killer with water.  You can easily overly strengthen as 2 Tablespoons = 1 once so it shouldn't be mixed stronger than one and half ounces per gallon.  No wonder so many reviewers claim this stuff kills their grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2023
review_content: Worked well. Most were gone after one application. Used with blue dye to prevent too much overspray. We used this on the yard and only the smallest amount listed.  A second application three weeks later and the weeds seem to be gone. We are having a very hot and dry spell, so we will see how it looks once we get more rain.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2023
review_content: I bought this specifically to try after a suggestion from someone who said this kills the artillery weed plants. Round Up doesn‚Äôt really affect those in my yard, which was very frustrating. I was happily surprised to see that this really did end up killing those weeds! Yay!!

review_content: Bought this to kill unwanted weeds and clover in my St. Augustine grass. Mixed as directed and sprayed areas of my lawn where unwanted weeds were a problem. It definitely killed the weeds but also killed the St. Augustine grass as well. Left my lawn with dead brown spots that will take months and perhaps years to recover. Do not use this product if you value your lawn.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2023
review_content: This spray is helping me eliminate my thistle problem I have tried to maintain for seven years by manual control and mowing.  I compromised by using this and spot spraying the invasive prickly beasts.  They have been wilting within a day or two after application.  Will be buying more in the future.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2022
review_content: This weed killer is a spray once and watch them all die weed killer.  It won't harm your grass either!  Be sure to mix according to the directions and don't overspray onto your grass or garden by keeping the sprayer pressure low and aiming directly at weed.  I did my entire lawn late in the afternoon and it ended up raining all night.  It didn't wash the weed killer off because the weeds were already dying despite a hard rain.If your lawn is covered with weeds, select a bag of pelletized weed and feed and apply that.  You'll still have some weeds left after a few weeks, but that's when this spray is the right product to finish the job.  I also spray the weeds in my neighbors' yards at night so that they don't spread right back into my lawn! :)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: My neighbors lawn hardly has any weeds. One day I asked him how he kept it looking so good. He said he uses 2 4,D and that it works really well for him. I have used several other fertilizer/weed killers and they never seemed to work as well so I wanted to give this stuff a try. I feel iike this product wasn't meant for the average home owner because for me at least the instructions were hard to figure out. I needed to mix the weed killer in a 2 gallon sprayer and the instructions don't include ounces per 2 gallon. I had to google it and luckily found someone that had the same problem and figured it out. Once I mixed it, it was very easy to apply and after my first application about two months ago I was very impressed at all the weeds it killed and my lawn was looking great. Fast forward to the present and I am now seeing more weeds pop up so I just applied another application. So far I am very impressed and really hope this helps kill the remaining weeds I have in my grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2023
review_content: Great value for money. Works great for yard and weeds.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2018
review_content: I wanted to wait a couple of weeks before writing a review. I live in Virginia and have tall fescue grass. This stuff is the Truth. I cannot understand why people are on here saying this product killed their grass, outside of them not following instructions on how to mix the concentrate with water. I used two ounces of concentrate to 1 gallon of water and added one drop of dish soap to work as a surfactant. My backyard had quite a few different types of weeds in it, and now it is 99% beautiful grass. Some weeds started to die on the second day, while others did not show signs of death for over a week. This will be my go to product for spot-spraying weeds in my yard in the future.Update 3/9/20: just a heads up, weeds need to be actively growing when applying this weed killer. In other words, it will not kill weeds in colder temperatures (less than 65 degrees F). My experience is optimal effectiveness comes with outside temps between 70-80 degrees. If it‚Äôs really hot outside (90-100), there is more risk that the weed killer could do a little damage to your grass. Really good for a spring time application. Use sparingly in summer, don‚Äôt waste it by applying in winter.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: This review asks for "Stretch" and "Thickness"... This unit is liquid and does not stretch!  That's good so... you get five (count them) FIVE starts in the stretch category!On a serious note, make certain to measure this stuff out.  A little bit too much broadleaf killer in your water will anger your grass that is trying to survive beneath it.  I used this in a spray bottle to roam my lawn and spray and stupid weeds.  This has been my summer cure to keep it under control.  I use a granule in spring and fall and use this stuff in summer.  Great to keep my lawn nice and clean!When I first started, I mixed it a little heavy.  Wrong move.  It looked like dogs had peed over my yard with the small brown spots.  I learned after that mistake to use the exact amount specified.The unit also comes with a phone book attached to it.  Not really a 'phone book' but roughly a 30 page pamphlet on the safety data sheet.This stuff will last me roughly 3 years on a 5000 square foot lawn for summer weed control.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2018
review_content: I'm in the PNW and have had horsetail on my 5 acres since I moved in 12 years ago. I've tried everything and was told the only way to eradicate was to change out all my soil! Impossible! After searching I found this product and read that it would work on horsetail. I mixed per the instructions and sprayed Sunday afternoon. It's now Tuesday and so far the weeds  have wilted over. Directions say to spray again 10 days after the initial but, so far this weed killer has impressed me! Round Up wouldn't touch these weeds in the past so I am keeping my fingers crossed. For now I am giving this 4 stars and will update after my second spray. The pictures are from today (2 days after spraying) and shows a tail I didn't spray and then the ones I did that are no longer standing tall and wilting over.The instructions were simple, wore the PPE, and a little does go along way. So glad I didn't buy the gallon size. I used 6 gallons (mixed) and will still have plenty left for my next spray!I also have dogs and kept them away from the area Sunday and Monday.Will update again next week!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: This is an old standby broad leaf weed killer that is safe for centipede lawns.Pros:*  Visible results on the fastest growing weeds in 24 hrs; all other broad leafs within a week.*  Much quicker results than Atrazine, which can take up to 4 weeks to kill, enough time for treated weeds to go to seed.*  Much cheaper than Atrazine, using only 1¬Ω oz/gal, instead of 4¬Ω oz/gal for Atrazine.*  Kills nearly the same broad scope of weeds as AtrazineCons - minor issue of not killing every weed type that Atrazine will.  However, it gets the majority quickly and Atrazine can be used to spot treat as a follow up, if necessary.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: One application took out nearly all BROADLEAF weeds in an otherwise healthy fescue yard. A second round 2 weeks later finally made a dent in the clover and dollarweed, both of which are heat/humidity-loving tough customers. The second application mixed with Ortho Chickweed/Clover GRASSY weed killer torched the clover. Still watching the dollarweed. My experience is that the Big Box/Big Brand liquid and bag weak killers just don't do the job and will keep you buying the product over and over in order to chase down effective weed control that the Southern Ag 2,4 d Amine delivers the 1st or 2nd time.* Recommend a backpack sprayer for a yard of more than 1000 sq. ft. for application of any liquid lawn product.Dilution is roughly 1 - 1.5 oz. per gallon (or 3 to 4 tablespoons per gallon) The sweet spot for our fescue + weeds was 1.5 oz. per gal in a backpack sprayer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2016
review_content: I just moved into a house where the back yard is almost all thistle. I had a friend once tell me the best weed killer is something with a high level of 2, 4-D. He has former experience in commercial land maintenance (even had one of those backpack sprayers) so I figured he knew what he was talking about. I couldn't remember the specific brand he used but he said it was expensive ($70-$100/gallon) but worth it. He typically sprays not only his yard, but all his neighbors too just to keep things looking nice and he said a gallon normally lasts a whole summer season. I found my way to this product which I know is different, but still had a high percentage of the chemical he told me about. It's safe for the grass, but still takes care of the broadleaf weeds. It's a little hard to know how much to use, but I've been starting with about two ounces (or two small measurements full with the bottle measurement cup) per gallon. I'll use that until I kill all the bad stuff and then maybe scale it back a little just to maintain and help it go a little further. I have been happy with the results and look forward to my yard looking like a yard someday.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2022
review_content: I do like to use this product however the instructions are not clear at all to the point that I had to Google in order to figure out the mixing ratio. I've tried to use more and less, so if I use less, it won't be very effective, if I use more it damages grass. All in all I would definitely buy again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2022
review_content: The Southern Ag Amine 2,4-D WEED KILLER is not really a "weed killer" -- it's more of a week wounder. I've been paying a lawn care company $60/mo for a smaller area of lawn and they can't seem to get the wild violets under control. Their only recommendation is to tear out the lawn and start over. The sod was just put down a few years ago. I discovered from the fellow who cares for my trees and shrubs, that the reason this stuff is so ineffective, is that it just rolls off the leaves. If you look closely, you'll notice that, for the most part, the only parts that actually die, are the edges of the leaves, which catch the liquid. He advised me to look for products with a simple additive that helps the herbicide stick to the leaves. For those already owning this stuff, you can actually add as smidgen of wood glue (yes, that's right, wood glue) to the mix, and that will help the herbicide stick to the surface of the weeds without clogging your sprayer. It's that easy. Meanwhile, the Southern Ag people surely know this and ought not sell this stuff without the additive.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2021
review_content: This killed clover and other weeds in my yard. I then bought a hose sprayer adapter where you can adjust the chemical/water for future use.I did have to google to find ratios as instructions on the bottle are very confusing.Most quarter acre lots, which is about what I have are approx 5k sq ft of grass.  I found the ratio for 1,000 sq ft and multiplied it by 5. Sorry I don‚Äôt have the ratio for you. My notes were deleted on my iPhone when I did the iPhone update (ALL my notes‚Ä¶.very frustrating).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2019
review_content: I was recommended this product by a friend. Like others have pointed out, the instructions aren't clear on mixing, so I took friend's suggestion of 2-3 oz per gallon of water. I also put in some dish soap before spot spraying all the broadleaf areas of my lawn. I also hit the clovers and crab grass, just to see what happens. Within a day, the broadleaf plants turned a lighter color green, and the clovers wilted. After heavy rain a few days later, I resprayed just in case. A little over a week later, the broadleaf has turned brownish white and is nearly dead. Surprisingly, it also seems to be working on most of the crabgrass too. However, it only seems to work on the younger crabgrass and has had minimal (but still some) effect on some of the larger weeds.Overall, very satisfied with the product and the value. I bought some other other "safe for grass" weed spray that wasn't nearly as effective and was only enough for half a season. I have enough of this left to last 4-5 years.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2016
review_content: I live in a rural area so we get all kinds of weeds. I was excited to read about this and give it a try. However, this is not my favorite stuff so let me clarify:Page 26 says to mix 1/4 pint in 3 gallons of water (not 2-3 TBS as listed in the product description). I did that in a backpack sprayer along with some surfactant and blue marker:* Dollar weed in common bermuda - great job (only thing it killed that I tried it on)* Burclover, clover and general broadleaf weeds in dirt, common bermuda, and Jamur zoysia - nothingAfter 3 weeks, I then mixed 6 oz. in 4 gallons of water, increasing the concentration:* Burclover, Virginia Creeper, Poison Ivy - good job* Bull/Stinging Nettle - good initial job, but it has since come back 2 months later in the same spots* Greenbriar (not listed as controlled) ‚Äì nothing, but figured worth a try* Oxalis/general clover (not listed as controlled) - nothing, actually killed the Zoysia at this concentration where I did a spot treatment but no damage to bermuda* General broadleaf weeks, including Bull Thistle ‚Äì better at this concentration, but many still left standing with little residual impactsI suppose it's better than nothing in my bar ditch or areas that aren't landscaped, but for anyplace that I have Zoysia and look to maintain, I'm better off pulling by hand at the start of the season and not worrying about it...

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2020
review_content: You will need a pump up sprayer! I used a gallon sized one and was able to do almost my entire families yards (about 5 front and back yards) for them and it completely rid out every single weed in my yard! I still have some left over and no weeds left in my yard. It took about 2 weeks for the weeds to completely die off, but you can see them laying down withing 24 hours, it is best to use this right before a hot sunny day! I found it best to pour about double of the recommended amount in my pump up sprayer to really get rid of the weeds! I sprayed this stuff into the dirt, aiming for the stem of every weed, my first application my weeds were so bad I just sprayed the entire grass! It took 2 applications to rid out all of my weeds. Definitely worth every penny and will be buying again and recommending this to anybody I can!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2021
review_content: Kills plantain weeds effectively. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2018
review_content: I did not follow the directions the first application (I went low on the amine:water ratio), but a month, and two applications later, and this stuff has been doing great!I have not noticed any browning of my grass, or any dead spots, and I sprayed everywhere (twice!). Yes, my front lawn looks lousy -- also not 2,4-D amine's fault. I'm just not good at lawn care.I also sprayed my neighbor's yard (with his permission), since it was being taken over by dandelions. He hasn't been watering lately, but now his front yard is just dead grass -- no dandelions! Haha!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2015
review_content: This definitely had an effect on the wild yellow flowers in our lawn (not sure what they are -- not dandelion, something else), which have never responded to other granular broadleaf herbicides (i.e., weed and feed type) or pre-mixed herbicides from the local hardware store.  These weeds are withering after one treatment.  Made a second treatment a week later so hopefully that will be the end of it.  Also worked well for the Creeping Charlie (aka Ground Ivy or Gill-over-the-ground) in our lawn, and the wild garlic/onion chives -- the Creeping Charlie is withering and the chives are withering and yellow.  Didn't affect the lawn, which is zoysiagrass.  Overall, pretty happy with this product.  I used it both as a mix for spot treatment (about 10 ml in 700 ml, which may be a little stronger than recommended, but worked well) and with a hose-end distributor for large lawn patches. Still waiting to see if the violets are going to die -- so far they seem to be somewhat resistant (although the most effective method I've found for those is to dig them out, so I don't have too many left as a test).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2023
