review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2023
review_content: We recently built a brick retaining wall.  Even with all the typical precautions (plastic cover, etc) ground cover  weeds started growing in between the bricks within a month.  They were easy to remove but always a new batch reappeared‚Ä¶.it was starting to become an annoyance that was taking 30 minutes a day to correct.Decided to try the Ortho Groundclear even though it seemed expensive.  Ordered and actually received it same day.  The wall is about 30 foot long and 3 foot high and I saturated the wall with the Ortho.  This was around 10 in the morning with temperatures expected in the 90s.  I went back out around 6 that evening and was amazed to see all the weeds looking dried out and dead‚Ä¶.like they had been sprayed days earlier.  I removed all the dead weeds and anticipated more the next day.Nope‚Ä¶.not a single weed showed up on the wall the next day or since.  It has now been around 90 days and not a single weed has appeared.  VERY VERY SATISFIED WITH THIS PRODUCT!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2022
review_content: I use several gallons of ortho ground clear each year; primarily on my gravel driveway and gravel paths. I also dose/ sprinkle in between flagstones and areas closest to the foundation of the house.I mix into a 2 gallon sprinkler watering can after transferring to half gallon cran juice empties to measure the  proportion of water to weed killer I think it is 3x water and 1x weedkiller? Check the instructions! This works on almost everything. It does take time for a complete kill. You can see results quickly 1 or 2 days , but it will be about 2 weeks until the weeds are really shriveled up and dry, which indicates that the roots ought to have died as well.There is a different product that has a higher % of _________ sorry!  cant think of the popular weed chemical that gets all the attention!  Anyway, it is that other product that seems to work best on mugwort.Ortho Groundclear  seems to work best for me if I apply in the early spring, when the weeds are showing, but not more than about 3" tall. If you wait, it takes so much longer for the product to kill the whole weed. I have had the best results when used in combination with PREEN; which prevents weeds from germinating.My plan was to spread preen in late fall and Ground clear in the spring, but Fall application did not happen. I will do both this spring.Buyer beware that this Amazon item is a smallish size, and I am sure the delivery expense has been added/incorporated into the price. I guess I usually buy several of the 2 gallon size at Home Depot. It is  expensive, but pretty high on my must have list.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2023
review_content: It seemed to clear most of the grassy weeds in the area well enough. Nothing with deep root systems, though, and nothing like saplings or suckers.It doesn't work nearly a year though. Maybe 3-4 months before grassy weeds were coming back, and suckers were growing large and tall. It works, but not for long.Two other issues I took issue with:It doesn't make very much. Just over a gallonIt's not even available in my state any longer. It was a few months ago.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2023
review_content: Update/Edit (+- 10 days after application)I had Followed directions to a tee, 10 days later, I did find some random discolorationon an occasional leaf of about 10% of the weeds that I sprayed,which is an  indication of some level of distress to that small % ofthose weeds.Bear in mind, as I've written below, this process becomes an issue ofuntold, countless, new weeds sprouting up during 'kill process' ifthat even becomes true,as well as 'sprayed' weedsliving long enough to 'go to seed' (drop seeds for even more weeds), allthe while, considering the methodology of the application and process,there is NO-WAY to know which weeds were initially sprayed, as newones come up along the way.Also the weeds that MAY eventually die very often already have seeds,and it can be assumed that leaving those dead-weeds that eventually die, willhave their seeds becoming weeds, weeks (+-) later.To end this nightmare of an ordeal ( I have a huge lot), and stressing overwhat could become a need for a tractor, I spent yesterday morning pullingweeds and tossing them in the trash so as not to allow them tocreate a greater nusance. For the first 8 or 9 days, Icouldn't help but think they should have called this product; Miracle Grow lol.I am going to guess that this product is no worse than others outon the market 'today', but I will conclude with certainty, that from myexperience, using this product was a massive fail, and I will pass, onconsidering the purchase of anything else from Ortho in the future.The kicker is the claim from Ortho of 'Visible results within3 hours' , to paraphrase, and having read positive reviews here on amazon.Have a great day all!Initial Review:Here is the big issue I've had with this product;I followed directions to the tee, we're going on 7 days now, they look ashealthy as when I sprayed them. By now I have lots of new weedscoming up, its the season, natural, but who can tell which ones need to besprayed NOW? ACKKKK!!! (I have a generous variety of weeds, this productso far has shown no effect on any of them.)I would have been miles ahead and able to sleep had I just pulled up theweeds that were up, it comes to a point where the ones I sprayed aregoing to go to seed if you know what that means, it means millions of moreweeds, a weed crop from ####, on a very large lot...I hope someone takes Ortho to court and gives them pause to rethink andfigure out how to make a product that works.I don't know if any other products are better, and I'm sure Ortho makes somethingworthwhile, but it sure isn't this product ; 'Ortho Ground Clear' .

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2021
review_content: The ramp in the photo is too wide and low to weed underneath with any tool I have. It‚Äôs so big and heavy that if I pick it up to weed, it‚Äôs tough to replace it without damaging the building. I‚Äôve depended on glyphosate. In my experience, it takes several days to see if glyphosate is working. During that period, weeds keep growing and I don‚Äôt know if I need to spray again.The last time, it took a week to kill the weeds. Two days later, new weeds were already quite big. I bought Groundclear to work faster and longer.A gallon of concentrate makes  5.3 gallons of mix, so it would be expensive to spray a large area. I made a liter. I put the bottle of a 2-liter pump-up sprayer on a scale, added 190 grams of concentrate, and added water to bring it up to 1,000. That was plenty for the ramp area and to test on other trouble spots.Later that afternoon, the crab grass and wire grass looked rusty and wilted. I took the photo 24 hours later. The camera still didn‚Äôt show had bad the leaves looked.  I had also sprayed broadleaf weeds. I kept an eye on them for 10 days and saw no change. Maybe their leaves were more water repellent. Next time, I‚Äôll add a little dish liquid.Pelargonic acid "burns" leaves. It‚Äôs 1% of the spray. It‚Äôs a fatty acid that‚Äôs in some human foods. It harms only leaves, and some weeds can grow new leaves.Imazapyr is 0.1% of the spray. Absorbed by roots, it kills plants. That rules out using Groundclear near shrubs or trees. In the soil, its half-life is in months, so it may work for a year. It helps to wash it in soon because light reduces the half-life to days.Keeping weeds from sprouting would greatly reduce weed problems. I‚Äôve found that an application of Prodiamine will prevent sprouting for a couple of months. It takes only 5-15 grams per thousand square feet, so it‚Äôs cheap to use. For smaller jobs, I have a scale that reads to .01 gram.Prodiamine doesn't kill existing weeds or prevent encroachment, so Groundclear offers more protection. I‚Äôve ordered a 1.5-liter sprayer. I don‚Äôt anticipate needing so much at one time, but if I keep the sprayer in a cardboard box to protect the herbicide from light, I‚Äôll probably use it often.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2022
review_content: I have a small farm and a big weed problem around my house. We get every kind of weed I think it's possible to grown in eastern America, and controlling them, especially in my long gravel driveway, is a nightmare.I try to stay as organic as I can, so finding an herbicide that doesn't kill weeds AND everything else is of concern to me. I don't want to harm the many amphibians, reptiles, and birds that inhabit my property.So after researching this Ortho GroundClear Year Long Vegetation Killer and seeing that its active ingredients are lethal to plants and nothing else, I decided to give it a try.My first pass, I goofed and got the mixture half strength. Still, it killed most of the weeds, even diluted. Another light pass at full-strength a month later knocked everything else dead.Well, except for one kind of woody weed. The instructions say that it's a lethal herbicide for your typical weeds and grasses, and it did indeed kill everything except for this one heavy-stemmed weed I can't identify. Still, I've never had anything do as well as this Ortho mix, so I'm thrilled with the results and will hand-remove the few stragglers.I first sprayed a couple months ago, so I'm confident that at this stage, with almost everything still dead, that it will last me through the rest of the year. But will it go six-months after that, as the "One Year" label promises? I dunno, but it's not a crushing disappointment if I have to redo this next spring.Recommended if you want a lethal, long-lasting herbicide that really works and isn't toxic to every living thing on the planet, just plants. I don't rate everything I review five stars, so this herbicide really did impress me.

It's a good product despite its overreaching promises.

review_content: I get a lot of weed growth both in my sidewalk and driveway joints, and in my back yard where I have river rock instead of grass.If you are going to mix it in your sprayer, make sure you have at least a two gallon sprayer because the ratio is 24 ounces to 1 gallon of water so you end up with almost a gallon and a half.What I do is mix two gallons in a washed out kitty litter container and use that to pour into my sprayer. Which is basically like a before picture. I also included pictures one hour later, the next morning, and 2 days later. It does seem like it started working pretty fast. But you can definitely see a bigger difference over time.  There are several parts of my backyard that I have to redo. I was trying to stretch it out as much as possible and I don't think there was any solution left when I got to those spots.Take a look at the pictures and judge for yourself if you think it works.It also claims that it will kill weeds for up to one year. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2022
review_content: It really does work and I use it every year around trees without harming them. it kills most stuff that grows but not vines like poison ivy. In fact it doesn't do a very good job killing poison ivy at all (and it isn't designed to do that). I took a star off because unless you really saturate the plants it works really slowly. In some cases the grasses have a chance to grow around the dying stuff so the slow effect doesn't really save me from having to get the string trimmer out. I have a pole fence on 3 acres and I don't want to do all that trimming. But, of you do saturate the plants around the poles well they will die and you can avoid a lot of trimming. I'd suggest buying twice as much as you think you'll need and using it liberally. Because it doesn't really affect below ground roots, nusiance trees will grow where the grass and weeds die. Keep those down with loppers and stump sprays. Kill poison ivy with different herbacide designed for poison ivy.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2022
review_content: If you're looking to kill some weeds, Ortho Ground Clear is good choice.  It won't kill every plant known to man, and that's not a problem.  All herbicides have limitations and recommended uses.  This product kills many grasses and broadleaf weeds (which means this product kills most of what you'll encounter in many residential areas).  If you're trying to kill Mesquite or other exotic plants like cactus on the ranch, you'll need to do some Googling to find the right mix of poisons to match your local area (e.g. use Sendero to kill Mesquite).I use this product every year to kill weeds that come up in mulch beds and hardscapes (e.g. grass between pavers, in gravel, etc.).  It works great, and one treatment generally lasts the full year if you spray in March or April when the growing season in Texas starts with warmer weather.  Sometimes I end up spot-spraying a few new weeds that poke up in the following cool season (e.g. October'ish), but that's not unexpected.Great price (~$42 in hyperinflation 2022) for 2 gallons of concentrate.  Mix 24 ounces of product per gallon of water (you can make ten gallons per two-gallon bottle of concrete).  This goes a long way for most homeowner scenarios (e.g. sidewalks, driveways, mulch beds, around the pool, etc.).  If you've got lots of acreage to maintain, do your homework, identify the plants in your area, find the best poison(s) for those plants, and get to work!

The Pros: per bottle it‚Äôs  not expensive like most weed killers on the market, but depending on your sprayer it‚Äôs pretty much a one time use per bottle.  AND  #2.., it does the job and it does it fast,  Would I buy this again??  Honestly, probably not. It‚Äôs a good product, but value per dollar‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not for meUpdate 6/21/21. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2023
review_content: Great for dirt/gravel areas you want to keep free of weeds. I live in the Phoenix area and have found this works best if applied a day or so before some expected rain. If I need to treat and there's no rain in the forecast I follow the treatment up by spraynig the area with hose water - just enough to help the chemicals get down to the roots. If treating existing weeds they will take 1-2 weeks to visibly die back. Smaller weeds die off quicker since they have smaller root systems. The bigger the plant and its root system the longer it will take for the weed to completely die. Once treated the areas remained mostly free of weeds for 6 months to a year. Just a few managed to come up that were easy enough to pull by hand in between. Bare areas remained bare - so this works well as a pre-treatment.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
review_content: Here in So Cal, weeds follow rain like clockwork. And since there was an untended lot across the street from me, I have about 15 years of weed seed accumulated in the soil. In addition, I'm trying to install a drought-tolerant native landscape, which requires that I clear the front yard first.Digging out weeds and grasses turned out to be a never-ending task. I have tried many different options, including hand weeding, various "organic" weed killer, flame torch, and glyphosate and decided to try this one.First, it is not OMRI (organic gardening) certified. But being a chemist, I researched the online Safety Data Sheet and found that it is mostly C8 and C10 saturated organic acids, which can be derived from coconut oil, with 20% "other" (nonlisted, therefore presumably non-hazardous surfactant). According to what I can find, the active ingredients are non-cancerous, not persistent, and do not bio-accumulate. That's a plus.Taking a cue from other reviews, I mixed it at the higher concentration and sprayed it on a variety of emerging and established weeds and grasses.First of all, it works really well on most newly-emergent weeds and grasses, including spurge, foxtail, and oxalis. It coats leaves evenly and - unlike glyphosate- "burns" them quickly, so I can see in two days where I missed, and re-spray where necessary.It does NOT work on established grasses, even tho I saturated some clumps thoroughly, and does NOT workon common mallow.Because it only works on leaves, and not seeds, it must be re-applied on each new crop of  sprouting weed and grass seeds. But because of the nature of this weed killer, I feel more comfortable re-spraying, and with each application there are fewer and fewer sprouts to contend with. Overall, this spray will make clearing the yard much easier, and reduce the amount of hand-digging by about 70%.It IS pricey, but because of the combination of positive qualities and the amount of work it will save, I feel it's worth the cost.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2023
review_content: The 1% solution sold in stores is ineffective--I sprayed driveway weeds two weeks in a row, the weeds hardly noticed. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
review_content: I have had a problem trying to get rid of a number of mature cr√™pe myrtles for years-- but the bio advanced brush killer did the job whereas none of the other brush killers that I've tried in the past have been effective, aside from simply browning some leaves from the cr√™pe myrtles. One of the things that definitely helped was that I or the brush killer into a 2 1/2 gallon sprayer, and I clipped as many of the branches as I could so as to expose the interior of the freshly cut branches so that the brush killer could penetrate inside. I also sprayed the brush killer full strength on some of the leaves, and I also used the remaining amount to pour as strategically as possible toward the root area of the cr√™pe myrtles so they would get the maximum effect, but was careful not to pour outside of the immediate root area. This product succeeded where others failed!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2023
review_content: I've ordered this brush killer a few times through Amazon.  At around $15-$16 it is less expensive than at the local home improvement stores.  It delivers on time every time I've ordered it.  The bottles come with a seal under the cap so I've had no issues with spillage during shipping.When used as per the instructions it works to kill brush weeds like lambsquarter, poison ivy, etc. and other hard to kill weeds though it takes a couple of weeks to see the results on some weeds. So some patience is needed.I've also used it to kill small tree stumps up to 4 inches from trash trees that sprout around our property, though you have to use it undiluted on tree stumps for it to work.  So far it seems to work. The tree stumps look like the wood dries out gradually.My one complaint is that the last two times I've order this product through Amazon the measuring cup was missing. Previous orders came with the cups, but last two orders were missing the cup.  I can see how easy it is for the cup to fall off during handling as any slight pressure can make it pop off. Not sure if it's an Amazon warehouse handling issue where it falls off during their handling of the product and they now have a collection of the measuring cups or if it's a manufacturer issue. In either case better quality control is needed to ensure each bottle ships with its measuring cup. Fortunately, I still had a measuring cup from a previous purchase so wasn't a big deal for me.  For someone else it might be an issue if they don't have a measuring cup since you need to measure the amount to use per gallon of water.  It takes anywhere from 4oz to 8oz per gallon of water depending on the type of weeds your trying to kill.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
review_content: This is my second purchase - the chemical itself worked great on a honey locus runner that my neighbor‚Äôs tree sent to my lawn, causing ‚Äúweeds‚Äù to sprout everywhere. The firstly purchase in October 2023 worked great, including the sprayer, though it was the older version that had only an on/off switch to control the spray.Purchased a second bottle about 6 weeks later, November 2023, had a different sprayer, with both an on/off switch and grip handle actuator - would have been great had it worked, but the nothing pumped out - this is after inserting the pump,handler fully into the bottle, pulling out the protective battery film, fully unfolding the spray tip,and then twisting the tip from the off to spray position.  The pump would turn on but nothing would com out. I opened the bottle to see if it was a priming problem, but the issue was that the pump mechanism could barely pull the chemical up the tube maybe 1 inch. After reading the other Amazon reviews, it became apparent that the electric sprayer frequently arrives defective. Too vad. I wonder how many I will have to swap before I get one that works.Edit: I reached out to BioAdcanced customer support, who responded the next day. They are sending out a replacement nozzle that should take 7-10 days to arrive.  Appreciate the prompt response. Will update when I receive it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2023
review_content: I've tried other herbicides on the wild berry vines I have on my property, and to be honest, they were pretty ineffective. But this BioAdvanced Brush Killer Plus Concentrate is a game-changer! I sprayed my berry vines with this product, and for the first few days, I didn't see any results. So, I waited about a week and went back out to check on the vines and ALL the leaves and ALL the vines had turned from a vigorously growing green color to  a shriveled-up, dried-up, flat-out dead brown. This product had killed every part of every berry vine I had sprayed. Finally, a vine killer that really works. Here's the mixture I used...I have a 1 gallon pump sprayer, so in one gallon of water, I added 4 oz. of BioAdvanced Brush Killer  AND about a half a teaspoon of "Liquid Harvest" brand surfactant which I also purchased from Amazon.The Liquid Harvest surfactant is a "spreader-sticker" which allows the herbicide to spread out and stick to the berry leaves which makes the spray much more effective. Before spraying, make sure the top of your sprayer is screwed on tightly, then gently shake the contents inside the sprayer to mix them well. By the way, I have no affiliation with either product that I mentioned in this review, and I payed for both products through Amazon out of my own pocket.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2023
review_content: This kills poison ivy plants, roots and all.I have a nasty poison ivy allergy - like potential hospital reaction, not just a bad rash, so I need an effective way to get rid of poison ivy.  I've tried many methods over the years - pulling, mowing, chemical sprays, organic sprays...  This is one of the few products that actually works, kills the entire plant and it doesnt come back.Once a year I use it in a 2 gallon garden sprayer and wander around the farm, spot spraying whereever I find it.  I also keep a small (1 quart?) hand spray bottle in the garage for spot spraying when I find a poison ivy plant in somewhere.  (Birds spread the seeds, and I cant kill the ivy on neighboring farms, so it is a never ending battle for me.)Yes, like the product description says, it takes a few weeks to completely kill it. Thats ok with me because it works.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2017
review_content: I was worried this was just like some others I have tried, but WOWOW was I ever pleasantly surprised, it killed them within just a couple of hrs. I sprayed even through my fence since I am too disabled to climb the hill behind my house. It killed em all. You should have seen my little backyard last year!!!! A jungle of trumpetvines and morning glory entangled, and the trumpeting poked out of every crack in my patio and up to the second floor balcony. Last year I was down and out with breast cancer so couldn't take care, nor did I care, for my small backyard and the much hated trumpet vine just grew under and in everything. They are pretty tempting with the red flower the bees love so much, and wouldn't mind if they didn't spread like weed.I tried some stuff two years ago but that didn't work, even though I cut them all back so we could paint every stump.But this year, yea!!! Wiped this trumpet wall out for sure!  I even managed to kill a bush that dropped over my fence from the entrance to the development , it's a prickly one with red berries which dropped into my little garden and promptly shrouded. Just sprayed it and it's gone.I didn't have a gardenhose, it's what you need to book the bottle to, so I poured some into a spray bottle, added water, kind configured on the dilution that would happen with a hose attached and depending on the amount of water, meaning how wide open you have the faucet, I.e. water pressure. I had a fine misting or spray so I missed all the vines I could reach close-up and sprayed it on to vines that had crept upstairs onto balcony.I have you know, ALL VINES OF ANY KIND.  are now gone, dead.I will keep spraying on any new shoots, the ecosystem is elaborate, under all of the paved porch, across underneath to the little flower garden I so cherish next to the sitting area. But I am 100% certain that I will finally get rid of all of the trumpet vine around my property.This product is perfect.CAV,ET:  don't spray it on anything you want to keep, my neighbor wanted to help me out and he sprayed the BlackBerry commuting out of a decorative bush. I had already sprayed it VERY CAREFULLY, covered the Bush where I knew it could hit the Bush. My neighbor just sprayed, apparently - I didn't see him do it -  but today that part of my decorAtive bush is dead, right on top center...grrr.  Sooooo.  be careful when you spray near plants you want to keep, protect them somehow.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2023
review_content: I love this stuff, poison ivy and poison oak try to take over parts of my yard every couple of years. I have previously been using the BioAdvanced non concentrated version of this with extreme success.Tried this as a money saving  alternative and it works just as well. Got same results spraying the plants and they all eventually just wilt away and die.Both products do not kill the plants immediately, like you spray and the go poof. You spray and over the course of a week or so they die a slow painful death until they are dust.I am totally cool with this and not having to go anywhere near these plants I can wait.Wish I knew why there was a need for this plant in nature and stop seeding itself near my fences and rock walls.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2023
review_content: Works well on berry vines and woody weeds.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2023
review_content: I use this to keep back kudzu, poison oak and raspberries. It will kill other things as well but has been the only product I‚Äôve found to kill the others enough so I‚Äôm able to take back control of my yard. It takes a long time though. That doesn‚Äôt bother me as I know it‚Äôs working but for someone just trying it out, you won‚Äôt see anything noticeable for about a week. Then a slight wilt. It gets to a point where you might forget you even sprayed but sure enough, one day, it is all dead and you can take it up. Done! It keeps it from growing back for a long time as well. I use it to clear a section, then manually pull anything that eventually pops up.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2023
review_content: Great value for what it does. I sprayed a tree. A 40/50 feet tree. Over three stories tall. I live lakeside and the tree blocks my light and view. So last year I sprayed the branches with the intention of just killing off the leaves so that I can get more sunlight and a better view of the lake. Well, bought more for this spring so I could do it again. However, where I sprayed last year DID NOT leaf this year AND more of the tree branches are clear. So it seems that it continued to work after the spraying ( only diluted 1:1) and did not have to do it again this year. With any luck the entire tree will die and it'll be cut down. It's a nusance tree in an apartment complex that lets everything just grow and NOT maintain anything until it's either in the street or on a building. So, this is great and clearing out the overgrowth.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2023
review_content: We use this undiluted and apply it to freshly cut stumps of undesirable brush.  If the remaining "stump" is small, we brush it on; if it is larger, we drill a hole in the stump and use a squeeze bottle to apply the brush killer.  Either method kills the brush!  We have been fighting honeysuckle on a property line for 8 years and are making progress!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: I only use such products to rid my yard of years-long growths of blackberries. I used to use Round-Up and wanted a product with less history of potential cancer.  I tried this brand and it is different but effective.  Round-up often acts faster and more evidently on the leaves. This one takes longer before you notice the plant is suffering. But in the end it seems to work better at preventing regrowth.  It's not perfect. Blackberries are insidiously durable. You kill them in one spot and a few months later they are growing up a few yards away.  I believe this works better on slowing regrowth than Round-up but that may simply be that 4 or 5 years of treatments have overall weakened the bushes' ability to pop up elsewhere.  All in all, I think this is better than any other products I've used on the blackberries and recommend you try it.  Best to use in spring but wait til the plants have developed leaves and are at least a foot or more high so that the poison covers a larger area of foliage and and you get more absorption.  I use it liberally and soak the leaves thoroughly.Some new plants will pop up in a month or two.  I just pull them up at about 8 to 12 inches tall instead of wasting poison on them because the plants are going dormant in a month or so anyway.  But re-application on these new plants may be better in the long run.  You need to experiment to figure out what works for you.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2023
review_content: I have everything growing in my gravel driveway and was looking for something that would kill it all. This killed some of it right away, but didn't kill everything.  Maybe after 2 or 3 applications it may get the rest .. we will see

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2023
review_content: We cut down four diseased cottonwoods and the roots exploded with sprouting suckers. Plus this has been a wet spring and summer and the weeds took off. For both the suckers and the perennial weeds I cut them off with the weed whacker and then painted the stub that was left. It not only works best that way, but it saves spraying a lot of product.For annual weeds, like dandelions, I use regular weed killer all summer and spread pre-emergent in the late fall and spring.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2023
review_content: I have these crazy vines that climb my trees and ensnarl everything on the ground.  This is the only product I‚Äôve found that kills these vines and keeps them from growing back in the same season

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
review_content: Dora‚Äôs okay, just takes awhile.  Have since bought another type to try.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2023
review_content: I mix 2oz if this with 2oz of any 41% glyphosate weed killer per gallon of water and it kills any brush, weed, grass, small tree in the woods.  Works great on poison Ivy and oak.  I also soak stumps with this concoction to stop the sucker branches from coming back.  Yes, it will kill the stump if you soak it well.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2023
review_content: I had already used this before. Just hot this more recent one because it was priced better here. I have problems with birds dropping seeds and new trees popping up along my fence. When I cut them down and put this on the cut/stump, it finishes the job for me and they‚Äôre dead.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2022
review_content: We purchased a home years ago that has a stand of bamboo in the back yard.  It was apparently planted by the genius neighbor who lived behind us several owners ago.  Anyhow, I have finally declared war on the bamboo and using this product seems to be working.  If you cut the bamboo down close to the ground below a node, and then fill the remaining cup like structure with this herbicide within five minutes, it will kill the culm.  My arborist agrees that this approach will work to rid us of this annoying and invasive non-native plant/tree if I can keep at it.  Also, the state university near me agrees with this approach, but adds that the approach is most likely to work when used from mid-September until mid-October, when the plant is sending energy to the roots to prepare for winter.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2023
review_content: I bought these instead of the usual concentrate that I use in a pump sprayer because they were on sale. The product works great and I can see the weeds and vines that I sprayed already wilting just a few days after application, so that part is great! My biggest complaint is the sprayer they come with - the little trigger sprayer might be fine for application in a small area, but it really stinks squeezing that thing a thousand times as you go around the whole yard and woods spraying things! If you're going to do a large area, look elsewhere. I may end up just dumping it in my pump sprayer the next time I need to use it, because I can't squeeze that handle that much!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2023
review_content: If you've got tough brush, this is what to get. I use it on stumps after I've cut down larger bushes or small trees to keep them from growing back besides brush like tall briers.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2023
review_content: July 6:  I initially received the product quickly but it did not include the wand (which I paid extra for). I reached out to customer service and received a prompt reply, apologizing and saying they would send this out to me. Instead of sending it quickly, they sent it via USPS (apparently).  After a week, I reached out asking where it was and was told I would need to give it a full 7-10 days. Today is the 11th business day and nothing. I wrote back and was told they will send me another one. I assume it will take another 7-10 business days before I see if they actually send it.They are fast to respond, but very slow to deliver. I would suggest going elsewhere for this product or any others they sell.This is, in my opinion, very bad "customer service". If they wanted to keep me as a customer, they would have rectified their mistake by overnighting or at the least, 2 day delivery of the part they forgot to include! I paid extra for the part - I should have the part and not wait weeks upon weeks to get it.  Never again with this company.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~I've used BioAdvanced Brush Killer for several years. It works and it works well! It's not instant, but it will kill anything you want gone and I have rarely needed to reapply. It eradicated poison ivy from my yard as well as VA Creeper and other offensive weeds and vines. It killed off a tree which was just a stump but kept regrowing for years - This product finally killed it off!  This year I have a new section of my yard that needs cleaning up and I ordered the 1.3-gallon size because it comes with the battery-operated wand (easier on my hands). It arrived in a couple of days, as promised, but without the wand. I contacted customer service and they replied the next business day and promised to send me the wand - in 7 -10 days. A little disappointed that I received the product in 2 days, but it will take a week or more to receive the missing part - but honestly - this stuff works so well that I'll wait!  I highly recommend this product!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2022
review_content: So I used this on a big swath of english ivy with some poison ivy mixed in about 2 weeks ago.  I want all of the ivy gone, but I really want the poison ivy gone so I can at least get in there and pull whatever lives without the itchy plant.  However based on the description I'd expect this to do all the work for me.  This stuff is slow, for sure but note I'm not a landscaper and never tried to kill ivy's before so I don't have any comparison.  I applied a second round (refilled with the concentrate) just yesterday.2 weeks in1) poison ivy leaves are pretty dead (mostly brown, dangling and dried out) hopefully the whole vines are dead as well.2) english ivy for the most part is drooping but still green and shiny in most areas, some small areas are slightly browned.  I'm 50/50 on if this stuff is gonna be killed or not.3) small wild tree and some other taller plants that I don't care about are browned and dead looking.4) a smaller tall tree, but much bigger than the one i just mentioned is partially browned but think the tree overall is fine.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2022
review_content: I'm on my third time buying this.  This is the only weed/brush killer that I've used that works.  It does take a few weeks, so you have to be patient.  You will see the weed start to sag and get all yellowish and brown in the first few days.  I had these "trees" that were growing in between my neighbor and mine's fence.  They were kind enough to cut them down for me and I have not had them come back in over a year.  Once they cut them down, I sprayed into the trunk and there has been no new growth.  I had an insane amount of poison ivy last year and this did the trick.  I do have some annoying vines and some other weeds coming up, but I've been spraying those as they appear.  The only thing is it will kill plants around the weeds.  I killed my hostas, but they were being taken over by vines.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2022
review_content: Used to kill started trees in fence line. I first sprayed at 4 Oz per gallon during late summer last year. A few trees mostly died but many were not effected. After some reserved I found that many leaves are able to shed off the spray and save themselves but using a surfactant allows the spray to stick and absorb into the plant. This worked very well. I sprayed unwanted brush with 1 gallon of water and 6 Oz of bio advance and a small amount of surfactant.  When I checked on the brush a week later there was significant wilted, drying up leaves. We have cut these trees multiple times over the last 20 years only for them to quickly grow back. I hope this is a permanent result.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2016
review_content: I used this on the Northern California Coast.  Fog.  Dampness.At first I was disappointing.  I used half the container on a 15' long 6' high 'hedge' of blackberries covering both sides of a fence.  I came back 3 weeks later and nothing except for some discoloration.  So I gave a poor review.6 weeks after spraying and 85 percent of the hedge was discolored, dead or dying.  I was able to crush it, cut at it and get it down where before it was just too big to tackle.  I will update if ultimately the roots don't come back, but for now this product was a big help.OLD REVIEW:  I purchased mainly for blackberries.  I sprayed liberally on a huge hedge of blackberries on a mild day.  No rain.  Some leaves got spotted but after 3 weeks I was really surprised how poorly this worked.  There has been no rain.  Very disappointing.I cleared another area of blackberries as well a few months back, and the vines that were left in the ground 'sprouted' and came back to life.. I used this product on those fresh leaves with poor results as well.  I will try another brand.I used something like this years ago and it really did a great job, roots and all.  Disappointing I did not achieve the same results especially as I really really sprayed with good coverage.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
review_content: We recently bought an old house with a small yard and the previous owners planted many bushes that have become old, scraggly and unhealthy. Two of them are GIANT flowering quince bushes which contain cyanide in the leaves. How do I know this ? Dog happily ate leaves, dog becomes violently ill, dog mommy looks it up....Dog completely recovered back to normal health.So my mission in life is to eradicate every ugly bush on our property and especially the quince. I bought 1 bottle of this stump killer (doubting it would really work) , cut down the entire gigantic bush, then applied this on the FRESHLY cut stems on half of the bush. I even split some of the bigger stumps so the mix could really get into the plant's system.Oh yeah! This stuff WORKS! This is a systemic killer and it does work. Half the bush is dead. (Only half because I wanted to see the differences ).  Not just dead leaves and/ or dead looking branches. I checked repeatedly to make sure it was actually dead. The branches & stumps turned grey and completely dried up. The plant stopped making suckers everywhere too. I LOVE THIS STUFF!

review_content: If you want instant death to your weeds, you are going to find this spray to be very frustrating. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2023
review_content: Nutgrass! üò™First application I mixed as directed. I sprayed on leaves after watering throughly.  It worked, but not completely. After a little more research, I did the 2nd application. I watered thoroughly and mixed double potency. I added a little bit of Dawn dishwashing liquid to mixture and switched to a prayer that sprays mist (not a stream).  I SOAKED the leaves. I also read that the plant should have at least 3 leaves out before application (mine all did, not sure how important that was but adding just the same). This 2nd application worked (so far, but in the past new growth would have happened by now, so I have high hopes).  I will watch and retreat immediately on new growth. This is in a flower bed, not the yard.  Also, I didn't water for 3 days after application.  Good  luck everyone. This tried to kill me, I'm thinking I won!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2017
review_content: I tried using Roundup Plus to kill sedges in my yard and garden, but they just survived right through multipe chemical assaults! I didn't know that for some reason, sedges are "immune" to Roundup, possibly because they have huge energy stores in that nut below ground.I bought Sedgehammer+ in April after reading reviews here, mixed it in my sprayer tank (1 pouch per 1 gallon, a per instructions), and sprayed everything that looked like a sedge. The sedges didn't die quickly (much slower than Roundup kills regular weeds), but they did stop growing and eventually the sedges looked brownish and died.My yard is approximately 4000 sq ft after subtracting the house and driveway concrete areas, so is much larger than the 1000 sq ft that one pouch (one gallon, mixed) can treat. However, I did not spray the entire yard with Sedgehsmmer+. I only sprayed the edges themselves, so one pouch was sufficient to treat the areas where I needed it.Attached are two photos. The first was taken in the most infested area on April 25th, just after I sprayed. The second was taken this morning (June 4th). As you can see, ALL of the sedges are gone. What's left there is the yucky, wimpy Bermudagrass (NOT recommended for any yard!). I'm waiting for the St Augustine in the top of the photo to fill in. It's gradually taking over the yard from each neighbor. (St Augustine is really the only effective grass for south Louisiana, btw.)I can't say enough to recommend Sedgehammer+ No Surfactant Needed. It was easy to use because or now includes its own surfactant, it's effective, and it didn't kill anything but sedges. If you have sedges in your yard or garden, use Sedgehammer. It works!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2015
review_content: When applied according to instructions this product is outstanding.  It has a self-contained surfactant so there is no need to mix with anything but water.  Put entire packet into a 2 gal. yard sprayer, fill with water, shake, pump up the sprayer and apply.  I live in a beautiful lake villa, directly behind a stone monument entrance sign with halo lighting.  The area was designed and landscaped by a world famous ASLA landscape architect.  However, our association did not know how to manage the sedge grass that annually invades the Blue Rug Juniper planted as an accent.  Unfortunately our friend, neighbor & landscape architect passed away before sedge grass had become a problem, so we were on our own.  I did a lot of research to find your product, Sedgehammer, and tried it for the first time last year.  One application got most of the sedge grass the first year we applied it.  I was actually hoping to see the few remaining blades pop up so they could meet their fate this spring.  There were only six additional outcroppings of 3 blades each.  They were quickly dispatched and we expect no further infestation of this insidious nuisance.  Before Sedgehammer it fell on me to monthly get on my knees and pull all the sedge grass that had sprung up over the past month.  This was a monthly ordeal throughout the spring, summer and into the fall seasons and was not a lot of fun.  Sedgehammer saves a lot of time, is very cost effective, is highly efficient and can be trusted to rid your yard, garden or flower bed of sedge grass.  Also, with few exceptions at a couple of specialty garden supply stores the only place we were able to locate the product has been at Amazon.  Hoping this review helps others with a sedge grass issue.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2013
review_content: Because the product details said "Low use rate. One Sedgehammer Plus packet per gallon of water". I thought it had two or more packets in each one so I brought two which would have been enough for my entire from and back yard!  But instead it has ONE packet in each!  It does not specify how much it has and fingered everyone should know that so they can purchase accordingly!Also by the way cause it does not specify if you know sedge or purple sedge by a different name you can use this on knuckle grass which by me is what we happen to know it by since we are not all professional landscapers or gardeners so of course not everyone knows what the heck sedge grass is!Don't be fooled you can dig around the plant to get up the whole weed but you will need to dig it up as we found out 8" in diameter around the plant and 18" down to make sure you get the whole thing and you have to throw away the dirt as you cannot see all the mini tiny little bulbs that you could end up leaving behind for the process to start all over again!  Also to replace the dirt!  You cannot save the dirt once you dig it up!  We were told by professionals that you have to buy dirt that has been freed and cleared of all things so you don't end up with the same issue!So do you need to buy this no you don't, but do you want to have t dig up your whole yard and replace the dirt then reseed and by the time your lawn is back to the way it should be you will end up wasting two years as the roots of need seedlings takes that long to really get down deep into your soil so if you reseed you end up needed to place more down the next year to replace any that might have dies off because not all of them survive and you end you with the same vicious circle every year!  So like I said you don't have to our have this, but why not purchase it?  You end up saving your self a lot of money and time with purchasing this!  Also don't mix anything into it other then just water as it already has everything you need right in the powder!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2021
review_content: I have used this product before and had "fair" luck with it against nut grass. Central calf  has a real problem with Nuts Hedge...i.e. nut grass and everyone is looking for a "perfect" killer.  This is not it.  It will kill nut grass  but takes a good two weeks to do it (read the instructions) and the kill is only fair.  It takes two to three "re treatments" to get a solid kill in an area.  Then if your neighbor does not kill his...well it's back in your yard!!  It's a constant battle.  Sedge Hammer does work. It takes the full two weeks to get most of the grass.  Be patient..the first thing you do notice after a couple of days is that the nut grass stops growing...it just sits there..looking green and healthy, but there is no growth..no spreading etc. Then after about 9 days it starts to yellow and then dies.  Two weeks later..healthy growth appears and you start again.  It can get expensive if you have a bad invasion..and I do.  Keep at it, this will do the job for sure, just takes patience.  Have fun gardeners!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2017
review_content: Works great! I had a major sedge weed infestation, and this knocked it on the head... but it took time, care and patience. I've seen some folks talking in reviews about unsuccessful sedge management, and figured I'd give some tips from my experience.First up is correctly identifying your weeds. Some onion and garlic weeds look similar to sedge. Ortho will treat both, but (in my experience) it is less effective on sedge weed than Sedgehammer. Much less, actually. Sedgehammer just treats the stuff listed on the label, which is far less broad than Ortho. Get the right herbicide for what you have. Type "identifying sedge weed" into your search engine to get some great tips on how its done. Favor the "edu" sites over commercial ones.Secondly, make sure you follow the directions. Don't do it when it's about to rain or on a wet lawn. Make sure it's the right amount of time between your mowing schedule. Check the growth of the weeds so that you know it's at the right stage that's printed on the instructions. Make sure your lawn and the weeds aren't under stress (plants tend to go dormant during stress times, meaning it won't "suck up" the herbicide). Don't just spray because you have time, get the timing RIGHT.Lastly, be patient. As it says in the instructions, it can take weeks to notice the effect. Dark rings will eventually appear on the sedge, and they will eventually blacken. To help, I've attached some images of how my lawn progressed. I live in Texas, and treated this during the Spring. From start to finish, it was 5 weeks. The photos are pre-treatment, 2 weeks after (the first visible results), 4 weeks after (mostly dead) and 5 weeks after (all dead and drying up).It's now July and some sedge has reappeared, but nowhere near as much (my lawn used to be about 50% sedge weed!). I'll treat again and let you know if there are any issues.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2013
review_content: I have Nutsedge extremely bad. It initially came from my neighbor, who apparently decided he wanted to start a farm of it. After a few weeks of it, I'm now a nutsedge farmer as well. With as bad as the infestation is, I didn't really expect miracles from Sedgehammer.I read the directions a couple times to make sure I did everything right. I mixed it to the right ratio, made sure I didn't mow for days, and turned off my sprinklers. Because of the size of my yard, I needed to make a few batches to get everything covered. After about an hour of mixing and spraying I was done.The results were great initially. Alot of the emerged nutsedge withered off and I didn't notice anything new coming up. I went on a two week vacation and returned to my nutsedge farm. As recommended in the directions to Sedgehammer, using multiple types of control on Nutsedge is probably the only path to success.All in all:Pros:Worked great on emerged NutsedgeCheapDirections are decentCons:Requires multiple applications for realistic weed control.I recommend it for anyone who isn't as severely infested as I am.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2018
review_content: I have used it in a hand-triggered spray bottle. Fescue lawn in the central Midwest US. I generally spray the sedge on Tuesday/Wednesday and mow the lawn on the weekend, because apparently you need to let the sedge grow for 2 days after mowing before spraying and then let the SedgeHammer work for two days after application before you mow. It works best when you spray it on sedges that have a couple (3-5) leaves, rather than when its just a single sprout. I've had to do a couple applications because not all the sedges are at the appropriate growth stage at the same time (hence the "persistence" in the first sentence). It takes several days before they even start to turn yellow (see "patience" above).Also: Due to the bulb-like nature of nutsedge (hence the word "nut" in the name), it will probably come back the following summer. But in a much more anemic fashion. Spray it again as above, and probably again the following year. Each summer, there will be less and less of it.Like I said: PATIENCE! But it works and won't torch your lawn like if you tried to use glyphosate on it!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2021
review_content: I used it to kill nutsedge in a St. Augustine lawn, in flower beds, and in borders of liriope.  The grass and in liriope were left unscathed, and the nutsedge was killed.  The plant has to take the herbicide through the leaves, past the first nut, and down to the mother nut which it starves to death.  The entire process takes 2-3 weeks, although weed damage will become apparent earlier. Be patient.  As with all herbicides, you want to handle, mix, and apply the product according to the instructions.  You can't store the mixed powder/water solution, so plan your application.  You can pull at nutsedge for the rest of your life and never finish, or you can use SedgeHammer.

review_content: Worked exactly as they said it would. Had an infestation in a few parts of my yard along my neighbors fence on 2 sides. It did say it may take several applications. Will continue to use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2019
review_content: This package contains enough material to make 1 gallon of spray. That was not quite enough for me I should have ordered 2. Older versions of this product needed an additional spreader sticker which is expensive and hard to find these days. This new formulation contains the spreader sticker that you need. Halsulfuron is a sulfonyl urea class herbicide that was origionally discovered  by DuPont agro in the 1970's. They are selective herbicides and are active at very low concentrations. They also have low toxicity to non target organisms. They work by inhibiting the production of branched chain amino acids. Just so you know sulfonyl ureas decompose in water so as soon as you mix it up, you should spray it within a day. if you keep it around for a week it will have decomposed  and will not kill your weeds. That is why the manufacturer ships it as a dry powder whereas most other herbicides are fomulated as water solutions or emulsions.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2022
review_content: I used this product in early spring 2022(Chicago) and it works EVEN before the nutsedge shows. The amount of nutsedge was reduced 95% from the year before. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2021
review_content: Sedge is a very difficult grass/weed to kill. I had to use it 2/3 times before it didn't come back. Most of the available brick/mortar stores don't do the job especially Ortho. I went online to try something different and it worked. Don't try and rip this weed out as the bottoms have seeds/nuts at the very bottom that are hard to remove and although you might kill the weed above, temporarily, it will only come back the next year. This product works well and do not need any agent to dispense it either. The "plus" in Sedgehammer plus means it already comes ready to go with the agent already in it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2012
review_content: Sedgehammer+ has killed the snot out of my purple nutsedge this season.My infestation was so bad; I've had to go through multiple applications so it's been an expensive process...  But one more application should finish off the purple.Where I'm at, the yellow has just started to crop up, so I have not had a good test of Sedgehammer on yellow, but expect it to work just as well.Tips:* Read the mixing instructions (They're there for a reason and it works as described.)* Thoroughly douse all visible nutsedge and the soil around it. (Schtuff's expensive but don't be stingy. It needs to be kill't, so kill it and kill it good.)* Watch your local forecast, and avoid putting on with rain in the forecast for the next 24-hours. (They say "rainfast after four hours" but I had one application rained on same day, and it didn't work as well.)* Be patient. It works but it's not instant. Don't expect to see the sedge dying off for several days after application. (It kills in a slow painful way, a death this scourge of a weed deserves.)* If you spray SedgeHammer on clover, dandelions, crab-grass or any other weed besides purple or yellow nutsedge and then claim "the crap don't work." You are NOT smart enough to be using chemicals, please keep playing with your crayons and let someone else handle the herbicides.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2012
review_content: Ive had a patch of nutgrass in the corner of my fescue lawn that appears at the beginning of each summer. While searching for a solution, I came across Sedgehammer on amazon. I ordered it based on the positive reviews, but was pessimistic based on my experience with other products claming to control nutgrass. I let my lawn grow out a week so the nutgrass would be large and easy to spray. After spraying, I didt mow the lawn for several more days. The nut grass started to turn yellow, but I had seen this before with other products only to have the nutgrass come back strong. I cant shut up about this stuff now, every time a see nutgrass in someone yard I feel compelled to do a quick unsolicited product endorsement for Sedgehammer. If you have nutgrass in your fescue lawn, I would definitely recommend this product.
