review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2019
review_content: Very impressive product with great results.Nutsedge is particularly infuriating because it grows so fast. I had a fairly large area in my backyard infested with it, as well as a small patch in my front yard. I'd mow the lawn, and the nutsedge would already be visibly taller than the rest of the grass in 24 hours. It also is not controlled by most usual herbicides, like Roundup.Sedgehammer is very easy to use - just mix one packet in a gallon of water in a standard pump sprayer. It took about 5 or 6 days to see results, and in 2 weeks, it was pretty much all dead.See the before and after pics.Note that the area of my lawn that had the nutsedge is now brown, but that's not Sedgehammer's fault. The nutsedge had crowded out most of the actual grass, so there was nothing left there when it died. It's time to overseed anyway.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2022
review_content: Sedgeghammer works great on sedge, but be patient, it can take a couple weeks before you see ANY results.  I put some down and expected to see yellowing within a few days.  It was super gradual, the leaves started looking sad after a week, then yellowed after two weeks.  Now, about three weeks in the pesky sedge is finally gone.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2013
review_content: I have been battling nutsedge since I first purchased my home.  It wasn't until recently that I even knew what it was.  I have tried pulling, weed killers, etc. to no avail.  A relative recently hired a landscaper to treat his lawn for nutsedge and they ended up destroying his entire lawn.  Needless to say, I was a bit timid to try anything after that.I purchased Sedgehammer with low expectations.  I mixed it per the instructions and tested on a small patch of grass on the side of my house.  After 3 days, I saw no changes.  I mowed my lawn that week and alas, the sedge grass never came back!  Next, I tried it on a larger patch of lawn and the result was the same.  I mowed a few days later and no more sedge grass in that area!  This stuff is amazing!  It has not had any negative affect on my lawn but the sedge is gone.  I expect to have to re-treat small patches each year as they come up but I was getting to the point that Sedge had taken over about 2/3 of my lawn.  Not anymore!!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2023
review_content: Used as directed and sedge is still growing and spreading.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2021
review_content: Nutsedge. What a pain. I dug up all my old grass and replanted seed this spring and somehow activated Nutsedge. It absolutely took over. This was my first DIY weed control. I used a pump sprayer and blue dye. After one application all my nutsedge is either dead or almost dead. My new grass seedlings (about 2 months old) were not hurt. I absolutely recommend this product.Now to try to control the crab grass with another product‚Ä¶(Photos are from BEFORE)Update: almost one month later and I have only seen 1 single nutsedge come up. This product was incredibly effective.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2022
review_content: My lawn has nutsedge problems. To treat it, I tried Ortho's Nutsedge killer. It worked, but it seemed expensive for the amount I need.  I read some reviews about nut-sedge treatments. Sedge hammer got good reviews and the 13.5 oz. packet mixes up a gallon, so I got some and mixed it up using a gallon of distilled water. Problem was that it didn't seem to stay mixed up. Every time I wanted to use it, I saw a layer of sediment on the bottom of the gallon jug I mixed it in. It would help to re-mix in the jug, but that created a foaminess like there was dish soap added.  It didn't seem to work well either. the Nut-sedge I treated on May 23 is still green with maybe a bit of yellowing. The Ortho Nutsedge killer worked much faster than that.  At this point, I'm going to have to treat again and I'm going back to the Ortho product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2019
review_content: After years of battling nutsedge that appeared out of nowhere, I've tried just about everything to get rid of it.  I was mildly concerned about some of the negative reviews, but opted to give it a try.  All I can say is WOW.I'm assuming it's a systematic herbicide, as you really don't see much in the way of results in the first few days. Eventually, I noticed that the growth had slowed. Then some browning of the edges of the blades. Then, finally overall yellowing and browning of the blades. It's been a little over two weeks since I sprayed.Understanding that nutsedge has a very extensive network of hardy rhizomes, I wouldn't be shocked to eventually see some new sprouts at some point. If they come back, I'll just hit them again.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
review_content: This is the exact item my local nursery sells but at a fraction of the price.  I have used this product for the past 3 years and have seen immediate results (within a week) every time.  The existing sedge stops growing, turns yellow wilts and dies so the product works as intended on the surface.The only reason I am giving this 4 stars is because the description says it treats the rhizomes and tubers which I interpret that to prevent the sedge from growing back year after year and spreading.  However every year for the past 3 years they grow back and spreads out further than the year before.  I might try a new brand next year in the backyard to see if it prevents regrowth and spread.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
review_content: This is the best product available if you have problems with nutsedge or nut grass in your lawn.  you can see results within 7 to 10 days and virtually no harm to the surrounding lawn.  It makes only one gallon but it goes a long way.  I'm in central California with a 7,000 square foot fescue lawn and every year when the summer heat hits new nutsedge shoots pop up.  Usually one spot spraying treatment will do the job for the summer and whatever is left over I'll use again after a few weeks for any shoots I missed.  I've been using this product for many years and won't get caught without it to maintain one of the best looking lawns in my neighborhood.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2016
review_content: I applied Sedge Hammer on a cloudy afternoon in late May with a small window for clear weather. It probably rained on my field 6-10 hrs. later. Although it took 2 weeks, the herbicide did kill 80 % of the sedge in the areas that I applied it to. I plan to apply a 2nd spray on the remaining nut sedge in my food plot. It may require more active herbicide than the packaging suggests. It is definitely a post emergent herbicide. Effect on young rizores is questionable for me.  My application was on a small area ( 3/4 acre ). I imagine that it is more effective when applied in dryer conditions. I plan to use Sedge Hammer again and can recommend it without reservation. It is relatively inexpensive.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2013
review_content: For the last 3 or 4 years, there has been yellow nutsedge in one of my planters.  The planter is about 30 square feet, so one package of the Sedgeehammer Plus is far too much.  And because the herbicide loses it potency once the water is added, I have a lot of product waste.  Am I the only person who need a smaller quantity?  On the positive side, the product works!  But, one or two applications will not get rid of it because the sedge sprouts over a long period of time.  Because I am elsewhere in the summers, I finally hired someone to spray every week or two.  Again, that makes for a lot of wasted product.  It would be great if the company could find a way to provide the product in smaller quantities so us homeowners wouldn't have to waste so much.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
review_content: Easy to use product if you have a tank sprayer. Note that one package covers 1,000 Sq feet. I had a sporadic sedge growing so I spot sprayed. Be patient, as it did not kill my sedge right away. It took about 10 days before the plant finally died, though it did start turning white within a couple days. Most challenging part for me was trying to figure out if the plant I had in the yard was sedge or not.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2023
review_content: Good value for price paid. Extremely happy with expected results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2022
review_content: This product performs as advertised without harming existing grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2019
review_content: Product arrived on time, no damage in perfect condition.THIS stuff is GREAT!! Easy to follow directions! I applied it to the damn nutsedge on a Wednesday, and one week later (the following Wednesday) I could clearly see the stuff being snuffed-out! The netsedge stalks were turning yellow, and no new nutsedge was growing! I waited one more week before pulling the weeds out, and by then, the weeds were brown, dried up and TOTALLY dead! This stuff is an excellent product, so glad I used it! Such a relief to have a clean garden, free of this nasty nutsedge! I know it may come back, so I ordered another packet and will be ready for it!I highly, highly recommend this product; it works GREAT!!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2019
review_content: It works, but for $13 I expected better results. You can see from the pictures that it killed the majority of it but not all of it (and I doused them in the liquid and followed the directions so it's not because of user error). I think next time I will try a competing brand that gets more mileage (sq. ft.) and kills more weeds at a similar price. I would say if you are looking to kill only a few selective weeds this is the best choice. The included surfactant is a nice touch.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2018
review_content: I had a pretty bad sedge problem that spanned a bed and into my lawn. A single treatment pretty much knocked it out in the lawn.  I could pull what remained by hand and the few that came back. I think having the Bermuda grass able to over power it while it‚Äôs weakened is key.In the bed it was less effective. I spent about an hour pulling the wounded weeds, but I‚Äôm still fighting it there. I think just roundup or a similar approach is more effective for that situation (at least for the money).I don‚Äôt think this is a deficiency in the product, just my lack of experience.Also this product does have the side effect of getting ‚ÄúSledgehammer‚Äù by Peter Gabriel stuck in my head, which is oddly enjoyable while spraying.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2022
review_content: It works, but takes about 10 days

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2019
review_content: Nut Sedge is a weed in your yard - it's a lighter green than grass, and grows much faster, so it sticks up above the lawn. Left alone, Sedge will take over your lawn.  This stuff works a treat - you need to buy one of those mix and spray things (container with attached sprayer) , but then you just mix and spray.  It's easy. and in a few days you will see the sedge turning yellow as it dies.I did have a problem with the vendor - I bought two packets, but only received one.  I reported the problem, and the second packet showed up in two days.  Very happy with that outcome.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
review_content: I had planted new grass about four months ago due to the fact my old grass was very thin and had lots of nutsedge. Before they planted my new grass they put weed killer and then planted grass. Low and behold the nutsedge started to appear again. Researched  on line and found this product. I have to say I was reluctant but I figured I would try it.Sprayed  it  on a week ago and so far nutsedge has disappeared. The day after I sprayed they cut my grass and by now I would see tons of nutsedge growing taller than my grass and I don‚Äôt see any.  I‚Äôm cautiously optimistic it‚Äôs good but we will see.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2012
review_content: This stuff is very effective.  Use the recommended amount - just a normal spray like you would with Weed-B-Gone, etc.  A previous review said you had to soak the ground and plant.  Not so.  Not only is this a waste of money, but very detrimental to the environment.THen, you just have to be patient.  For the first week, it will look like nothing is happening.  Somewhere in the second week, you will notice the sedgegrass is a lighter shade of green.  This continues as the grass gets lighter and lighter.  Eventually it turns brown and just disappears.I had a huge problem - way worse than I realized.  It took about 3 weeks before I really felt like the plants were dying.  But they did, and are all gone now.I will probably have to retreat this year, as there are probably many nutlets lying dormant in the ground.  But I feel confident knowing the efficacy of Sedgehammer.Excellent product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2019
review_content: This stuff works, but it takes some time to take effect. It took 2-3 weeks to notice the weed actually start to die. Add some a little bit of Original Johnson‚Äôs Baby Shampoo to help the product stay applied to the weed. Add one oz of baby shampoo. The baby shampoo acts as a surfactant, allowing the weed killer mixture to work better. The baby shampoo, in addition to the fan tip nozzle, will keep the weed killer from simply beading up on grass and weeds (like water on a freshly waxed car). You will want to top off the mixture with water, but you don‚Äôt want it to bubble up so add the water slowly and gently. Good luck!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: I've had this nutsedge grass in my backyard for a couple years and through some research, came across this product. This completely eradicated all signs of nutsedge grass after two weeks or so.During the first week, you won't see any changes, but the following week, that's when you start seeing the nutsedge change from bright green to a yellow. Third week, it's pretty much browned and dead.Just follow the instructions provided and you'll have your yard back in your control.(Just a heads up, if you have concentrated areas of nutsedge, it WILL leave brown spots in your yard. Over time this should disappear with normal grass taking its place, naturally or with grass seed.)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2018
review_content: I would have given the sedgehammer a minimum of three stars for the name alone, which is incredible. However, this was also the only product that actually got rid of our pesky nutsedge, after trying numerous other products. Be sure to give it time to work after application. Our nutsedge continued to grow and look healthy for about a week after I sprayed it on. But then, it started to wither and die. A month or so later, I had a bit of the sedge start to regrow, but only a fraction of what was there initially. I let it establish itself for another week or two, then applied another round of sedgehammer. Since then it's been gone entirely. I can't recommend this sedgehammer highly enough.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2022
review_content: Had SedgeHammer in numerous spots in my St Augustine grass and used other products that didn‚Äôt get rid of it. This product worked great just be patient it took over a week before you see results. Very convenient and easy to use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2021
review_content: It took a couple weeks to do the job, but it killed my purple nut sedge completely and didn't harm any of my other plants or grasses.  It didn't even harm my dahlias.  I would give 5 stars, but holy cow it's expensive!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2019
review_content: Product came timely and was pretty easy to mix.  I included a before pic and gave 5 stars to start off.  I'll update in a few weeks when I see the results.  Just added a pic of day 1, 3, 6, 7 and day 10.  Results look great.  I see no sprouts sticking up in my yard while they are visibly 2 to 3 inches high in my neighbor's yard and we cut our yards on the same day.  They have clearly stopped growing.  I have another packet I can use in a few weeks if I see more popping up but for now I am very satisfied.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2022
review_content: Have an area about 5‚Äô by 15‚Äô of nut grass. Sprayed whole gallon on area. In my case I needed to wait a couple of weeks but now I‚Äôm starting to see results. Not sure how long it will last before the next application.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
review_content: I applied SedgeHammer with a 2 gal tank sprayer and spot sprayed my lawn. We have had a very wet Spring & Summer in St. Louis, and the nutgrass has gone crazy. Tried SedgeHammer and it definitely killed or slowed down the majority of the nutgrass in my yard. It takes awhile to see initial results (at least 2 weeks), then steady improvement. I am thinking about doing a second application towards the end of September to finish off the remainder of the nutgrass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: My newly installed Zoysia sod was developing nutsedge in a few areas a few weeks after the sod was laid. I applied SedgeHammer using a spray bottle in a small area to test its effectiveness as well as whether it would damage my new sod. It took about a week to start seeing results, but the nutsedge started to turn yellow and there was no impact on the Zoysia grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2022
review_content: Performed as stated. It does take at least a week before you see any change, but after 10 days I mowed the grass and it did not return. It was also during an extended hot weather without much rain.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: This product did as it says.  Normally the Nutsedge on my property would grown about 4 times faster than the grass.  I used this product after mowing 3 days prior and I didn't mow again until about 3 to 4 days later.  The nutsedge stopped growing and has turned brown.  I am on the 10 day and you can actually see it dying.  It just takes time.  So be patient there are many products on the market that kills Nutsedge.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2018
review_content: Sledghammer works well with reservations. I have a serious  nut grass infestation in my garden that apparently came with the compost I added .  It has been 3 or 4 years now and has spread quickly. it was hot and dry weather When I sprayed the first time,  After a week there was no  sign that it was working.  The 2nd. time I sprayed it was right after a rain shower. After 2 or 3 days I could see some results and now after about 10 days, the  nut grass  has turned brown and is mostly on the ground.My suggestion is to wet the grass before applying .

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2019
review_content: I live in North Texas and have a Bermuda grass lawn.  This did not discolor or negatively affect the grass at all, and has eliminated the nutsedge stalks in a single application.  I sprayed it fairly heavily to ensure each stalk was wet with the product.  Per the instructions, I may have to reapply it after six weeks, but 1) I doubt that's going to happen based on what I'm seeing, and 2) the cost is so reasonable I'm OK if it does (my lawn service wants $70 extra to treat for nutsedge).  Sedgehammer is exactly what I'd hoped, and I recommend it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2022
review_content: I have a nice zoysia lawn but nutsedge has popped up and looks awful while my lawn is dormant. I read reviews and thought it would effectively solve my issue. It didn‚Äôt and I followed the label but still gad very little impact in solving my problem. I will not use this again and continue my quest for an efficient nutsedge killer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review_content: I followed directions and sprayed the areas with this nuisance grass and a week later it was browned over.  A few popped up nearby within the next week, and those got sprayed and browned over within a week.  The third week I only had to spray two spots and the grass has been gone since those last couple of spots.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2022
review_content: I bought this to get rid of purple nut sedge in a flower bed that the lawn service won't treat.  It unusual for an herbicide to come in powdered form.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
review_content: Nut grass is a pain to get rid of but this stuff works.  You just have to be patient. It does take about two weeks to kill the nut grass. The package does need instructions on how much product (in teaspoons) you need to make a pint. I use a hand held spray bottle to spot spray in a flower bed. Sure as heck do not need a gallon of the nut grass killer laying around.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2023
review_content: This item is effective and would recommend to anyone.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2021
review_content: Sedgehammer works well, but give the nutsedge time to die (about 14 days).  Mixes with water, but be sure you shake the solution before applying.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2022
review_content: Not much to talk about....product is easy to use and does it job in two weeks.  Amazing how well it destroyed the enemy....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2018
review_content: Took a little time, but this took care of our sedge.  I sprayed our area, and after waiting about 2 weeks, the sedge was yellowing a bit and not looking quite so robust, but wasn't sure if I had sprayed well enough, so sprayed again.  That did the trick.  I actually used this a few years ago to knock the sedge down, which it did, but it returned this year.  I'll buy it again when it comes back.  Hopefully it will work as well next time.  Also, this listing is for one package only (I had it in my mind that it was 2 for some reason).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2022
review_content: This works!  after trying several other weed killers that would turn it brown but didn't kill it I came across this.  It's not cheap but well worth the investment.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2023
review_content: The directions call for 2-3 ounces of product for 3 gallons of water.  I mixed the product at 2 ounces and it works great.  My grass/weeds are pretty yellow as you can see in the picture, so it does stand out pretty good.  If your grass is a lot greener you might have to go with a bit more in the water.I works great on the grass, but wear rubber gloves when mixing it unless you enjoy being mistaken for part Smurf.  You can see my hand in the picture and that is after scrubbing with soap and water.  It also will stain concrete.  It will also stain dog feet!  No, there was no chemical in the water when I did any of this, it was just the Blue Turf Mark.  I just got the sprayer hooked up to my new lawn tractor and was experimenting with the color, flow rate, etc.  I found that it also stains the bare feet of my 4 year old grandson!All in all I'm quite pleased with it.  Now that I know how it sticks to non-grass surfaces, I'll be more careful in the future.  I will definitely purchase more when I need it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2023
review_content: Works well. Next to impossible to not get some on yourself. However, it is water soluble and can be removed. To expedite removal, 10% bleach solution helps.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2023
review_content: This product was very easy to use. Not messy at all; Didn't get blue dye everywhere like the last product I purchased. My go to from now on.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2015
review_content: I used this for the first time today, spraying weeds in my outdoor riding arena and in the gravel driveway.  I used about 10 cc in 3 gallons of spray, and the color showed up enough for me to tell where I'd sprayed. The directions say 6-10 ounces per 100 gallons, so I figured 1 oz/10 gals = 1/3 ounce for 3 gallons.  At about 30 cc per ounce, that came to about 10 cc.  I used an old syringe (farm stores have them) to measure.  I think this product will be fine for doing the spot-spraying for weeds on gravel and sand, but I'm not sure how well the color would show up on a lawn.  I also noticed that it did stain the concrete floor in my garage (I dripped a little...), but others have said it washes off driveways in a few days.  I wouldn't spray on nice concrete without testing it first. I dribbled water on the spots and left it for a couple hours.  The stain is more pale but still visible.  (Oh well.  That stain is nothing compared to the oil stains from the truck!)  For my purposes, it will work fine.  If I want a deeper color, I'll add more dye.  I don't go through enough spray in a summer for volume to be a concern.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2021
review_content: Used this for a lawn spray indicator. First and foremost, having the ability to measure the product with the little squeeze chamber is critical for a dye like this, and if you look at other indicator products, the most common negative is from staining issues. With this product, I had no issues spilling it on myself, my clothes, or my driveway. Mixed well with a cocktail of ingredients, and provide a nice blue that was definitely easy to see on my mostly-dormant grass. It was almost nice, because the next day it had faded in a bit and combined with the lime green grass just waking up, it almost looked like an early summer green just coming out of winter. Anyway, it does the job you want it to. No, it won't make your lawn look like a smurf, but it's enough of an indicator to show where the spray is landing. Decent value for the amount of product, and definitely the easiest to use of everything available out there.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2023
review_content: I‚Äôve tried others but none have worked as well as this one. No permanent staining of concrete or any other hard scape. I used it over a 5000 square foot area in one day and it was easy to tell where I had been even a couple days later. It was gone within a week. Like their slogan ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt make a lot of things you buy, we make a lot of the things you buy better‚Äù BASF is top of the line.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2023
review_content: Turf mark arrived quickly and in good condition. The dye was further packaged in a sealed bag in case of leakage if damaged in transit.Have been using this product for over 10 years. Really satisfied with the quality and how many uses you receive from one container.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2017
review_content: I thought this might be a 'luxury' I didn't need. I've been spraying for years without it. Well, for gross spraying - down the edges of the rural driveway and some general areas, I can still do without it. But when spraying "Cat's Claw" vine in the woods around my house; when trying to get rid of all the bermuda grass when preparing a new planting bed - or for anything else that requires some finesse and accuracy, this stuff REALLY helps. I find for most of my stuff I can use it about 1/2 strength (& sometimes 1/4)  & save a few bucks. It shows easily on bare ground / dry & dead grass / driveway rocks / and concrete (edge). But it also easily washes off in a day or two of sun and/or rain. Sometimes within a few hours it's hard (at 1/2 strength) to tell where I've sprayed. If vegetation is lush and you're only wanting to spray part of it - use more. It's harder to see on just green vegetation than on surrounding ground, but even at 1/2 strength you can see if you look. I won't use it ALL the time, but I will have it available ALL the time for when it's most helpful.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2023
review_content: This is a powerful dye. As with many others like this the container looks easy to use but is too easy to spash little drops of dye out onto equipment, self. Inevitably I get some of the dye on my gloves, equipment, then on my hands. I find I have to use a little bleach in wash water to get it off. It's easier to get off my clothes, but with some stain sprayer too. But it marks the areas I'm spraying so I can see what is done and not done. Will continue buying despite drawbacks. No other dyes have been easier to use!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review_content: Measuring is fantastic. This type of container is the only way to go if you can get it. Used this to mark for herbicides on my lawn. Not as dark as I expected even mixing heavy. I found that at a distance I could see it, kinda like a shadow, but up close looking for the overlap not so much. Still worth using. This was the case when spraying the entire lawn with pre-emergent. For spot use the color stands out much better.  I had no issues with clean up. Overspray on concrete & synthetic fence (not sure of the material but not wood) rinsed right off. Got quite a bit on my thumb when my rubber glove tore, cleaned off pretty good using a fingernail brush and aggressive cleaning, completely off my thumb on the next day.  I use this with: MSO surfactant, 2,4D, XLR8, and Dimension. Mixed fine with any mixing combinations I needed at the time. I have a 2gal backpack sprayer and no issues at all with spray pattern. I did start every mix with about 2/3 water and blue dye first, I always add the MSO last. I‚Äôm not sure if it matters but some info out there suggests mixing in that order.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2022
review_content: Spraying Canadian Musk thistle and Knapweed, I've found I need to use more than what's recommended, about 3.5-4 oz in a 2.5 gal sprayer.  I now buy this by the gallon.  On the bright side, you can see where you've been especially in a pasture.  It's definitely 100x better than Mark it brand.  With the drought, the thistles were horrible this year.  They were springing up worse than you could imagine and sometimes right next to some I'd sprayed if there was a little rain which we did get.  Positive was I could still see the ones I'd already sprayed 1 or 2 days before and tell what was new and needed to DIE.  It does mark YOU well and good luck NOT getting any on you.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2023
review_content: Seems to do the job.  Be careful not to stain your hands.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2022
review_content: Good  product...I'm spot spraying for  crabgrass.  Easy to  see what  you've  sprayed. I'm  using  a 25 gallon tank with 12 Oz of Turf Mark. Slightly more than  suggested  on the  label. Does wash off your  hands and disappears  on the grass in a couple of days.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2015
review_content: I recommend it for spraying weeds and ants outside, although I don't know that I would trust it to fade if sprayed indoors even though its stated that its safe for that.I read the reviews prior to mixing it the first time and mixed it 1/2oz per 1gal. It was blue, although going from direct sunlight to shade (NM has over 300 cloudless days) it was difficult to tell if I'd sprayed in the shade. Going from shade to sunlight did not cause me to have the same confusion.I went back the next day to finish spraying, and I could tell what I needed to spray still, which was great. All of the blue disappeared eventually, some surfaces took closer to 2 weeks instead of 48 hours.I did mix it once at the 1oz per 1gal and that is very, very blue. It was easy to tell where was sprayed going from direct sunlight to shade and in reverse. At this strength I accidentally misted my shoes (wind shift) which caused faint blue speckles. The speckles have remained for over 2 weeks and don't appear to be fading. As a note, there is a warning that this can possibly stain, and my shoes (Wolverine tan boots with leather upper and manmade sole) definitely resemble that.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2017
review_content: BEWARE!!!This marker is fabulous! I have saved a LOT of money because I'm not overspraying the same areas.  This particular one washes away from my gravel, and whatever I you spray it on.  The self measuring bottle is perfect (because you don't want to get this stuff on any more items than necessary.) The negative side of the measuring spout is that after measuring the first ounce, you have to look at the fluid from above because you can't see through the plastic. On the plus side: since I have always had problems seeing the fill line through my tank, the die darkens the liquid adequately, making the fill line visible.Another negative with this die: NO MATTER THE GLOVES--somehow, some way, this vibrant blue goo finds its way to your skin.  I guess that is a blessing in disguise--you can see if/where you may have gotten some herbicide on you.

It does start killing some things pretty quickly, but you also have to drench them. Even though I drenched them, there are still areas that didn't die. But it does work fairly well. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2023
review_content: Having used several spray bottles of Round-Up in the past, I wanted to buy it in an economical size and also stop wasting so much plastic.  So I ordered this jug in April 2022.  Refilled a small spray bottle 2-3 times that I used in the yard, and then carefully stashed the closed gallon jug in my cool (60s-F year-round) basement.  This spring (2023) I filled up a spray bottle again and made the rounds in the yard, soaking the leaves of a broadleaf lily weed that we have.  (It successfully killed this weed last spring).  I followed directions, sprayed in direct sunlight with no rain in the forecast, thoroughly drenching the leaves.  Did this on several days.  On a couple of the plants, the very tips of the leaves turned brown, but the plants are mostly unaffected.  I an only conclude the jug degraded within a year.  If that's expected behavior, the product should warn you:  ONLY BUY WHAT YOU'LL USE IMMEDIATELY.  Rather annoyed.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2023
review_content: As a dedicated gardener and lawn care enthusiast, I have found the Southern Ag Methylated Seed Oil (MSO) Surfactant to be an indispensable tool in my weed control arsenal, earning a glowing 5-star review! This high-quality surfactant has significantly enhanced the effectiveness of my herbicides, helping me achieve the best results in my weed management efforts.The quart-sized bottle provides ample supply for multiple applications, making it a cost-effective option for my gardening needs. A little goes a long way, and the MSO surfactant has proven to be a valuable addition to my gardening toolkit.The surfactant's formulation is top-notch. It improves the spreading and coverage of herbicides, ensuring that the active ingredients reach their target more effectively. This improved coverage translates into better weed control and ultimately saves me time and effort in the long run.The compatibility of the Southern Ag MSO Surfactant with various herbicides is a standout feature. I have used it with different weed control products, and it has consistently enhanced their performance without any adverse effects on my plants.The ease of use is another strong point of this surfactant. Mixing it with my herbicides is a straightforward process, thanks to the clear instructions provided on the label. I appreciate the convenience of being able to use it with both liquid and dry formulations.The methylated seed oil in the surfactant acts as an excellent penetrant, ensuring that the herbicides effectively stick to the weeds and are absorbed more efficiently. This potent combination significantly improves the weed-killing action of the herbicides.I also appreciate the versatility of the Southern Ag MSO Surfactant. Whether I am tackling broadleaf weeds, grassy weeds, or other unwanted vegetation, this surfactant consistently delivers excellent results.Moreover, the quart-sized bottle is easy to store and handle. The resealable cap prevents any spills or leaks, keeping the product fresh and ready for future applications.In conclusion, the Southern Ag Methylated Seed Oil (MSO) Surfactant is a game-changer for any gardener seeking improved herbicide performance and better weed control. Its cost-effectiveness, compatibility with various herbicides, ease of use, and potent formulation make it a standout surfactant for gardening and lawn care needs. Enhance the effectiveness of your herbicides with the Southern Ag MSO Surfactant and achieve a weed-free garden and lawn with ease!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2019
review_content: I have a 3/4 acre lawn of hybrid bermuda grass.  Every year I have to deal with crabgrass and other weeds popping up in the lawn.  I needed to give the crabgrass a fairly good soaking with the herbicide, because the liquid would run right off the crabgrass like water off a duck‚Äôs back.  This would cause a brown spot in my lawn about the size of a pie plate, until the bermuda grass would recover.  Not anymore!  Mixing Methylated Seed Oil (MSO) with my herbicide allows me to apply much less product to the weed.  It coats the weed nicely and stays on it.  This has multiple benefits.  I use less herbicide, the weed dies quicker, and my lawn has much smaller brown spots in it.  The herbicide/MSO mixture I used was this; In 1 gallon of water mix 1.5 oz of Drive XLR8 (herbicide) and 1 oz of MSO.  This mixture was recommended by a lawn care professional on a Youtube video.  It works great.  You can also substitute MSMA for the herbicide.  This is a selective herbicide that doesn‚Äôt harm bermuda lawns. Life is a learning process, and I learned that this is a valuable product to me.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2018
review_content: Makes sense why people buy this.After testing - MSO is definitely more powerful than the same tablespoons of non-ionic surfactant. And with MSO + NIS + herbicide - the herbicide actually works at its rated dose finally.Not sure you can justify the price of MSO though. It would be cheaper to just mix a NIS a bit heavier like 1.5 tablespoons/gallon. If you want to experiment or you‚Äôre killing mature weeds like large crab grass - get this. Otherwise meh.Time-LineI‚Äôd say plain herbicides take about 7-10+ days to know if they worked. Herbicides + NIS takes 5 days to see results. Herbicides + NIS + MSO saw decent results/trend at 3 & 1/2 days.Very hard to pour compared to the Non-Ionic Surfactant. Currently testing this side by side vs. a surfactant. Comparing Dicamba with MSO vs. Non-Ionic. And 2-4D with MSO vs. Non-Ionic.Non-Ionic is currently much cheaper. Both require 2 teaspoons per gallon. Aka. 0.67 Tablespoons, aka: 1/3 Fl. Oz.On the plus side, MSO is much easier to see where it has been sprayed compared to Non-Ionic Surfactant. You have to know what you're looking for though. You're looking for a glossy wet appearance with a slight orange tint.I'm slightly expecting MSO to damage the grass more in comparison to a Non-Ionic Surfactant. But I'm also hoping it damages the weeds more. The only herbicide MSO is 100% required for is Quinclorac and Crabgrass - for everything else it's just a helper.Currently, Non-Ionic + 2-4D took approx. 2 weeks to kill 50-70% of the weeds

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
review_content: A few weeks ago, I applied BASF Drive XLR8 (formerly Drive 75) to control crabgrass on my property. The manufacturer recommends using Methylated Seed Oil as a surfactant for best results. I was not disappointed with Drive XLR8 or this product. Fast forward a few weeks (the end of July in NJ) and everyone else's laws are covered in crabgrass while mine only has a few small patches here and there. Don't try and use dish soap or a regular non-ionic surfactant. BASF says to use MSO and they know best. You are spending a lot to use professional herbicides so don't cheap out on the required surfactant.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
review_content: This stuff works well with any herbicide. It's required for things like quinclorac (aka Drive 75), but I mix it with any herbicide I spray. If the herbicide label doesn't list a mix rate for MSO, you normally mix it at about 1 tablespoon per gallon. At this rate this size is very economical and will go pretty far. It makes the leaves you spray very obvious with a wet, shiny look that helps tell where you have and haven't sprayed.MSO can fill in for a normal non-ionic surfactant, but the opposite is not the case. MSO is designed to be used against weeds with a thick, waxy coating that it helps the herbicide penetrate. Due to this it will help herbicide penetrate almost any weed.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2021
review_content: I‚Äôm quite impressed! I‚Äôve used this style of container and electric pump with bug spray so I figured it would be an easier way of killing some weeds and grass. We tried weeding by hand but it took forever and grew back in a few weeks. So I read some reviews and went for this product. Works super well. Some reviews noted it didn‚Äôt work in 15 mins like some of the product photos showed. Mine didn‚Äôt either. I gave it a day/overnight and the grass I sprayed died. Within two weeks or so the dead grass flopped over and blew away or is barely noticeable.I attached a photo showing my initial test area. I started in one area where the grass was pretty thick on my walkway. So ugly. We have large stones as steps, then some small pebbles between them with dark mulch on either side. You can clearly see where I started and specifically left the upper area alone for comparison. I love it! It killed the grass I sprayed and didn‚Äôt discolor the large stones, small stones or mulch. I also sprayed in areas with pine type bushes and it didn‚Äôt bother them. I kept it away from flowers but sprayed near the base and they were fine too.I highly recommend. I sprayed each section twice. Nothing overly heavy but ‚Äúwiggling‚Äù it back and forth as I sprayed. Aimed at the base of the grass then the upper ‚Äúleafs.‚Äù Worked better than expected. I used two containers to do a backyard patio with much larger stones and then the front walkway.I don‚Äôt know longevity but it‚Äôs been 3-4 weeks and in those areas, no grass has come back. I will need to spray a little next year I‚Äôm sure when new grass seeds float around but hopefully nothing this bad.Highly recommend!

review_content: I just had to say all the bad reviews about this weed killer not working are ridiculous. I bought this particular weed killer because it's for "Hardscapes" because my landscaping has patio blocks in part of it white rock on other parts & red mulch in others. I also have stepping stones personal walkway.With all that said, I just sprayed patio blocks & everything else during the hottest part of the day & made sure it wasn't going to rain. Needless to say it didn't even take 2 weeks to work. It worked completely within 3 days but I did soak the weeds & things pretty heavily.Nonetheless, the meat & potatoes of it is this stuff for surely works great. I will definitely buy again & I would definitely recommend for hardscape landscaping situation. The bad reviews saying this stuff doesn't work are nothing more than ridiculous in my personal experience with this stuff. Oh & the battery operated wand is definitely the only & best way to go in my opinion also

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2023
review_content: I wanted to wait until I used it to leave a review. After using it I am highly satisfied and surprised how fast it killed the weeds. My backyard honestly looked like an abandoned jungle before using this. They say it takes a few days to work fully but for me within the hour the weeds were already turning black and the next day were completely dead. Only one that took a few days was a blood berry weed that was basically a medium sized tree. I am definitely 100 percent satisfied and highly highly recommend.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2023
review_content: This showed fantastic results just 24 hours later. I didn't expect it to work so well so quickly. My photos show crabgrass where I sprayed and crabgrass where I didn't spray. I didn't spray everywhere because I figured I'm doing a test where I would compare results in a week. Only took 24 hours. Only problem is, now my grass has so much brown in it because this product killed off so much crabgrass. I bought it for Goosegrass as well and it's killing those as well. A tad slower than the crabgrass, but still working great.I've tried other products for crabgrass in concentrate form and they didn't work half as well as this. I have a hunch you're supposed to add a surfactant with concentrate, but this ready to go product had everything all mixed. All you do is flip the safety lock and spray.I was so impressed I will now look at Ortho's backyard bug killer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2021
review_content: I am a picky lawn person so was in need to find something to get rid of the Dallisgrass in my lawn.  Unfortunately the previous owner had not done much to fight the fight so pulling it out by hand was not a real option, it had taken over in some places.  I used 2oz to 1 gallon in a hand sprayer and this seems to have done the job while not killing my bermuda.  Takes awhile to work, this is not a 24 hour solution.  You spray it and you will see the Dallisgrass start to turn a lighter shade of green almost a yellowing color.  Wait about 30 days and you will need to go back and hit those spots again. Keep your lawn mowed and the bermuda will find its way back into those bare spots.  This is an expensive solution but after looking at other ideas I think it was the best one.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2020
review_content: I bought this mainly to get rid of all the tall fescue clumps (as well as random areas of regular fescue grass) in my bermuda lawn. This stuff works awesome!! Nearly knocked out nearly every bit of it on the first application and didn't even phase the bermuda at all! Also applied it to Poa Annua growing in certain areas and it wiped it out completely as well. The only warning I have is that a you use a respirator when spraying this stuff. It has a very powerful chemical odor and it will strongly irritate your sinuses, as well as leave a strange taste in your mouth for several hours afterwards. This happened to me more than once before I figured out it was the Revolver causing the taste and irritation. Very unpleasant! Other than that it is worth it's weight in gold!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2022
review_content: I did my first application of this product over three weeks ago, and it has been the only weed killer I have ever used which kills crabgrass!  I use a tank sprayer to spot treat weeds. It is VERY important to follow the instructions to the letter so the product works successfully.  I had some Triton X surfactant in the house, and used a small amount of it (diluted) with this weed killer and it helps make the solution stick to the weeds.  Also, only a very small burst from the sprayer is needed to coat the weeds--if you apply too much, you will burn the lawn.  I'm still getting crabgrass but 1) I realized I missed a few spots (including an entire row ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è), and 2) I have some crabgrass emerging that sprouted after I applied the first treatment, so I need to do a second treatment now that more than three weeks have passed.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
review_content: As a homeowner striving for a lush and weed-free lawn, Gordon's SpeedZone Lawn Weed Killer has become my ultimate solution for effectively eliminating unwanted weeds and maintaining a beautiful yard.The first thing that impresses me is the effectiveness of this weed killer. It targets a wide range of common lawn weeds, including dandelions, clover, chickweed, and more, ensuring comprehensive weed control.The 20-ounce size is a standout feature of Gordon's SpeedZone Weed Killer. It provides ample coverage for my lawn, allowing me to treat large areas and address weed infestations effectively.One significant advantage of this weed killer is its fast-acting formula. It starts working quickly, showing visible results within a short period, which is particularly beneficial for those seeking rapid weed control.The ease of application is another highlight of Gordon's SpeedZone Lawn Weed Killer. It can be conveniently sprayed over the affected areas, making the weed-killing process simple and straightforward.In conclusion, Gordon's SpeedZone Lawn Weed Killer is more than just a weed killer; it's a game-changer for achieving a weed-free and beautiful lawn. With its effective weed targeting, ample size, fast-acting formula, and easy application, this weed killer has become an essential part of my lawn care routine. For homeowners seeking a reliable and efficient weed control solution, Gordon's SpeedZone Lawn Weed Killer is a top-notch choice. Transform your lawn with confidence, thanks to Gordon's SpeedZone Lawn Weed Killer!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2022
review_content: Easy to mix when following directions.Do not use this on a Windy day as instituted or if rain is expected within 24 hours.First application worked great on Creeping Charlie weeds and clovers. Second application worked great on the remaining Broadleaf weeds and Crab Grass. After the two applications and following the directions on container i decided i will be doing a third application just because my yard was neglected for several years and this will ensure i am weed free for overseeing my lawn just before autumn. As to note, Creeping Charlie, Clover and those annoying Broadleaf weeds have no chance against this product. Clover and Creeping Charlie die noticably in a few days. Clover turns white and Creeping Charlie turns brown when dead. You do not need to water your lawn while product is on. Let mother nature do her work and in a week or so you definitely will see the full results. A second application will kill whatever was dormant and may have then grown after the first application. Do not rush anything. Take your time and be happy later with a weed free yard. Follow all directions on container.Also as a tip you Surfactant. It helps the product stick to this pesky Clovers and Crab Grass. I got great results following directions and with the use of Surfactant mixed together.Good luck and stay safe.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2017
review_content: I "had" a terrible speedwell, creeping charlie and violet infestation on my lawn.  Like another reviewer I combined this with Ortho WBG chickweed killer and applied with a sprayer every 10-14 days for 3 applications.  In addition I picked up clippings for 3 mowings as speedwell propagates from readily from  any small clipping as do many other weeds from my readings.  The results are amazing.  After one application they were knocked back but I saw many sprouts popping up. After the second mostly dead and the 3rd application gone.  Weeds die and shrivel up, although it does take a few weeks and the grass is filling in very nicely.  These are hardy weeds and will take some work but when properly applied this does the job.  I have had no grass stress, but it has been somewhat cool and wet.  I will have to spot spray a few spots but overall excellent.  For speedwell regular WBG has almost no affect as many seem to attest.  I tried the WBG Chickweed, Clover and Oxalis killer and it did have some impact but the speedwell came right back.  BTW, this mix also seems to knock out the sedge grass.  32 year home owner and DIY guy.  This stuff works.Be careful and read the directions and measure into your tank sprayer.  This is highly concentrated syrupy consistency, please pay attention to directions, safety and wear gloves, eye protection, mask and long sleeves and pants and shower up right away.

review_content: I've tried everything going after Creeping Charlie with various success with MANY different products. Minus ONE Star) The cap on your windshield wiper solution in your garage will fit perfectly! review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2019
review_content: This is first weed killer that we‚Äôve used and actually worked. Our yard was completely green before trying the product, but that‚Äôs because it was completely covered by creeping charlie. In the late winter, we still were having to mow every 6 days. After the first application (using the highest amount of recommended ratio of weed killer to water), I didn‚Äôt see much of a difference, so I tried it again a week later. Within the next few days after the 2nd application, you could see a drastic change. Now it‚Äôs 2 weeks later and the clovers are dead. Our lawn looks dead, but that‚Äôs a good thing because it means the creepy charlie was gone and now we can work on building a healthy lawn! As a bonus, an infestation of sticker burs that plagued us was no longer a problem. Our poor dog would come in with so many and they were all over our house. We had too many to pull out one by one. They were in every square inch. This formula killed them as well! We also had poison ivy and other various weeds growing in our bushes. After spraying them, the bushes are fine, but the weeds are completely dead. Now our backyard still has certain types of weeds (crabgrass is one of them) that it didn‚Äôt work on, but our biggest issues are gone. I would recommend this to anyone to at least try. Especially if nothing else has worked. One bottle will last us quite a while, so I think the price is worth it!**Side note, I did keep our dog out of the backyard for about 4-5 hours after applying. She is only about 12 pounds, but walked around the entire yard after I let her out and there were no side effects from the treatment.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023
review_content: I knew I'd need to get a sprayer. I must say however, the ad that lead me to the product specifically for crabgrass, did not reflect the actual product directions which don't mention crabgrass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
review_content: Pros:1. Visible results in hours: This is not an exaggeration. I applied this product in the morning, took a nap, and woke up to find my lawn looking like it had been on a strict diet and workout regimen. It was like watching one of those time-lapse videos of a caterpillar turning into a butterfly, but for my lawn.2. Covers a large area: I own a pretty large property (don't mean to brag), and this product covered it all. It was like having a magic carpet that could spread over my entire lawn and transform it into a lush, green paradise.3. Rapid and effective weed control: This product showed no mercy to the weeds. It was like a superhero for my lawn, fighting off the evil weeds and restoring peace and tranquility.4. Does not harm lawn grasses: My grass seemed to love this product. It was like a spa treatment for them, leaving them looking refreshed and rejuvenated.5. Cool Weather Performance: This product doesn't care if it's chilly outside. It's like the mailman of lawn care products - neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.Cons:1. Too effective: My lawn now looks so good that it's attracting too much attention. I've had neighbors I've never spoken to before stopping by to ask what my secret is. I've even had a couple of garden gnomes go missing, presumably taken by envious neighbors.2. Rapid results may cause shock: The transformation was so quick that I had a hard time recognizing my own lawn. I had to double-check my address to make sure I hadn't wandered into someone else's property.3. May cause feelings of inadequacy: My lawn now looks so perfect that it's making the rest of my house look bad. I'm now considering a complete home renovation to match the beauty of my lawn.In conclusion, this product works a little too well. Use with caution, unless you're prepared to deal with the consequences of having the most beautiful lawn in the neighborhood.

review_content: This product helped with controlling the weeds on my lawn. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2016
review_content: Whoever thought up this concoction is a genius! The last few years my backyard has been over taken by creeping charlie, clovers, and wild violets. It's really hard to find something that will kill broadleefs, dandelions, and wont damage your grass. This stuff hit it on every level. I've done two applications so far and just about all of the wild violets, creeping charlie, and clovers are either gone or dwindling to near death! My grass hasn't looked this good in years. The dandelions don't even stand a chance! I had about 15-20 in my front yard and I sprayed each one individually and I'm not even kidding, they we're falling over within 12 hours and didn't even remotely damage the grass.The best part is you can see throughout the neighborhood that the dandelions and wild violets are terrible this year, but you wouldn't know it if you looked at my yard! If you're having the dandelion problem this year buy this and apply immediately you will not be disappointed. Without a doubt I will continue to buy this year after year.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2020

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2012
review_content: I've tried them all! A retired pro landscaper recommended this product to me. He said you can try all the other stuff, but bottom line - Speed Zone is all you need. I'm generally suspicious of such an absolute endorsement, but he was right on target.It's quite expensive for a 20oz bottle, but it is concentrated. You will need to mix 1oz Speed Zone per gallon of water, as indicated on the product label. (1 oz. = 2 tbls.)I can spot treat my entire lawn (7500 sq. ft.) with only 2 oz of Speed Zone concentrate. So, as it turns out, it is quite economical for my purposes.As far as its effectiveness, this stuff is fantastic. It whacks everything you spray it on EXCEPT your lawn. In my case, cool season grasses - Tall Fescue and Kentucky Bluegrass mixture in Northern Virginia.All this leads me to my next point... Be careful where you spray it! A slight breeze while you're spraying near the flower bed and you've just whacked the wife's garden. Walk away slowly and disavow any knowledge.I have been able to completely turn around my crappy lawn (inherited from the previous owner) in large part thanks to Speed Zone. I would recommend it to anyone. My search for a consistent, effective herbicide is over.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2018
review_content: I bought this through another website but wanted to share my review so someone else doesn‚Äôt get their hopes up for this product.Does it kill on contact? Yes.Does it kill quickly? Yes.Does it keep it dead? NO.I did a lot of research on this product but clearly not enough. It does not move throughout the plants, so will only kill parts of the plants that it contacts. I don‚Äôt know if I just assumed this would kill to the roots or if I just didn‚Äôt see it stated otherwise. I wanted to control the grasses next to the lake but as soon as it was dead there was new growth. At this point I would be spraying every week and constantly have half dead grass, which is ridiculous. I can‚Äôt think of a need for a product I am constantly reapplying unless it‚Äôs for sod preparation so it won‚Äôt kill new grass. This is not the reason I bought it. Sure, it‚Äôll kill grass and cattails, but only temporarily and only where it touches, but they will be back, and soon! For such an expensive product I expected more, very disappointed and I won‚Äôt be purchasing this again.In the photo, you can see where I sprayed a week ago, everything ‚Äúdied‚Äù within 3 days, and it is clearly growing back just fine.
