review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: I have great success with Amazon's Southern Ag Atrazine 1 Gallon where Crab Grass, Spurge, Poa Annua & Wild Bermuda is a problem in my Centipede lawn when applied according to label:  * 4.3 oz. per gallon covering 500 sq ft of mix  * No Rain or Irrigation for 72 hours for the contact control to be effective  * Must have water within 7-10 days for pre-emergence to prevent seed germination  * Then be patient - Atrazine takes a few weeks to achieve its full potentialThe treatment will retard the growth of Crab Grass allowing the Centipede to out-grow & squeeze the Crab Grass out, same goes for Bermuda Grass in my Centipede lawn. Fertilizing at the same time (Optimum end of April for me Zone 6) will give the Centipede the edge over the tough to kill weed grasses, just be careful - not too much Nitrogen - apply up to 30-0-10 ratio of slow release twice a year and stay under the 2 pounds per year nitrogen limit for Centipede.  Too much Nitrogen and Centipede will decline.I use a Tractor Supply 15 gallon (three boom) pull behind sprayer which I modified to include a deep cycle battery for power and larger #4 orifice nozzles. The sprayer came equipped with connections to the riding mower, however a riding mower's electrical output is simply not enough, hence the deep cycle battery.  I use 5 ounces Southern Ag Surfactant along with two quarts of Southern Ag Atrazine mixed into the 15 gallons of water. It works great and is applied to approximately 7,500 square feet in very short order.Atrazine controls a wide variety of weeds and Centipede seems to really respond to it, greening up within a few weeks even without fertilizer. If applied according to the label, Atrazine will make a real difference and get rid of your weeds for the season. Please be kind to our environment:  * Read the label, use recommended rates, don‚Äôt apply in front of a rain event  * An initial treatment and possibly a follow-up for stubborn weeds like Spurge should work  * Triple rinse & properly dispose of containers

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2023
review_content: There aren't many herbicides you can use to kill weeds in St. Augustine.  This is the one I have used for years.  One thing is I live in central Alabama where it is 90 degrees almost every day from May until October.  You cannot use this on the grass when it is that hot.  But... if you can find a day when temps dip and it doesn't rain for a day or two - it works the best of any weed killer I have found for St. Augustine.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2022
review_content: It does what is says but is slow as it says, once I saw it working during the second week I went ahead with a second application, and it did kill all the species it stated, did not have an effect on torpedo grass, so that was sad.Biggest complaint, it takes long enough that by the time it treats the first set of weeds, new weeds will come in which requires nearly a weekly cycle, not a two week cycle, which it does not declare on the bottle.And after a long battle of two months, and the whole bottle, gave enough footing for the st.austine to grow densely enough to get the weeds out of there.Mission accomplished!4 stars just due to the time it takes, then again I did not find a more efficient or effective brand, even from my lab buddy as this would have also been his offering, had I asked him for a recommendation.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2017
review_content: So this kills Poa Annua (Blue grass). That annoying smelly grass that grows in the middle of the good grass and gets in the way. I have Bermuda grass in my yard (the typical builder grade Bermuda sod installations in north GA). And I read (too late) that this is really meant for St.Augustine and some other specific grass and will kill everything else. Well like I said too late to read this warning as I had already sprayed the front yard with this per recommended dosage on the bottle. After a little bit of panic I watered the lawn to water down the effect of this thing to save my Bermuda from dying, a dire attempt if you will. Low and Behold... it did not kill my bermuda but wiped out Poa Annua completely and any other thing that could have potentially grown in the spring/summer. Well why it did not kill Bermuda.. is a question to ask and will it kill the next time I use it. The answer is yes. It will kill Bermuda BUT not when its dormant or just about to start greening in early spring. Confirmed after a good read on a website that talks in detail about this chemical. So I happened to spray this when the bermuda was just about to start greening or coming out of dormancy. Guess what.. I got lucky with the timing. It did stress the greening parts a little bit so everything looked brown in about two weeks. But then when it started uniformly greening up all the stressed out Bermuda came back right up EXCEPT the annoying Poa Annua. This thing works and is indeed slower. I mean I tried watering it down quiet a bit but it worked despite that. So people who aren't getting results are being too impatient with this weed killer. Let it work for you. I almost felt like I washed the weed killer out after watering down my lawn and thinking that its ok to not kill Poa Annua but save my Bermuda. But it still worked. The next time around I am going to be a little more careful and time it when Bermuda grass is dormant. I am also thinking that this may actually work as a pre-emergent in case if I time it properly and do it early spring.Disclaimer: I wasn't given a product for free. I thought I made a mistake by applying it to Bermuda lawn. But it still worked and it did not kill Bermuda. I think it did not because it was early spring when most of the Bermuda was still dormant or just greening up and Poa Annua was already green and shinning. YMMV. So don't count on my experience a 100%. But it does kill the annoying Poa Annua in 2, 3, or even 4 weeks down from the application date provided there has not been too much rain right after the application.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2023
review_content: Keeps the grass healthy and get rid of picker grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2020
review_content: I have been using Atrazine for the past three years. Its for centipede lawns. It works ok on some things but does not seem to even wither or brown Annual Blue Grass/Poa or Dichondra. I had a lot of it left over so I thought I would try it again on Annual Blue Grass/Poa. The label says it kills it in 2 to 3 days and after I think 7 days it prevents any seed from sprouting. It's been over a week now and it hasn't changed the Poa one bit, still just as tall and just as green. I have also tried Image with about the same results. For that purpose I would try something else. Problem is I don't know of anything else to try. I always mix them a little stronger than suggested to make sure my measurements are adequate. I have spent hundreds of dollars on these two brands and many an hour and many a mike spraying it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2023
review_content: Product showed up in a completely blank, unmarked bottle. Didn‚Äôt even know that was legal on a herbicide type product. Thankfully I use the stuff regularly and can recognize the fluid, but was pretty disappointing to show up like that‚Ä¶

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2023
review_content: Good value for the quantity as compared to smaller containers sold in big box stores. Won‚Äôt go bad so will last several years.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2023
review_content: I use this on my Centipede grass and it has worked so far. It kills the weeks with ease after a few months. The key is making sure you apply both times instead of just once. I apply to about 4,000 sqft and I have used it 4 times and I still have 80% of the gallon left.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2023
review_content: Atrazine is great for controlling listed weeds in Centipede Grass. I'm working on crab grass this fall and next spring to see if atrazine helps to manage as a pre emergent.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2014
review_content: My yard is mostly bahiagrass, bermudagrass, and weeds, with a little centipede that I am trying to encourage.  This is a very slow-acting weed killer, but it will work eventually.  One application conquered the more delicate  weeds (if there is such a thing) in about a week.  I used two applications about a month apart on most of the yard (about 1/2 acre) and the Atrazine has killed most of the dandeliaons, of which I probably had 75 or more.  It also seems to have slowed the growth of newly sprouted crab grass and some of it is very yellow now, a month after the last application.  I have a lot of newly sprouted crabgrass, however, which I don't expect the Atrazine to take care of.Application is tedious, since you must use a pump-up sprayer, and if you have a large area to cover, it's extremely difficult to keep track of where you've sprayed.  It would be nice if it could be applied with a hose-end sprayer and also to have some kind of coloring to it so that you could tell where you've sprayed.I would buy it again because it's more effective than other weed killers and it does not kill the desired grass as one of the others I tried did, even though it was labeled for centipede.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2022
review_content: It‚Äôs difficult to find this at the box stores.  My neighbor mentioned he got it on Amazon.  This stuff works well on picker grass and clovers.  Read the directions and you should be fine.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2023
review_content: Purchased to kill doveweed. Doveweed growing and Bermuda grass is dead around the weeds instead. Measured and diluted in sprayer per instruction

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2023
review_content: I did one major treatment and one follow up and all the St. Augustine turned yellow and the whole yard is devoid of any of it, without affecting the bermuda.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2022
review_content: After reading some of the reviews, I was a little skeptical if this would actually work but it did an amazing job! I followed the directions and sprayed my yard which had a good amount of clover and other weeds that came up over the past year. I gave it a few weeks and could see that it was working but needed a second application. Two weeks after the second use and there are no weeds/clover in the yard. I was afraid it would kill the St. Augustine sod we had laid the previous year but it is still lush and super green. Highly recommend.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2023
review_content: St Augustine is temperamental so cation is needed when trying to get rid of the worst weeds like crabgrass and dollar weeds. Atrazine works! I set my dispenser on 8 oz per gallon and it does the job after 3 applications.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020
review_content: I tried four other herbicides trying to find something that will kill Carolina Geranium.  This stuff WILL kill it, but the formula they give you is TOO strong for tall fescue.  When I used the recommended 4 oz per 1 gallon of water, I killed everything I sprayed it on.  It was like I had sprayed RoundUp.  Then I tried 2 oz / gallon.  It still killed everything.  Finally, I tried 1 oz / gallon.  That formula worked better.  It killed the Carolina Geranium, but it left the tall fescue.  The tall fescue was "stunned", but it will recover.  It is now to late in the season to try again.  Next spring I will try 1/2 oz / gallon.  Hopefully, that will still kill the Carolina Geranium, but not stun my tall fescue.Oh, I almost forgot.  This stuff takes a week to ten days to do it's job.  If you try it, wait at least that long before you decide it doesn't work.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2023
review_content: Open the box to find the cap you must squeeze to open the actual cap  was in the bottom of the box and the cap holding the liquid in the bottle was cracked. Very little product out apparently. Some paper around the plastic bottle would likely prevent the damage..

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2023
review_content: This works, it may take about 2 applications and some patience, but works without killing grass.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2022
review_content: I have a 4 gallon backpack sprayer. Calculated the square footage of my yard and how much atrazine needed for the job. Added a splash of surfactant and blue lazer. No doubling up.. these are my results in about 3-4 weeks. Dying slow enough to where grass is able to grow where the weeds once were as their dying.I am so impressed! I had a really bad invasive weed problem.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
review_content: Crab Grass was over taking my St. Augustine lawn.I find that Atrazine Herbicide works well in controlling Crab Grass and Dove Weed.However, Atrazine must be sprayed on lawns in the fall and spring to be effective.  In South Louisiana, this is normally in early November and February.Do not spray Atrazine when daytime temperatures are regularly in the 80s.  The Atrazine will suppress the St. Augustine‚Äôs growth.It will take 2-3 years of using Atrazine, properly,  to completing defeat the growth of Crabgrass and Doveweed.Note: During February 2019, the Supplier was change and a one gallon container of this product had a 22% price increase.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2022
review_content: This is an affordable product that is easy to use. It will not stop all the weeds but it stops most of them before they ever come up.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2016
review_content: I had a lot of dollarweeds popping up everywhere through my yard (Daytona Beach area), along with some other broadleaf weeds that I never could identify properly.  In any case, one spraying (following the recommended dosage) of this product cleared them all up, leaving me with a perfect lawn again.  The St Augustine grass doesn't seem to have been affected at all; only the weeds were killed.As others have noted, it does take a while to do its work.  I didn't notice any effect for the first several days, and thought that I might need to spray again ... until I went back and read the directions and many other user's comments here.  Eventually (in 2-ish weeks), all the weeds were dead.  So have patience.Oh, I also dded a teaspoonful of surfactant (from the same company) to the mix, as recommended for spraying.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: I have waited to leave a review on this product until I had a chance to use it for a while to make sure it did not harm the grass.I started by using a small 1/2 gal hand sprayer and treated a small area. I think my first application was a little light and after about one week the clover just looked a little sick. I then gave the area another shot, this time I sprayed it more heavily.  Well that did the trick. Clover all gone and no damage to the grass.I have treated all of the spots since then and most of the clover is all gone.  Very happy with the results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2017
review_content: I am ordering two more gallons, today. I use 16 ounces in a four gallon backpack sprayer. I will wait to see if other reviews saying it its strength has been diluted before I give 5 stars. Spurge is our main weed problem. A search for spurge weed killer for St. Augustine brought up weed killers that the manufacturer said the user should wear gloves, rubber boots, an apron and a face mask. Not so with this product. This killed the spurge without harming our grass. Those people who have written that it killed their St. Augustine should buy blue marker dye so that they only make one application in any one spot.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2018
review_content: Works well, but does take some time!! Can't stress that enough.  It killed weeds that I am not really sure what they are pretty quickly, but just took a while on the dollar weed. In fact I was watching it closely daily and thinking it wasn't working after about 2 weeks.  So I considered it a treatment failure and stopped paying so much attention to the grass, while I browsed for other treatment options.  A few weeks later I noticed that the grass was looking great, and the areas I sprayed with the most dollar weed were essentially dollar weed free.  Thus, I would recommend applying it, and just try and forget about it for a few weeks.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2022
Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2017
review_content: Worked on Ephedra plant though we cut down 8 feet tall bushes with a chain saw to about 4 to 6 inches tall before using this about 3 times in 3 weeks in 80 F sunny, dry weather. Ephedra is a genus of gymnosperm shrubs, the only genus in its family, Ephedraceae, and order, Ephedrales. Six months later we still spot treat about every 3 weeks, new growth from the ground near the bushes.This is the 6th herbicide we tried. Nothing else killed new growth or existing growth.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2018
review_content: Are use this on my centipede lawn to kill out the weeds. I was kind of late in the year so I could not use a deterrent for weed so I had to go with this product. I was kind of afraid to use it but I am glad I did! The weeds started dying off within a week. They killed most of them and now I have to do a couple spots sprays and that‚Äôs it!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2018
review_content: only works on certain types of weeds but works good on those and st augustine grass 4oz/gallon has been safe for mesprayed every week for 4 weeks didnt harm grass. in some areas (direct sun) and when its above 90 atrazine will slow the grass down or make some brown here and there. but spraying 4 weeks in a row is pretty extreme but i am tired of the weeds and not afraid to kill some grass it grows back fast here if other factors are good.had to use bonide and tricloro for some other weeds

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
review_content: I was using this product to control mini-mimosa weeds. So far it‚Äôs not doing a great job. Possibly too late in the year. I‚Äôll use it again in the spring and see. The product is very thick and doesn‚Äôt dissolve well in water. It also clogs the filter of the sprayer which I had to stop and clean a couple of times per gallon. I had used another product that contained Atrazine that came in a container that was attached to the garden hose. It seemed to work better but cannot find it now.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
review_content: If you use EXACTLY as directed it will only kill the stubborn weeds like a miracle and leave your St Augustine grass green and growing. Apply product with only 1 overlapping pass - too much concentration will effect the grass however. I am so impressed this actually worked where all other store products failed.

Does take 10 days to 2 weeks to see results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2022
review_content: After first application, I didn't see any dead weeds in my lawn.  Next month is my next application.  Hope to see some success after next application.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2017
review_content: Some times you need to call out the big guns and this is it.  I use it occasionally on some tough weeds in Floratam St. Augustine grass.  Take appropriate protection measures such as gloves and respirator as this stuff is not good for living things.  Use sparingly and not as first choice.  Look at Celcius for a likely safer experience.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2022
review_content: Bought this as a less expensive alternative to Image. I have centipede grass and you can't put much on it that would not kill it. I viewed this and reviews said it would take care of the poa anna and not hurt my centipede. I sprayed as per the directions in early February when everything was dormant. Did not see any change after 3 weeks, gave it a couple more weeks and the poa anna is now going to seed and still healthy. Soon after the centipede was coming out of dormancy and I noticed that where I sprayed wasn't greening up like the rest of the yard. A few weeks later and my yard looks like crap, poa anna is thriving and centipede where i sprayed is mostly dead. What a waste of time and money, I should have stayed with Image as it is expensive but it kills the poa anna without damaging the centipede.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
review_content: This is AMAZING stuff to use when trying to kill tough vegetation.  I have pachysandra overtaking my woods and flow beds.  I've tried generic glyphosate, which had almost no affect on it, even after applying it 3 times at 2x the dose and waiting over 3 months.  Roundup concentrate was only marginally better (it turned the leaves slightly yellow, but that was about it.)Crossbow is one of the two herbicides that were mixed together to make Agent Orange.  For those of you too young to know what that was, let's just say it made a desert out of the jungles in Vietnam (but also made humans, who were unfortunate enough to be directly exposed to it, into real live monsters).I mixed it at about 6oz/gal.  This is slightly higher than the highest recommended concentration.  I sprayed it liberally onto the pachysandra during the morning in the summer when the sun wasn't shining too hard (that way it has more time to sit on the leaves before it evaporates).  You'll need to do this during the growing season (spring through fall).  It takes about 2-3 weeks before you start seeing the leaves turn brown, but it's all downhill from there.  This seems to be the only stuff I've heard of that can kill pachysandra.Not wanting to take any chances, I bought a decent disposable paint mask and wore rubber gloves while mixing and spraying it.  And so far, I still don't resemble a monster.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
review_content: 11/3/18:Really good product... depending on your soil type. I use for killing Creepin' Charlie (Ground Ivy).  I have 3 places in 3 different states/climates/soils.  I am using in mid-to-late October and early-to-mid November right now.  I realize that it takes several weeks to show results. The brownish Ohio soil is the best for killing the stuff.  Worked awesome.  Even used 2 days before rain and it rid CC in large test patches.  It has been 2 weeks, since using it in a wider area.  Will post results soon.I used on poor, brownish soil in south central Indiana.  Still awaiting results.I used on black, rich Northern Illinois soil and it is hesitant to work.  Still having poor results.One problem, and it is a biggie, is that it rains a day or two after putting on CC.  This, I know, is not good to do.  I try to put it on 3-4 days before the next rain.  However, midwest rainfall during this time is unpredicable.  Some of the Crossbow may be washing off.  However, it should kill the roots.I put it on my test patches in Ohio and it rained 3 hours later.  Still killed the CC.  It may have been warmer/drier out so it worked better.Illinois: No luck.  Put a second spray on a larger test area and only a little area died.  However, it has only been about a week-and-a-half.I did an entire front yard in Indiana 2 weeks ago.  Haven't checked results.  Being hopeful!Note on product:  STRONG ODOR!  WOW!!!!  Use ingredients correcly.  Use gloves.  Be safe.------12.3.18 Update.Did very well in Ohio, with almost 85% creeping ivy killed off.Northern Illinois:  Had bad weather and early snow that yielded poor results.  I will have to wait until early Spring to try again.  Killed off about 30-35% of area treated.Indiana: 70% killed.  Again, bad weather hindered product working.  Will also have to wait until Spring.------7.17.19 Update.Well, Spring has come and gone.  In Ohio, the creeping charlie ivy was 95% gone from the previously treated areas.  However, it did not do much to the wild violets, that seemed to spread where they were intermeshed with the ivy.  I treated the lawn again in late April and that took care of most of the remaining ivy in those test areas.  I am pretty happy overall with the results there.  I sprayed other parts of the yard that I hadn't before 2 weeks ago.In Northern Illinois.  I haven't retreated the grassy area where the ivy was located.  However, that area is about 60% clear of the creeping charlie ivy that was present last year.  I will treat it when the weather gets cooler.  It has been quite rainy here and that area stayed pretty wet.  I tested this on weeds like poison hemlock (little to no results noted yet) and jewelweed (drooped in hours; browned in days).Indiana - I just did a second treatment this year in my yard.  In the front of that house, I did not spray this year;  the ivy was gone.  GONE.  However, like Ohio, I have violets all over, and this did not even deter them.  I have sprayed the back yard in test places once in early May to test with mixed results (40-50% ivy and some other broadleaf weeds killed).  I treated the entire backyard last week.  Again, the rain there has been unrelenting, but I managed to spray with a 3-4 day break in precipitation.  I will see what happens in 3 weeks.  The earlier spray looked promising on pokeweed (that horrid giant purple berry producing weed!).  It wilted and browned OVERNIGHT!  I like that result.More results soon....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: Crossbow isn't Roundup, so that's plus #1.Plus #2 is it's short half-life (3 days) in soil and it's easy application.Plus #3 I haven't found glycophsphates or neoctinoids in it, so I consider it safe for my property is small amounts applied a few days before rain. The half-life is rather long in water, so don't apply within three days if rain if possible. Please correct me if I'm wrong about the neoctinoids, I definitely do not want to harm my bumble bee population.The solution suggested on the bottle (1%) does work well just take quite a bit of time, often near a week. The same rules apply as when using vinegar and soap; spray at the beginning of a warm dry day for best effects.For vines, shrubs and ragweed this systemic killer works well when painted onto an open stem. Are vines invading your flower beds, and you don't want to spray herbicide everywhere, but also don't want to take forever to remove the vines by hand? No problem. Snip a few of the vines, get a cheap paint brush and a paper cup, pour some Crossbow in the cup and paint it onto the snipped ends. Within 1 week everything attached to those vines will be dead and stay that way. It's how I do most of my applications. This stuff also works very well on ivy, both ground level and on trees. I haven't seen my trees suffer, but I've been extremely careful to only paint chopped sections of the ivy vines.In general I'm extremely happy with this product, as long as it's used responsibly.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
review_content: Does exactly what you expect it to do. Our neighbor had ivy growing through half of her backyard and growing into our yard. Her's and the big ditch in our yard were completely over grown and haven't been touched in at least 7 years. This stuff killed everything; ivy, vines, 8 feet tall weeds, small trees (few feet tall), bushes, grass, and anything else back there (except spider lilies they came out after everything died) ü§îHere's what happenedIt was the morning 14th of September i remember the eerie calm from a night of concurring land by the enemy. I thought to myself 'No More' ! You will not breach my boarders! I ran for the supply shelter and prepared my arsenal of Southern Crossbow.......I then snuck around back to face my enemy. Looked them square in the eyes and said "say Hello to my little Friend" Set the chamber to a 2oz flow rate and laid down fire. Covering 2 feet at once, it didn't take long before it hit all of them. They didn't even know what happened.Within 48 hours, you could see the massacre happening. Everyday more and more lay defeated on the battlefield.One week later from the kitchen I glanced into the backyard and saw a white flag üè≥ waving in the air (surrounded by red spider lilies/flowersü§î) I knew then I had won this battle. üçª

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2015
review_content: This is getting hard to find.  Lowes and Home Depot just looked at me like I was hallucinating when I told them how 2-4-D worked.  They kept pushing RoundUP and Spectracide's total vegetation killers.  Incredibly, they didn't seem to see any use for a product that might kill poison ivy and dandelions and leave some grass (and other desirable plants like native ferns) living.The only caveat I have for users hoping to kill poison ivy is to pay attention to the directions.  Spraying it only poison ivy once it is completely leafed out is not nearly as effective as spraying it on emerging or even early summer poison.  This doesn't work the same way as total vegetation killers--and that's what sets it apart.  It is a niche product--not intended for all-purpose weed-killing.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2019
review_content: I used the "4D Killer" (2,4-D herbicide) for spot treating a lawn with a never-ending dandelion and other broad-leaf weed problem with a bit of surfactant mixed in for better application efficacy. Just MAKE SURE you dilute the concentrate according to the directions (or a bit more dilute) to protect surrounding areas. Repeat application of a dilute solution seems to be safer / more tolerable for surrounding grasses than a one time application of a strong solution.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2023
review_content: I use it on my centipede lawn to kill crabgrass and bermuda grass that invade it without harming the centipede. Do not use on fescue. My neighbor saw me killing crabgrass with it, bought some for her fescue yard and killed it. Easy to mix in a sprayer. One ounce product to one ounce of dawn dish washing liquid to one gallon of water. The soap acts as a surfactant. You can buy a separate surfactant but it will cost a lot of money and dawn does the same thing. Just remember to add the water to the sprayer first and then the soap or you will have suds all over. Gently swirl shake the sprayer after filling. The product selectively inhibits photosynthesis so the crabgrass and bermuda grass will turn brown and die. The only downside is this stuff is expensive.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2020
review_content: This products works really well to kill  short, growing grass. Grass that has reached a height of more than six inches will usually turn partially purple or yellow and, thou it will probably not die, it will be stunted to the point where the plants you are trying to save will out-grow the grass. This product works very slow, usually taking a week or more to begin showing any results. So don't give up. That's why I write that it is only one tool. You will still need to cultivate, plow, or hoe if you desire a totally grass free garden.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016
review_content: So I applied this shortly after it arrived, about 10 days or two weeks ago. It SORTA worked. It browned out the top sprigs of the homicidal bermudagrass that has taken over the poolside flower garden. Applied it again a few days later, with approximately the same result.This product contains Sethoxydim. It is NOT THE SAME as the old Over-the -Top. The old product really, truly did work on grasses without taking out broad-leafed plants. But it's no longer available...at least, not as Over-the-Top. The new product stinks something fierce: be sure to use disposable gloves when applying, so as not to get it on your hands. Don't apply it on a windy day, and stay out of the overspray.As it happened, a few days ago I decided to clean out the garage cabinets. And what should I find but a years-old squirt bottle of the original Over-the-Top! Instead of Sethoxydim, the original stuff contained fluazifop-p-butyl. Wondering if it still worked, I tried it on the still-vigorous, barely scathed bermudagras. And LO! The old stuff WORKS! As in it really works: the bermudagrass promptly croaked over, and later today or tomorrow I will pull its remains out of the ground.You can still get fluazifop-p-butyl -- apparently it's not one of the effective products that have been taken out of consumers' gummy little hands. It's in Ornamec 170 herbicide...also available on Amazon. Here's a US Forest Service risk assessment of this chemical: [...] Scroll down to page xv for a summary. In brief, risk to humans is fairly low; don't spray it on food crops, don't pour it in ponds, lakes, or streams, and don't saturate the ground with it. Use it, literally, "over the top": a little goes a long way.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: This product didn't work like I remembered.  Like the other reviews, I agree, this isn't effective on grass type weeds, or anything.  The chemical"fluazifop-p-Butyl" is what everyone is wanting, it kills grasses, not ornamentals.  (Follow the label) This "Fertilome" product did nothing.  I sprayed the same area 3x & waited, and waited.  Nothing.  I used Orthos "Grass-b-gone" 1x, and the pesky grass is history!  What remaining product I have, I'm junking.  Waste of time.  If you need larger concentrate instead of a rinky dink spray bottle, another brand name, I forget which now, makes it.  I have a farm, so a teeny 8oz spray bottle won't last, the grass will attack me & bury me alive.  And if anyone has experience with vile Bermuda grass, you understand my battle!  That evil grass could survive living on the moon.  It laughs at my torch.

review_content: I bought this for all the darn clover and nutsedge in my yard. Living near an interstate, I also dwell in the hell of Bahia grass, throwing its tall seed heads up 32 inches in a week. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2015
review_content: I have used this on my oriental jasmine to kill the dollar weed and it works quite well.  I can get it cheaper at Home Depot, but couldn't get away from the house to buy it so got it on-line for a close to retail price.  Be advised it won't kill wire-weed.  The only thing I have found that will is Roundup.  And that I have to apply directly to the stalk a blade at a time.  Put cotton glove over very sturdy rubber glove.  Wet the cottom glove with Roundup and draw over the blade of grass.  Takes several days for grass to die.  I have to repeat this every year.  This weed is terrible to get out of beds.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019
review_content: I have a sedge problem in the backyard.  I have used Ortho Nut Sedge Ready to spray, Sedge Ender, Sedge Hammer and finally this.  The Ortho worked well the very first time, but when sprouts came back the following Spring, 2 repeat sprayed failed to do anything.  Then I moved on to Sedge Ender.  The first application killed most of the sedge, but them they all came back 2 weeks later.  Repeated applications of Sedge Ender didn't do anything.  Moving on to Sedge Hammer.  This stuff works slow.  I won't see any change for up to 7-10 days.  Then by the time the old ones are dead, new sprouts came up so I would need to spray the stuff every other week.Then I saw this.  Sprayed it twice and it kills the Sedge within 2-3 days.  This also didn't hurt the bermuda grass I have in the backyard.  Now, it could be that I have different sedge and that's why the other stuff stopped working.  But Sedge is hard to get rid of and I have been spraying almost constantly for last past 2 years and I'm still getting them back, until now.  We'll see in 2-3 weeks if new ones sprout out.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: Product shipped on time. I mainly use for Poa Annua in my Bermuda lawn as well as other weeds. Works well for me over last couple of years and as stated will take a week to 2 for results, mix as directed with surfactant.A good value compared to some other brands.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2022
review_content: Was having lots of problems with nutsedge in my bermuda grass. And if anyone knows anything about nutsedge, they know it spreads like wildfire. This stuff kills this weed without harming your ornamental grass. You don't even know you put anything down and next thing you know the nutsedge just goes away in about a week. Of course you have to keep spot spraying because this weed has a tendency to keep popping up all year long wherever it wants to. But if you have big patches like I did, this is the perfect fix.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
review_content: I've had a terrible problem with Nutsedge and Virginia Buttonweed that not even a commercial lawn care company could deal with. Buttonweed is extremely pernicious because most herbicides will not kill off the roots, so it always comes back. I tried Weed Free Zone in spot treatment and that killed everything including the grass. So on the recommendation of a local nursery (in South Louisiana), I tried Image. Their recommendation was to use it in +90 degree conditions, which we have every day in the summer. This product works! I have a variety of grasses, including St. Aug, centipede, zoysia, and bermuda. It stunted the growth, but did not kill, all of these, except the bermuda, where it displayed no perceptible impact at all. It took one to two weeks for the weeds to begin showing stress, and three to five weeks for the complete die off, just as the instructions predicted. Also per the instructions, a second treatment of the buttonweed was necessary in some areas. But bottom line, you can use this product on your lawn and still have a lawn left afterwards (assuming proper mix and application).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2022
review_content: Worked on my bermuda lawn. Apply early as this stuff takes time to work. Fully read the instructions. Also the hose end version is easier to use.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2022
review_content: This is my second year to purchase this product to treat POA annual in my Bermuda lawn.  It was a success last year, so I purchased again this year.  However, there must be something wrong with either their new formula or with this particular bottle of product.  I applied it one and half a month (in middle of March) to kill the POA annual while the Bermuda grass was still domain.  It did kill the POA annual.  However, while my neighborhood's Bermuda lawns gradually turned green over the last 45 days, and all had become complete green now.  My Bermuda grass remains domain and had become an eye sore to the neighborhood.  As matter of fact, the law looks like a patch of green and yellow with the place I applied more of the product remains yellow, and even appears dying.  Clearly this product did not protect my Bermuda lawn, and actually kills it!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2015
review_content: I've bought 2 containers of this herbicide, and am very pleased with it. I will continue to buy it in the future.I have Celebration-type Bermuda in central North Carolina, which is noted to be especially resistant to herbicides. I have never noted any yellowing or stunting of my Bermuda where I have used this herbicide. It has been very effective in clearing out all of the undesirable weeds/grasses i have used it on.I have found the best use of it (this may just work on my Bermuda type) in my yard is to use it once, wait for a rainfall, wait 2+ weeks, then after a mowing and enough time for weeds to sprout (=very visible), use again. The instructions advise against using it so soon on the same spot because over-use can kill some desirable grasses, but I experimented for the heck of it, and found it hasnt seemed to affect mine.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2012
review_content: Yellow nutsedge is very difficult to control in lawns.  My infestation, courtesy of my neighbor, was slowly taking over the front yard.  I had kept the creeping weed somewhat at bay with another product, since discontinued by Monsanto, and had seriously thought about digging out the turf and replacing it.  I found Excel's Image on Amazon and bought some.  It's not cheap, but I can say now, after several weeks, that it seems to work just fine.  That part of my lawn is now stunted and yellowed, but it's the nutsedge that's dying... the grass seems only 'set back' a bit.  Time will tell whether this pernicious weed can really be controlled, but it sure looks like it at this point.  I will add to this review as the treatment progresses.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
review_content: I have a severe nuts hedge problem due to old farm land that my home (and neighborhood) are built on. I have fought nut grass for 40 years and so far we are about even.  If I pull it up and dig up the roots and nuts it goes away till the next year then any nut I missed, well it's back!  Very severe now so I had  hoped this stuff would work.  I mixed it as instructed and applied via hand sprayer as the nut grass is in my bermuda  grass lawn.  This stuff did not even make it sick!!  In areas it killed the bermuda so I have large dead grass spots that I will have to replant.  The  nut grass that was there turned a little yellow but now has returned in full force!  I had a large patch of crabgrass in my back yard so I decided to soak it with this stuff.  Did not even turn it yellow.  Use at your own risk it may kill your lawn. Oh, I had one area that was solid nut grass..did nothing.UPDATE:  I tired double strength and still it barely made the nutgrass angry.  Turned a bit yellow, but then kept on growing.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2020
review_content: I originally bought this in a store and used it on my Zoysia lawn. A lower concentration stunted my lawn, where I sprayed it.  It does kill nutsedge and it does kill poa annua( annual bluegrass).  I bumped up the concentration slightly because I was having the spray it multiple times. My zoydia definitely does not like it.  I mixed the same concentration as I did was store bought and spot sprayed, but it acted just like Roundup.  This product does kill the weeds that it advertises. The problem is that it killed my Zoysia too.  After the voices dies it takes a very long time to come back in the spots that were sprayed.

I caution those new to this product to read the tiny information guide that comes attached to the bottle (that you can find elsewhere on line in larger font). Reading reviews here and elsewhere helped me avoid burning my grass (which is more than possible in the hot and humid south Texas climate).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2023
review_content: spending $130 on a jug might seem expensive but holy smokes let me tell you it's worth every single penny if you value your time. im a father of 2 and i also mow my 6000 sqft lawn once a week for about 90 minutes, which sometimes feel like eternity in the 110F Texas heat. i don't particularly enjoy mowing like those guys who constantly brag about their lawn on FB groups. my lawn is still above average compare to my neighbors. after 2 applications, i can tell my grass grow sideways rather than vertically. it's more lush and thicc. i no longer have to mow every week because I'd rather use those time and hang out with the family. $130 jug will last me a few years but the time that i save for not having to mow so often is priceless.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2023
review_content: I have builder grade 419. And left on vacation for more than a week. I applied this 1 week before leaving and cut it right before I left again (barely taking anything off) I didn‚Äôt have to cut again 10 days after that. It‚Äôs amazing!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2019
review_content: I have TifWay 419 bermuda grass that I like to cut very short (5/8") using a reel mower.  This requires cutting 2-3 times a week about every 3 days.  I read about this product on a different website and decided to try it.  I will never go back.  I applied on Saturday June 9th.  Normally by Wednesday I have to cut again and would have some seed pods sticking up.  I found that there were almost no seed pod and I did not see much vertical growth.  I decided to cut anyway and grass catcher only had grass clipping around 1/16 - 1/8".  Normally they would be around 1/4 - 3/16 clippings.  I added chelated liquid iron to my sprayer as well.  Very impressed and will use again.*** Remember to follow the instructions carefully, more is not better with this product.

review_content: Game changer for your lawn and your time spent mowing it. Used to have to cut my Bermuda grass every 4-5 days to keep it from getting too tall and leggy. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2020
review_content: I replaced my front yard with TifTuf Bermuda grass because of the drought tolerance and the looks compared to a yard of 3 different types of grass.  The TifTuf Bermuda looks great, but it grows super fast and requires mowing every 3 days.  When I found this product I thought it was really expensive and it would last a lifetime, but I was so tired of mowing so often I had to give it a try.  All I can say is, WOW!  I applied it for the first time at half rate of what was on the label because I was afraid it might really stunt the grass.  It didn't change the color of the grass and it cut the mowing interval to once every 8 days.  Now I can do other things beside mow the grass.  Love it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2021
review_content: The lawn picture is hard to tell, but you can see that I missed a bit when I applied it.  No,  its not missed by the lawnmower.  I actually mow that corner 3 times, theres no way it was missed.This took a good couple of weeks to set in.  At first it took about 3 days to see the golding in the lawn leaf.  Then after cutting that gold out two lawn mowing cycles it really showed what it can do.This made my lawn stop growing up and bush out giving more area that carpet type look in some places.  I have a really horrible red fescue grass, so to see any carpet type look in this type of grass is very rare and absolutely not from natural growth.I do think it's quite expensive.  I'm only going to say that it's worth it if it helps to make the roots grow deeper.  This may take a while to do and probably have to go through a few years to get that root growth, but we'll see.I'd buy it again though.  I can go every other week mowing without even noticing that I skipped a week.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2020
review_content: I‚Äôm sorry for the bad photo angle, but you get the understanding of what it does to your grass. I just moved into a new home and allied this to 8 month old Bermuda grass. The thicker, short grass is the front yard and where I applied t-nex. The longer, thinner grass is the back yard, with the same number of cuts.In areas of the front yard where I reseeded with higher quality Bermuda, it made the grass so thick that the only comparison I could find is it looks like a fake Christmas tree  limb. It was lush, green, and extremely thick.On the builder grade Bermuda I had varying results. It didn‚Äôt keep its green like the higher quality grass, and spotted and turned brown in a lot of areas. I‚Äôve been hitting it with ironite and it seems to be greening up again after a few weeks.My suggestion, read the instructions carefully and if you don‚Äôt understand it, YouTube offers multiple channels about how to apply this stuff. For example, for the 1000sqft in my front yard I put 3 teaspoons mixed with 1.5 gallons and it was the perfect spreading rate for me. Next time I will drop to 2 teaspoons to try and not stress the yard as much. This is definitely one of these products where more isn‚Äôt better.Lastly, if you have any residue left over in your sprayer - dispose of it properly. I rinsed my sprayer out and dumped it in the yard, and the area I did that in turned more brown than the rest of the yard.Overall I would but this product again, but one gallon is enough for almost 300 treatments for me, so it may be 5 years from now.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2015
review_content: OK, I admit today was the first day I've used it, but I really love it.  I have 1/2 acre lot in NC with tons of mosquitoes, and I believe this will be a tremendous help.  I'm spraying a powerful product that leaves a residue and lasts for 6 weeks.  I sprayed probably about 1/2 of the yard today and except for hoisting the heavy thing (when full, of course) onto a work bench where I could put it on, I have to say it was actually fun to use!  I sprayed on and under all the back yard shrubs (a lot!), and around the perimeter, and except for the heat and humidity, I would have continued on and finished the job in one day.  I bought mine cheaper than Amazon has it, at a big box store, and if I only get one year of use out of it, it is still WAY cheaper than having the mosquito service treat the yard even once!  Again, I love it!  I'm grateful for time and work savers like this.  PS  I'm a 65 year old female.

I also found that the pump handle on the backpack was much easier than smaller sprayers where you have to place the canister on the ground and then pump it. It comes with multiple sprayer nozzles to allow different patterns and flow rates. It also has tank markings for 1, 2, 3, & 4 gallons.

But I have to say, the thing works, and the user manual is better written and more useful than most. We'll have to see how well the sprayer holds up. My 3-star rating means it's OKAY. I'm not displeased with my purchase.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2015
review_content: Great product, however it was different than advertised. Received instead Weed-Out by ferti-lome (which contains Trimec).Was not thrilled to get a different brand of what is advertised on this page. That being said, I gave it a try and it performed wonderfully.Main intent was to get rid of Virginia Buttonweed which was beginning to take over our St. Augustine turf. This is a very hardy weed that is very hard to eradicate. Creeping Charlie was also starting to take hold on other parts of the yard, so this would be a great test to see if this was the product to conquer both.To apply it, I also bought the "Chapin G362 Professional All Purpose Hose End Sprayer with Metering Dial", dialed on the "1" setting,and was able to treat the front and back yard (~3,000 sq. ft.) with 16 oz of product. I could have used less, perhaps 12 or 13 oz, but on some areas I did go over it more than once since I had some product left on the sprayer's container. The beauty of the G362 is that you could put the product back on the container if there's some left over, as it does not get mixed with water in the container.Applied this at around 83 deg. Instructions say to not apply above 85 deg. Within about two to three days, the Creeping Charlie begin to wither and were completely dead by the end of the week. The Virginia Buttonweed took a about a week to show signs of discoloration, but it was very subtle, so it seemed that it may have beat me =D.I resisted the temptation of reapplying in stronger dose, figuring it probably would take a little longer due to the hardiness of this weed, and was rewarded by an accelerated degradation of the health of the plants two weeks after application. After that, they rapidly begun to wither and ultimately turn black and die (see attached photos).Turf now looks healthy, although it has several patches of yellow throughout, which is the weeds that are dead and not the actual St. Augustine, so I am assuming it will be a few more weeks until the grass covers those voids. I have also bought liquid chelated iron that I've just applied yesterday to help the lawn get greener quicker. I'll try to update this review in a couple of weeks to convey results.This is definitely no my area of expertise, so it's sheer happenstance that I was able to nail my weed treatment on the first try. Hope this review helps someone with a similar issue.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2023
review_content: Best price for the best weed killer for lawns, only kills the weeds but keeps the lawn growing well!Don't try to get by w/ a generic version, Trimec is what you want!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
review_content: This product works well at killing weeds without harming grass.  I have an easement that was over-run with Creeping Charlie.  I used about double the concentration recommended and after two applications, all of the Creeping Charlie was gone.  I‚Äôve used the proper mixture in the yard over the summer and it kills most of the weeds and the grass looks the best it has in a long time.  Violets still come back, but this will weaken them and keep them from spreading as much if left untreated.  It might even kill them with continued application every week.  I did not have any burn issues and the grass has been fine with about 3 applications over the course of two months using a hand-held sprayer.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2018
review_content: It's legit Trimec, so it does what it is supposed to do.  However bear in mind that this is a much lower concentration than you'll find on pest control websites.  The concentrate in this bottle is enough to do about 32,000 sqft of lawn. The same size jug is available on websites like domyown.com for about $10 more and is 4x more concentrated.  I bought this thinking it was the same product for $10 cheaper since I didn't read the details. As it turns out, this is actually a rip off as it relates to price.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2019
review_content: Kills weeds like it is supposed to.  My onions were knocked down quickly.  I haven't seen a single dandelion. The chickweed is looking very sickly.  Give it a few days after spraying to notice the difference.  The direction say not to use more than 2 times per year but this might be for homeowners because the chemical lawn care companies use the same chemical and do it much more often.  Add a surfactant to your mix and it will work much better.  Wear chemical gloves and don't get the concentrate on anything that you care about.  Messy stuff.  Expensive but worth it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2022
review_content: We have four crabapple trees and several rose bushes. Trimec is the only thing that gets rid of Japanese beetles. We have used it for several years with great success. Highly recommend it.

Carrying about 34 pounds on your back is very easy when younger but not at my age now and being a woman.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: OK folks a couple of things. YOU NEED SURFACTANT for this to work. The amount of Trimec is based on volume per 1000sqft. So if you have 4 gallons and it takes a gallon of water to spray 1000sqft you then can use .5oz-2.0 oz per gallon.  If your lawn is 10000sqft you will need 10 gallons of water with 5oz-20oz mixed in the water.If you don't want to go through the hassle 1.5oz per gallon will kill weeds once you hit the 2.0oz+ per gallon the likely hood of killing grass is EXTREMELY high.Finally, surfactant is an agent that makes herbicide stick to plants. Some people use crop oil, kerosene etc. YOU NEED surfactant with Trimec. 2.0oz of surfactant per 4 gallons works. Rad the label as different herbicides need more surfactant. I use surfactant with all herbicides. I even use it with glyphosate and 24D. If you don't use it you will waste your money and your results will be poor.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2017
review_content: This is my second year using Trimec.  Three years ago our lawn was infested with dandelions.We would dig grocery bags out of our lawn daily.  We tried granulated weed killers, no dice.  A friend from work that also works at the local farmer's co-op suggested Trimec.*WARNING* Do not buy the cheap $12 bottle.  The $50 will kill a larger variety of weeds. I applied once last spring, and our lawn was Dandelion free until mid-summer.  Applied again, and while my neighbors had dandelion farms all year long, mine was green and beautiful.  I used it on my mother's lawn last year, but after the dandelions by that time were rampant.  Later on that day, the dandelions were seriously wilting.  After two weeks,and two lawn cuttings,  there were no more dandelions in her yard.  It stayed that way for the rest of the summer.  Just re-applied on her lawn for the coming summer this morning.  Looking forward to the results!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2014
review_content: Purchased the Trimec weed killer specifically to eradicate bindweed or morning glory yard vine.  I live in North Texas and this weed has taken over the neighborhood.  It is not a patch that can be topically treated with roundup but invasive and runs over most of the yard.  With Texas summer drought, yard grass can't compete but the bindweed has no problem killing everything as it grows on top of the grass.  Received the Trimec and a Gilmore 362 sprayer and tried it out.  Instructions on the container were not very clear to me so I just tried a setting of "2" on the Gilmore sprayer and applied over a section of the yard.  The next day the bindweed with the small white flowers disappeared, and by the end of the week the vine looked wilted.  Trimec did not harm the St. Augustine grass only had to be careful of shrubs and tree drip lines and not spray in those areas.  Highly recommend this stuff as I had asked local nurseries and they did not have a clue.  A Gallon will treat a very large yard front & back.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2023
review_content: I live on an acre and half of Bermuda Grass and weeds can get out of hand if you don't spray for them.  I've tried several different types herbicides and Gordon's Amine 400 2,4-D works great on all our broadleaf weeds.  Works so much better than that you get at most other stores.  I spray once in the Spring and again in the Fall when temperatures cool off a little.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2017
review_content: This stuff is very effective against buttercup and a variety of other broad-leaf plants. I have been completely overrun by buttercup, as in there is an entire 1/4 acre of my property that had not a single blade of grass because it was all buttercup. I also have bindweed. (I was thinking maybe I should just move lol) I was looking for something to kill the weeds but keep what I had left of my grass, so I tried the 2,4-d. For a few days after spraying it looked like nothing was happening, and then the buttercup started to wilt. And then it progressively withered away, with the stalks becoming soft and mushy, until it withered away into basically nothing. I didn't even have to pull up any of the dead stuff, it just kind of disintegrated in a very satisfying way. This took about a week or two, so it was a slow but a very complete death. There were some patches of buttercup in the very thick patches that made it through the wilting stage and then perked back up (I'm guessing they didn't get saturated enough because they were protected by more buttercup) so I sprayed those a second time and that did the trick. So that 1/4 acre of buttercup became 1/4 acre of dirt since there was nothing else growing there, but it's been about a year and the grass has come back, with the buttercup gone. Everywhere else that I still had grass, the 2,4-d killed the weeds but not the grass. It's not impossible to kill grass too, but you have to be very heavy-handed with it. You can apply this stuff pretty liberally without affecting the grass at all.For my bindweed, this stuff was ok as a deterrent but not great at killing it. It would make the bindweed wilt and I would have to keep re-spraying it every 2-3 days to kill it, however it would just come back. I found that Triclopyr is very effective against bindweed though, so mixing that into the 2,4-d would be great if you have a bindweed in addition to other weeds. The 2,4-d has been great at killing dandelions, chickweed, and most everything else that's been taunting me.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2018
review_content: Using to get rid of weeds in my lawn along with killing St. Augustine which I don't like and it's doing that slowly along with cutting the lawn very short. Application is easy, just follow the instructions. Fair warning - follow the instructions concerning exposure. This stuff did make me a little uneasy after applying it to my lawn with a pump sprayer. A shower after applying and drinking down a few glasses of water cleared the problem. I was also spraying in shorts and sandals (not recommended - pants and shoes). I know better now and haven't had the problem again. I also used this on some vines from my neighbor. He has vines that are climbing over the top of the fence. This is doing the job of stopping that problem.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2019
review_content: If you are looking for a very effective broadleaf herbicide for your home, farm, etc., this one is hard to beat. The active ingredient (2-4D) has been in use since the 1940's and works by mimicking a natural plant hormone causing the plant to die from desiccation. I have found that this product works much better by using a recommeded surfactant (helps it stick to the leaves) and using one of the blue marking dyes to help you see where you've already sprayed. Buying it in this concentrated form in a gallon container, is MUCH CHEAPER than buying similar products at the big box store. For those of you looking for a safer and effective alternative to glycophosphate (Roundup), this is a good one!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2017
