review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2022
review_content: This aerator is well made. I was surprised that it came with inflatable tires instead of the cheap plastic ones. Yes, you will have to inflate the tires with a bicycle pump to 30psi. The metal structure is thick and the very sharp aeration blades are made of stainless steel. Assembly was lengthy in time. About 2 hours using small electric impact. I found myself referencing the hardware guide often to verify correct fastener selection. There are at least two confusing assembly steps as the drawings were not detailed enough. I used the aerator immediately after assembly as it just finished raining (to soften soil). I placed two concrete blocks and one bag of sand on the tray. I towed the aerator with a typical 42 inch lawn tractor and went over the yard twice with great results. My soil in very compacted sand/clay. The aerator pulled 3 inch plugs on average. I was very pleased with the results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2023
review_content: This product ships completely disassembled. Be prepared to spend atleast 1-2 hours assembling this product. Once assembled pulls behind the lawn tractor nicely. I added 3 cinder blocks for weight and was amazed at how deep and well it  pulled plugs. I had mixed feeling about renting a professional machine or purchasing this product. Fully stand behind my decision of purchasing this product and being able to aerate my yard whenever needed.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2023
review_content: Well built but had to go to the hardware store because it was missing 6 bolts various sizes and 8 nuts!  Other than that it seems okayUpdate: This works better than I thought it would, being the price point.  I am very happy with this unit.  I bought it with the separate dethatcher.  Definitely worth the money

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2022
review_content: This product works as advertised. You definitely need the extra weight / cement blocks to get maximum penetration into the soil.Assembly was fairly easy as they produce a video on YouTube with the step by step directions.  Even so, there is a point, when installing the next to the last bolt for the wheel lever, I encountered a problem. The 1 1/4" bolt is too long to fit in the space that is provided, however, a 1" bolt fits just fine. I believe, early on in the instructions, where you are instructed to install the very first 1" spacer on the axle, I believe if the 1 1/3" spacer is installed instead, then the 1 1/4" bolt would fit. And in place of the first 1 1/3" spacer, you install the 1" spacer instead. Since that part of the assembly is very near to the beginning, I didn't go back and try it.  Nonetheless, I was able to finish the assembly by substituting a 1" bolt near the end.Even with that complication, I still give 5 stars as it looks like I'll be getting many years of good use out of this product.Addendum: After reading someone else's review about a couple of bolts through the tray that appear to have no purpose. I would leave them installed as they serve to keep any weights that you add from sliding into the wheel lift lever.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: Fantastic investment. I recently got interested in lawn care for some reason and this thing did wonders. Throw down your top treatments (fertilizers, pest control, seed etc) then pull this thing through after a good rain. In another week or two you'll be amazed at the difference.Like others mentioned, assembly isn't fun... But I didn't have any problems with missing pieces or not understanding the instructions. There are one or two parts that require re-reading and comparing the diagram. And the final step is the worst bur... It says so right in the manual. Wear gloves! I slipped a few times while tightening things and smacked a spike which drew skin and blood.I tossed a few heavy stepping stones and a bag or two of soil on top and pulled it behind my mower. Just go slow and watch it work. Plugs out real nice. Especially if you get a good full day or two of rain beforehand.Only downside is that I don't see any way to really disengage the spikes. Like if I wanted to pull it across the driveway or up the street to a neighbors. Not sure if it's design or my assembly but the spikes do not fully leave the ground when I lift the lever. They aren't weighted as much, but would still drag concrete if I tried.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2020
review_content: Let's get right to the DOWN side.  I was an aircraft mechanic and electrician in the Navy for 20 years: It took me 2 hours to put together.  I had to back up & disassemble a previous assembly step at some point during the assembly of the aerator tines onto the rotating shaft, 3 times, to correct something I overlooked because there are a LOT of parts that go together in a complicated sequence.  I can't blame it all on the Directions (I read them VERY carefully) but it's got a LOT of parts and nothing is preassembled. You MUST have a very complete set of tools to tackle this thing. NOTE: there is a clevis pin and key to hold the control handle together in addition to the pivot bolt and lock nut - I have no idea why the clevis pin is there instead of a bolt.  NOTE: Don't overtighten the wheel bolt jam nuts against the wheel hubs.  NOTE: Don't forget the plastic 'bearing inserts' in the ends of your tine tubes.Now for the UP side:  It WORKS, it WORKS, it WORKS!!  It's WELL made (HEAVY GAUGE SOLID STEEL) and should last for YEARS even after loaning out to your neighbors. (Rental?) My Toro Riding Lawn Mower pulled it without ANY trouble. This $150 SAVED me $1000 for a Lawn Service contract per year.  Remember, aerating is the hardest part of a Spring Yard Prep.  The fertilizer, lime, and seed are a snap beside the aeration.  This is a SOLID BUY recommendation!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: A) The aerator is very sturdy.  I used two 70# sand bags in the tray and It was no issue until I needed to lift the tunes to engage the wheels ; you need separate weights on either side of the lift handle.B) the only issue was the assembly instructions were not entirely accurate. I wrote my ‚Äúlessons learned‚Äù during assembly and shared them with a friend when he assembled the same unit. Maybe you‚Äôll find these helpful.  Agri-fab should update the instructions.1) Tools required for Assembly: add Combination square or anything you can use to square the sides in step 102) no step 10 you say!  See #33) starting with the bullet beneath the Caution on page 4 number all the bullets into steps.  Should end up with 17 steps.4) in step 6 it says ‚Äúdo not tighten until step 8‚Äù change to ‚Äúdo not tighten until step 10‚Äù.5) step 7a) Last instruction says ‚ÄúTighten‚Äù but don‚Äôt tighten until step 8b) it shows (4) 3/8 x 1 hex bolts installed in line in the tray.  Don‚Äôt install the center 2 of these until step 15; these attach the wheel shaft center brace to the tray in Step 16.  The left photo above shows those 2 cemetery holes after attaching the wheel bracket.6) in step 8 it uses four 3/8 x 1-1/4 hex bolts.  I could only use 2 at the ends.  The center 2 could not be used: there are no holes for this. In the Middle picture above you can see 2 holes (1 slotted) on the left but there are no holes in the tray7) Step 10: this is where I used the square to make sure the end plate is perpendicular.  Had to suspend the end of the tray over the work table to get to both sides of the bolt/nut.8) Step 16: uses two 3/8 x 1-1/4 hex bolts to attach wheel bracket to lift handle. There is not enough clearance to attach the bolt that is closer to the wheel shaft: the aerator spike and attaching plate are in the way.  This is the picture to the right.  I cut the bolt shorter.  Attached the nut on the bolt and cut it with reciprocating saw then backed off the nut to make sure the threads were not damaged while cutting.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2022
review_content: First thing first , you need to sort out all the nuts and bolts make sure that there‚Äôs the right amount then check out the video how to watch how to install/put together this is vital and will make it a lot easier to not miss the stop after that the assembly went quite well problem as you get to the very last bolt for lifting lowering the tires, the bolt is a quarter of an inch too long after fighting with it for over 10 minutes I gave up and went to Lowe‚Äôs and bought one that was a quarter inch smaller fit right in and I was done in my honest opinion way too many different bolts and nuts the system could‚Äôve easily been put together with all the same type of nuts and bolts for the most part let‚Äôs call it 90% this was way more complicated than it need to be with all the different bolts and nuts not necessary could‚Äôve easily done it with basically with the same notes and bots

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2023
review_content: I am an intermediate DIY'r and this thing took about 1 1/2 hours to assemble with a bunch of different ratchets and wrenches and a few extenders.  If you have those tools, you should have no problems.  I recommend you get the Agri Fab assembly video off of Y outube and sit on the floor assembling while watching the video on a laptop, worked well.  When the instructions tell you not to tighten a bolt, don't do it or you'll have to undo it several steps down the road.  When you get to the end where you are bolting on the engagement handle and adjusting it, it will be an ah hah moment why you left the bolts loose.  You wiggle around the top table and supports to get a good fit and engagement for the handle and then tighten the specified bolts.I went to home depot and got (3) 16" x 12" x 8" cinder blocks for weight, they fit nicely.  I pulled the aerator around with a John Deere S120 and was getting about 1 1/2" plugs.  The ground was firm so I might aerate the afternoon after it rains??  I think it will get deeper when the ground is softer.Overall, I'm happy.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
review_content: I haven't used this yet and I'll probably up the stars when I do. But I couldn't wait to tell you about building it. I'm the kind of guy, I can look at something and build it in a fraction of the time without even looking at the instructions and I get it right. This thing.... 4.5 hrs of work to put it together. It's heavy, the parts are heavy and you will get cut and bleed from the blades no matter how careful you are. That's the con. Here's the pro, you want this to be heavy and sharp, that's the point, it needs to dig holes and do it fast. So don't be a whimp and get to it. Sweat, smell like grease and metal for 4.5hrs (if your good) otherwise expect longer. It's like putting together that swing set you made for your kids in the backyard, you thought it was simple but it took you two weekends to complete. This is like a mini version of that.There is one true complaint I do have. There's a mount you need to slide smack in the middle of the axel. Well it ain't going there. Nope I mean it. You'll be cruising along, saying to yourself, that dudes a troll I'm kicking ass on this build, then you'll get to the mount that has to slide on the shaft and after about an hr of swearing and pacing you'll have two choices, put this pie hole of a metal contraption back in the box and send it back or... put a grinder on your drill and spend another hour grinding out paint and metal from inside the mount to get it to slide down the shaft. That's the extra two hours. If you read this I just saved you an extra hr of standing there thinking this can't be right, well it is, get over it and have your grinder ready to ream out the hole so the mount slides on. By then you'll probably have about two cuts on your fingers.Once you get past that point your almost done. Only 1.5hrs left. Everything is a lock bolt, so you'll need every Damn ratchet you have to hold both sides. It's going to be like wack a mole from this point forward. Can you swing that ratchet back and forth without slicing your fingers down on the blades? I call that entertainment and this thing gives you the sense of feeling alive. It reminds me of when I competed in the tough mudder run. Yeah putting this together is just like that.I'll give you an update once I use this. With how Heavy duty and sharp it is. I'm sure it'll earn its 5 star.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2023
review_content: My lawn guy wanted $850 for core aeration and seeding. The seed is costs around $200, so this aerator saved me some money. Assembly was not difficult. I watched the video instead of the written instructions.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2023
review_content: The manufacturer label/emblem kind of said it all with it‚Äôs foreshadowing. First off, make sure you have a decent tool set. I consider myself to be mechanically inclined. I‚Äôm 42 years old I‚Äôm a ASE master technician and a Toyota master technician. I thought it would take an hour, maybe an hour and a half to put this thing together. It took almost 3‚Ä¶ My irritation started when they shorted me a nut for the carriage bolts, which I had to purchase later at a hardware store. There are bolts that are instructed to be inserted and tighten that fasten nothing. A bolt that has to be substituted for a shorter bolt in order to be able to fit between one of the inner spools and the lift handle, to secure the lift handle to the inner wheel bracket. I had remove the lift handle after installing it and place it in a vice to bend it because it was dangerously close to slipping out of the recess notch which locks the wheels in the down position. Four extra washers that are not stated to be installed anywhere in the instructions.. and then I had to sharpen the blades after dulling them on my garage floor while wrestling with this thing during assembly. All in all it seems like a decent product but you will need to bring your tools including sockets larger than you may have at your home and you will definitely need to bring your patience. Some modifications may be required as well as purchasing parts that maybe missing and scratching your head with parts you have left over.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2022
review_content: Quality product but a little difficult to assemble and I would consider myself fairly good at doing these sorts of things.Give yourself some time- it took me 3 hours.I found it helpful to view the YouTube video.I also recommend unpacking everything and laying out all the screws by height (as they are- in the less than helpful instructions and by diagram).You can also confirm by counting and comparing that all necessary bolts, screws, and washers are included and accounted for. (Mine were).As others have stated, be very careful as the aerator spikes are VERY sharp and despite being careful I still ended up with some pretty nicked up hands and fingers...After following the -and again --"less than helpful instruction sheet"And following them to a T -I somehow ended up putting the wheel assembly on upside down on the axel which of course would not allow for the product to be wheeled around without the spikes tearing up everything.After finally figuring out my error even though I followed the instructions as written it was a quick fix and I finally finished putting the darn thing together and it is a very high quality product now.Oh, and one other little fun fact you might want to know about before you assemble it- the tires come or at least mine did uninflated. They need to be filled to 30 PSI

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2023
review_content: This took a couple hours to assemble but wasn‚Äôt too complex. No major problems except one of the wheel arms wasn‚Äôt welded quite right so I had to drill the hole out slightly. Used it once already and it doesn‚Äôt seem to go as deep as I would like and the holes are sometimes more like tears, but I also used it right after a heavy rain and have clay soil. Probably should have waited until it dried up a bit as my mower had some difficulty pulling this if I went too slow up grade. Regardless I would recommend it given the price. We will see if the aeration depth will help my soils any though.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2023
review_content: I looked into renting an aerator for the day . Home Depot wanted $ 80 and change for 4 hours in my area..Plus the driving back n forth with gas at $20 bucks a gallon thanks to you know who .It wasn't worth it..So I looked at the reviews and picked this one . I have an acre of land . With some power tools I had the unit together in an hour . Was super easy and great instructions.We did just have 2 days of rain so I was anxious to see how it did ..Well ..with only 3 cinder blocks on it..it was amazing !!! It had no problem digging in the 3" it calls for and spitting those plugs out all over the yard .Truth be known I was having a blast driving around puncturing holes everywhere ...I will admit , I did do a little PM work on the blades . The factory only places 2 not so great welds on the spindles , so yes I did throw a little extra weld on the spindles just to be sure ...but this unit is perfect for the average home owner .. I attached a few pics just to show how well it does ..

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2022
review_content: The assembly process is quite complex (think IKEA level 3). There are many, many similar screws, nuts, and components. The YouTube video is very good, but it continually refers to the alphabetical letter (ex. nut "B") so you need the manual to match the parts correctly. It took about 2 hours to assemble at a leisurely pace while being careful not to cut myself on the sharp blades. You will need various SAE wrenches and sockets. Also, there are several steps that will require a second person to help. Unfortunately, it was missing the nylon lock nut to attach the last wheel {sigh} so I went to the hardware store and purchased a similar nut to get me by. I entered a support request on the website and the nut arrived in 3 days by mail.I used 4 cinder blocks to weigh down the aerator. Overall, it did a decent job even though I have southern red clay soil which can be difficult to aerate without proper watering. For the price, it's a good value.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: UPDATE.....After recieving the correct axle with help from customer service and rebuilding, this works perfectly. I have used several times and it is sturdy enough that will get plenty of seasons out of. Great plugs in the yard for aeration and overseeding. Reason for 4 stars and not 5, is because the cinder blocks don't fit perfectly for whatever reason, I kind of have to cockeye them.Also, be sure your mower can handle the weight, I have to use 3 blocks not 4 else my mower struggles to pull with tines lowered. I am sure I am part to blame, as I am adding 250lbs plus on the tractor seat LOL.I believe I was given the wrong part, after putting this together, no matter where I place the lever, the tines are the same height, and will not penetrate the soil. I contacted Agri-Fab via the website asking if i could have been given the wrong part, as it seems my lever is not the one shown in the picture. I am waiting to hear from them. Hopefully they will be able to help me, I was hoping to be able to use this for years, for the price, it is well constructed, if i can get 5 years plus out of it, the cost certainly saved me versus renting one. I will follow up after customer service gets back to me, and I get to use the product, for a better review on fuction.  Assembly was easy, but I did have to redo a few steps, being that it seemed some things were easier if done slightly out of order, but I will contribute that to me being me. Be careful and pay attention to the parts you are using, some of them look the same.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
review_content: I had used a neighbor‚Äôs tow behind plug aerator when I lived in a different city, so I knew what to expect. I debated the 48‚Äù vs 40‚Äù and glad I went with the smaller unit. This saved me about $80 and some storage space ongoing. The 40‚Äù unit is already just over 50‚Äù wide at the wheels, so the larger unit could be expected to be almost 5‚Äô wide.Like several other reviews, it took me just over 2 hours to assemble by myself. I‚Äôm a retired engineer, so fairly handy with tools. The instructions aren‚Äôt great. I laid out all the parts and tools first and made sure everything was there. They even gave me one extra carriage bolt for the knives.You need to pay attention to the orientation of the wheel brackets to be sure both are facing the same direction and the the center wheel bracket is in the opposite direction. You can see this on the assembly instructions but it is not obvious. Wear gloves to protect against knicks and knuckle busters. I wore a pair of rubberized nylon gloves that gave me good dexterity and had no injuries.I had one assembly issue and that is the 3/4 flat washers. They provide 8, but I only see where 4 are called out in the instructions. I can see where others could be used, but did not install them.In operating the unit, I pulled it behind my 48‚Äù Husqvarna with 24HP and had no real issue except loss of traction going up a wet red clay hill. Backing the aerator is a challenge. The unit would be much better if knives were spaced closer and there were more of them. Multiple passes are required due to the wide spacing and then you trample over the plugs making a muddy mess. Also the wheel lift lever does not want to stay in the up position, but they do give you two raised bolts to attach a short bungee to assist.If the unit had more knives with closer spacing, I would rate it 5 stars, but can give it only 3 due to need for multiple passes.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2023
review_content: The bracket underneath the top tray. This needs to be installed with the bolts earlier in the assembly. This will prevent having to take apart the whole blade assembly to get your hands  in this space. this bracket cannot be tightened down at the current assembly instructions.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2023
review_content: Update:  We contacted the company directly about the missing bolts, they sent  them to us within a few days.  We have finished assembly, and look forward to using on our acre.Missing 6 3/8 - 16 x 1" hex bolts, all other parts were included in shipment. Quality control needs to make sure all parts are included before shipment.  Tray scratches easy, thought it would be better for the cost. As soon as we purchase more bolts and finish assembly, we will try it out.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2023
review_content: I have way more washers than I know what to do with and not enough lock nuts I am short 4 lock nuts. This is sad to me that I have to drive to the hardware store to buy them.  Thought I paid enough for the complete package. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO PUT IT TOGETHER WITHOUT HELP.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2021
review_content: The reason for the 3 star is because after I began assembling this product, I ran into issue a major issue. Fortunately, it was during the initial assembly of the blades, which is the first part of putting the aerator together.  I put the entire blade assembly together, but noticed the bar that held the blades didn't have enough room for anything else, especially the wheels. So, I thought I assembled the parts wrong and disassembled everything thing. After carefully reassembling everything again, I had the same issue. The bar appeared to be to short, missaligned or something.  This entire process, at this point had already taken about 1 hour and a half oor so. Once I couldn't figure it out, I contacted the manufacturer. After speaking with customer service, it appeared they knew about a defective part that was in the box. The defective part was the bar that the blades went on. Apparently, the center hole was improperly drilled and caused a space issue.  The customer service representative was very helpful and told me they would send me out a new bar. They did and it arrived in a few days. Once I recieved the bar I immediately began assembling the aerator.  Unfortunately, after another 1 hour and a half, right when I got to the last bolt, I noticed the bolt was missing! I couldn't believe it! I had to wait until the next day to go Lowe's to get bolt.  What was hard for me to believe, was that this manufacturer actually sent out a defective unit with good quality control. I will wait to write an additional review after using the aerator. Make sure you check out the videos for the assembly. It's a bit tricky!  UPDATE: The aerator itself worked great! Very sturdy product that should last years to come. No issues.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2023
review_content: One of the aerator wheels bent the first time I took it out, somewhat disappointing

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2023
review_content: I've read some of the reviews and many said it was a pain to install.  I disagree, the parts were machined well, and really easy to put together (2 hours or so), just read the directions and you will be fine.  Also helps to have a a couple good ratchets with deep sockets.  One of the last steps was to put on the control handle, there is not a lot of room to tighten the bolts there so a couple of crescent wrenches will come in handy for that last step.  With a little weight, this is digging in nicely to my lawn and doing the job well towing behind my lawn mower.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2023
review_content: Written instructions were terrible, you need more tools then listed, difficult to reach in between parts to attach, holes filled with paint, part sizes listed incorrectly, one side panel warped, had to hammer into place. Finally assembled, looks like it will work okay, haven't used it yet. Video was better but still had errors.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2023
review_content: Value priced and robustly built.  Easy to assemble.  Just read, understand and follow the instructions provided.  Works well and all you need to do is weigh it down with a couple patio blocks that you can get at your local home center (not included with aerator).

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2023
review_content: Yes value for the money is outstanding, it‚Äôs better then paying for something that‚Äôs $1k  Bad reviews is because the build takes a while, you definitely need to be handy because the directions are not as clear as you would want them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2022
review_content: Really can‚Äôt say anything that hasn‚Äôt been skillfully written by other owners.  It will take a few hours to assemble‚Ä¶(mine took longer because they shorted me a couple 1.33 spacers and I had to order them AND pay for them.)Use the video to put it together, not the instruction sheet, and be prepared for some bloodshed.  No matter how careful you are, you will get scraped up by the pointed ends of the blades.  Just rub some dirt on it and keep going.As for operation‚Ä¶.fantastic!  It does a great job and has really started bringing my yard around.  It is sturdy enough, and with four cinder blocks on the rack, it does a great job.Personally, if you have the time (and a neighbor) to help assemble it-I highly recommend this product.  I would have graded higher if not for the time needed to assemble, and most definitely for having to order parts that they failed to send‚Ä¶AND as mentioned had to pay for them.  Overall a quality product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2020
review_content: The product itself is about a 3 and a half. But I have it a 3 over all. The instructions are a nightmareIt has you assembling the tow arm to the tray and tightening only to have to remove half the bolts later for the center support.  Then the handle has two bolts and you attach it near the end of the process and one of the bolts is two long to fit in the space to insert it to attach the handle. I had to swap out another bolt of the same thickness but shorter to insert it and attach the handle. Over all the instructions as a whole are ridiculously written. Very frustrated. Took about three hoursI have not used the product yet but it seems fairly sturdy. If I don‚Äôt have any issues I‚Äôll leave this review as it is. If I have problems after using I‚Äôll update review. I‚Äôve seen this on you tube and I think it will get the job done.  Just beware of the assemblyUpdated. I changed my review from three to 4 after using. It is sturdy and works well. But the assembly instructions are a nightmare. A real pain to put together. But the item worked well!  Worth the money

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: I can't find the YouTube assembly videos for the 45-05182, the one I received. I would guess this might be an update to the 45-0518? The tray and lift handle are different. They are not assembled the same way. The paper manual that came with it seems to have errors, and there are no assembly videos that I could find showing how to assemble the lift handle for the 45-05182. The  link to the manual on the product page is for the 45-0518. The written instructions tell you right off that it is a difficult step to attach the lift handle. I  had to go to the hardware  store to pick up a shorter bolt in order to come close to following the instructions.In the end, I was able to assemble it. I just finished using it for the first time attached to a John Deere LA125, a smaller 42 inch bed riding mover. It worked great, no issues, did the job. A fraction of the cost to  hire a lawn service to aerate just once - around here anyway.  Worth the effort to assemble I think, but know that it will take time. There are a lot of pieces.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2022
review_content: Like others have said skip the included instructions and watch the YouTube assembly video. Everything assembled well but I could see this thing breaking with some abuse. After one use it pulls descent plugs. If you make tight turns it rips up your grass. The lawn need a to be a little wet like the day after a good rain to pull a decent plug. Need to be pretty well weighted as well. This doesn‚Äôt reproduce the same result as a rented powered aerator but the ease of pulling this behind your lawn mower makes it well worth it. Overall I‚Äôm happy with the purchase but I fully expect to be welding some repairs to this thing after a few uses. Time will tell.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2022
review_content: I like the value for cost.  I paid a landscaper last year to aerate and fertilize.  This year, I paid for the aerator and fertilized for less than having it done. Next year will be at no cost. I do have 1 criticism‚Ä¶the mechanism to life the blades out of the yard when crossing a sidewalk or driveway is not adequate.  And bump and the blades come back down.  A better latch assembly on the lift bar would help prevent this. Otherwise, it was well made.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2023
review_content: I took me 3 hours to assemble this. Some holes did not line up properly. This was very challenging to assemble and I have had much experience working with tools repairing and assembling things. I would have paid more for one at the local hardware store if I had of realized this.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2023
review_content: assembly was pretty easy, just time consuming. As others have noted, one of the last assembly steps (lift handle - lower bolt) is too long.  Instead of 1.25" long ... should be 1" long.  Easy fix with a hacksaw.  Really good assembly video on u tube

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2022
review_content: Believe the warning about sharp parts during construction. Wounded myself 3 times.The manual is decipherable - not the best, far from the worst.As for assembly, you'll encounter many bolts of the same diameter of 1 inch and 1.25 inches in length. Though I can't swear to it, I believe they could have limited themselves to the 1 inch variety. This comes into play only in one spot. Down in the area of the tines a 1.25 inch bolt was called for and there just wasn't quite enough clearance. I ended up trading for a shorter one from the deck. Note several of those bolts through the deck are only there to act as a fence to keep weights from roaming too much.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: Look, this is a great product!  Creates nice size plugs and is very easy to use. Gets the job done and will save you money compared to hiring someone to aerate your lawn.  First off the bat, assembly takes time but seriously....this isn't hard if you just don't rush.  Take 5 min to separate your parts into their respective groups on pieces of paper labeled by part number.  Trust me, you'll be glad you did. The instructions list everything you need at each step by part number so organizing things this way makes it dead easy to find what you need. If you're used to building LEGO Technic stuff, you'll know that looking at the ORIENTATION of the parts in the diagram is very important. Again, don't rush and just make sure your set up looks just like the diagram.  You won't go wrong.  This non-technical chick assembled this herself in 1.5 hrs but if you can get a second pair of hands to help, things will go much quicker.  Finally, you don't necessarily need cinder blocks to add weight.  Fertilizer bags or sand bags worked greatüëçDon't let all the negative reviews about assembly dissuade you.  No good thing came about without time and effort.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
review_content: Just like all the other reviews said, this is difficult to put together. I finally got to use it today and it did a decent job. I have steep hills in my yard and my riding mower struggled to pull this up the hill so I tried going side to side but it didn‚Äôt seem to pull very deep cores when I was on the hills. If you have a flat yard, this would probably work pretty well. I still gave it four stars because it seems to be a good product, but just not suited for my application. I put over 100 pounds of weight on here to try and push the knives further into the ground. That extra weight eventually caused one of the bolts to sheer off on the handle so I could no longer raise and lower it. Just be cognizant of how much weight you put on there and don‚Äôt overload it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2023
review_content: I read about the difficult assembly. True, it does come in several pieces and took some time but wasn‚Äôt hard to follow along. Took right at about 50 minutes with no problems.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2021
review_content: First, I didn't have any missing pieces. Everything came as expected.I spent about two hours or longer assembling. The directions are "ok" but leave out a few important items. After I started assembling, I stopped to watch the actual assembly videos posted by argi-fab and it made the process so much easier.The lever to raise/lower the tines, as some have mentioned, will pop out if you hit bumps, etc. Argi-fab actually posts how to correct this issue in their assembly video. It's mentioned in the written directions, but it isn't fully detailed. Basically, the frame bolt/nuts are loosened to allow the frame to move. Two people definitely help here, as one pushes on the end over a tire while the other tightens the bolts. This makes the lever lock in place very well and requires a lot more effort to release and drop the tines. I highly recommend watching the video on how to do it.This process also works for the detacher unit they sell.I highly recommend this aerator. I used this one last year and purchased my own this year seeing how it pays for itself quickly.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2023
review_content: well-built and fairly easy to assemble. Order was missing a part, but their customer service answered quickly, and shipped the part.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: I was surprised at the quality of this aerator; however, the assembly instructions contain errors which made it all trial-and-error after step  3 of 15 steps. Step 3 states: Attach the wheel bracket to the hole in the middle of the shaft..." There are two holes in the shaft, and neither are in the middle. Step 7 states: "Assemble the tongue to the tray using four 3/8 x 1 inch hex bolts and 3/8 nylock nuts. Tighten. Much later in the process, after several trials, I discovered that the two center bolts which attach the tongue to the tray weren't supposed to go in until step 15. At that point, I had to remove the wheels and the shaft/spool assembly to correct the error.  Otherwise, the assembly instructions are vague, relying on pictures, and the pictures aren't done well. For example, Figure 12 shows the lift handle attaching to the wheel bracket. It's hard to tell if the lower bolt should go through the hole in the middle brace that's just above the hole for the shaft. The hole in question doesn't show in the drawings on page 2, it doesn't show in Figure 4, and it doesn't show in figure 11. But it shows in Figure 12, and it's in line with the lower bolt hole in the middle brace where the wheel bracket bolts on. Besides the assembly instructions, I have one "concern:" The spool bearings are plastic. I don't have a lot of confidence that they'll last, but time will tell.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2023
review_content: I usually don't write reviews (I do read them) but this product does what says it will do.Well built and does a good job of aeration. You want the plug type aerator as it open the soil better in my opinion. Do watch the assembly video. The written assembly manual is hard to follow in spots.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2022
review_content: Just as others have said the assembly instructions are poor but there is a YouTube video that does a good job you have to keep your perspective otherwise you will miss and need to reassemble.  For this tow behind aerator you need to add weight and I had to max it out before I got reasonable depth. Finally it pays to go slow.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
review_content: I promise to update this once I actually get to USE it.  I have been assembling this over several days now.  I have a Masters Degree and have assembled log splitters, chipper/shredders, snow blowers, spreaders, etc.  THIS product?  Holy cow!  Do yourself a favor:  lay out ALL of the pieces and label them (I know that seems crazy extreme right now, but trust me).  Then YouTube the Craftsman 40 in Plug Aerator video.  It is actually the SAME aerator just in a different color.  I had to take the aerator apart after watching that, and play it back again on my phone while assembling the AgriFab product!  I will assemble the handle today and tighten all the remaining bolts - then I should actually have it together!  GOOD LUCK!!!4/27/2020 UPDATE:  I completed the assembly and tried out my new Agri-Fab aerator.  I have to say it was Agri-FABULOUS.  It totally worked like a charm.  It's best to use it after a good rain, and drive SLOW, but it pulled plugs as though it was done professionally.  For the price, 5 stars for the product and functionality.  That assembly process? - Don't bother with the Agri-Fab directions.  Go straight to YouTube and watch the Craftsman video I mentioned earlier.  Enjoy!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2022
review_content: I got it put together but have to take it apart because the arm won't lock in the up position. I spent over two hours assembling. I would recommend watching the actual assembly videos posted by Argi-fab online. The lever can be hard to reach if you must travel across the sidewalk or driveway.This aerator is so much easier to use than renting the walk-behind at your local hardware store. Just make sure you have indoor storage or a cover from the rain and snow.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2023
review_content: I haven't used it yet but it is very sturdy and solid.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2020
review_content: It took over two hours to assemble.  Not difficult just time consuming.  It came with some corrections for the assembly instructions.  The issue there was the corrections required an additional spacer that was not included in box.  I made one out of some PVC pipe I had laying around.  It's been two weeks since we have had any rain so I had to water the lawn real well before it work properly.  If I had gotten it a month earlier it would not have been an issue.  The handle that raises the knives so you can go across driveways will break loose if you hit a bump so you had better secure with a cord of some type.  when block are loaded be careful if you want to disconnect from your lawnmower.  I could quickly flip backward and could hurt you.  Best thing is to remove the block before disconnecting from lawnmower.  luckley i figured that out before disconnecting.  It works but be careful.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2022
review_content: Purchased this last week.  Arrived quickly and intact.  Took a while to assemble, with many parts and bolts and washers.Easily pulled by our Ryobi Zero turn mower.  It is slightly wider than our mower, so the raised wheels touched a tree and bent easily (will have to repair).The plugs were produced quickly and easily in our Eastern Texas soil.Would recommend for small 2 acres or less yards like ours,

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2021
review_content: Works great for what I need at the best price around. However, don‚Äôt get overly confident in assembly (before you assemble it). I am a guy that rarely entertains following any directions. In this case, I heeded the warnings and read through the reviews that guided us through the process. I even went back and revisited some of them just to be sure. After a couple hours, I still ended up getting to the end and having two parts left over that required me to take the unit apart and re-assemble.Happy I came out of the deal with no major nicks or cuts. Use caution during assembly as this puppy has some very sharp pieces.Love the little machine (especially with 2 cinder blocks on the deck), not in love with the assembly.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2021
review_content: Like most of the reviews on this product, the instructions were not very good, however I had no problem getting it assembled, just by looking at the drawing. The lift lever is a problem but after seeing the video on this issue the problem was solved by loosening the frame bolts and pushing in the direction of the notch and retightening. I made some concrete weights to fit the tray by forming up two squares and one 80lb. bag of cement in each, they fit snugly enough that they won't bounce out. I have used it for two seasons and it has made a huge difference in my lawn which is mostly clay soil. About 1 and 1/2 acre. I have other Agri-Fab lawn tools for many years and haven't had any real issues, and have been able to get replacement parts when needed. For the average homeowner I feel it is a good value.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2020
review_content: This aerator took a couple hours for me to assemble by myself.  All the necessary parts were in the box and the instructions were easy enough to follow.  It just takes time.  I followed the recommendation of another reviewer and saved the installation of the knives for the last step, and I'm glad I did.  I would have cut myself to shreds otherwise.  I finally got to use the aerator this past weekend, and it did a great job on mine and my neighbor's lawn.  I used 4 cement blocks with 2 straps on the shelf to secure them and towed it with my lawn tractor.  My only gripe is that the handle seemed prone to occasionally dropping when I was towing it when not aerating.  Not a deal breaker, but something to be mindful of when crossing your drive way, or sidewalk, etc.  A tweak of the handle will probably fix it.  The plugs it pulled were perfect and I'm overall happy with it's performance, especially considering the price.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2022
review_content: Solid and well built.  Tolerances were a little off when assembling plug wheels on shaft where there was a little movement along the shaft but a little field engineering adding in a spacer easily solved the issue.  Performed very well, creating solid plugs/plug holes.  Overall, quite happy with this purchase.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2023
review_content: This aerator works as stated. However, you will have to modify one or more parts to assemble it. At the very least you will need to bend the wheel engagement lever as it does not naturally fit into the notch. I also had to shorten one of the plastic spacers in order to assemble the axle.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2020
review_content: I just purchased this in October 2020 an the paper directions HAVE BEEN CORRECTED from all of the reviews that they are incorrect.  However I strongly suggest you take a laptop out to your setup area and follow it!  There is a new YouTube video that was released Sept 2020 that is spot on.. Just follow this, throw the paper instructions away.  It wont let me post the link to it but search YouTube directly using this "03 Assembly Agri-Fab 40" Plug Aerator [45-05182]" and it is the video from Sept 2020 I did and with an electric drill to tighten all of the bolts and only one person, I timed myself and it took 55 minutes.  I ended up with FOUR extra washers which were extra than what is listed in the parts description.  I believe these are for spacing the axle/gap as needed and/or wear down the road.  This seems extremely well made but I haven't actually used it yet, I just put it together.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2018
review_content: This unit was not at all difficult to assemble, it seems very sturdy, and all of the parts were in the box and correct sizes. If it were not for the worst packing I have ever received it would have rated it 5 stars. The fact all of the hardware was still in the bags is a miracle, the box arrived with the top front torn completely away (about 6" X 8") The Box was from the manufacturer-not an Amazon box. All of the major machine parts were loose in the box and the tong was the part that had slid around and ripped off the top of the box. The heavy spike assemblies were also loose and had slid around inside the box impaling both of the otherwise heavy duty plastic bags of hardware. The fact that the spikes were still in the bags may have prevented the loss of nuts and bolts. I can easily see why other reviewers reported missing hardware. The other result was dozens of scratches in the paint on the other parts. If this had normal cardboard separators or Styrofoam molding to hold the big parts in place this would have been a glowing review and a top notch product. I will spray paint the scratches to help prevent rust and the resulting machine will be fine for its purpose. If you care about appearance you will hate this unit. If you value practical use at moderate price over appearance you may be ok with it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
review_content: Do not assemble this after you worked all day. This is a Saturday morning project. Have a few cups of coffee and a pretty big work area. This is not something that you can assemble in the middle of the yard. It says to use wrenches, I say you will need a decent socket set and band-aids. The tines are super sharp, you need to be careful. Once it is together make sure that your lawn is pretty moist, not soaked. It did a pretty good job. My recommendation is to do horizontal passes then vertical passes. It weighs like 80 lbs so you may want to think about where you are going to store it when the job is done. It does a nice job, you just need to be patient. You will have to go slow with this.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2023
review_content: Not hard to build. Instrutions are fine. Great quality.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2022
review_content: Bad things:1.The assembly manual is a JOKE.  Use the video.2.There are many sharp edges on the stamped parts.  I told AgriFab about this ion the past.  Still not fixed.3. Coating scratches easilyGood1. Made in USA2. The unit unit seems sturdy3. customer service is excellent

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2023
review_content: Sturdy.  Easily installed.  One nut and bolt were missing, but very helpful service lady and new ones arrived in a couple of days.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
review_content: Good aerator for the price. As everyone else has mentioned the instructions are lacking. I would say they are terrible though, just read ahead and look at the pictures to make sure you are right. It does a great job once you get going though. Just take it slow and try to avoid sharp turns and hard objects. My only 2 complaints are I wish I could reach the handle from my seat and I had one of the parts that hold the tines on break. My fault I hit a tree root while making a sharp turn. Both things you should avoid with it. It could have been welded on better. I'm sure they would have done a warranty exchange but I just welded it back on and kept going. Aerated about 3 acres worth now with now trouble after that.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2022
review_content: Loaded it with 4 cinder blocks and away it went.  Does a real nice job and very happy I purchased it.  Had my yard done this past spring for $150.  Just did my own this fall and by spring it will be more than paid for.  There's no doubt that plugging your lawn is the key to a nice yard.  It took about 2-3 hors to assemble, but not that difficult.  Agri-Fab has a very good video and also U tube videos.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020
review_content: After getting sick of borrowing an aerator every year, I decided to buy my own. Found this one after some research and bought it. To my surprise, it was waiting on me bright and early on Sat. morning which gave me time to put it together and then put it to use.The instructions were pretty straight forward which made assembly an easy but time-consuming process. If you aren't good at putting things together, this may be a tough one to get through. Once the assembly was complete, with no extra parts lying around, I found the aerator to be really solid and was impressed with the quality of the materials. It's going to last me for years.The actual performance of the aerator was impressive as the steel pluggers dug nice and deep with 140 lbs of weight on the platform. I'm very pleased with the purchase and wish I didn't have to wait another year to use it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2020
review_content: The aerator seems sturdy and high quality. One of the aerator knife mount plates wasn't welded perpendicularly with the axle but it doesn't seem to affect performance. This wasn't too difficult to assemble but it did take about two hours. I think there were a few mistakes in the directions, specifying to tighten bolts that should have been installed/tightened at a later step for attaching the mid-axle support bracket to the tray. Also the aerator knives are quite sharp (as they should be). It would be worthwhile to wear gloves and take care of working over the knife assembly during the final steps with the aerator turned on its back, especially when forcing that final bolt for the wheel lever attachment into place. Losing one's ballance would be painful...

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2020
review_content: First it was not as easy as you make it out with all those pages of parts to put it together. The entire thing was great and worked great. My biggest complaint was the welds. So I had to have it welded the right way. Get a better welder, and you will have a great product here.This thing works great, even in the hard clay here. Locked on 125 lbs on the tray and she dug plugs, making nice holes all over.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
review_content: Took a few hours to complete the assembly. All parts were included and directions were ok. I found a you-tube video that was also very helpful for assembly. All parts fit well and are good quality. Only exception is the small diameter (1/4 inch I think) bolts that are used to secure the wheel assembly. I think one size larger would be better. Also, I had to rotate the position of the wheel brackets to allow the lift handle to work properly. Instructions could have been more clear to eliminate that extra step. Once assembled it worked very well and I am happy with results.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2022
review_content: What's sold me is the customer service on the 3 year warranty.One of the aerator plate welds broke. Simply filled out the on-line form. Got confirmation that replacement part would be sent out. Had them in 2days.  Hard to find Cust Serv like this anymore.Strongly Recommended on Support alone!Operates just fine.Raise/Lower handle in "lifted" mode does pop out pretty easy.Assembly Instructions aren't as clear as I would personally expect - but it worked out with a little patience.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020
review_content: Just a note for those of you that received the model that has the lifting arm that passes through the deck plate like I did (Model 45-05182  20042).  Save yourself some aggravation. The assy drawing on pg 5, Fig 4, shows a 1" spacer in the wrong position.  This spacer needs to be put on the shaft BETWEEN the wheel bracket (lift arm) and the middle brace for proper alignment of the brace with the deck.  The text for this assembly sequence is also wrong.  Assemble it like the directions indicate and you will be taking it all apart again as the brace will be angled and the lift arm will not operate as it should.  YW

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: Assembly was a bit over an hour, use a drill and torque limiting extensions.  All the parts were there and some extra washers that I didn't need but were included if the stack up along the shift was a bit long.  It worked it popped plugs from my 1/2 acre in no time.  Reason for a lower review is that on 1st use (towards the end)  the 1/4 bolt that connects the lever which raises the wheel sheered clear off when trying to lift the plugs out so I could cross the driveway...  a $1 at HD/Lowes but annoying as its rated for 140lbs and I had 100lbs (2√ó50lbs of play sand) on the sled.  Every other bolt was oversized by these so im treating it like a bad screw from their supplier.  Also the handle doesn't stay in the lifted position well,  I have the dethatcher as well and that handle doesn't bounce around and drop the spikes going over a bump.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2022

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
review_content: Update. Assembly is not difficult, but the ground clearance of the spikes to the wheels is only 1-2" so the holes cannot be no deeper than that. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2020
review_content: The directions to put this together were wrong. There is a spacer required between the middle wheel bracket and the center brace. The directions do not tell you to put it there. Also it is worded poorly about which way to put the center wheel bracket as you can mount it either direction but won‚Äôt figure out it‚Äôs backwards until much later. Finally it tells you to put two screws in before you need them to secure the center brace so you end up having to take them back off to attach the center bracket. The product works great so far just bad directions.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2022
review_content: This is a badly engineered aerator, if engineered at all.It took over 4 hours to correctly put together with all the different parts and bolts.After double checking with the supplied manual, the handle was offset and would not engage in hinge to keep wheels up.  Also, you have to get off the tractor to move the handle.I solved both problems with a rope attached to the handle that I could pull and keep pulled to lift the wheels and aerator spokes.  The spokes are extremely sharp.  I got cut several times while assembling all the bolts and nuts.  Also, the aerators are attached to a metal plate that is only welded 1/2 the way around the plate.  The spacers are plastic and I expect to wear quickly.  Overall, very flimsy.  I had two cement block weights on top tied down with zip cords that worked fine after the yard was softened by rain.  I would not use this on a dry yard in that it probably would not stand up and work well given flimsy design.  In short, I can throw it away in that it was less than the cost of one lawn service but what a hassle.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2022
review_content: For the home user is very awkward to store - if it had a feature allowing for vertical storage on the floor it would be extremely good.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2020
review_content: The Agri-Fab 40" Tow Plug Aerator was perfect for what we needed...Having used a John Deere 48" aerator in the past, we needed to purchase our own and this was the one we chose...The only issue is we had to use a shorter bolt (switched the longer bolt to the tow connector part and took the shorter bolt from there) when connecting the lever to raise and lower the tines...Once we did this, everything worked perfectly.  The tines are sharp and pull the plugs on a properly moist day to 3-4" deep when adding proper weight to the top of the aerator...We used two 70 pound bags you can buy at the Big Box store or any local hardware store in our area.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020
review_content: The part that the that the tines are attached to is called a spool . The spool goes over the wheel shaft and the spots where the spools connect to the shaft are poorly welded. It's only spot welded in places, and the first time I used it one of those welds broke. At that point you're dead in the water. If you keep using it you will tear up the entire thing. I'm having to get a replacement spool sent to me, but I'm also going to have to dismantle the entire thing and take the other spools off, remove the tines, and get them welded correctly. Then put it all back together again. It's a lot of work for something that could have just been done right in the first place.When I spoke to the very pleasant young lady at Agri-fab , she shipped a new spool out the same day. She told me that I was not the first person who had called about this, and it's something they are looking into. I'm not so sure I would buy again. This simply should have not happened.When I get this replacement part and replace it, as well as getting the other spools re-welded, will see how it works. I'll give an update if it seems deserving

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2022
review_content: When I ordered the agri fab 40" tow behind aerator model 45-0518, it was advertised to have flat free tires. The amazon page showed pictures of the flat free tires, the featured highlights and the description both said the product has flat free tires, and the manufacturers promotional material said that the product had flat free tires. When I received the product, it did NOT have flat free tires. It instead had regular tube tires that appeared to be very cheaply made. They seem more like plastic than rubber. Even the outside of the box advertised that the product had flat free tire. I called the manufacturer's customer service number about this issue. While the customer service representative was mostly polite, they were very unhelpful. They would not send me the correct parts, even though she said they still use that part in other models. Their only advice was to return the product if I did not like it, and provided no way to correct the problem. The manufacturer lied about what product they are selling, and they would not correct the issue when called out on it. It makes me concerned about what other aspects of this product where changed without my knowing it.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2016
review_content: We keep a chemical-free lawn, which means we tolerate a lot of miscellaneous species in our grass.  However, when Creeping Charlie began a death march across the front yard, we simply couldn't hand pull it fast enough.  Where we live, Creeping Charlie chokes out and kills everything beneath it, so we had to temporarily compromise our environmental principles and move to more drastic measures to kill it off and win back the lawn to replant with a grass or ground cover more hardy.  I was highly skeptical of the selective nature of this herbicide, but in general it worked as advertised.  After one application, the majority of the Creeping Charlie began to die back.  It wasn't instant, took about 2 weeks for most of it to brown and wither.  Another application was needed to address whatever was left.  Other "weed" ground cover mixed in the lawn also died back (clovers, etc.), but the law grass appears to be unaffected at all and desirable border plants that were sprayed seem to be doing OK (vinka, lamimum, yarrow...).  Ours was a massive and aggressive infestation, and the Bonide chemical made it practical to recover the yard without gutting everything down to the soil. We've got a substantial "scar" to repair where the Charlie had taken over, but it's an easier and cheaper fix than it might have been without this chemical intervention.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2023
review_content: Oxalis is a major PITA to treat.  It spreads incredibly fast and the usual selective pesticides are completely ineffective.  If you have a thin lawn in a heavily shaded yard like mine and use a lot of moss killer like me, this weed can be a real scourge.I've used this specialized Bonide product and the Ortho Weed B-gon Chickweed, Clover & Oxalis Killer.  Basically, they both have triclopyr, but this product also contains 2,4-D and dicamba.  The concentration of triclopyr is a lot less than what's in the Ortho product, but perhaps the other two drugs make up for that.Both of these products seem to work, but are harsh on the lawn, perhaps Ortho a bit more so.  I used 1.5 oz per gallon for the Bonide, and 1 oz per gallon for the Ortho.  I also added about a half tablespoon of Bonide Turbo surfactant to each gallon to improve sticking.  To treat a full scale infestation, I covered the entire lawn.  Not much seems to happen over the next two weeks save the weeds slowing down a bit.  After a second treatment, they finally slowly start to turn white and die.  However, the lawn slows down during this time too.  In the past, I've applied too much of the Ortho stuff and killed my lawn, so you have to be careful not to overdo it.The two treatments take care of about 80% of the weeds, but because of the toxicity, I would definitely not do a third treatment.  Instead, I spot treat any surviving weeds for the next few weeks and then continually spot treat or pull out any new weeds that pop up.  Because they seed so efficiently, you really have to be complete with your eradication and then be vigilant forever to prevent another infestation from occurring.It's a grueling war, but I think it's a bad idea to do full treatments annually because your lawn would never grow to its full potential.  Once you get the upper hand though, it gets easier.  I'm holding out hope for a better pesticide to arrive someday, but until then, this seems to be the best that we have to work with.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
review_content: Since discovering Preen I rarely pull a weed anymore.  As soon as I see those pesky critters I spread more Preen. Preen DOES NOT kill weeds. It kills the seeds.If you do your flower beds correctly it lasts six months or more. I did two large flower beds at my daughter's house and didn't see a single weed for over a year!Start a new bed by pulling every weed or blade of grass. (Yes, a lot of work, but it will save tons of weeding later.) Then scatter Preen on the bare dirt. Lay your landscaping fabric. (Use a high quality fabric) Cut X slits and plant your plants. Spread mulch and scatter another layer of Preen on mulch and water in thoroughly. Every month or so scatter Preen around the perimeter of the flower garden. You won't see weeds. If you do, it's time for more Preen. Pull the weed and scatter again. Eventually you will see very few weeds.I once read a blog by a gardener who said no weed is too small to pull. Pull the small ones before they make new seeds.

I had a couple of sprouts come up right after as they were already sprouted  so the preen wasn't going to do anything for a weeds already in the process of growing. Absolutely in love with not having to mess with weeds anymore.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2023
review_content: Used all kinds of 2,4-d products to kill Henbit and other weeds.  Trimec works as well or maybe better to control Henbit.  Thing you must remember, is that you have to hit Henbit twice, maybe 3 times.  Saturate it in late winter early Spring when you first see it.  Then wait a week - 10 days, absolutely before it flowers, and then soak it again.  If you don't, it'll look bad for a while then recover.  If your neighbors let their yard go to Henbit, you'll be spraying all the time.  Been there - doing that!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: OK folks a couple of things. YOU NEED SURFACTANT for this to work. The amount of Trimec is based on volume per 1000sqft. So if you have 4 gallons and it takes a gallon of water to spray 1000sqft you then can use .5oz-2.0 oz per gallon.  If your lawn is 10000sqft you will need 10 gallons of water with 5oz-20oz mixed in the water.If you don't want to go through the hassle 1.5oz per gallon will kill weeds once you hit the 2.0oz+ per gallon the likely hood of killing grass is EXTREMELY high.Finally, surfactant is an agent that makes herbicide stick to plants. Some people use crop oil, kerosene etc. YOU NEED surfactant with Trimec. 2.0oz of surfactant per 4 gallons works. Rad the label as different herbicides need more surfactant. I use surfactant with all herbicides. I even use it with glyphosate and 24D. If you don't use it you will waste your money and your results will be poor.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
review_content: I live in "Goathead Country".  (If you don't know what those are, count yourself VERY fortunate!)  This weed almost seems to come in two forms: ground cover and something that looks like wild grass.  Regardless, both let you know when they come in contact with a body part -- very memorable!  I used Round-Up in the past, but stopped due to rumors of it causing cancer in lab rats or something.  Anyway, Spectracide may be found to do the same one day, but until then, it totally gets my vote as being just as good or better than Round-Up.For those who don't find it successful, I have two tips that make my weed hunts more effective:1. They may say it is rain safe in a few hours but I prefer to give it a day, assuming I spray in the morning.2. Like hunting, morning and evening when the sun isn't a factor is best.  I had a guy tell me hitting them early morning is best because weeds have some kind of protective "enzyme" that gets stronger as the sun comes out and it gets hotter -- sort of a protective mechanism, I guess.I find if I spray at sunrise and it doesn't rain all day, I can see evidence of wilting the next day in many cases.  Within 5 days, they are brown.  I know Round-Up used to have the commercial that showed weeds wilting, disintegrating, then blowing away in the wind like dust -- never happened for me!  Real world was them turning brown and me pulling out the dead carcass.  Regardless, this stuff is effective on everything!Results will vary, but I attached a same day pic taken the afternoon after I sprayed that morning.  Less than 24 hours and I can hear the death rattle on this weed!

I use a two-gallon hand sprayer (purchased from Amazon!), and follow the label directions for mixing. The type of weed & grass killer I am using in the interim requires more than twice as much concentrate in the mixture. While the results are "okay", weeds are returning faster than with the Spectracide. My most recent purchase of Spectracide was for two bottles, in case it gets scarce again. I recommend the product for its ease of use, effectiveness, and while it isn't inexpensive, it is worth the cost.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
review_content: Spectracide Grass and Weed Killer Concentrate actually works well, but the manufacturer's instructions are making people to think that it does not. Apparently, whoever wrote the instructions wanted to make the product look more attractive to the potential buyers rather than honestly explaining what and how it does. You should completely ignore a few statements on the label, particularly about the "normal" as opposed to the "best results" amount to use, and about how fast the results show up. Here's what you need to do:1. Use 7 ounces per gallon of water (which is advertised as "best"). Do not use less than that!2. Wait at least 24 hours to see the signs of grass and weeds dying. It will not happen any sooner!3. After 2 days the grass and weeds will actually look dead. Not after a few hours!4. I do not know why, but it works slower in the shade - you may need to wait 2-2.5 days to see visible results in shady areas.If you ignore the misleading description provided by the manufacturer, you will see that it actually kills even tough weeds, although some of those may require a second application. Be patient! Wait 2-3 days to see the results. I have tried using it a few times, and I found that it works well despite being a lot cheaper than many other brands. After 2 weeks, there's no new growth in the treated areas.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2021
review_content: Have tried a variety of weedkillers in neverending battle against hearty, spikey Arizona weeds. We get stuff that can thrive in a hostile desert. This is the first product that performed as advertised here. Within 15-20 mins, noticed weeds and grass patches wilting. I'm no botanist or even amateur gardener and can't tell you what kinds of plants this killed... But the context was we had a bunch of different varieties of spikey-vines, grass breaking through gravel, and what looked like several species of clover-style weeds all growing fast after monsoon season rains. This melted them all. Within an hour and a half, they were all dark brown, clumped flat like wet tissue paper.I'd been slowly losing the weekly whole-yard hand-weeding battle and was at the point of needing something to kill off the blooming weeds en masse to get control back. I mixed this with a longer-lasting ground coverage type product (to ensure the weeds this product nuked don't return). The other product in itself didn't kill the existing weeds quickly, so this was a great addition.Would definitely recommend it for an initial weed kill-off, or as a spot treatment if you don't have time/ability to pull weeds on your knees.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2017
review_content: ***Update***What it "killed" is now back.  This DID NOT kill to the root.  It browned the grass quickly...VERY quickly but now I have new growth on every part of the lawn sprayed...and I mixed int on the strong side.  The Compare N Save and HDX are is still dead...took much longer but killed to the root!  Spectracide DID NOT kill to the root and all the grass area to be killed off...90% has grown back.Product did not work for me as I hoped it would.  If your looking for a quick brown...this is your product but it did not kill the lawn to the root in the areas desired.  I have Floratam St Augustine which is a rather sensitive and many weed and feeds will kill it off...so I totally expected this to work completely....and it did not.Wasted money...at least it was on sale.  Going back to Compare N Save and/or HDX.So far this appears to be one of the best products I have used (based on the visual appears of grass/weeds being dead).I am doing a complete yard renovation and the backyard is approximately 12,000 sqft.  I have used HDX brand and Compare and Save brand grass/weed killer.  I used both individually in applications in areas of the back yard, and  mixed them both with a surfactant into one application.  In all of the cases I used a few ounces over the strongest recommendation.  It took about 3-4 days to start yellowing and about 10 days to get to brown.  To be fair it did rained a few hours after some of the applications, but the product still worked very well.  In most cases plenty of sun light was present, live in Central FL, and temp was low 90s to mid 80s.Spectracide was MUCH quicker....how much...damn near instant!  I sprayed about maybe a 2000 sqft area finishing about 2pm ish (just in time to watch the Canes whoop up on the Noles).  Visible discoloration in probably 2-3 hours.  By Sunday same time the grass was almost as brown as the grass sprayed almost two weeks early.  Yes, in about 24hrs!  Everything is brown...St Augustine grass and all the weeds in it.  Maybe 3-4 spots that have a slight hit of green...which may just be what I missed spraying.  This appears to be the real deal.  I hope it truly does kill to the root.  I will give it another day or two then dig up some of the yard in all the test areas...I will compare the roots which will tell the real story.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2017
review_content: Several people have compared Spectracide Weed and Grass Killer to Glyphosate (trade name Roundup).  IMO they are comparing apples and oranges, as these are complementary products that happen to work differently, but each have their strengths.  To wit:- Spectracide is a "foliage burner" i.e. it burns back whatever green foliage you spray it on, but does not go after the roots to the extent that roundup does.  This makes it ideal for spraying the "runners" that my hybrid Bermuda lawn sends out into the flower beds next to the lawn.  It kills those without affecting the parts of the Bermuda plant that stay on the lawn.  And it does it quickly, turning them brown within a day or so.- Glyphosate works by inhibiting the formation of certain plant proteins; this process takes longer (up to a week or more during cool months, or days during the warmer actively-growing summer months) but it kills the entire plant including roots.  Furthermore you don't have to cover the entire plant for it to absorb enough herbicide to completely kill the plant.  That makes it ideal for spraying some of the hardier, more "shrubby" plants that grow around our property.Taken together (note: not applied together) these two herbicides provide the complete solution to my weed-control needs.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
review_content: Will kill a wide variety of grass and weeds, but plants that have shiney and waxy leaves tend to survive treatment.  For example, most types of arrow head are unphased when SOAKED with this product.  Most types of Jasmine are also immune.  For best results, you need to use the MAX recommended ratio, which is 7oz per gallon... so you can get about 9 gallons from one of the 64oz bottles. Depending of the density of your weeds, you might get 250 sq. feet coverage from 1 gallon... depending on the density and height the weeds.This product seems to have ZERO residual effectiveness, which means that while the weeds might "die", I don't believe the product actually kills the root.  The weeds simply grow back within 3-4 weeks.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2016
review_content: Looking at the product label, this contains Fluazifop-p-butyl in addition to the typical weed killer ingredients Diaquat dibromide and Dicamba.  Fluazifop-p-butyl has been around for decades and it is also safe to use around the house.  This weed killer is unique because most others do not contain a specific grass killer ingredient in addition to the broadleaf weed killer ingredients.  If you have a lot of grassy weeds, this is a good product to rotate into your arsenal.According to the Center for Invasive Species,"Fluazifop-p-butyl kills annual and perennial grasses, but does little or no harm to broad-leaved plants (dicots).  It kills by inhibiting lipid synthesis (lipids are necessary components of cell membranes), particularly at the sites of active growth.  In the environment, fluazifop-p-butyl is degraded primarily through microbial metabolism and hydrolysis.  It is not degraded readily by sunlight.  The half-life of fluazifop-p-butyl in soils is one to two weeks.

review_content: This is my go to weed killer product. The active ingredient is Diquat Dibromide. This is not Glyphosate that RoundUp uses.
