review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
review_content: We've had a millipede infestation this summer in our house. First it was in the kitchen when the Dallas area was getting lots of rain this spring. We've lived in this house since 2003 and NEVER had I experienced this kind of crawly bug infestation. Once the rains stopped, they slowly disappeared out of our kitchen. At least the crunching under my shoes stopped.But then they started appearing in our bedroom. And since our floors are very dark wood, they were difficult to see. But not in our bathroom that has beige tile! I couldn't figure out where in the world they were coming in at. Talked to a pest control company and they said since we lived on the edge of the woods they were coming in around the windows. But they weren't. Because of pets in our home, I tried diatomaceous earth since it's safe around pets, but the powder was terrible to work with. And it didn't really kill the buggers like I'd hoped.So before I called in the pest control company, I thought I'd try this. I knew it was not going to be something I could let my pets get around, so we kept them out of our bedroom. I vacuumed and steam cleaned our bedroom and bathroom floors (no carpet, just hardwood and tile) thinking I'd start fresh with this poison that says it kills millipedes.Well, I finally saw where they were coming in at......from around my toilet and any crack at my baseboards in the bathroom. OMG!!!  So after spraying this in ever crack and crevice I could find, I would see these crawly bugs coming up. But they would soon die. Curled up in a little circled and they DIED!! I had to spray heavy doses for several days and nights to finally get them to even slow down in coming in through the cracks that of course formed as our house settles each season. But this was the only thing that I tried that finally REALLY WORKED! And the pest control company swore they had to be coming in under my doors and windows. So if you have millipedes and they gross you out like they do me (they actually make a crunch sound when you step on them) you have to try this out. It worked for us, hopefully it will help you too.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2015
review_content: You cannot go wrong with this! We don't have roaches and some say this doesn't work on those (even the Demon website says they have something specific for that) what we DO have is black widows, brown recluse and big biting ants that break through the asphalt up and down the street! When we moved in 4.5 years ago the house (in the desert) had been vacant for around 3 years and the spiders had taken hold. Seven exterminators over the first year and nothing helped. I spent 100's of dollars and was told at every turn that I needed to have the house tented plus monthly maintenance which was too costly for what they said would be a never ending battle. I first tried this after sending a desperate message to the makers asking for help and will never not use it.This will drop these mothers like no ones business but it is HIGHLY toxic to anything it come in contact with until it dries (per the manufacturer) so I notify my neighbors when we spray the perimeter of the house and yard so they can keep their dogs in for a few hours. I spray inside the house and attic once a year on the day I take my dogs in for shots and grooming then air it out to protect them. If you have any questions contact the makers, they are very helpful! My adult son does the sprays and to be safe he keeps old shoes just for this, undresses int he garage, throws everything he has on directly into the washer and runs into the shower wrapped in a towel. I wouldn't recommend spraying on a windy day.As far as maintenance we spray the perimeter of the house along the ground, along the roof line, around all windows and doors (be sure to put towels down if you have kids or animals inside) in the late winter/early spring, once the heat reaches around 100 deg then again when it cools off for the season. If we see those damn biting ants in the yard or even in the street we mix up a batch, find their opening and spray directly down their tubes sending them somewhere else.That first year we literally had "spider mallets" (rubber mallets) in every room because nothing worked. Now we might see 10-20 a year. I'll also add that some people in my area have started complaining of scorpions even as close as the house across the street but I haven't seen a single one here!The seller was super quick, I received the shipment within days of ordering. You will need a 2 gallon pump sprayer which is very cheap compared to an exterminator.I hope this helps.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2021
review_content: Got roaches? Have a pressure sprayer? Buy this stuff because it works!!!Back in the 80's we had a battle with cockroaches in Birmingham Alabama. We used everything and even "bombed" the house several times a year, but those little buggers were relentless. From the tiny German ones to the giant water bugs, we had them all. Our house was clean, but the roaches remained.There was a Do-it-yourself pest control place in town that recommended this and we used it. I had a great pressure sprayer with a crack a crevice tool as well as other attachments. I sprayed down behind cabinets and in-between places I never knew existed. (No spiders or centipedes either.)I would suggest reading and following the instructions to the letter. Also, avoid getting this in your eyes and wear a mask. This is strong stuff and will irritate your skin, eyes, and lungs.Another long story about Brown Recluse spiders in Bowling Green, KY... I'll spare you but it worked for those too. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2012
review_content: If you are still buying your pest control products at a regular store, you are wasting a lot of money. So did I before I started deeply researching the pest problem. The building were I used to live was flooded with roaches and no matter how I tried I carried some of them into my new clean apartment. Seven months later, my new apartment was infested again., even though I called pest control twice. Also wasted money. Enter Demon WP. This stuff is potent, however you have to give it time to really work and this product will NOT eliminate the entire infestation. I call it a butcher's axe. If you look at it like that, this product is amazing. Taking into consideration that my infestation was pretty bad, it axed about 95% of it within 2 weeks. I was amazed myself how many of them dropped dead, i had to swipe them off every day. This product is a good starting point. I realized that in order to completely get rid of these nasty creatures, you have to use Demon in conjunction with other products. Residual sprays only kill roaches that walk across their residue, and eventually there will be survivors even if you spray everywhere, because most of them hide in cracks and can sit there and wait for up to 2 weeks. Roaches reproduce very fast, so you also need baits, so they can carry the poison into their harborage sites, where the rest is hiding. I placed DuPont Advion baits and Gentrol stations ( this product controls insects growth, so they can't reproduce) 3 weeks after I sprayed with Demon, so I could fully control their population. Dont use Demon together with baits, wait until it starts wearing off a bit, otherwise it will repel roaches from eating baits. So far so good. I am not completely roach free, since there is no miracle product, but I am relived, I only see a couple of them sometimes, less and less everyday. I will continue placing fresh baits and update in 3 months.NOTE: I used a stronger concentration - 2 pouches for 1 gallon. I also sprayed twice, once a week for 2 weeks and a few more times specifically under refrigerator where their reproduction site was.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2013
review_content: We live next to the woods.  There are ants.  They try to get in the house every spring; it's just something to deal with.Once I hired an exterminator.  They spray everywhere with tons of spray and never really solved the problem.  So I researched it myself and figured out how to deal with it every year using a fraction of the chemicals.First, use bait WITHOUT spray outside to poison ants and their colonies.  You can make your own bait super cheap with Borax.  Just google "Borax Ant Bait Recipe" and find recipes on the internet.  Borax is safe enough to wash your close in.I then use Demon in a sprayer.  I USE A DEDICATED SPRAYER.  If there's any scent on the spray, the ants will avoid it.  I then spray inside in just certain specific spots where I know the ants get in.  I use maybe 1/50th the amount of spray the professional exterminated did.Demon WP being unscented is an excellent blocking spray but it won't wipe out a colony as the ants die to quick and don't bring the poison back to the nest.It takes a few weeks to get them blocked but ever year I nip the problem without an expensive professional exterminator with less chemicals.If you do go to one of the two nationally-advertised exterminator companies (you know who they are), they will want to come quarterly in order to warranty their work.  That means $100-200 several times a year and lots a spraying of lots of chemicals.  Ask yourself, if you are paying someone every three months to fix your problem, do they have an incentive NEVER to fix the problem all the way.If you can do research and read labels carefully, you can do a better job cheaper yourself.  But only if you are technically and scientifically oriented and can research the exact techniques you need.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2016
review_content: When I got home from being gone 4 months it looked like the roaches had a party.  Lots of bodies all over the place.  After researching how to get rid of them and NOT spend a fortune with an exterminator I bought this product.  On going to their web site they say you need to also use a bait to get them to take it back to the place they live.  This product will kill them when they come out and walk around.  The bait I used seemed new as it was a liquid.  It's called Hotshot Liquid Roach Bait.  I spread out the little canisters and waited for the Demon WP to arrive.  I could begin to see a decrease on roaches at night until the Demon arrived.When it arrived I mixed it as directed for initial treatment and sprayed it under the washer and dryer, refrigerator, stove and dish washer.  Also spayed it in all the holes where the drains for sinks and washing machine were located.  Also sprayed it around baseboards in bathrooms wherethey seemed to really like showing up.  Spayed baseboards in kitchen and around outside near doors and garage door.Roaches rapidly started decreasing at night.  In about three days after spraying Demon there were no more roaches I saw but did find a few bodies. After about a 5 days there were no more bodies and no live roaches.  I'm sold on this stuff.  Along with the bait I used this roach killer really worked.  I live in Florida so roaches can be a way of life if you don't act on them.  Great product.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2015
review_content: Demon WP is incredible for killing insects.  This product was recommended to me by our last pest guy.  We live out of the city so spiders, crickets and scorpions are the norm.  I typically spray this 2-3 times a year both inside and out.  Our lower floor is all wood, which leads to the only downside to this product.  At the mixture I use, this does leave a splotchy white residue on the wood floors where sprayed.  Typically, by the time I'm spraying this product inside, the insects are enough of an issue that I don't mind.  So long as it does the job (and it certainly does the job), I'm fine with the residue for a couple of weeks before it gets mopped up.  Even with this downside, I've continued to use it and recommend it to friends.Another way around the issue would be to just spray in the hidden areas, where most of the little critters hide out anyway.  If I focused behind the chairs and chests, in the door jams, in the cracks and crevices, this would be much less of an issue and likely still just as effective.The packets are water soluble, so they just need to be dropped in your sprayer before you begin to fill it up with water, keeping you from having to touch the powder at any point.  However, make sure that you're not picking up the small powder bags when your hands are wet or they will start to break down.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: Demon WP is the best insecticide I have ever used, and I have tried quite a few. I live in Central Texas and am constantly faced with combatting spiders, scorpions, fleas, ants, mosquitoes,...you name it. I spray around the perimeter of my house both inside and out, including the doors and windows frames. I only spray quarterly, but this stuff is super effective! I constantly find dead or dying insects inside and outside my house. When I find an active scorpion or 2, that is when I know it's time to spray again. I used this stuff in West Texas when I had tried everything under the sun to combat the fleas in my dogs. This is the ONLY thing I found that worked. Most Tractor Supply businesses sell it as well, which is where I initially purchased the product. Use a one gallon pump sprayer, and it will take one packet to cover the interior of the house and one for the outside. The paper package comes with 4 water soluble packets, so you get essentially 2 applications out of each package. My aunt used to be an exterminator, and she said this was what her company used. She even commented that it was safe to eat off a plate that had been sprayed with Demon once the product was dried. Don't hesitate! Buy this!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2014
review_content: This stuff worked great. The order comes with 2 foil envelopes. Each envelope looks like it has 6-8 water soluble packets. I combined one of those packets with a gallon of water in a simple pump sprayer (also purchased on amazon). It worked like a charm. It was enough solution to spray around the edge of the pool, the hottub stairs, around the entire base of the house, the courtyard, and inside the garage. We have stacked stone surface on most stuff in our backyard (pool, retaining wall, fire pit, pool equipment platform, etc.) so there are tons of little crevices for spiders to hide in.As for effectiveness - this stuff basically rains death. It's not instant - I saw some one-star reviews saying that they sprayed the spider and it just ran away. That happened to me too - especially with the larger ones (a few of those black widows were the size of a quarter). But I intentionally went out at night with a flashlight so they would be out in their webs and easy to spray. As long as you get them with a good dose, within 5 minutes they are dead. The ones that ran away crawled back out from their hiding spot within a minute or two as they were clearly heading toward the light. When I went back out this morning and walked the perimeter of the house, I saw curled up dead black widows everywhere.Summary: this stuff performed exactly as I needed it to, at a fraction of the cost of a professional company doing the exact same thing.

review_content: This product was mentioned in a social media post, so I tried it. Didn‚Äôt want to pay the money for professional service here in Florida, where cockroaches are a huge problem. So I bought a $10 spray tank and ordered these packets. Easy to mix, because you just put the plastic packet in the sprayer and it dissolves in the water. Did my spraying and haven‚Äôt seen a roach since the first dozen came crawling out from under the house to die in the driveway. Now I have enough powder to spray three more times, making my cost for the entire year less than the cost for one month of service. It has been six weeks, and so far, so good.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
review_content: I've used food-grade diatomaceous earth around the house and occasionally on my cats for decades. Safer's says "not for pesticidal use," but I tested it and it works just fine. I'm not going to worry about the labeling - as long as it's food-grade, this is safe for pets and people.This year we have a plague of fleas. I thought it was because SoCal had lots of rain, but people on social media are reporting it's bad all over. And the fleas seem to be on steroids this year.  I'm using Frontline every three weeks (vet approves this frequency) on our cats right now. Most warm seasons I use it once every six weeks. This helps the cats, but there are fleas and flea eggs on the floor and furniture. That's where regular sweeping, vacuuming, and diatomaceous earth come in.I put the DE in a shaker bottle or flour sifter and put it on area rugs and let it sift in between the fibers. The DE destroys insect exoskeletons. (It's fantastic for getting rid of ants safely, too.) I lightly sprinkle the furniture, leave it overnight and vacuum. I sprinkle it on hardwood and tile floors. On the cats' bedding. Basically everywhere. Sometimes, I even rub a bit onto the cats themselves - the ones who are flea magnets. I do this a few days after the Frontline goes on if they need it. Usually just treating where they sleep - furniture, cat beds, the bedspread of our bed - is enough.Vacuuming takes care of. You can also use it in the kitchen. I like to put it at the edges of counters and across doorways or wherever else ants think they should enter. You can also make a paste of it with a little water and smoosh it into openings that ants use to travel into the kitchen or bath.It won't get rid of all the insects, but it really, really helps. It's safe. But keep in mind that it's very dusty - it always is - so if you're using it heavily, use a mask and keep the pets away until the dust settles.One more great use: Sprinkle it on your rose bushes. It will stop ants from farming aphids on them.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
review_content: Safer Brand 51704 Food Grade Diatomaceous Earth ‚Äì 4 lbI wasn't paying close attention to this since I have used DE for so many different things around the house and in my garden.  This has a big statement on the back stating not for use as a pesticide.  That was my main use in creating barriers for bugs to avoid.  I have also used it to treat whiteflies in my trees since they bred in the ground and then spread to the leaves.  I still applied it to the ground under the affected tree.  So far the flies have left.This is really a clean formula for silica and I already take that for my skin in a collagen powder mix I take daily.  I have more research to do on dosage but now I am intrigued.  You can also use this for your pool and to clean other things as a scrub.  I already tried a paste of this to remove some stain on concrete and it worked well.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
review_content: I usually buy the other Safer Brand DE from Amazon (https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B01D60GAW2/ref=emc_b_5_t).  I assumed this is the same product, but it is clearly marked "not for insecticidal use."  So, take that into consideration when buying.  Please don't assume it can be used safely as an insecticide just because I did it.  For obvious reasons you definitely don't want to breathe in or ingest it which is why I recommend wearing a dust mask, eye protection, and airing out the room after vacuuming.I found silverfish under some boxes under the bed in the guest room.  That room is closed off to kids and cats so I decided to sprinkle some DE under the bed and all around the carpet in that room.  Waited two days and vacuumed the bulk up, leaving a little dust around the edges of the room.  No more silverfish and the room even smelled fresher.  Just because of the labeling, I'll just be using this to prevent ants from getting in the trash outdoors and won't use it indoors anymore.  Still confused why I shouldn't though...  I've always bought food grade DE in the past and had no problems...  So confused....

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
review_content: I have been using Diatomaceous Earth for years on my vegetable garden but only started using it a year ago on my pets when our rescue had worms. It works even better as a flea repellant and worm killer in the dogs and I was already a huge fan.  I sprinkle this over my lawn occasionally as well, to keep down the bug population during the summer. This particular brand came packaged well, in a perfect size, at a great price.Pro:This is a great size for dusting the lawn or garden or mixing with the dog foodWorks well (while dry) as an insecticide outdoors in the garden or on the lawnCan be put in lids at the bottom of your bed (under the legs) to prevent bed bugs from crawling up (I do this every time we return from vacation to make sure we didn't bring any home with us.Helps keep the pets healthy by killing intestinal bugs as wellThis particular brand is a good weight (4 lb. is bigger than it sounds) and good value at $12.99This brand is as good as any of the other food-grade brands I've tried.Cons:Some people can't breathe well around this powder, so if you have trouble, wear a mask while applying it.Update: 7/23/19: After using this I noticed another reviewer had questioned why this is not for use as a pesticide. Since I already used mine as an insecticide and it seemed identical to other diatomaceous earth powders I have used, I'm puzzled as well as to why this is supposed to only be used as a "feed additive".  We do use it as a feed additive for our dogs, but I hope Safer will comment further on why they are distinguishing this from all the other diatomaceous earth on the market and if there is a reason it shouldn't be used around the house and garden.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2019
review_content: It says that it's not for use as a Pesticide but I will just put it out there that it does work as a Pesticide but I'm not sure why it isn't labeled to be used as such, it's the exact same thing and it is labeled as food grade but I won't recommend it for that use just because of the labeling so.. please use discretion when using this item.. I used it for fleas in desperation because my poor dog got a bad case of fleas and the house was infested in no time flat because his treatment was pretty much useless. I also gave my dog some sprinkled on his food to keep him healthy and internal pest free- a stray I rescued gave us fleas so I worried about him getting worms too but he was apparently fine, or the DE killed them, either way the product is good and I recommend it. Many uses for this wonderful product. 4 stars!

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2019
review_content: Diatomaceous earth is the only pesticide I have used for years and although the information on the product bag states it is not for pesticide use and I normally do not ignore such statements but I am so accustomed to using it for that purpose that I didn‚Äôt notice the statement.But, to test its ability I applied the product to some carpenter ants on my driveway and they quickly met their demise. So, although an inadvertent oversight, this particular food grade product is working well as a pesticide.  I prefer this method of controlling bugs because it is natural and not toxic for pets and people.It is an eye and lung irritant so use a dust mask and eye protection which probably a good idea for use with the dangerous chemical pesticides as well. The powder is easily vacuumed up if used indoors and note that if used outdoors it will need to be reapplied after rain, etc. like any pesticide.To control the application I find using a ketchup/mustard condiment plastic squeeze bottle works well. I use a funnel to fill the bottles and when needed I just squeeze a line of the powder wherever needed. I only use the product when I see a problem and it has always cleared up the issue quickly and thoroughly.  I am confused as to the labeling, but it works well for my use.

review_content: I can't say for certain this would work in normal circumstances these ticks were in a container with the powder and were unable to escape, or clean off in anyway, ie rain, water.**after 30 hours both ticks are inert one is moving its legs but very little they are no longer able to move around the container.**after 24 hours both ticks are unable to extend their legs leaving them unable to move around easily or climb anything.Unfortunately like others I did not realize this was not intended for use as a pesticide. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: Freshwater diatomaceous earth is commonly used for grain and food storage as it has anti caking properties as well as pest control benefits. You can add this to your feeds for those reasons as well as possibly helping with internal parasites in your animals. I think Safer doesn't market this specifically for pesticidal use as it doesn't have any other additives like some other varieties. It also could have been heat treated which renders it less effective for pesticidal use. Whatever the case I think they put that disclaimer on it so they don't have any claims as such. Rather it is intended for feed stocks. This variety also has use as a soil amendment. It in particular it is very popular for bonsai potting where it has been used as the sole potting medium. It has properties similar to perlite and vermiculite in that it drains well while also retaining and holding nutrients and just the right amounts of water.  Safer is a brand that I use and am very familiar with. I would consider this a very good quality product as such. It has a very fine feel to it. Be sure to use a dust mask.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2019
review_content: Safer is a trusted brand in organic gardening. In this case, the product is a powder that is added to animal feed. Sometimes it is used by humans but this is not accepted enough to be advertised as recommended.This product should not not exceed 2% of the animal's diet. Mix thoroughly. Do not breathe it in because it is irritating to lungs.It is labeled not for pesticide use, probably because there are regulations that must be followed in order to package as a pesticide.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2019
review_content: I sprinkle a layer this across the length of my garage door with extra at the corners.  It has made a huge difference with bugs coming in.  Sprinkling some outside the garage door is also helpful, but if it rains or is windy, it's a waste.  But  even if they cross the line i'm confident they will die within a few hours because they have gotten it on their bodies which should dehydrate them. And if you have pets and so forth you just don't want anything toxic getting tracked in the home.  It's not the easiest to use, because it's not a spray. I bought a "puffer" but it has it's own problems. Sprinkling this at basement doors and areas where you see bugs is great as well. But keep in mind that you will need to keep reapplying.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
review_content: It says not for pesticidal use but we had an invasion of ants in the kennels and a generous sprinkling of this along the trail back to the nests either killed them or discouraged them from getting into the water buckets. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2019

Breathing it in is not fun and it will dry your skin out.That‚Äôs being said, I love using this in our chicken feed containers. It keeps the food from clumping together due to moisture and it prevents the feed from being overtaken by insects. It also works well in herb garden. In the house we only use a fine dusting of it under and behind the furniture that our pets and toddler can‚Äôt access as we don‚Äôt want them inhaling it if we can help it, it‚Äôs not toxic but it can be irritating.

Twice a year I use Blue Seal Safe and Simple Weed Control (corn gluten) for weed control and quick lime to balance the PH (early spring and early fall). I cut the grass at a height of 4 inches. Also has treated some indoor plant mite issues. It is messy as it is a fine powder and it doesnt work when wet but its worth clean up and re applying! Most pest control methods seem to only claim to be effective if regularly repeated and cleaned up after.When i first moved in to a new rental i wasnt aware that it would need to be flea bombed after 2 weeks to kill what wasnt killed the first time. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2021
review_content: I bought this for 2 uses: chickens and cats. I dust the inside of my chicken coop ( using a filtered mask) before laying down pine shavings to prevent mites. Works well. Second use was to worm several cats. I had been having trouble administering dewormer to all of them ( own 3) . Wound up putting about a tablespoon of DE into about 2 tablespoons of water, and mixing this into a can of pate style cat food. Distributed amongst the 3 cats, who devoured it with no problem. After a few days, there was no sign of worms in the catbox stool. It did not appear to affect their digestion, as in make them nauseous or give them diarrhea, as had been the case with deworming medicines. Kept the treatment up for a week, waited two weeks, then gave them another course of treatment just in case. The worms have not made a return appearance. This bag is large and very reasonably priced. Properly sealed and stored, it will last a long time.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2022
review_content: I have been using this for some time and love it. I mix it with distilled water (maybe that's overkill, but I have hard water) and it never leaves stains or residues on all the various surfaces I have sprayed it on. The type of bottle this comes in is the best -- it makes it just so easy to measure out and pour the needed amount. I actually bought a bunch of these bottles to use with other chemicals as well, but they are not cheap. So great value to get it already in this bottle!BUT the listing here is just incorrect or something. I mean, it says 176 gallons from this 32 fl oz bottle -- the standard mixture rate is 1 fl oz makes 1 gallon; doing the math that is... 32 gallons from this 32 fl oz bottle. I guess they are showing you use the minimum mixture rate there, so be aware.I use this product as a general home defense product. Applied at the typical 1 fl oz to 1 gallon rate, spread around the foundation 2 feet in each direction where the foundation and grade meet. Also 2 ft around every doorway and window, spray the eaves and soffit too. Don't forget your garage doors as well, as insects love to get in there. I don't use it indoors, because I don't want to unless absolutely needed, but I am starting to experiment with using it in the garage, as that is a sort-of outdoors location and there is all kinds of random spots bugs love to collect.When applying this way, and comparing to neighbors, it seems very effective. Don't have issues with insects like wasps under the eaves for example. I apply at least once a month, but when there is a lot of insect activity I do it every other week (instructions say you could do it as often as every week, but every other week seems effective enough to me). I try to apply when there will be no rain in 24 hours in each direction (before and after application) to make sure it doesn't get washed off.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023
review_content: I mix 1 oz of this into a 1 gallon spray jug and hit the perimeter of my home usually monthly (or after any big rain fall). 1 oz will cover ~60-65% of my exterior with heavy spray around the front porch. I live in NC near water so we get all sorts of bugs - especially spiders (black widow/brown recluse) and palmetto bugs. This has done a great job of keeping bugs at bay and you can absolutely tell it works when you step out on the patio or front porch and see the dead bugs.While it isn't necessarily great for spiders (since spiders have longer legs that tend to keep the body away from the spray), this spray does a great job of taking care of all the other bugs which tend to be a food source for spiders - remove the food source and you keep the spiders at bay.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2023

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2023
review_content: This stuff has saved us a world of annoyance from ants and other creepy crawlies. We spray all around the outside of our house and we've not had any ants. This is SO much cheaper than calling a pest control person! I recommend it, get a good sprayer and you'll be set. We spray after each rain too, and spray our outside porch. When we had carpenter bees, it worked on them, as much as we HATE killing bees of any kind, they were making a mess out of our back porch. We sprayed at night after they had left the holes they'd been drilling. When they came back the next morning they left those area's alone. We were happy because we sure didn't want to kill them. It is their world we invaded after all, and we need all of the bees we can get.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2022
review_content: I had a severe wasp problem here. On soffits and vinyl siding to soffit are wasps were buzzing around. Several corners of the house had this issue. I could not sick on deck, since wasps would buzz me, sometimes aggressively for no reason...I was 30+ feet away from end of house where they seemed to buzz around every day. Warm days, cold mornings...so I got up early and sprayed one really bad corner, soffit, corner vinyl trim piece, got all the cracks and crevices...while the bees slept in out of the cold. I was nervous spraying, expected a swarm. I would spray a second and run far away and observe. Braver and braver I sprayed more. That was one corner on day 1. It stayed cold all day, no wasps. The next day it warmed up, but I was never outside n deck. The day after I walked out and saw several wasps dead on the deck. Hooray! I sprayed again since I did see a few random wasps flying around. Then a day or two later I sprayed all the soffit areas, vinyl trim corners, gaps, holes, crevices, around crawl space to floor wall, in crawl space vents, any place I felt bugs or bees could intrude or live. Success. I occasionally see a yellow jacket or wasp, but no swarms on house or attacks on the deck. A European hornet buzzes by once in a while, but they nest out on the woods. So much happier now without wasps everywhere. Well worth the money and 1 gallon sprayer to treat this house. Also no more crickets in crawl space or inside house. Crickets use to be inside once or twice every week. Happy camper here :-)

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2020
review_content: Best bug killer I've used. I live on the edge of a forest that is nearly 100,000 acres of open chaparral. The spiders and other nasties that crawl out of there are shocking and dangerous.This products toxicity is low for humans and animals, yet yields a high degree of toxicity for flying insects, arachnids and other creepy crawlies.One broad application on my eaves and ground perimeters, topped off with spraying the tops and sides of all bushes and trees, keeps our family and animals bug free for months and months.It seems to keep killing week after week because I find new carcasses months after applying.The amount of airborne insect traffic throughout the day into the evening has decreased dramatically. I believe that to be the result of spraying the tops and sides of all bushes and trees.I have recommended this product to my neighbors for them to try. Its effective for long term pest management and allows us to spend more time outside.This is not a "bang your dead" bug spray. Its systemic and persistent. It will ultimately kill the bugs in large numbers over long periods of time. That reduces the overall population and keeps them from reproducing in annoying numbers.Best wishes and happy bug killing.

review_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review_content: This stuff kills whatever it can reach including fire ants, spiders, beetles etc.  Like any insecticide it will only go so far down into an ant bed & kill whatever it reaches, You will see a ton of dead ants shortly after spraying but alas the survivors will simply resurface somewhere else again after a heavy rain. It continues to kills all kinds of bugs for months after spraying, even outside after a rain.This concentrated bottle will make a BUNCH of insecticide, simply go by the mix directions & get yourself a quality pump sprayer to use. review_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2013
review_content: Lowes doesn't carry this product. Home Depot does, but only online. Home Depot was also asking twice the price I found on Amazon, and with Prime, shipping was free, so the cost was even lower! One other significant difference between this brand and others is that this has 7.9% Bifenthrin, whereas other brands only have slightly over 2%. This is a concentrate, so it does pour out quite thick, but it easily dilutes in water in the sprayer. It's best if you mix the solution before you begin spraying. Just shake your bottle sprayer and you should be good to go.As for how the product worked, I found it to be excellent. I got this specifically to kill the Spittle bugs that were killing my lawn. After I figured out how many sq. ft. my lawn was, I only needed to mix 1 oz. per 1000 sq. ft. in a hose sprayer filled with water,  and I was good to go. It took me two days to do my lawn - I had to blow the leaves off first - completing the front and sides on the first day and the back yard the second day. I covered over 1/2 acre and still have plenty left over for a 2nd application.After spraying my front yard and sides, I went out the next morning and saw plenty of dead Spittle bugs lying in the grass, road and on my driveway. The second day went similarly in the back yard. Now, I'm starting to see my grass come back from the brink of dying due to a very wet Spring and Summer when Spittle bugs are very actively laying eggs and chomping my centipede and zoyzia grasses like there's no tomorrow! Happy spraying...
